The bombardment was allegedly intended as cover for a government convoy of dozens of vehicles that were observed on their way from Malam to eastern Jebel Marra.
Looting: Unknown gunmen attacked Khamsa Dagaig IDP camp in Zalingei looting three stores before burning them down.
Militiamen in military uniforms allegedly beat and robbed farmers who protested their driving of dozens of camels and cows onto their farms in Tabit, leaving at least three seriously injured.
SAF dropped 13 barrel bombs on the area of Jawa in East Jebel Marra, killing a girl and seriously wounding another person, as well as killing dozens of livestock.
Armed herdsmen attacked the farm of the Central Darfur Governor in the area of Deleig in Wadi Dalih locality, beating the farmers and stealing their belongings.

Unidentified militiamen raided the Khazan Orshi market, beating a number of shop and stall keepers, and attacked nomad settlements in North Darfur's Um Baru locality, robbing people of their belongings.
A woman and her daughter were gang-raped at gunpoint by a group of janjaweed in Tagaliwemagali area of Tawila locality in North Darfur, leaving them seriously injured.
Unidentified gunmen looted Al-Wihda neighborhood in southern Nyala, beating 12 people with gun stocks.
Camel herders beat a farmer as he tried to prevent them from entering his farm in Deleig, Central Darfur.
A group of paramilitaries riding motorcycles shot and seriously wounded a Jedda IDP camps Sheikh and his daughters in Garsila, Central Darfur.
Three Janjaweed militiamen attacked Gergif and Hasknita villages in north Darfur, leaving eight displaced people from Rwanda IDP camp injured and looting property.

Members of the opposition Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) staged a sit-in protest in front of the Ministry of Justice in Khartoum, demanding to investigate the killing of hundreds of anti-austerity demonstrators in September 2013. Anti-riot police intervened to disperse the protesters and prevent them from handing a memo to the Ministry.

Abala herders shot and seriously wounded four farmers at Mertala and Fallujah areas of eastern Jebel Marra as they tried to expel the herders camels from their farms at Mertala area in eastern Jebel Marra.

Four Janjaweed militiamen shot and killed an accountant and employee of the Ministry of Finance in Al-Radoom locality as he collected the salaries of employees from the Sudan Central Bank in Nyala, fleeing with the money to an unknown location.
Armed militiamen killed a displaced farmer, injured four others and robbed them of their belongings in Umbalula, southwest of Gereida in South Darfur.
A young boy was killed and another seriously injured when an unexploded ordnance (UXO) detonated when they played with it near Al Aradib Al Ashara in eastern Jebel Marra.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: SLM/AW abducted two humanitarian workers in Sortony, North Darfur, over spying for the Government. They released them the same day.

Unidentified militiamen opened fire on a group of women at Wadi Kella in South Darfur, leaving one dead, three seriously injured, three kidnapped and another seven missing. They were on their way from Al Malam to Rubicona village near Nyala after shopping.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column17: Agents from the military intelligence service beat and detained two shoppers at Deribat market in Darfur's East Jebel Marra. No reason was given for their arrest.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Elements of the Rapid Support militia allegedly raped a schoolgirl in Kabkabiya locality in North Darfur, as she had gone out of camp Sortony for IDPs with three other women to collect straw. The three other women managed to escape.

Janjaweed militiamen from the areas of El Malam, Kabkabiya, and El Gubba, attacked displaced farmers in Tawila locality, North Darfur, as they tried to chase hundreds of camels and cattle off of their farmlands, leaving one killed and another two seriously injured. They also threatened other displaced farmers to not return to their farms.
A Janjaweed militiaman stabbed a policeman, who in turn shot the militiaman in Zalingei after the Janjaweed refused to hand over himself to the police for robbery.

Hundreds of people protested in Wadi Halfa, Northern State, against a decision to move the Customs post from Argeen to Dongola, as it has traditionally been an important source of revenue and employment for the city.

Hundreds of people gathered outside the house of the chief of the Dago tribe in Nyala, South Darfur, after he was shot dead by armed robbers, in protest against lack of security in the town. It was the third incident of deadly looting in a week.

More doctors and hospital workers from Ibn Sina, Ali Abdelfattah in El Doroshab, and El Bulook hospitals in Omdurman, as well as from El Nahud hospital in West Kordofan, laid down their tools in protest against attacks on doctors, demanding laws to be passed to protect medical workers as they perform their work.
Janjaweed shot and killed a woman farmer in Rubkona area of East Jebel Marra.
Residents of El Daraja El Talta district of Khartoum took to the streets in protest against the selling of a playground in the neighbourhood to a member of the National Congress Party.

Four unidentified gunmen opened fire on the headquarters of Al-Malam administrative unit, killing the commissioners driver and bodyguard who were standing in front of the headquarters at the time of the attack. The gunmen seized the commissioners vehicle before fleeing.
Armed paramilitaries shot at two farmers working in their lands near Birkat Seira in North Darfur, killing one and seriously wounding the other. The gunmen stole their belongings.
Armed paramilitaries shot and killed a farmer west of Kachelingo in Gerida locality, South Darfur. The gunmen stole his belongings.
A group of 40 unidentified gunmen attacked Assalaia of al-Rudum in South Kordofan state, leaving five people killed and looting more than 500 cattle. The cattle was later recovered.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) University Police
column17: Khartoum University police reportedly beat a student at the universiyt with an electrical cattle prod, leaving him seriously injured. Students later condemned the police treatment of students. The university police unit was formed in August this year following widespread unrest at universities across Sudan.

Students of the Faculty of Medicine of El Fasher University held a demonstration and later a sit-in to protest the increase in registration fees. Police arrested three students after the protest, and reportedly beat one of them during the arrest. The sit-in was continuing two weeks later.

Students of the Faculty of Medicine of El Fasher University held a demonstration and later a sit-in to protest the increase in registration fees. Police arrested three students after the protest, and reportedly beat one of them during the arrest. The sit-in was continuing two weeks later.

Strike:Dozens of doctors in at least two government hospitals in Khartoum reportedly went on strike, dealing only with emergency cases. This comes a day before an announced nation-wide strike by doctors to demand better facilities, higher wages and protection from security forces. Simultaneously, students at various faculties of Khartoum university organised speeches and announced a strike from study until the dismissed students and students union following unrest earlier in the year are returned. A committee was created to engage in dialogue with the students.
SAF fired two shells on civilian settlements controlled by SPLM/N in Umhetan town, Delami county. No casualties.

Three militiamen shot and killed a construction worker in Turr in Kass locality, South Darfur as he refused to give them the the machetes he uses for his work. Bystanders arrested one of the perpetrators.
Unidentified gunmen shot and seriously injured the son of the Chairman of the National Umma Party (NUP) in North Darfur as they attempted to steal his car in El Fasher.
Unidentified militiamen abducted two of four women on their way from Sina village in Darfurs Jebel Marra.
Unidentified gunmen abducted a shopkeeper in Fassi in Zalingei locality, Central Darfur after he refused to pay compensation for a militiaman's broken finger.

column7: FCD: Federal Committee of Doctors; Health Workers (Sudan)
column17: Strike:Medical strike was renewed by doctors led by the Federal Committee of Doctors to demand better facilities, higher wages and protection from security forces following a spate of violence and armed robberies targeting them, and extended to 46 hospitals, including 21 in Khartoum state and others in West Darfur, North Darfur, Jazira and Sennar states. All sections were affected, except for emergencies and accidents. Doctors in some hospitals were threatened with arrest and dismissal by their administration, while the government was accused of resorting to twisted methods to break the strike, such as distributing 800 interns in government hospitals or giving attractive offers to doctors in Khartoum. Dozens of other hospitals in the same states joined the strike in the days that followed, including hospitals run by the countries armed and intelligence forces, bringing the total of hospitals striking to 136 by 13 October, when it was called off after directives were issued by the vice-president to introduce a bill to the parliament to improve the situation for doctors.

column7: FCD: Federal Committee of Doctors; Health Workers (Sudan)
column17: Strike:Medical strike was renewed by doctors led by the Federal Committee of Doctors to demand better facilities, higher wages and protection from security forces following a spate of violence and armed robberies targeting them, and extended to 46 hospitals, including 21 in Khartoum state and others in West Darfur, North Darfur, Jazira and Sennar states. All sections were affected, except for emergencies and accidents. column17: Strike:Medical strike was renewed by doctors led by the Federal Committee of Doctors to demand better facilities, higher wages and protection from security forces following a spate of violence and armed robberies targeting them, and extended to 46 hospitals, including 21 in Khartoum state and others in West Darfur, North Darfur, Jazira and Sennar states. Dozens of other hospitals in the same states joined the strike in the days that followed, including hospitals run by the countries armed and intelligence forces, bringing the total of hospitals striking to 136 by 13 October, when it was called off after directives were issued by the vice-president to introduce a bill to the parliament to improve the situation for doctors.
A militiaman in military uniform opened fire on a group of people at Hayel Jebel market east of Nyala, South Darfur, leaving three seriously injured.
Four armed herdsmen shot and killed a displaced couple as they tried to prevent the herdsmens livestock from tramping and grazing on their farm east of Sortony IDP camp in Kabkabiya, North Darfur.
Five government militiamen reportedly abducted Sheikh Ahmed Ismail Abdullah from his home near Kabkabiya, taking him at gunpoint to an unknown destination.

A group of herders on a search and rescue mission clashed with unidentified gunmen who had stole their livestock the same morning in Telehoon area in South Darfurs El Radoom locality, leaving five dead, including three of the robbers.
Clashes between members of the Falata and Salamat tribes over cattle-rustling in Wad Hagam near Buram, South Darfur, left around five people dead.
Unidentified gunmen riding camels raided the village of Um Direisaya, west of Shangil Tobaya in North Darfur, firing in the air, leaving one student injured.
Armed gunmen shot and robbed three people in Wadi Domaya, west of the south Darfur capital Nyala.

Armed herdsmen riding camels beat and whipped three farmers working on their farm at Un Ashal in Gereida locality, South Darfur, leaving them seriously injured. They were also robbed of their belongings.
Three unidentified gunmen shot and killed a civilian during an armed robbery in Turr in Kass locality, South Darfur.

Bashir extended the ceasefire in Darfur, Nuba Mountains and the Blue Nile until the end of the 2016. The ceasefire was initially declared in June but has been described by armed groups as an internal monologue for Bashir.

Armed herders besieged the Sese IDP camp in Murnei in West Darfur as they accused IDPs of killing one of their relatives a few days prior. They surrounded the camp and threatened to kill anyone who would attempt to enter or leave the camp. Three days later, they shot and killed a resident of the camp as he was trying to escape. Three women were also repeatedly raped and severely beaten with axes and knives by the militiamen as they were returning to the camp on that day. Reports of people being beaten by the militiamen also emerged as the siege entered its fifth day.

Suspected armed pastoralists shot and killed a farmer on his land near Habila in northern South Kordofan. His crops were destroyed by grazing cattle. Police was stopped from entering the nearby Faio village during the investigation the day after by a group of paramilitary Popular Defence Forces (PDF).

Report of gunfire exchanges between unknown gunmen and government guards and soldiers near the residence of the South Darfur Governor in Nyala, South Darfurs capital, causing panic among residents. One attack was reportedly arrested.

SAF dropped a barrel bomb on the Tring west area of Deribat in Darfur's eastern Jebel Marra, leaving one man killed and scores of livestock lost, and forcing civilians to flee to surrounding mountains, forests, and valleys.

Armed herders besieged the Sese IDP camp in Murnei in West Darfur as they accused IDPs of killing one of their relatives a few days prior. They surrounded the camp and threatened to kill anyone who would attempt to enter or leave the camp. Three days later, they shot and killed a resident of the camp as he was trying to escape. Three women were also repeatedly raped and severely beaten with axes and knives by the militiamen as they were returning to the camp on that day. Reports of people being beaten by the militiamen also emerged as the siege entered its fifth day.
A herder beat, racially abused and insulted a Nuba farmer who was protesting the grazing of the herders livestock on his farm in El Fayd in South Kordofan. Police watched but did not intervene.

Unidentified gunmen attacked workers at the El Daleea mining site near Delling in South Kordofan, leaving one dead and eight others injured including three policemen. The attackers robbed the workers of their belongings.
Unidentified armed militiamen stormed the Nierteti North IDP camp in Central Darfur and abducted three people whom they accused of stealing and killing cattle, taking them to an unknown destination.
A herder ambushed, beat and raped a woman as she was working on her farm in the area of El Hamboul, south of Lagawa town in West Kordofan.
Abbala herdsmen in search of nine missing camels kidnapped five farmers working their fields near Faluja in South Darfur. They later demanded a ransom for the release of the five.
SAF shelled Alnugra village, Tangal Payam in South Kordofan State, wounding a child.
Seven Janjaweed militiamen attempted to rape a woman and her daughter, killing the man who attempted to defend them and stealing their cattle in Korofola in Tawila locality, North Darfur.
Hundreds of people in Sawadera, Northern State demonstrated against the use of cyanide in gold mining near a water station in the area.

Two Maalia tribesmen were killed by Rizaygat militiamen in Abu Karaynka, East Darfur, on 14 and 15 October, following a series of cattle-rustling incidents, raising fears of renewed clashes between the two groups. The two sides failed to reach an agreement at a peace meeting held in Abu Haraz area near Khartoum a few months before.
Armed herders shot a number of farmers in the area of Azirni in West Darfur, killing one of them and injuring another one seriously.

A Maalia tribesman was killed by Rizaygat militiamen in East Darfur as he was trying to recover stolen cattle from a group of raiders, raising fears of renewed clashes between the two groups. The two sides failed to reach an agreement at a peace meeting held in Abu Haraz area near Khartoum a few months before.
SAF fired 27 shells on Umserndiba village, Tangal payam. No casualties.
SAF fired three shells on Alnugra village, Tangal Payam, damaging a farm.

Students of the University of El Fashers Medical Faculty in North Darfur staged a demonstration in front of several faculties in protest against high tuition and registration fees. They have been holding a sit-in to protest these same elements for the past two weeks.

Clashes between NCP and opposition UPF student supporters at a rally at Al-Salam University in Babanusa in Sudan's West Kordofan State, leaving four injured, including two critically. Police intervened and used tear gas to disperse the students.
Armed militiamen fired on a group of herders while attempting to steal their livestock in Mulagat, near Kutum, leaving one dead and at least two others injured, and stealing 450 cattle.

Clashes between NCP and opposition UPF student supporters at a rally at Al-Salam University in Babanusa in Sudan's West Kordofan State, leaving four injured, including two critically. Police intervened and used tear gas to disperse the students.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Abu Tira
column17: Abu Tira forces raided the Kario camp for South Sudanese refugees in Bahr El Arab locality in East Darfur allegedly searching for illegal wine-making operations. They fired shots in the air and beat at least 12 people, including camp leaders. They later took the 12 wounded people into custody from the hospital. Three days later, the Public Order Court in Darfur sentenced and fined six South Sudanese from Kario camp on charges of obstructing an officer on duty and terrorism against the state during the raid.
Gunmen ambushed a group of villagers who had gone to collect straw in Tur in East Jebel Marra, abducting one of them and taking him to an unknown location.
Armed Abbala herders severely wounded the Imam of the local mosque in the village of Lippe, north of Mershing, and abducted his two sons, while searching for missing cattle.
Four unidentified herdsmen allegedly gang-raped a girl at the Al Salam camp for South Sudanese refugees in White Nile State as she had gone to the river to fetch water.

Armed Abbala herders attacked a group of people returning from Kdeneir market in Mershing locality, killing three, injuring five, abducting six and robbing them of their belongings. The herders also clashed with military troops stationed at the market, but were not apprehended. They later demanded a ransom for the release of the six.

Armed Abbala herders attacked a group of people returning from Kdeneir market in Mershing locality, killing three, injuring five, abducting six and robbing them of their belongings. The herders also clashed with military troops stationed at the market, but were not apprehended. They later demanded a ransom for the release of the six.
Demonstration by IDPs from Sese camp in El Geneina, West Darfur. Authorities arrested at least six leaders of the camp the following two days.

Students at Omdurman Islamic University staged a demonstration protesting against the frequent interruptions of water and power supply and the deterioration of the environment in the dormitories. Police intervened and fired tear gas to disperse the demonstration and detained one of the students.
Agreement: The Maaliya and Rizaygat tribes reached an agreement aimed at putting an end to frictions between the tribes in East Darfur. The agreement was facilitated by UNAMID.
Unidentified gunmen shot at people in Anet market of Abyei, South Kordofan, killing one and wounding another.

Police in the Karaki area of Sennar state in Blue Nile reportedly fired on South Sudanese pastoralists who were calling on the government to give them land to live in the area, injuring two and detaining nine. The Sennar state government had earlier promised to grant the pastoralists pieces of land for cultivation and accommodation but they were not granted the land.
Gunmen attacked the Abyei market, killing one person and injuring another. Two people were later arrested in relations to the attack.
Looting: PDF militia looted 180 cows from three families in Hadara village, Umhetan payam in Delami county.
PDF militia shot and seriously injured a widow working on her darm in Kadugli county.
Six members of a government-backed militia beat and robbed the passengers of two commercial vehicles on their way from Karnoi to Kutum, in the area of Shag El Nakhara in North Darfur.

Residents of the eastern Khartoum neighbourhood of Al Geraif and leaders of the National Consensus Forces, staged a sit-in on 23 October in protest against state land expropriation. The next day, police and security agents fired tear gas to disperse the sit-in and beat the protesters with sticks. The protesters confronted them, drawing the agents back to outside their sit-in area. 14 were arrested, including the residents spokesperson, who later claimed to have been beaten and assaulted while in detention. On the third day, police again stormed the sit-in using tear gas and live bullets, beating the protesters and smashing the chairs and the loudspeaker, leaving at least one injured.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Abu Tira
column16: Radio Tamazuj; Radio Dabanga; Sudan Tribune
column17: A policeman was killed by an armed herder in the Kokary area of Sennar state. Following the event, Abu Tira forces engaged in a gunfight with herdsmen grazing their livestock on a land guarded by the forces in the Kokary area of Sennar state, leaving one of the herdsmen killed and two others seriously injured. Later in the day, the herdsmen attacked the Abu Tira camp in Kokary in revenge, leaving 13 Abu Tira forces and 2 herdsmen killed, dozens injured, and burning the camp after chasing the forces away. Abu Tira forces are accused of using agricultural land in the area to carry out systematic targeting and use of force against civilians.

Unidentified assailants tortured and electrocuted a Darfuri student at the Islamic University of Omdurman in El Fitihab district of Omdurman, causing his death. Security officers allegedly confiscated his death certificate.

Soldiers exchanged fire with armed herders who were clashing with farmers over grazing cattle on their lands in Sirba, West Darfur, leaving one of the herders killed and several others arrested and detained at the Abu Suruj police station in Sirba locality. The herdsmen attacked the police station in retaliation the following day, firing shots in the air that forced the policemen to withdraw, seizing weapons and freeing the detainees and the cattle.

Armed herders shot and killed a farmer as she was attempting to chase away the herders camels from her farmland in Hawa Nureldaim near Tawila locality. Two other people on the farm were abducted and livestock taken.

Soldiers exchanged fire with armed herders who were clashing with farmers over grazing cattle on their lands in Sirba, West Darfur, leaving one of the herders killed and several others arrested and detained at the Abu Suruj police station in Sirba locality. The herdsmen attacked the police station in retaliation the following day, firing shots in the air that forced the policemen to withdraw, seizing weapons and freeing the detainees and the cattle.

Armed herdsmen opened fire and seriously wounded a farmer and his wife at Um Gafala area in Tawila locality, North Darfur, as the farmer tried to drive their livestock out of his land. One of the suspects was holding a military ID. Recently, farmers in the area have been regularly threatened with death by herdsmen driving their camels on farms by force of arms, forcing dozens to flee to IDP camps.

Residents of the eastern Khartoum neighbourhood of Al Geraif and leaders of the National Consensus Forces, staged a sit-in on 23 October in protest against state land expropriation. The next day, police and security agents fired tear gas to disperse the sit-in and beat the protesters with sticks. The protesters confronted them, drawing the agents back to outside their sit-in area. 14 were arrested, including the residents spokesperson, who later claimed to have been beaten and assaulted while in detention. On the third day, police again stormed the sit-in using tear gas and live bullets, beating the protesters and smashing the chairs and the loudspeaker, leaving at least one injured.
SAF shelled the Deribat area of East Jebel Marra, leaving a woman killed and putting another two in a coma.

Residents of the eastern Khartoum neighbourhood of Al Geraif and leaders of the National Consensus Forces, staged a sit-in on 23 October in protest against state land expropriation. The next day, police and security agents fired tear gas to disperse the sit-in and beat the protesters with sticks. The protesters confronted them, drawing the agents back to outside their sit-in area. 14 were arrested, including the residents spokesperson, who later claimed to have been beaten and assaulted while in detention. On the third day, police again stormed the sit-in using tear gas and live bullets, beating the protesters and smashing the chairs and the loudspeaker, leaving at least one injured.

Armed herders raided the village of Dill Urdu in Sirba locality in West Darfur, whipping and beating villagers, which caused injuries to at least 46, and plundering the village of its property and livestock. Such repeated attacks have forced more than 600 people to flee to Abu Suruj.

Abala militiamen ambushed a family of displaced farmers returning from a day of farming through the Pellja Valley, near Wadi Saleh in Central Darfur, leaving the head of the family killed as he attenpted to prevent the militiamen from raping his daughters. The following day, a vigilante group who went to pick up the body caught two of the alleged perpetrators of the killing, beat them and handed them over to the police in Garsila town. Abbala tribesmen then surrounded the Jeddah, Jebelein, and Ardeba IDP camps in Garsila, threatening to invade, loot and torch the camps unless their comrades were released and firing into the air, which left at least one IDP killed and one injured. They surrounded the camps until authorities intervened the following day.
Unknown gunmen shot dead a man in Nyala in South Darfur.

Darfur University Students' Association members and supporters staged a mass demonstration at the Islamic University in Omdurman, the university of Haroun, to denounce the killing of a student three days prior and the perceived systematic targeting of Darfuri students by Sudanese security services. Four students were seriously injured when riot police intervened using teargas and severely beating them to disperse the protest.
Unknown gunmen opened fire on a group of displaced people on their way to the Qnaga Valley of Darfur to collect straw, leaving at least three injured and killing their donkeys.

Hundreds of IDPs living in the Hasahisa camp in Central Darfur demonstrated against continued bombing and alleged use of chemical weapons in the Jebel Marra mountain range and calling upon UN bodies to establish a committee to investigate allegation of chemical weapons use and bring the perpetrators to justice.

Abala militiamen ambushed a family of displaced farmers returning from a day of farming through the Pellja Valley, near Wadi Saleh in Central Darfur, leaving the head of the family killed as he attenpted to prevent the militiamen from raping his daughters. The following day, a vigilante group who went to pick up the body caught two of the alleged perpetrators of the killing, beat them and handed them over to the police in Garsila town. Abbala tribesmen then surrounded the Jeddah, Jebelein, and Ardeba IDP camps in Garsila, threatening to invade, loot and torch the camps unless their comrades were released and firing into the air, which left at least one IDP killed and one injured. They surrounded the camps until authorities intervened the following day.
Three unknown gunmen intercepted and killed a secondary school teacher on his way back to his home in Ereli in Kass, South Darfur. Police did not intervene.

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: At least three members of the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia were killed when their vehicle drove on a UXO near Guenk village in North Darfur. They were part of a convoy of 45 RSF vehicles on their way from El Fasher to Jebel Marra.

Darfur University Students' Association members and supporters staged a mass demonstration at Khartoum university to denounce the murder of a Darfuri student in Omdurman four days prior and the perceived systematic targeting of Darfuri students by Sudanese security services.

Abala militiamen ambushed a family of displaced farmers returning from a day of farming through the Pellja Valley, near Wadi Saleh in Central Darfur, leaving the head of the family killed as he attenpted to prevent the militiamen from raping his daughters. The following day, a vigilante group who went to pick up the body caught two of the alleged perpetrators of the killing, beat them and handed them over to the police in Garsila town. Abbala tribesmen then surrounded the Jeddah, Jebelein, and Ardeba IDP camps in Garsila, threatening to invade, loot and torch the camps unless their comrades were released and firing into the air, which left at least one IDP killed and one injured. They surrounded the camps until authorities intervened the following day.

Abala militiamen ambushed a family of displaced farmers returning from a day of farming through the Pellja Valley, near Wadi Saleh in Central Darfur, leaving the head of the family killed as he attenpted to prevent the militiamen from raping his daughters. The following day, a vigilante group who went to pick up the body caught two of the alleged perpetrators of the killing, beat them and handed them over to the police in Garsila town. Abbala tribesmen then surrounded the Jeddah, Jebelein, and Ardeba IDP camps in Garsila, threatening to invade, loot and torch the camps unless their comrades were released and firing into the air, which left at least one IDP killed and one injured. They surrounded the camps until authorities intervened the following day.
Two militiamen entered the Kerkeri camp in Kabkabiya in North Darfur and shot and killed a displaced man who was protesting their refusal to pay for mobile phone credit.
Gunmen attacked policemen stationed at El Shabeik bridge in Kassala,killing one policeman and wounding another. The group is believed to be involved in human trafficking activities.

Four armed herders riding camels ambushed a woman and her daughter while they were tending their farm in Ernei area, southwest of Mershing, beat the mother and raped her daughter alternately. On the same day and in the same area, herders beat farmers who were protesting their driving of camels onto their fams, leaving four farmers seriously wounded.
Four gunmen attacked a commercial vehicle with nearly 20 passengers between Dokura and Amiet, leaving one person killed, another wounded, and looting properties.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column9: Health Workers (Sudan); SCP-Democratic Front: Sudanese Communist Party-Democratic Front
column17: Arrests: NISS arrested the Sudanese Communist Party's political secretary in Khartoum and detained him lacking access to basic utilities. He is a member of the Khartoum Teaching Hospital (KTH) trade union which opposes government's health policies and has seen various strike actions in the past months and announced the resumption of the strike two days later. An additional three senior members of the CPoS were arrested and detained by NISS on 30 November as they attempted to hand a memorandum to the Presidential Palace and called for the resignation of President Bashir.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) University Police
column17: Medical students staged a sit-in protest at the University of El-Fasher following five weeks of strike against increase in registration and tuition fees. University guards, supported by people in civilian clothes, beat the protesters with weapons, sticks and hose-pipes, leaving at least three injured. A week later, the universities administration suspended indefinitely the student protesters, after failure to dissuade them from protesting.
Four herders shot and killed a resident of El Salam IDP camp in Gireida locality as he was trying to chase their cattle off his farm. They stole his horse and cart, and fled. Police did not react.

Non-violent activity: A senior SPLM member has formed a new political party (""Al Haq"") in Khartoum, accusing the ruling SPLM faction in South Sudan, led by Kiir, of failing to implement a reform agenda and the 2015 peace accord. While the party is not armed, it supports the use of force to overthrow the regime.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Armed raid by members of the NISS on El Geneina hispital in the context of strikes by health workers asking for improved working conditions. A doctor was arrested and reportedly beaten in detention.

Teachers of the Egyptian Educational Mission in Sudan staged a sit-in in Khartoum demanding payment of their salaries in Dollars instead of Sudanese Pounds. The continuing increase of the value of hard currencies against the Pound in Sudans black market has resulted in a huge rise in the prices of essential goods and services throughout the country.

Clashes between the Awlad Zaid subclan of the northern Rizaygat and Zaghawa tribesmen in Kulbus in Jebel Moon locality pver 30-31 October left 16 people killed and several abducted on both sides. Two days later, West Darfur authorities banned UNAMID air and ground operations in El Geneina after the agency cancelled a flight to Jebel Moon to monitor the situation over 'security and time concerns"".

Clashes between Darfur bandits and a Chadian pursuit posse near Mary in Jebel Moon locality left at least 20 killed and dozens injured. The Chadians were pursuing the bandits who had earlier crossed into Chad and committed looting and robbery. Two days later, West Darfur authorities banned UNAMID air and ground operations in El Geneina after the agency cancelled a flight to Jebel Moon to monitor the situation over security and time concerns"".
Renewed clashes between police and nomad herders from South Sudan in Kokary in Sennar state over land rights, leaving four killed on the herders side and an unconfirmed number from the polices.
Gunmen raided the office of the Sudanese Railways Corporation in Babanussa in Kordofan, severely beating the paymaster.
Armed herders shot and killed a South Darfur Sheikh as he tried to protect his farm from their livestock in the Nbakaah area of Gereida locality, South Darfur.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Border Guards
column17: Six Border Guards abducted a merchant from Dirige market in Nyala, South Darfur and took him to an unknown destination. Residents threatened to demonstrate after authorities inaction.
An armed herder shot and seriously wounded a displaced girl from Otash camp in Nyala, South Darfur as she was taking cattle out for grazing and refuged to hand him over the animals.
A group of 30 armed herders attacked farmers in Dubbo El Omda in Tawila, North Darfur, injuring nine, including three seriously and stealing their money, donkey and other cattle.

Janjaweed clashed with police after they sought to ambush a number of women who were tending their farms in Seraf Jidad in Sirba locality, West Darfur, leaving one of the attackers injured and his horse killed. The police detained the wounded man.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Agreement: Around 80 SLM/A rebels defected from the SLM/A Abdul Wahid faction and signed a peace agreement for the Koron area of western Jebel Marra with the Governor of Central Darfur in Zaligei two days later. The defectors include SLM/AWs founder, field commander and military spokesman in western Jebel Marra.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Arrests: NISS agents arrested the deputy chief of the opposition Sudanese Congress party in Khartoum for giving a speech that criticised a government decision to raise fuel prices by about 30% in an attempt to help stabilise the countries battered economy, calling on the Sudanese people to organize general protests, strikes and sit-ins.
A man was killed as a UXO exploded in East Jebel Marra while he was on his way from his village in Falluja, south of Dubbo El Omda, to collect firewood. A horse was also killed.

Janjaweed militiamen attacked Seraf Jidad area in Sirba locality, West Darfur, in retaliation for clashes with the police the previous day, abducting four people, destroying farms and stealing hundreds of heads of livestock.
""An INGO security guard was abducted, along with two other people, from their residence in the Tombasi area of El Fasher. There is no further information about the perpetrators or their motives.""
Clashes between members of the Falata and Salamat tribes over cattle-rustling in Nadhif near Buram, South Darfur, left around five people dead.

People protested against fuel price hikes in Wad Madani. Police dispersed them with force, leaving at least one protester injured. A member of the Democratic Unionist Partys Politburo was also detained.
Gunmen abducted a farmer in Turdi in Tawila locality, North Darfur, approaching his farm while firing in the air.
Rioters burnt tyres and tried to stage demonstrations over fuel price hikes in two districts of Khartoum, until riot police dispersed them.

Khartoum university students protested against fuel and electricity price hikes. They were dispersed by police using excessive tear gas and batons, leaving several injured. At least four students were arrested.
Students in Atbara in River Nile state protested against fuel and electricity price hikes. Police dispersed them using tear gas and batons, and arrested an unknown number of students.

Residents in Khartoum block the road and burn tyres to protest against a four day interruption in the water supply. The demonstration goes on for two days with the police failing to disperse the demonstrators.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Arrests: NISS arrested three leading figures of the opposition Sudanese Congress Party, including its former chairman, its secretary general, and its political secretary, in the context of protests against fuel price hikes. By 12 December 17 SCP leaders remained detained incommunicado, including an additional 2 arrested in El Geneina of West Darfur on 12 December.
Clashes between armed men and a rescue group sent to find a girl abducted by them the day before left five killed and many others wounded in Aradib, southwest of Muhajiriya.
Khartoum university students protested against fuel and electricity price hikes. Police dispersed the protesters by forces, and detained an unknown number of students.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Border Guards
column17: Border Guards members opened fire on a convoy of 11 commercial vehicles in Mershing locality, South Darfur, leaving one man dead and another injured, and stealing peoples belongings. A local rescue team of police and Popular Defence Force members arrested one of the offenders the following day.
On 8 November 2016, clashes between armed men and a rescue group sent to find a girl abducted by them the day before left five killed and many others wounded in Aradib, southwest of Muhajiriya.
Clashes between Rizaygat and Masalit tribesmen over the attempted rape of Masalit girls by armed Rizaygat in Um Sharanah near Gereida left six dead.

Clashes between armed herders and farmers accusing them of trespassing on their farms left two farmers and three herders killed, and several injured on both sides, in Goghana area, South Darfur. Armed herders attacked and burned at least ten villages in the area the following day in retaliation.

column6: SLM/A-General Leadership: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (General Leadership Faction)
column17: Agreement: Darfur government signed a peace deal with a breakaway group of commanders from SLM-AW known as the Korona peace agreement for Jebel Marra. SLM-AW downplayed the agreement as ""mere play"". The splinters include Abu Gamal Khalil Bakr, Al-Amin Abdel-Jabar al-Tahir (aka al-Amin Turo) and the movement's spokesperson Shihab al-Din Ahmed Hagar. The movement of the dissidents is to be called the Sudan Liberation Movement General Leadership.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Small demonstration against fuel price hikes at El Haj Yousif Station in Khartoum. NISS arrested five leaders of the Reform Now Movement and of the opposition coalition after holding a public speech at the demonstration. One of them was severely injured by NISS members during his arrest.

Residents and students from the University of Wadi El Nil in Atbara in River Nile state protested against fuel and electricity price hikes. Police dispersed them, arresting 25 students. The protesters took the street again after the arrests, to which police responded by using tear gas and sticks.

Armed herders attacked and burnt ten villages of Goghana area in South Darfur, including Dendora, Matiya, Haraza, Dahab Sharo, Myola, Kafla and Roina villages, in retaliation for clashes with farmers in the area the previous day, leaving at least seven people killed and dozens of others injured. Farmlands were also significantly damaged and livestock looted. Dozens of people fled to Gireida camps after the attacks.
At Khartoum University, an NCP-affiliated student stabbed Darfur students holding a rally to discuss political developments in the country, injuring at least two.

Residents of Gereida, South Darfur, protested against deadly militant raids on ten villages in Goghana area the previous day. Police and security forces shot live ammunition and tear gas, and used batons to disperse the demonstrators, leaving several injured. At least eight demonstrators were also detained and beaten in detention in Nyala and in Gireida, while the head of the teachers union in Gereida was arrested five days after the protest. Four were released soon after their arrest, while another four were released six months later, on 24 April 2017, without charge or trial.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: NISS beat and detained three journalists and an activist in Khartoum. Three of them were leaving the premises of a courtroom where they attended the trial of several civil society activists.
Clashes between the Habbaniyah and Salamat tribes in Buram locality, South Darfur, after a series of assassinations and robberies by tribesmen of both sides, left nine people killed or wounded.
A group of seven militiamen opened fire on farmers in Tebra, Tawila locality, North Darfur, killing one and wounding another five.
Armed bandits ambushed a commercial vehicle in Dalal Angara, on its way from Ed El Fursan locality to Nyala city, leaving two killed and a number of other passengers wounded.
Looting: PDF members stations in Balula area attacked 12 traders at al-Wakar market in Abbasiya Tagali area in South Kordofan, robbing 1 million SDG from them at gunpoint.

column7: Mahariya Tribal Group (Sudan); URFF: United Revolutionary Forces Front
column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Clash between a leader of the El Mahariya tribe heading the URFF and the local RSF commander-in-chief over development demands in tribal areas of North Darfur. The tribe leader was later arrested by security forces.

Armed herders attacked five people on the road between Tabit and Hashaba in North Darfur in two separate incidents on the same day, injuring three and abducting two. The ambushes followed a clash between herdsmen and farmers south of Abu as the farmers were attempting to remove livestock from their lands, which left a herder and seven camels killed, and at least two others injured.

Police and security forces fired tear gas and used sticks to disperse a sit-in by Darfuri students led by their association at the Islamic University of Omdurman demanding an exemption for the payment of tuition fees. A number of students were reportedly injured. At least one journalist was arrested for covering the protest - he was released soon after but had his material on the protests confiscated.

Armed herders attacked five people on the road between Tabit and Hashaba in North Darfur in two separate incidents on the same day, injuring three and abducting two. The ambushes followed a clash between herdsmen and farmers south of Abu as the farmers were attempting to remove livestock from their lands, which left a herder and seven camels killed, and at least two others injured.

Non-violent activity: Reports of El Mahriya tribesmen blocking roads north of Kutum since 14 November in relations to the arrest of their chief two days prior. The blockades were still ongoing a week later. No reported abuse.
Looting: Gunmen attacked farmers on their farms and robbed agriculture products in Geisan locality in Blue Nile, raising fears of attacks during the upcoming agricultural season.
Looting: Gunmen on camels and horses attacked Buri and Junga villages of Sirba locality in West Darfur, stealing a number of livestock.

Two prisoners released from two months detention in Kober and Dabrak prison in Khartoum report that torture of detained oppositionists and members of rebel groups is standard practice. In one instance, a friend of activist Mudawi Ibrahim was arrested at the latter's home in November and subjected in detention to torture, including through electrocution and beatings, and forced confession. He remained detained without charge as of March 2017.

Clashes between police and herdsmen as the police and a local group intervened to calm tensions between the herdsmen and farmers south of Tabit, left two killed, a police officer and a herder. The Tabit high secondary school headmaster and a PDF member were also seriously wounded.
Gunmen beat and robbed eight displaced people near Kassab camp in Kutum locality as they were returning from Mulgat.

Renewed clashes between farmers and herdsmen at Dmiosei area in Goghana, South Darfur as the herdsmen were attempting to enter libestock on the farmers lands. One of the herdsmen was killed. In a retaliatory attack by the herdsmen the following day, eight people were killed, at least five wounded, while a number went missing.

column6: UNISFA: United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (2011-)
column17: The U.N. Interim Security Force of Abyei mandate was extended to 15 May 2017, with the Security Council demanding South Sudan and Sudan to urgently establish an Abyei Area Administration and Council, as well as a police service that would protect oil infrastructure.

Renewed clashes between farmers and herdsmen at Dmiosei area in Goghana, South Darfur as the herdsmen were attempting to enter libestock on the farmers lands. One of the herdsmen was killed. In a retaliatory attack by the herdsmen the following day, eight people were killed, at least five wounded, while a number went missing.

SPLM-N shelled Sudanese forces garrison base in Al Azraq and ambushed a convoy of soldiers attempting to leave the base. Government forces repelled the attack, leaving at least 12 rebels injured, including one severely. Some casualties were also reported the governments side.

Militiamen opened fire on a group of 50 people on their way from Kado market to Nertiti, killing a man, injuring another, robbing people of their belongs and abducting nine. The militiamen asked for a ransom the following day.
Armed herders abducted two farmers while they were tending their farms in the Tayara area, south of Tabit.

Three police officers were killed and others injured in an attack on a customs police station by an unidentified armed group in Gagago area east of El Fasher. The assailants fled with a police vehicles and arms.
PDF militiamen abducted a man while working on his farm in Tembera village, Kumbur payam, Heiban county.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: NISS dispersed a protest by residents of Goghana over renewed herder violence in the area with live ammunition, tear gas, and batons, detaining at least eight people, including three secondary school teachers. Four were transferred to a detention centre in Nyala the following day.
Agreement: Leaders of Chadian Arab and Sudanese Zaghawa tribes signed a reconciliation accord in El Geneina.

Masalit farmers killed two Rizaygat nomads who allegedly grazed their cattle on their farm in Dimasoya in Goghana area, South Darfur. Retaliatory attacks over the next two days in Goghana and Dimasoya led to clashes that resulted in the further killing of 21 Rizaygat and 10 Masalit tribesmen. (first day's fatalities coded in other event)

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: SLM/AW reportedly attacked Sudanese forces in Sarrong, Central Darfur, injuring 16 soldiers.

Mahariya tribesmen shot a resident in the leg for refusing to hand over his mobile phone. The tribesmen have been blocking roads to North Darfur in the town since 14 November calling for the release of their leader. Lootings were reported in the town.
SAF fired four shells on Alnugra village and five shells on Umserndiba village, Tangal payam. No casualties.
SAF fired four shells on Alnugra village and five shells on Umserndiba village, Tangal payam. No casualties.

column9: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Dozens of Sudanese staged a demonstration along the Airport road in Khartoum to protest the government's decision to raise fuel, electricity and drug prices. They were dispersed with tear gas and batons by police and security services. 26 protesters were arrested by security officials; they appeared in Court the following days and were acquitted on 4 December after a court ruled that their action did not constitute an offense. It is notable that three brothers committed suicide in Omdurman as their family could not afford to buy treatment for their acute depression as a result of the price hikes.

Darfuri students at the university of Khartoum went on a strike to protest the decision repealing the fee-exemption granted to Darfuri students according to the Doha Document Peace in Darfur. Police and security services intervened two days later to quell the protest, dispersing the students using tear gas and sticks. They arrested six Darfuri students and detained and beat them until later that day, when they were released.

Four gunmen in military uniforms shot at two merchants moving their livestock from Deribat to El Fasher, leaving one of them killed and the other injured, and stealing their livestock. The assailants fled to South Darfur.
Armed hersmen killed three farmers and wounded others in three separate incidents in South Darfur on the same day.

Dozens of Sudanese women staged demonstrations and sit-ins in several cities across Sudan, including Wad Medani, Kassala, Port Sudan and Khartoum's twin city of Omdurman, to protest the government's decision to raise fuel, electricity and drug prices. In Omdurman, police beat the protesters with stiks, and detained 17 women, charging them with disturbing public order. In Kassala, police also violently dispersed the protesters, arresting seven of them and charging them with rioting before releasing them later that day.
Armed herders abducted a policeman in Mukjar after the towns Commissionner refused to release three of their companions.

Dozens of Sudanese women staged demonstrations and sit-ins in several cities across Sudan, including Wad Medani, Kassala, Port Sudan and Khartoum's twin city of Omdurman, to protest the government's decision to raise fuel, electricity and drug prices. In Omdurman, police beat the protesters with stiks, and detained 17 women, charging them with disturbing public order. In Kassala, police also violently dispersed the protesters, arresting seven of them and charging them with rioting before releasing them later that day.

Dozens of Sudanese women staged demonstrations and sit-ins in several cities across Sudan, including Wad Medani, Kassala, Port Sudan and Khartoum's twin city of Omdurman, to protest the government's decision to raise fuel, electricity and drug prices. In Omdurman, police beat the protesters with stiks, and detained 17 women, charging them with disturbing public order. In Kassala, police also violently dispersed the protesters, arresting seven of them and charging them with rioting before releasing them later that day.

Dozens of Sudanese women staged demonstrations and sit-ins in several cities across Sudan, including Wad Medani, Kassala, Port Sudan and Khartoum's twin city of Omdurman, to protest the government's decision to raise fuel, electricity and drug prices. In Omdurman, police beat the protesters with stiks, and detained 17 women, charging them with disturbing public order. In Kassala, police also violently dispersed the protesters, arresting seven of them and charging them with rioting before releasing them later that day.
Armed herder shot dead a woman south of Nyala as he tried to kidnap her daughter at gunpoint.
Armed herdsmen shot and killed two farmers and wounded another as they worked on their farm and tried to prevent the herdsmen from driving cattle onto their lands around Kass.

column7: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Darfuri students at the university of Khartoum went on a strike to protest the decision repealing the fee-exemption granted to Darfuri students according to the Doha Document Peace in Darfur. Police and security services intervened two days later to quell the protest, dispersing the students using tear gas and sticks. They arrested six Darfuri students and detained and beat them until later that day, when they were released.

column7: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Darfuri students at Omdurman Islamic university staged a strike to protest the refusal by the university to register new Darfuri students without tuition. Police and security services intervened to disperse the protesters, arresting a large number of students.

A militiaman opened fire on shoppers at the Kabkabiya market for refusing to comply with his demands, leaving two displaced people injured. In another incident, gunmen hijacked a vehicle carrying school equipment from Kabkabiya to Malaga area.
Gunmen abducted a displaced man near Sortony camp in Kabkabiya.
SAF fired eight rockets on Ardicanan illage in Heiban, injuring a civilian travelling to the village market and burning down three huts.
Looting: Over two days, groups of militiamen plundered Tori, Gori, Hilla Jadeeda, Arida, and Um Shijera villages in Disa, Kutum locality and stole livestock, forcing villagers to flee.

Students and residents of Khartoum protested in front of Khartoums Faculty of Medicine against fuel subsidy cuts that have led to spiralling prices in the country. Police dispersed the protesters, arresting at least four. Three activists were allegedly subjected to beatings after their arrest.
Armed robbers shot a displaced man near a camp north of Nertiti in Central Darfur, leaving him severely injured, and stole his property.
Youth and other residents of Atbara in River Nile state staged a peaceful march to protest authorities recent economic decisions.
SAF fired missiles from Kadugli on SPLM-N positions in Umm Serdiba, Al Nogra, Al Labo and Tablo areas of Um Dorain county, South Kordofan over two days. No mentioned casualties.
SAF fired missiles from Kadugli on SPLM-N positions in Umm Serdiba, Al Nogra, Al Labo and Tablo areas of Um Dorain county, South Kordofan over two days. No mentioned casualties.
SAF fired missiles from Kadugli on SPLM-N positions in Umm Serdiba, Al Nogra, Al Labo and Tablo areas of Um Dorain county, South Kordofan over two days. No mentioned casualties.
SAF fired missiles from Kadugli on SPLM-N positions in Umm Serdiba, Al Nogra, Al Labo and Tablo areas of Um Dorain county, South Kordofan over two days. No mentioned casualties.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Arrests: NISS arrested four opposition NCF members after summoning them at their office in Khartoum ""in an anticipated move"", allegedly as part of the governments campaign against the emerging of more protests. The NCF vowed to exert every possible effort to overthrow the regime and achieve aspiration of the Sudanese people - freedom, peace and justice.

Agreement: The Humanitarian Affairs Secretary of the Justice and Equality Movement in Kordofan and three other militants of the movement split from the movement and returned to Kadugli town to join the national peace process in the country. They denounced human rights violations committed by the group, including recruitment of child soldiers.
Property destruction: Report of more than 400 farms damaged or destroyed by herdsmen in Tawila and Koroma constitutencies in North Darfur, forcing hundreds of people into displacement.

Around 300 Sudanese students and schoolchildren marched in Khartoum, Bahri, Omdurman and Gebeit in eastern Sudan to protest price increases nationwide. Police dispersed the protesters violently in Bahris Shambat neighbourhood and Ombadda in Omdurman.

Students affiliated with the NCP attacked other students with sticks during a discussion at EN Nahud university in West Kordofan. After the incident, some students went in the street to protest. Police fired teargas to disperse them.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column17: Two youths died two days after being released from military intelligence custody in Ed Damazin of Blue Nile. They had allegedly been tortured while in detention. Rising arbitrary arrests and bad conditions in detention have been reported in the area.

Around 300 Sudanese students and schoolchildren marched in Khartoum, Bahri, Omdurman and Gebeit in eastern Sudan to protest price increases nationwide. Police dispersed the protesters violently in Bahris Shambat neighbourhood and Ombadda in Omdurman.

Students affiliated with the NCP attacked other students with sticks during a discussion at EN Nahud university in West Kordofan. After the incident, some students went in the street to protest. Police fired teargas to disperse them.

Around 300 Sudanese students and schoolchildren marched in Khartoum, Bahri, Omdurman and Gebeit in eastern Sudan to protest price increases nationwide. Police dispersed the protesters violently in Bahris Shambat neighbourhood and Ombadda in Omdurman.

Around 300 Sudanese students and schoolchildren marched in Khartoum, Bahri, Omdurman and Gebeit in eastern Sudan to protest price increases nationwide. Police dispersed the protesters violently in Bahris Shambat neighbourhood and Ombadda in Omdurman.
SAF fired nine shells on Nyakima village in the Al Azraq payam in retaliation for an attack by SPLM-N rebels a few days prior. No reported casualty.
SAF fired missiles from Kadugli on SPLM-N positions in Umm Serdiba, Al Nogra, Al Labo and Tablo areas of Um Dorain county, South Kordofan over two days. No mentioned casualties.
SAF fired missiles from Kadugli on SPLM-N positions in Umm Serdiba, Al Nogra, Al Labo and Tablo areas of Um Dorain county, South Kordofan over two days. No mentioned casualties.
SAF fired missiles from Kadugli on SPLM-N positions in Umm Serdiba, Al Nogra, Al Labo and Tablo areas of Um Dorain county, South Kordofan over two days. No mentioned casualties.
SAF fired missiles from Kadugli on SPLM-N positions in Umm Serdiba, Al Nogra, Al Labo and Tablo areas of Um Dorain county, South Kordofan over two days. No mentioned casualties.

column9: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: Gunmen abducted four Sudanese working for UNAMID near Nyala Technical College, while on their way to the missions headquarters in Sagra, north east of Nyala. They looted their vehicles. They were released hours later.
Militiamen attacked a family of farmer in Tonj area, south of Kass
Gunmen opened fire on three brothers on their way from Ardamata camp to their families farm in Azirni in Kereinik locality, West Darfur, leaving one killed and the two others severely injured.
Militiamen attacked a group of about ten women returning from shopping in Nertiti in Central Darfur, raping four of them and leaving two with severe injuries.

Non-violent activity: Armed herders fired at the vehicle of the Commissioner of Mukjar locality in Central Darfur on its way to retrieve camels released on farms by the herders near the town. No injury.
Renewed demonstration by women in front of the Atbara Grand Mosque to protest soaring prices nationwide. NISS arrested and detained an SCP member and a student after the protest.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Students at four high schools in El-Fasher in North Darfur,later joined by a number of residents, staged a demonstration to protest the high cost of living and the recent increase in drug prices. Police used tear gas and fired shots in the air to disperse the demonstrators, causing several cases of fainting and light injury. NISS also arrested some of the protesting students.

A group of six suspected Sudanese militiamen led by Yousif Ahmed Ali Guttiya (nicknamed Kabro) abducted three UNHCR staff members (two foreign employees and their driver) in El Geneina, west Darfur, as they were returning from a mission.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Joint Sudanese-Chadian Border Guards
column9: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Joint Sudanese-Chadian Border Guards
column17: Darfuri militiamen clashed with Chadian militiamen in Manjura and Rufeid villages in West Darfur, after they raided the Sunta area on the Chadian side of the border. Two Chadians and a member of the joint Sudan-Chad border forces were killed in the clashes. The Darfuri militiamen gave populations in the area a 24h ultimatum to join them in their fight against the Chadians or to join IDP camps.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Joint Sudanese-Chadian Border Guards
column9: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Joint Sudanese-Chadian Border Guards
column17: Darfuri militiamen clashed with Chadian militiamen in Manjura and Rufeid villages in West Darfur, after they raided the Sunta area on the Chadian side of the border. Two Chadians and a member of the joint Sudan-Chad border forces were killed in the clashes. The Darfuri militiamen gave populations in the area a 24h ultimatum to join them in their fight against the Chadians or to join IDP camps.

A number of Sudanese in Khartoum followed a call launched on social media by a group of political activists under the name of Khalas for three days of civil disobedience over 27-29 November to protest the recent price hikes in the country, staying at home instead of going out to work or to school. The protest was most followed on the first day. A medical student was reportedly detained for filming the empty streets of Khartoum on the first day of action.
SAF dropped two bombs between Hajar Bako and Hajar Tia villages, near Heiban Town in the Nuba Mountains. The two bombs fell near a primary school, injuring four people and destroying four homes.
Armed herders shot and killed a farmer as he was tilling his farm in Tamra, west of Khazan Tunjur, North Darfur. They robbed his of his belongings before fleeing.

Clashes between students at Al Nahud university in west Kordofan as a group of students affiliated to opposition political parties prevented the rest of the students form entering the university to sit examinations planned on that day. Property was damaged at the universiy, while police intervened to contain the situation.
SAF dropped two bombs on Lula village in Al Azraq payam. No casualties.
Armed herders shot and killed a displaced man of Shadad camp in Shangil Tobaya as he tried to chase away their livestock and camels from his farm.
Janjaweed herdsmen beat farmers as they attempted to chase away the groups livestock from their farms in the area of Abu Zerega, southwest of El Fasher, leaving seven injured, two severely.

column7: NOAWI: No Oppression Against Women Initiative; Women (Sudan)
column17: More than 30 women of the No Oppression Against Women Initiative staged a peaceful sit-in against the price hikes outside the home of Prime Minister Ismail Al Azhari in Omdurman. Security forces dispersed them and arrested seven. The group was charged with disturbance of public peace and public nuisance, and released a few hours later on bail.

column7: NOAWI: No Oppression Against Women Initiative; Women (Sudan)
column17: More than 30 women of the No Oppression Against Women Initiative staged a demonstration against the price hikes in Khartoum. Security and police forces reportedly violently dispersed them.

Movement of forces: Report that government forces are buliding up SAF-aligned militias in Khor Deleib, Kadugli, Abu Jibeha, Al Himer, Al Hadmor and Kutang in South Kordofan in preparations for dry season offensives against SPLM-N rebels.
Six gunmen fired on a group of farmers at Manora area, south of Gireida, South Darfur, leaving one killed and two others wounded.
Militiamen abducted two show owners from the market in Nyala.
More than 300 people staged a march in Omdurman to protest fuel subsidy cuts. Police fired tear gas to disperse the protesters.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: A group of around 150 lawyers marched in front of the high court in Khartoum to demand the release of the unlawfully detained people and called for the strengthening of the rule of law. Security services beat and arrested one of the protesters, detained three journalists, seizing their equipments, and confiscated the protesters banners.
Janjaweed herdsmen raped a woman on her farm in Arasho area, north of Shangil Tobay, amid reports that they are forcibly grazing livestock on farms in the area.

NCP student supporters attacked Darfuri students with live ammunition at the Holy Koran University in Khartoum, leaving eight students injured. Riot police fired tear gas to disperse the students, and arrested at least three. The Darfuri students were holding an event on tuition fee exemptions - they had held protests over the issue in Khartoum and Omdurman universities earlier in the month.

column7: CCSP: Central Committee of the Sudanese Pharmacists
column17: Pharmacists in Khartoum, led by the Central Committee of the Sudanese Pharmacists (CCSP) staged a sit-in to reject drug price hikes and demand the release of its detained members since 28 November, while 57 pharmacies went on a strike in the capital for three hours in the morning. A large security force attempted to prevent the sit-in and arrested at least two.

Gunmen attacked a man and his wife in Malgo, near Nertiti, leaving them severely injured. As he was later tracking down the perpetrators, a policeman died and 12 people were injured as his car overturned.

Armed pastoralists allegedly killed a herdsman and stole 250 camels and 150 cows from him in Katur. The following day, armed herders retaliated by attacking pastoralists in the same area, leading to clashes that left at least three shot and injured. Soldiers intervened to separate the two groups.
Two gunmen shot and killed a man in front of his house for unclear reasons in Kabkabiya.
Armed herdsmen killed a farmer in Babiker village, north of El Fasher in North Darfur as he was preventing the herdsmen from forcibly bringing their camels on his farm land to graze.

Armed herders clashed with pastoralists in Katur over their alleged theft of 250 camels and 150 cows from them the day before. At least three villagers were shot and injured in the clash. Soldiers intervened to separate the two groups.
Unknown gunmen shot and killed the coordinator of the Popular Defence Forces in front of his house in Foro Baranga in West Darfur.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Sudanese forces attacked SLM/AW positions east of Nertiti in retaliation for an earlier attack by the group. Impact of the attack is unclear due to lack of access to the area.

Armed pastoralists ambushed a convoy of passenger buses in Deribat, and seized 25 commercial trucks traveling from Nyala to El Fasher, to protest the theft of 250 camels from pastoralists in Katur area on the border three days prior. The passengers were released soon after after negotiations with local authorities, but the armed pastoralists refused to open the strategic road to Darbat until the cattle was returned, affecting local economic activities. The lifted the blockade three days later.

column7: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: Dozens of former UNAMID local staff protested in front of the mission's premises in El-Fasher, Nyala, El Geneina and Zalingei in Darfur, for non-payment of pension entitlements since 2010. UNAMID declared that a majority of the payments had been made while the rest were being finalised, and denounced movement blockades by the protesters affecting UNAMID staffs access to camps and to their workplaces.

column7: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: Dozens of former UNAMID local staff protested in front of the mission's premises in El-Fasher, Nyala, El Geneina and Zalingei in Darfur, for non-payment of pension entitlements since 2010. UNAMID declared that a majority of the payments had been made while the rest were being finalised, and denounced movement blockades by the protesters affecting UNAMID staffs access to camps and to their workplaces.

column7: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: Dozens of former UNAMID local staff protested in front of the mission's premises in El-Fasher, Nyala, El Geneina and Zalingei in Darfur, for non-payment of pension entitlements since 2010. UNAMID declared that a majority of the payments had been made while the rest were being finalised, and denounced movement blockades by the protesters affecting UNAMID staffs access to camps and to their workplaces.

column7: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: Dozens of former UNAMID local staff protested in front of the mission's premises in El-Fasher, Nyala, El Geneina and Zalingei in Darfur, for non-payment of pension entitlements since 2010. UNAMID declared that a majority of the payments had been made while the rest were being finalised, and denounced movement blockades by the protesters affecting UNAMID staffs access to camps and to their workplaces.
PDF elements exchanged fire with a gang in El Taweisha locality in North Darfur as they were attempting to smuggle cannabis to the Sudanese capital, leaving two killed, including a PDF member.

Armed herders shot and killed three people and injured several others in an attack on Barkendi village in Dobo el Omda. Some people reportedly went missing after the incident, while the herders also stole property and livestock before leaving.
A child was killed by a bullet at the Sortony IDP camp in North Darfur when Sudanese soldiers at a nearby military base opened defence fire into the air towards the camp.
Gunmen abducted a trader on his way home in the Congo neighbourhood of Nyala. He escaped 10 days later, on 15 December.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: A human rights activist and head of the youth camps in North Darfurt detained by NISS early December described being beaten, kicked, and tortured with electric cables in NISS detention. He was still awaiting prosecution as of March 2017.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column7: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Prison Guards
column17: NISS arrested and detained human rights defender, Mudawi Ibrahim Adam, at Khartoum University, where he works as an engineer professor. He has allegedly been severely beaten and tortured in Khartoum's Kober prison.

Residents in Khartoum block the road and burn tyres to protest against a four day interruption in the water supply. The demonstration goes on for two days with the police failing to disperse the demonstrators.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Arrests: NISS arrested and detained a prominent human rights defender, Mudawi Ibrahim Adam, at Khartoum university, where he works as an engineer professor. He was charged on 5 June 2017 with six offences, including charges of espionage and intelligence activities for foreign embassies, some of which are punishable by death.

Four gunmen opened fire on two IDPs in El Matar camp in Kabkabiya while attempting to raid their home, leaving at least one severely wounded. On the same day, militiamen kidnapped the son of the deputy of the Chamber of Commerce in Kabkabiya.

Militiamen surrounded the Shadad IDP camp in Shangil Tobaya, accusing the residents of being involved with rebel movements in Darfur. They remained there a week later, and were reported to have assaulted and verbally abused camp residents outside the camp, including beating some with rifle butts.
Gunmen shot at a vehicle traveling from Ed Dain to Nyala in Tortahan area of East Darfur, leaving one of the passengers killed.

Unknown gunmen attacked two displaced people returning from their farms north of Murnei camp in West Darfur. The woman was shot and killed on the spot, while her husband stabbed one of the perpetrators and killed him. The husband sustained injuries.
Clashes between locals in Artala, Mukjar locality, left four people killed and an unknown number of people wounded. The dispute had not been resolved a week later.
One person killed and another injured in two separate attacks by unknown gunmen in Ed El Fursan locality in South Darfur, on the road to Nyala.
Gunmen attacked Bol Jamil village in the Abata admministrative unit of Zalingei, opening fire on villagers, leaving six injured, and robbing and burning property in the village.
Relatives of an abducted merchant in Nyala staged a sit-in to protest the rising number of abductions in he area and failure by authorities to arrest the culprits.
Gunmen ambushed two commercial vehicles on their way from Zalingei to Saraf Omra in North Darfur in the area of Naga Delwa, beating the passengers and stealing the merchandise.
Clash between government and SPLM-N forces in Jardan, Deim Mansur area of central Blue Nile state. No reported fatality.
Gunmen shot at a commercial vechile in the Tamur area, near Hamidiya IDP camp, leaving one IDP injured.
Two boys were killed and one sustained injuries when an unexploded ordnance detonated in Tamra village, Tawila locality in North Darfur.
Unknown gunmen attacked people fetching firewood on their way from shopping in Nierteti in Rokoro area, leaving one killed, seven injured, and stealing their belongings.
Armed herders killed a farmer in Abu Rizaigha area of Dar el-Salam locality, North Darfur, as he tried to prevent their cattle from grazing in his land.
A large group of armed herders abducted a man in Fanga village in East Jebel Marra and fired in the air in the village, in retaliation for the theft of some of their cattle two days prior.
Unknown gunmen killed a displaced woman on her way from Tanoko to Murnei IDP camp. Details are scarce.
Unknown gunmen attacked farms at Haidoub area near Gireida, leaving five farmers wounded, stealing money and cattle.
Armed herders killed three IDPs and wounded four others as the displaced tried to stop them from stealing 40 goats in Gireida, near the Foreika IDP camp.
Unknown gunmen attacked the Dor market in Kutum locality, North Darfur, leaving one person killed, four wounded and stealing large amounts of cash and goods.
Unknown gunmen killed a man on his farm in Azerni. Details are scarce.
Teachers and school employed in Abu Zabad, El Fula, El Muglad, and Babanus localities of Kordofan staged a three-day strike to demand the payment of their November salaries.
Teachers and school employed in Abu Zabad, El Fula, El Muglad, and Babanus localities of Kordofan staged a three-day strike to demand the payment of their November salaries.
Teachers and school employed in Abu Zabad, El Fula, El Muglad, and Babanus localities of Kordofan staged a three-day strike to demand the payment of their November salaries.

Non-violent activity: Militant herders set up new road blocks at Deribat, on the main road from the South Darfur capital of Nyala to the North Darfur capital of El Fasher, still demanding the return of cattle stolen from them by suspected Katur pastoralists two weeks prior.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Women activists in Sennar protested in front of the hospital against the governments new economic policies, the increases in prices, and violence against women. Two of the participants were later detained by authorities, including a human rights activist and lawyer, and a journalist.

Non-violent activity: NCP governor and chairman in Blue Nile state dismissed 69 members after a dispute. They include the former secretary general of the party, the former secretary general of the party in Damazin locality, and the speaker of the state parliament. The dismissed members formed a new ""reform wing"" in the party calling for reform in the state government.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column7: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Prison Guards
column17: In December 2016, a British journalist and his American-Sudanese translator, who entered Darfur to investigate Amnesty International's report that Sudanese security forces used chemical weapons against civilians in Jebel Marra, were detained for nearly two months and severely tortured with beatings, electric shocks, and mock executions.
Two girls of 12 and 16 years were raped near their camp in Tawila, North Darfur. Approximately 13 armed men on camels attacked a group of women

Report of regular physical assaults on IDPs from Sortony camp in Kabkabiya locality by armed herders and militiamen affiliated with a local militia leader, Asbad Mohamed Khater. The gunmen also regularly close roads leading to the camp, disrupting provisions of water and food.
Unidentified militiamen shoot a farmer dead in Kabkabia
