Further clashes took place between the Southern Rizeigat and Ma'aliya in Sabah al-Nima on 18 April.

column7: NCP: National Congress Party; Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) University Police; Students (Sudan)
column17: Clashes between ruling NCP student supporters and Darfuri students at the University of Sennar in Al-Suki area. NCP supporters reportedly attacked the Darfuri students at their hostel and looted their belongings. In parallel, security personnel reportedly injured Darfuri students within the university, and arrested around 11.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Prison Guards
column17: At least 49 convicts were injured during a clash with guards at El Huda prison in Omdurman. The incident occurred after prison guards reportedly insulted the inmates when conducting a personal inspection of the inmates and their luggage upon orders from the new prison director.
Militiamen abducted a lawyer from Kabkabiya in North Darfur, while on his way to his house in El Amiriya district.

column7: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: More than 50 former UNAMID staff launched a three-day sit-in strike in El Fasher to demand financial rights for dismissed workers. On the second day, NISS dispersed the protesters, taking them to their office.

Looting: On 19 April, armed men carjacked an United Nations Humanitarian Air Service minibus driven by a national staff member in the Hay al-Muglis area of Nyala, South Darfur. The driver was released by the perpetrators on the Nyala-El Fasher road after being robbed of his personal belongings.
Armed herders abducted two farmers from Katur in North Darfur.
Militiamen raided five villages in East Jebel Marra (Jasu, Hai Mudraj, Hillet Sheikh Adu, Hillet Liba and Hillet Adam Abdelmajid, north of Mershing locality), leaving 2 killed and three injured.
SAF bombed at least 15 villages in the area between Maya in Kabkabiya locality and Aja in northern Jebel Marra on 22 and 23 April, setting fire to many houses. Unclear if civilian casualties.
SAF bombed at least 15 villages in the area between Maya in Kabkabiya locality and Aja in northern Jebel Marra on 22 and 23 April, setting fire to many houses. Unclear if civilian casualties.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Clashes between SLM-AW and pro-government militiamen in Torang Tora, Nertiti locality in Central Darfur, left at least 17 killed. Hundreds of people fled in fear. Pro-government forces during their withdrawal from the area allegedly burned three villages: Kutur, Tebin Foka and Tordi.
Unknown gunmen attacked a number of nomad settlements in the area of Falluja in east jebel marra, leaving two herders shot and wounded and dozens of cattle stolen.
SAF bombed at least 15 villages in the area between Maya in Kabkabiya locality and Aja in northern Jebel Marra on 22 and 23 April, setting fire to many houses. Unclear if civilian casualties.
SAF bombed at least 15 villages in the area between Maya in Kabkabiya locality and Aja in northern Jebel Marra on 22 and 23 April, setting fire to many houses. Unclear if civilian casualties.

Clashes between the Al-Ziyoud and Awlad Omran clans of the Misseriya tribe at Nama area in Dabab Locality, West Kordofan, left at least six killed and several others wounded. The fighting started after a dispute over ownership of a water point used by both communities.
Darfur militiamen attacked Birka Toli village in South Darfur, firing shots in the air, attacking worshipers, beating the Imam of the Haroun El Haj mosque, and stealing property.

Darfur militiamen attacked Mura and Barkoro areas west of Katur in eastern Jebel Marra, leaving two people killed, seven injured, three missing and thousands of cattle and cash stolen. The assailants then headed towards El Malam area of South Darfur.
A militiaman raped and stabbed a displaced schoolgirl as she was collecting firewood at Bir Jongu, north of Kabkabiya.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 27 April, former SLA/AW rebels led by Sadiq clashed with Arab nomads over access to the Kube water point, north-west of the Sortony IDP site, resulting in the death of three nomads and one former rebel. SAF deployed reinforcements and facilitated an agreement between the two communities over access to the water point.
A UXO explosion killed a boy and his two camels at Khor Mali, west of Tabit in North Darfur.
Unknown gunmen ambushed displaced women collecting straw in the Gallab area, near El Fasher in North Darfur, leaving one killed, one injured and five others missing.
Militiamen abducted a merchant while he was on his way from Fanga in East Jebel Marra back to Tawila, at Tarni, in Tawila locality.

At least 11 people were killed and 17 others wounded in a clash between Salamat and Habbaniya tribesmen at Um Sial, west of Buram in South Darfur. The fighting was triggered by the theft of about 150 cows of Salamat herders by Habbaniyah tribesmen.

A group of three herders shot and injured two women collecting straw near Falluja village in eastern Jebel Marra. They accused them of collecting straw in lands meant as pastures for their livestock. The two women's donkey were killed.
Three gunmen shot and killed a man at his house in Dalmanja, West Darfur. The motive of the attack is unknown.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column8: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: Arrests: On 20 and 30 April, Military Intelligence detained three peacekeepers for allegedly taking pictures of the local SAF headquarters and being present in a restricted military area. All three peacekeepers were released immediately. On 28 May, a UNAMID national staff member was arrested by the National Intelligence and Security Services in Ed Daein for alleged corruption.

JEM and SLM-MM militants jointly declared a unilateral six-month humanitarian ceasefire ""to protect civilians, provide unhindered humanitarian access to war-affected populations, and create an environment conducive to peace"". The declaration was made after meeting between both groups' leaders in the French capital Paris.

column8: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: On 3 May, armed men in military attire on board a Toyota Land Cruiser vehicle attempted to carjack a minibus belonging to the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees near the World Food Programme warehouse in Nyala. The perpetrators fled the scene following the intervention of UNAMID troops escorting the vehicle. No casualties were reported.
A group of four militiamen abducted a Muslim man after the Friday prayers in Dunkolat, south of Kutum.
Militiamen abducted five people in Korma in North Darfur at gunpoint and took them to Amo area, west of Kutum.
Sudanese army soldiers shot and detained incommunicado a Nuba farmer in Delling. Intelligence officials are regularly accusing people in Delling of supporting the rebel SPLM-N.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 7 May, according to local sources, SAF retaliated to the 7 April SLA/AW ambush on police forces by attacking their positions in Katti, Kurifal, Burro, Kadingo, Marra, Kwila, Boga and Barbara, within 20 km south and south-east of Guldo, Central Darfur. Unclear if clashes were involved. Reports at the time mentioned nine people, mostly women and children, killed, another 22 injured and four women raped by RSF, while properties were looted and burnt down. A Central Darfur government official denied the attack.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 7 May, according to local sources, SAF retaliated to the 7 April SLA/AW ambush on police forces by attacking their positions in Katti, Kurifal, Burro, Kadingo, Marra, Kwila, Boga and Barbara, within 20 km south and south-east of Guldo, Central Darfur. Unclear if clashes were involved. Reports at the time mentioned nine people, mostly women and children, killed, another 22 injured and four women raped by RSF, while properties were looted and burnt down. A Central Darfur government official denied the attack.

column17: On 7 May, according to local sources, SAF retaliated to the 7 April SLA/AW ambush on police forces by attacking their positions in Katti, Kurifal, Burro, Kadingo, Marra, Kwila, Boga and Barbara, within 20 km south and south-east of Guldo, Central Darfur. Unclear if clashes were involved. Reports at the time mentioned nine people, mostly women and children, killed, another 22 injured and four women raped by RSF, while properties were looted and burnt down. A Central Darfur government official denied the attack.

column17: On 7 May, according to local sources, SAF retaliated to the 7 April SLA/AW ambush on police forces by attacking their positions in Katti, Kurifal, Burro, Kadingo, Marra, Kwila, Boga and Barbara, within 20 km south and south-east of Guldo, Central Darfur. Unclear if clashes were involved. Reports at the time mentioned nine people, mostly women and children, killed, another 22 injured and four women raped by RSF, while properties were looted and burnt down. A Central Darfur government official denied the attack.

column17: On 7 May, according to local sources, SAF retaliated to the 7 April SLA/AW ambush on police forces by attacking their positions in Katti, Kurifal, Burro, Kadingo, Marra, Kwila, Boga and Barbara, within 20 km south and south-east of Guldo, Central Darfur. Unclear if clashes were involved. Reports at the time mentioned nine people, mostly women and children, killed, another 22 injured and four women raped by RSF, while properties were looted and burnt down. A Central Darfur government official denied the attack.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 7 May, according to local sources, SAF retaliated to the 7 April SLA/AW ambush on police forces by attacking their positions in Katti, Kurifal, Burro, Kadingo, Marra, Kwila, Boga and Barbara, within 20 km south and south-east of Guldo, Central Darfur. Unclear if clashes were involved. Reports at the time mentioned nine people, mostly women and children, killed, another 22 injured and four women raped by RSF, while properties were looted and burnt down. A Central Darfur government official denied the attack.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 7 May, according to local sources, SAF retaliated to the 7 April SLA/AW ambush on police forces by attacking their positions in Katti, Kurifal, Burro, Kadingo, Marra, Kwila, Boga and Barbara, within 20 km south and south-east of Guldo, Central Darfur. Unclear if clashes were involved. Reports at the time mentioned nine people, mostly women and children, killed, another 22 injured and four women raped by RSF, while properties were looted and burnt down. A Central Darfur government official denied the attack.
Gunmen killed a man and abducted a woman and her two children as they returned from shopping in Mara to Niertiti in Central Darfur.
Two farmers were abducted by unknown gunmen in Tawila locality. The gunmen accused them of cultivating on their ""liberated lands"".
Further clashes took place between Maaliya and southern Rizaygat tribesmen in Okus, north-east of Muhajiriyah, on 7 May, resulting in four Ma'aliya and three Southern Rizeigat fatalities.
Suspected SPLM-N rebels ambushed Sudanese soldiers near Bolen area in Bau locality of Blue Nile state, leaving 2 killed.

Renewed clashes between the Salamat and Habbaniya tribes in Nadeif on 8 May and in Sakhara on 10 May, west and south-west of Buram in South Darfur. Around 17 fatalities reported over the two days of clashes.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column17: Arrests: Military intelligenc services arrested at least 25 women and an unknown number of additional men in Samsur and Boleng areas of Bau locality, Blue Nile state, after an ambush on government soldiers in the area. They accused them of spying for SPLM-N.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Arrests: NISS arrested a West Kordofan Member of Parliament in El Fula following a dispute with the state's Governor over a chieftaincy issue.

Clashes between students and police at the Faculty of Education of the University of Bakht El Rida in Sudan's White Nile state after disagreements at the sudent union left two dead, including one policeman. Police used tear gas, rubber bullets and live ammunition to disperse the protesters. Several students were detained.

Hundreds of Sudanese citizens protested in front of the UN Head-Office in Khartoum in solidarity with Palestinian prisoners in the Israeli jails. National Federation of Sudanese Youths, a number of Sudanese parties, unions and the Palestinian Embassy in Khartoum took part in the protest.

Renewed clashes between the Salamat and Habbaniya tribes in Nadeif on 8 May and in Sakhara on 10 May, west and south-west of Buram in South Darfur. Around 17 fatalities reported over the two days of clashes.

column6: Military Forces of Egypt (2014-) Border Guards
column17: An Egyptian military patrol fired at a group of miners at Ibrahim Hussein mine near Wadi al-Aalagi inside the Sudanese territory, leaving at least one injured. They took the injured to a border guards' post on the Egyptian side of the border, and later released him. Egyptian border guards had come to the mine a few days prior and claimed that it belonged to them. Tensions between Sudan and Egypt have recently escalated over several issues.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Agreement: Sudan's First vice President and Prime Minister announced a new National Consensus Government, including 31 ministers and 44 secretaries of state. The new cabinet is tasked with the implementation of the dialogue's recommendations and the adoption of a new constitution. Several armed groups have refused to join the process before the stop of the fighting. On the same week, the government deployed a contingent of more than 10,000 additional RSF forces to Darfur to curb any rebel, criminal and tribal activity in the region. President Bashir underlined that they were given all necessary powers to that aim.

Demonstrators from the Ma'aliya tribe held a protest in front of the Ministry of Justice in Khartoum demanding the arrest of Rizaygat tribesmen accused of being involved in recent tribal clashes in East Darfur.

Looting: Armed men wearing military uniforms raided the hospital in El Fula, seizing important amounts of money. An increasing number of similar incidents have been reported in West Kordofan since April.
Armed men abducted two displaced men at a local market of Murnei in West Darfur at gunpoint. The men were from Murnei IDP camp.

Police raided the Jebel Regel village near Basunda in El Gedaref state, beating residents and demolishing houses of the village, following a dispute over ownership of the village land. At least one person was injured.
On 14 May, armed Rizeigat clashed with South Sudan security forces along the border at Tuhama in Bahr al-Arab, East Darfur, reportedly resulting in 20 casualties among the security forces.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column17: Members of the military intelligence killed a villager, beat dozens of others and looted property in Hajar Jawad village west of Delling, South Kordofan. They had come the day before to look for a person, but were unable to find him.

An SPLM-N faction reportedly attacked the headquarters of the movement's chairman and a military garrison in areas controlled by the group in Blue Nile in May. The violence is suspected to be linked to internal dissensions over the movement's leadership following the resignation of the deputy chairman Al Hilu in March, and to have been launched by supporters of Al Hilu and the Nuba Movement Liberation Council.

Looting: Sudanese military forces and PDF looted hundreds of cattle in Delami and Heiban counties of South Kordofan in four incidents between 1-18 May (no casualties). This includes 205 cows from Sanjarand Dokuri villages, Nyukur Payam (Delami) on 1 and 18 May; 50 cows from Deri village, Aberi Payam (Delami) on 11 May; and 32 goats from Hajarbako village, Alazrag Payam (Heiban) on 15 May. Due to fear and insecurity caused by looting incursions, at least 27 people left SPLA/M-N areas for SAF controlled areas of SK between April-May.
Unknown gunmen raided the house of a couple in Karka district, west of Kabkabiya, opening fire on them, leaving them killed.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: NISS members backed by a pro-government student militia forcibly dispersed a sit-in held by Darfuri students at the University of El Zaeem El Azhari in Khartoum. Police fired tear gas and rubber bullets leaving at least two Darfuri students injured. Police also evacuated the university complex, and arrested at least 20 Darfuri students. The charges against them were dropped the following day. The Darfuri students, led by the Darfur Students' Association, had gathered in a sit-in to demand the university administration to exempt them from tuition fees.

Misseriya herders attacked civilians at the Amiet common market in Abyei, leaving one civilian dead and five wounded. UNISFA captured two of the assailants, who were handed over to the Misserya traditional leaders on 21 May at the UNISFA Diffra camp in Sector North.
The son of the Omda of the Salamat was gunned-down at Um Dukhun market by unknown assailants.

Renewed clashes between Misseriya and Salamat tribesmen over cattle-rustling and other crimes ensued in Umm Sory, south of Um Dukhun, on 16 May; in Magula, north-east of Um Dukhun, on 17 May; in Bir Bagara and Mogali, west of Bindisi, on 19 May; in Sure, north-east of Um Dukhun, on 20 May; in Murraya, east of Um Dukhun, on 21 May; and Salayle, south of Kabar, on 22 May. A total of 15 Misseriya and 24 Salamat were killed, with reports that the Misseriya burned down 10 Salamat-inhabited villages and that 716 households were displaced to Um Dukhun.
Armed herders shot and wounded a farmer and abducted another as they worked their lands in Wadi Barkoro area near Dobo El Omda in Tawila locality, North Darfur.

A six-year-old girl was raped and killed by a shopkeeper in her neighborhood in Nyala. The shopkeeper was arrested and imprisonned. Residents of Nyala gathered to protest the murder when the news broke out.

Renewed clashes between Misseriya and Salamat tribesmen over cattle-rustling and other crimes ensued in Umm Sory, south of Um Dukhun, on 16 May; in Magula, north-east of Um Dukhun, on 17 May; in Bir Bagara and Mogali, west of Bindisi, on 19 May; in Sure, north-east of Um Dukhun, on 20 May; in Murraya, east of Um Dukhun, on 21 May; and Salayle, south of Kabar, on 22 May. A total of 15 Misseriya and 24 Salamat were killed, with reports that the Misseriya burned down 10 Salamat-inhabited villages and that 716 households were displaced to Um Dukhun.

Clash between military force and a criminal gang near the water station of Shagtabeldi in Ed Daein locality, East Darfur, left eight Sudanese soldiers and one gang member killed. The gang had committed several raids and road robberies in the area, and the force was tasked to eliminate them.

column7: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: A suspected pro-government student militia backed by security forces beat a group of Darfuri students who were protesting in Omdurman against recent expulsions from the University of El Zaeem El Azhari leaving several injured. The forces used tear gas to disperse the crowd and the students were beaten with sticks. At least ten students sustained injuries and were transferred to the hospital for treatment. Seven students were arrested and detained incommunicado in an unknown location before being released at a later unknown date.
A woman died when a UXO detonated in Daba Naira in Central Darfur.

Renewed clashes between Misseriya and Salamat tribesmen over cattle-rustling and other crimes ensued in Umm Sory, south of Um Dukhun, on 16 May; in Magula, north-east of Um Dukhun, on 17 May; in Bir Bagara and Mogali, west of Bindisi, on 19 May; in Sure, north-east of Um Dukhun, on 20 May; in Murraya, east of Um Dukhun, on 21 May; and Salayle, south of Kabar, on 22 May. A total of 15 Misseriya and 24 Salamat were killed, with reports that the Misseriya burned down 10 Salamat-inhabited villages and that 716 households were displaced to Um Dukhun.

Renewed clashes between Misseriya and Salamat tribesmen over cattle-rustling and other crimes ensued in Umm Sory, south of Um Dukhun, on 16 May; in Magula, north-east of Um Dukhun, on 17 May; in Bir Bagara and Mogali, west of Bindisi, on 19 May; in Sure, north-east of Um Dukhun, on 20 May; in Murraya, east of Um Dukhun, on 21 May; and Salayle, south of Kabar, on 22 May. A total of 15 Misseriya and 24 Salamat were killed, with reports that the Misseriya burned down 10 Salamat-inhabited villages and that 716 households were displaced to Um Dukhun.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column9: SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction)
column16: Radio Dabanga; Sudan News Agency; Sudan Tribune; UNAMID
column17: Clashes between government forces supported by RSF militia and SLA-MM supported by SLA-Transitional Council forces (a splinter faction of SLA-AW) on 20 May in Ushayrayah area of East Darfur. Government claimed to have killed 25 rebels, including an SLA-TC commander, arrested 17 and lost 5 on its side .Rebels claimed to have inflicted 214 government fatalities and lost 15 on its side in clashes in North and East Darfur on 20 May. Numbers could not be verified by UNAMID.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column9: SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction)
column16: Radio Dabanga; Sudan Tribune; Sudan News Agency; UNAMID
column17: Clashes between government forces supported by RSF militia and SLA-MM supported by SLA-Transitional Council forces (a splinter faction of SLA-AW) on 20 May in Musbat and Wadi Howar of North Darfur. A majority of rebels were said to have retreated from these areas to Chad by 22 May. Rebels claimed to have inflicted 214 government fatalities and lost 15 on its side in clashes in North and East Darfur on 20 May. Numbers could not be verified by UNAMID.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column9: SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction)
column16: Radio Dabanga; UNAMID; Sudan News Agency; Sudan Tribune
column17: Clashes between government forces supported by RSF militia and SLA-MM supported by SLA-Transitional Council forces (a splinter faction of SLA-AW) on 20 May in Musbat and Wadi Howar of North Darfur. A majority of rebels were said to have retreated from these areas to Chad by 22 May. Rebels claimed to have inflicted 214 government fatalities and lost 15 on its side in clashes in North and East Darfur on 20 May. Numbers could not be verified by UNAMID.

Renewed clashes between Misseriya and Salamat tribesmen over cattle-rustling and other crimes ensued in Umm Sory, south of Um Dukhun, on 16 May; in Magula, north-east of Um Dukhun, on 17 May; in Bir Bagara and Mogali, west of Bindisi, on 19 May; in Sure, north-east of Um Dukhun, on 20 May; in Murraya, east of Um Dukhun, on 21 May; and Salayle, south of Kabar, on 22 May. A total of 15 Misseriya and 24 Salamat were killed, with reports that the Misseriya burned down 10 Salamat-inhabited villages and that 716 households were displaced to Um Dukhun.
Explosion at an RSF ammunition depot in Darfur's Nyala left at least 12 dead, 18 injured and hundreds of home destroyed.
Unknown gunmen attacked and beat to death a woman as she went to cut grass south of Abyei town. Other women were found injured.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column9: SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction)
column16: UNAMID; Sudan News Agency; Radio Dabanga; Sudan Tribune
column17: Further clashes between government forces supported by RSF militia and SLA-MM supported by SLA-Transitional Council forces (a splinter faction of SLA-AW) were reported near the Adoula mountains and Arto Bargo, 25 km south and 16 km south-east of Shearia, respectively, on 21 and 22 May, resulting in the death of seven SLA/MM fighters and one Sudanese Armed Forces soldier. Rebels earlier claimed to have killed 68 government troops, wounded more than 80 others, and destroyed 23 vehicles on the first day. State forces captured several leaders of the two rebel movements.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column9: SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction)
column16: UNAMID; Sudan Tribune; Radio Dabanga; Sudan News Agency
column17: Further clashes between government forces supported by RSF militia and SLA-MM supported by SLA-Transitional Council forces (a splinter faction of SLA-AW) were reported near the Adoula mountains and Arto Bargo, 25 km south and 16 km south-east of Shearia, respectively, on 21 and 22 May, resulting in the death of seven SLA/MM fighters and one Sudanese Armed Forces soldier. Rebels earlier claimed to have killed 68 government troops, wounded more than 80 others, and destroyed 23 vehicles on the first day. State forces captured several leaders of the two rebel movements.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Residens of Ed El Fursan in South Darfur held a three-day sit-in demanding that the locality's Commissioner provide electricity, health care, and drinking water. Three young men were later arrested and detained incommunicado by NISS, during which they were reportedly subjected to abuse and torture.

Renewed clashes between Misseriya and Salamat tribesmen over cattle-rustling and other crimes ensued in Umm Sory, south of Um Dukhun, on 16 May; in Magula, north-east of Um Dukhun, on 17 May; in Bir Bagara and Mogali, west of Bindisi, on 19 May; in Sure, north-east of Um Dukhun, on 20 May; in Murraya, east of Um Dukhun, on 21 May; and Salayle, south of Kabar, on 22 May. A total of 15 Misseriya and 24 Salamat were killed, with reports that the Misseriya burned down 10 Salamat-inhabited villages and that 716 households were displaced to Um Dukhun.
Authorities demolished and forcefully removed residents of dozens of houses in El Shajara neighbourhood in south Khartoum, beating them with sticks, leaving several injured and seven arrested.

Militiamen attacked a commercial convoy consisting of seven vehicles and a relief truck at Tundabia gate between El Fasher and Tawila. They clashed with police and PDF forces who intervened, leaving one PDF member killed 20 gunmen injured.

People in Ed El Fursan held a peaceful protest against the deficit of basic services, in particular a shortage of clean drinking water and electricity. At least three activists suspected of having led the protest were arrested and detained by NISS the following day.

People protested in front of the Ministry of Health in Khartoum to condemn authorities' silence regarding an outbreak of cholera that has affected thousands of people killed dozens in several Sudanese states over the past six months. The protesters asked them to declare a state of emergency to effectively combat the disease.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF beat and arrested at least seven people, mostly herders, in Muzbad and Arori areas of Um Baru and Karnoi localities in North Darfur for allegedly communicating with the armed movements.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF beat and arrested at least seven people, mostly herders, in Muzbad and Arori areas of Um Baru and Karnoi localities in North Darfur for allegedly communicating with the armed movements.
The family of a detained human rights activist arrested in December 2016 protesterd in fron of Kober prison against the renewal of his detention without charges in his absence and his lawyer.
Gunmen ambushed a vehicle in Tundobaya in Tawila locality, beating, robbing and kidnapping six people inside the vehicle.
The family of a Sudanese human rights activist detained without charge since December 2016 broke their Ramadan fast in front of Kober's prison in protest against his detention.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column9: Militia (Col. Gardi); SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction)
column17: Renewed clashes between government supported by RSF forces and SLM-MM supported by SLM-TC faction and allegedly by Chadian rebels led by Colonel Gardi at Ain Siro area in Kutum locality, North Darfur, over 28-29 May. Government forces said they defeated the rebels, inflicting heavy human and material damage. Rebels also said they killed at least 16 government troops.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF and other pro-government militias attacked civilian targets in Ain Siro locality, North Darfur, from 28 May - 6 June, leaving at least 14 civilians killed, 19 seriously injured and seven villages set on fire and burnt to the ground. Areas mentioned include Farang East and Farang West (which are comprised of 30 smaller villages, including Masteriya, Tanweer, Tajojo, Miri, Takjo, Kola and Tanunu), Furokat, and Abdelshakur.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column9: Militia (Col. Gardi); SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction)
column17: Renewed clashes between government supported by RSF forces and SLM-MM supported by SLM-TC faction and allegedly by Chadian rebels led by Colonel Gardi at Ain Siro area in Kutum locality, North Darfur, over 28-29 May. Government forces said they defeated the rebels, inflicting heavy human and material damage. Rebels also said they killed at least 16 government troops.
SAF dropped four barrel bombs on an area 15 kilometres south of Fanga in east Jebel Marra, near the border with Tawila locality, killing livestock.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF and other pro-government militias attacked civilian targets in Ain Siro locality, North Darfur, from 28 May - 6 June, leaving at least 14 civilians killed, 19 seriously injured and seven villages set on fire and burnt to the ground. Areas mentioned include Farang East and Farang West (which are comprised of 30 smaller villages, including Masteriya, Tanweer, Tajojo, Miri, Takjo, Kola and Tanunu), Furokat, and Abdelshakur.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF and other pro-government militias attacked civilian targets in Ain Siro locality, North Darfur, from 28 May - 6 June, leaving at least 14 civilians killed, 19 seriously injured and seven villages set on fire and burnt to the ground. Areas mentioned include Farang East and Farang West (which are comprised of 30 smaller villages, including Masteriya, Tanweer, Tajojo, Miri, Takjo, Kola and Tanunu), Furokat, and Abdelshakur.

column8: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: Unknown gunmen shot and kille a Nigerian UNAMID soldier in downtown Nyala, South Darfur. The assailants left with his vehicle.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF and other pro-government militias attacked civilian targets in Ain Siro locality, North Darfur, from 28 May - 6 June, leaving at least 14 civilians killed, 19 seriously injured and seven villages set on fire and burnt to the ground. Areas mentioned include Farang East and Farang West (which are comprised of 30 smaller villages, including Masteriya, Tanweer, Tajojo, Miri, Takjo, Kola and Tanunu), Furokat, and Abdelshakur.

A gunfight between a military commander and a member of his force resulted in the killing of four people, including the commander, two other force members and a civilian in a market in Kabkabiya, North Darfur.
Police beat and detained a lawyer who was with a client at the police station in Port Sudan. The reasons are unclear.

Inter-communal clashes reported in Blue Nile between the Ingessana and Uduk tribes as part of recent dissensions between leaders of the SPLM-N movement. The Inegssana support the SPLM-N faction led by Malik Agar, while the Uduk support al-Hilu.

Herders beat a number of women farmers at Saraf Jidad area in West Darfur's Sirba locality, leaving them injured, including two severely. The herders claimed that the farmlands should be used for grazing their cattle.
Dozens of employees and workers of El Gedaref staged a protest against a deduction from their salaries to prepare their pensions without their consent for the second consecutive month.
PDF government militia reportedly attacked a cattle camp in the outskirts of Kalkada village of Nuba mountains, killing two civilians and looting 150 cows.

Fighting between two rival groups of South Sudanese inside the Um Sangur refugee camp in Al-Salam locality in White Nile State in the week of 29 May after one was beaten by members of the other group left one killed. In a retaliatory attack at an undisclosed date, another three were killed. Police arrested 30 suspects who participated in the clashes and charged them with murder and inflicting grave harm as well as causing instability in Aal-Na'im Police station in the locality.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF and other pro-government militias attacked civilian targets in Ain Siro locality, North Darfur, from 28 May - 6 June, leaving at least 14 civilians killed, 19 seriously injured and seven villages set on fire and burnt to the ground. Areas mentioned include Farang East and Farang West (which are comprised of 30 smaller villages, including Masteriya, Tanweer, Tajojo, Miri, Takjo, Kola and Tanunu), Furokat, and Abdelshakur.

Arrests: Police in New Halfa locality in Kassala detained 30 students on the grounds that they did not comply with an order to evict student dormitories for maintenance during the holiday season. Most of the detained students are reportedly from Darfur unable to afford a trip to see their relatives. Similar evictions were reported in Eil Obeid in North Kordofan.
Armed herders shot and killed a farmer who attempted to prevent them from raping her daughter in Khajagli, north of Kadugli in South Kordofan.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF and other pro-government militias attacked civilian targets in Ain Siro locality, North Darfur, from 28 May - 6 June, leaving at least 14 civilians killed, 19 seriously injured and seven villages set on fire and burnt to the ground. Areas mentioned include Farang East and Farang West (which are comprised of 30 smaller villages, including Masteriya, Tanweer, Tajojo, Miri, Takjo, Kola and Tanunu), Furokat, and Abdelshakur.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF and other pro-government militias attacked civilian targets in Ain Siro locality, North Darfur, from 28 May - 6 June, leaving at least 14 civilians killed, 19 seriously injured and seven villages set on fire and burnt to the ground. Areas mentioned include Farang East and Farang West (which are comprised of 30 smaller villages, including Masteriya, Tanweer, Tajojo, Miri, Takjo, Kola and Tanunu), Furokat, and Abdelshakur.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF and other pro-government militias attacked civilian targets in Ain Siro locality, North Darfur, from 28 May - 6 June, leaving at least 14 civilians killed, 19 seriously injured and seven villages set on fire and burnt to the ground. Areas mentioned include Farang East and Farang West (which are comprised of 30 smaller villages, including Masteriya, Tanweer, Tajojo, Miri, Takjo, Kola and Tanunu), Furokat, and Abdelshakur.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF militiamen opened fire into the air before they stormed Deleba El Kabir and Deleba El Saghir in western Kutum and robbed money, property and livestock from villagers. Report of casualties but unverified number at the time of reporting. Militants have continued to steal money, property, and livestock of residents of Ein Siro area and the areas north-west of Kutum in North Darfur since end May.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF and other pro-government militias attacked civilian targets in Ain Siro locality, North Darfur, from 28 May - 6 June, leaving at least 14 civilians killed, 19 seriously injured and seven villages set on fire and burnt to the ground. Areas mentioned include Farang East and Farang West (which are comprised of 30 smaller villages, including Masteriya, Tanweer, Tajojo, Miri, Takjo, Kola and Tanunu), Furokat, and Abdelshakur.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF and other pro-government militias attacked civilian targets in Ain Siro locality, North Darfur, from 28 May - 6 June, leaving at least 14 civilians killed, 19 seriously injured and seven villages set on fire and burnt to the ground. Areas mentioned include Farang East and Farang West (which are comprised of 30 smaller villages, including Masteriya, Tanweer, Tajojo, Miri, Takjo, Kola and Tanunu), Furokat, and Abdelshakur.
Unidentified militiamen abducted two people from the Kila district north of Mershing because of a missing camel.

column6: SPLM-N-NMLC: Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement (North) (Nuba Mountains Liberation Council Faction)
column17: Change to armed group: The Nuba Mountains Libertion Council (NMLC) relieved SPLM-N Chairman Agar, Secretary General Arman and Chief of General Staff Lt Gen. Mukwar of their functions and prevented them from entering SPLM-N controlled areas in South Kordofan. They temporarily replaced Agar with his former deputy Al-Hilu. Agar claimed NMLC's decision had no legal basis and represented a coup based on tribal alliances, signalling a rift between two factions within the SPLM-N. Al-Hilu had resigned earlier in March to protest the movement's failure to bring up the issue of self-determination for the Two Areas in peace negotiations with the Sudanese government.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: NISS detained and tortured an IDP from Kasab IDP camp at the NISS HQ in Kutum, North Darfur. He was accused of being a supporter of one of the armed rebel movements in Darfur, and beaten with fists and batons by the officers. He was also burnt by hot water and cooking oil. He was released with severe injuries on the morning of 10 June and dropped by car near the perimeter of Kasab IDP camp.

From 7 - 10 June 2017, security officials detained and tortured an IDP in North Darfur who was working in a displaced persons camp. Following his release, officials dropped him in front of his home unconscious. The man was refused medical treatment in a government hospital because he had not reported the torture to police and obtained a 'form 8'.

column8: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: Ten UNAMID soldiers were injured when their patrol vehicle drove on an UXO in Al-Tina locality in North Darfur.

Militiamen opened fire on a commercial vehicle in Zalingei city. The vehicle had traveled from Nyala. The owner of the vehicle exchanged gunfire with the perpetrators. At least six were wounded, including two seriously.
Police intervened to disperse a peaceful protest against the enforcement of land distribution in Asalaya, White Nile state, firing teargas and rubber bullets that wounded four residents.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: In a pursuit operation in Khazan Karbiya area, Kutum locality of North Darfur, RSF reportedly killed an SLM-MM commander and a number of his fighters. A rebel was also captured alive.

Clash between cattle thieves and a rescue team from the Gimir and Rizeigat tribes left three dead and others injured at Sesabana of Katila locality. In a revenge attack the following day, Rizaygat attacked worshipers at a mosque in Sesabana, leading to a clash that left two Rizeigat, one Gimir and one Fallata killed. The two tribes reached a ceasefire agreement five days later, on 14 June.

Armed militias opened fire on 20 displaced women who were gathering straw in the Mundo area south of Tawila. All women survived, while some of their cattle was killed. The militiamen threatened to hit, assault, and kill them if they returned to collect straw. Later on the same day, militiamen shot a young herder and stole his 350 livestock in Murtal in Tawila locality.

The Government forces and SLA/MM clashed on 9 June in Uru, 39 km north-west of Umm Barru in North Darfur. Eleven SLA/MM members were reportedly killed, while three Sudanese security personnel sustained minor injuries.

Clash between cattle thieves and a rescue team from the Gimir and Rizeigat tribes left three dead and others injured at Sesabana of Katila locality. In a revenge attack the following day, Rizaygat attacked worshipers at a mosque in Sesabana, leading to a clash that left two Rizeigat, one Gimir and one Fallata killed. The two tribes reached a ceasefire agreement five days later, on 14 June.
Unknown militiamen shot dead a civilian returning to a cattle camp east of Mershing in South Darfur and stole his cattle.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: In Central Darfur, on 10 June, there was a confrontation between the Sudanese Armed Forces and SLA/AW elements in Thur village, 15 km south of Nertiti, triggered by an alleged theft by the latter of livestock belonging to the Nawaibah clan of the Northern Rizeigat.

column8: JEM-New: Justice and Equality Movement (New Faction)
column17: Change to armed group: After several weeks of mediation, 13 JEM dissident officers announced that they failed to find a compromised solution with the JEM movement and confirmed their defection from JEM led by Gibril Ibrahim to the splinter faction ""New JEM"" led by Mansour Arbab Younis. New JEM wants to remove Ibrahim from the leadership of the movement.
Militiamen beat two women at the market in Tabit in Tawila locality as the women insisted that they should pay for their commodities. The women sustained injuries.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: A woman was killed and a driver injured when suspected RSF gunmen opened fire on a motor rickshaw in the Central Darfur capital of Zalingei.
On 11 June 2017, clashes between livestock thieves and a local rescue team from Umkutkut village north of Taweisha in North Darfur left two people killed and 10 others injured.
Militiamen attacked Jurof village, east of Mershing in South Darfur, in retaliation for the killing of one of their relatives the week before. They abducted nine villagers.

Despite the peace agreement signed between the two tribes on 29 May, the Salamat attacked the Misseriya in the Sure area, 40 km north-east of Um Dukhun in Central Darfur, on 12 June, causing the death of one Misseriya.

column6: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: The African Union Peace and Security Council of (AUPSC) extended UNAMID's mandate for 12 months. The Council decided to reduce by nearly a half the strength of the mission, and change its mandate from a peacekeeping to a peacebuilding operation. A week later, the UN Security Council confirmed the mission's year-long extension and reduction of police and military personnel by 30% and 44% respectively from 31 January 2018.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Looting: Suspected RSF gunmen intercepted two trucks on their way from Fanga market in Tawila locality to El Fasher, at El Aradeib El Ashara area, robbing around 100 passengers of their belongings. No casualty.
Unknown gunmen killed an IDP at Banjadeed camp in Sirba locality in West Darfur.

column8: UNISFA: United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (2011-)
column17: Looting: UNISFA chased a group of armed assailants who robbed and hijacked a car at the Amiet common market in Abyei, seizing one rocket-propelled grenade launcher and recovering the vehicle and money stolen. No report of fire exchange.

People protested against the deterioration of services and marginalisation in Wadi Halfa of Northern state, paralysing access on the main highway to Khartoum. Police broke up the demonstration using tearfas and batons. The demonstrators were calling for maintenance of Wadi Halfa hospital and mortuary. They also demand that the main border crossing into Egypt be returned to Argeen, which lies on the western shore of Lake Nubia opposite Wadi Halfa.

Unknown gunmen ambushed the car of Central Darfur's Health Minister in El Mashrou area, 30km west of Zalingei, firing shots that left two killed, including the Minister's brother and bodyguard, and the driver seriously injured.
Militiamen opened fire on a group of civilians in Kass locality, South Darfur, over an alleged cattle theft. They killed three people, injured several others and kidnapped five.

On 14 June, a group of armed Nawaibah (clan of the northern Rizaygat) attacked IDPs, killing two of them, in Wisa village near the Thur East IDP camp. 10 women were also abducted and at least 5,000 individuals were displaced from the area.
Three persons were killed and 14 others injured in clashes between youth groups following differences over a seat in al-Daba in the Northern State.
In June, gunmen beat a driver with an automatic rifle, leaving him unconscious, and seized his car near al-Kuma area in North Darfur as it was coming from El-Malha.
A UXO explosion left one killed and another person injured losing both his legs near the Abuzaid agricultural project in eastern Jebel Marra.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Seven shoppers were abducted on their way from Jebel Marra to Nierteti by government sponsored militia on horseback and with camels alongside the RSF and Border Guards. Earlier, the same group had attacked six villages (Sulu, Waru, Faki Yaha, Luku, Fata Karga, and Kajawarai) in Rukaero locality of Jebel Marra region. The markets and homes were raided and looted, and a number of livestock were stolen. At least one killed.
Five herders were killed and another injured in an attack by bandits who attempted to steal their cattle near Bout in western Blue Nile state.
Agreement: On 17 June, 13 SLA/MM members surrendered to the Sudanese Armed Forces in Ayn Sero.
A South Sudanese Dinka threw a hand grenade at the Amiet Joint Market in Abyei, leaving other Dinka men injured.
On 18 June a police officer shot and injured a civilian in Habila, West Darfur.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 18 June, Nawaibah militia (clan of the northern RIzaygat) clashed with a group of SLA/AW elements in the vicinity of the Thur East camp in Central Darfur, which led to the injury of one Nawaibah, followed by the intervention of the Sudanese Armed Forces and police personnel.
Armed men opened fire on people near Hashaba in Tawila locality, North Darfur, leaving a number of people wounded and four children missing. The attackers stole livestock and property.
On 20 June, armed individuals shot and seriously injured a civilian in Beida, West Darfur.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Border Guards
column17: Members of the paramilitary Border Guards abducted a civilian in North Darfur's Saraf Omra. He was released 40 days later, on 27 July.

A new dissident group from the SLM-AW led by commander Haroun (aka Kalmang Koi) has joined the peace process at Fugi area east of Golo in Jebel Marra, Central Darfur state over what the commander termed ""the futility of war without achieving anything but further suffering.

Camel herder militiamen ambushed a vehicle and kidnapped 16 passengers at Kator area in the locality of East Jebel Marra, South Darfur state. The militia demanded to retrieve 85 heads of camel stolen by SLM-AW elements before releasing the hostages.

A group of six gunmen ambushed a vehicle in the Majzoub area, 20km south of El Fasher in North Darfur, forcing the pasasengers out at gunpoing, taking all of their valuables, stealing the vehicle and abducting the driver.

A violent incident between refugees living at Um Sangour camp, White Nile, led to seven deaths and four refugees injured at some point between 16-30 June. Local authorities intervened to secure the site and prevent further escalation.
Armed herders abducted two farmers at gunpoint in the Gallab area in North Darfur's Tawila locality.

Movement of forces: Arab militiamen expelled a number of villagers and displaced people from their farms In Gallab and Kolgi areas of Tawila locality in North Darfur, claiming the land was theirs. The Shattiya Arab returned to the area in 2016 after leaving the area 70 years prior for South Darfur.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Border Guards
column17: Members of the paramilitary Border Guards abducted a cafe owner in North Darfur's Saraf Omra. He was released early September.

SPLM/N forces (Malik Agar faction) claimed government forces and allied militias attacked their positions in Khour Jadad area in Blue Nile. ""Scores"" reportedly died or were injured in the 2h-battle.

In East Darfur, on 26 June, the conflict between the Ma'aliya and Hamar reignited, despite a reconciliation agreement signed in 2014, when the Ma'aliya clashed with the El Gekhisat clan of the Hamar in Karkadeh village, 18 km west of Sharif, over livestock theft. Six Hamar and three Ma'aliya were killed. Two days later, on 28 June, another confrontation occurred at Um Totahana village, 65 km north-east of Adilla, in which one Misseriya inhabitant of the area was killed.

Misseriya gunmen attacked fur returnees at Bau village, north of Shataya, opening fire on residents. At least 14 people were wounded, property stolen and a number of houses torched to urge people to leave for a nearby camp for internally displaced persons. The Government deployed security forces and arrested two perpetrators.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Arrests: NISS arrested nine members of the Sudanese Congress Party (SCP) holding a seminar on the cholera epidemic in Umbadda in Omdurman. This includes the former head of the party's Central Council, a member of the Political Bureau, and the head of the SCP Khartoum branch.

In East Darfur, on 26 June, the conflict between the Ma'aliya and Hamar reignited, despite a reconciliation agreement signed in 2014, when the Ma'aliya clashed with the El Gekhisat clan of the Hamar in Karkadeh village, 18 km west of Sharif, over livestock theft. Six Hamar and three Ma'aliya were killed. Two days later, on 28 June, another confrontation occurred at Um Totahana village, 65 km north-east of Adilla, in which one Misseriya inhabitant of the area was killed.
A robbery attempt of a Fur by armed militia in Kaira, 38 km north-east of Nertiti, Central Darfur, escalated into a clash that resulted in the death of five militia members and three locals.

A prominent youth activist and leader in the Nierteti IDP camp was killed by two suspected SAF soldiers in front of his home. The police refused to file a criminal complaint while NISS prohibited his family from holding a public funeral or creating a visitation site. The local hospital also refused to accept his body for an autopsy.
A group of gunmen stormed the village of Kulu, 12km west of Tawila town in North Darfur, and kidnapped two villagers. The reasons are unclear.

A group of army soldiers raped a number of women who were collecting water at a well near Golo in Rokoro locality, Central Darfur. People in the area rushed to the scene and beat the rapists with sticks and stones, killing one of them, and wounding others. The soldiers retreated to the military garrison of Golo but later besieged the area, firing bullets that reportedly killed 11 people, raiding houses, shops and markets, and robbing people of their belongings.

A group of army soldiers raped a number of women who were collecting water at a well near Golo in Rokoro locality, Central Darfur. People in the area rushed to the scene and beat the rapists with sticks and stones, killing one of them, and wounding others. The soldiers retreated to the military garrison of Golo but later besieged the area, firing bullets that reportedly killed 11 people, raiding houses, shops and markets, and robbing people of their belongings.

column8: UNISFA: United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (2011-)
column17: On 30 June, an unknown armed assailant raided 43 cattle belonging to a Misseriya herder at Sink, in Sector North of Abyei. The assailant killed one person and injured another. UNISFA troops were dispatched to the area and exchanged fire with the assailant, who abandoned the cattle and fled. The cattle were handed over to the Misseriya owner.

On 30 June, an unknown armed assailant raided 43 cattle belonging to a Misseriya herder at Sink, in Sector North of Abyei. The assailant killed one person and injured another. UNISFA troops were dispatched to the area and exchanged fire with the assailant, who abandoned the cattle and fled. The cattle were handed over to the Misseriya owner.

Salamat tribesmen abducted two Misseriya scouts who were observing their movements in Sure near Umm Dukhun in Central Darfur. As the Salamat refused to respond to demands to release them, fears of renewed clashes between the two tribes heightened.
Arab tribesmen shot dead a farmer tending his farm in the outskirts of Tawilah, North Darfur.

column6: SPLM-N-NMLC: Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement (North) (Nuba Mountains Liberation Council Faction)
column17: Three cases of fighting between SPLM-N factions in Blue Nile in July. Dates and circumstances unclear. Battles spread throughout July.
Militiamen severely beat a hospital employee in Garsila, Central Darfur, prompting her co-workers to enter into a general strike the next day.

Change to armed group: Three Darfur armed factions (the Sudan Liberation Movement for Justice, Sudan Liberation Movement-Unity and the Justice and Equality Movement led by Abdallah Bishr Gali) declared the formation of a new rebel movement called Sudan Liberation Force Alliance (SLFA). SLM-MM and JEM welcomed the move. On the same week, the SRF coalition grouping Darfur, Blue Nile and South Kordofan rebels, called on the opposition forces to hold an urgent meeting to coordinate efforts to escalate the daily confrontation against the regime.

Sudanese President al-Bashir issued a decree to extend the unilateral cessation of hostilities in Darfur, Blue Nile and South Kordofan until October 2017. The first ceasefire was declared on 1 June 2016 and has been prolonged on several occasions.

Three unidentified gunmen abducted 18 Eritrean refugees from the Refugee Commission office in Kassala town, and took them to an unknown destination. The refugees were waiting for the completion of their papers for their transfer to the El Shajarab camp.
An armed herder shot and injured a farmer at Um Gantoura area, 10 km east of Gireida in South Darfur. The farmer was trying to force livestock out of his farm.
Hundreds of farmers in Sudan's El Gezira and El Managil agricultural scheme protested in front of the Agricultural Bank of El Hosh against the non-delivery of fertilisers and herbicides.
Strike:Militiamen severely beat a hospital employee in Garsila, Central Darfur, prompting her co-workers to enter into a general strike the next day.
Militiamen stole cattle and abducted two displaced farmers from the Abyei camp while threatening others as they were farming in Rahad Zarroug, 15km west of Gireida.

Armed herders beat and injured a farmer returning from his farm after collecting straw near the village of Kadarik, 5 km north of Tabit, North Darfur. The militiamen burned the straw, and took his donkey. A group of eight militant herders had entered Wadi Garangu near Tabit the day before ordering two thirds of the farmers' harvest.

Villagers from El Sukout took to the streets in Himeid in Northern State's Wadi Halfa locality to protest plans to build a gold extraction plant in their area. The demonstrators were forcibly dispersed by security and police forces.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Paramilitary forces ambushed a number of troops loyal to ex-rebel leader El Sadiq, aka Fouka in the Aramba area along the Kabkabiya-Sortony road in North Darfur, killing four and wounding others. Fouka (leading a splinter faction of SLM/AW) had signed a peace deal earlier this year with the government of North Darfur.
Armed herders killed two farmers on their way to their farm near Borgo village, 15 kilometres west of Fanga, Central Darfur.

A youth activist from Tor, Central Darfur, was abducted by unidentified gunmen on the road between Tor and Kass. His body was found four days later in a remote area near Tor, with gunshot wounds to his head and chest. The police refused to issue Criminal Form 8 to document the crime and the hospital refused to conduct an autopsy.
On 8 July, a group of unknown armed persons shot and killed a woman and injured a man in the vicinity of Marial Achak in Abyei.
Two people were killed and seven others were wounded in a clash between residents of Merifein village, south of Abu Jubeiha in eastern South Kordofan, over a gold extraction plant in the area.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Police and RSF forcibly shut down Karnidink market in El Geneina, West Darfur. One woman and two children were killed during the incident, and twelve people were injured.
Three herders riding camels and wearing military uniforms beat women on their heads with sticks in Wadi Fagra in Tawila locality as they refused to leave their farms, leaving two severely injured.
On 9 July, an armed group of four Misseriya opened fire on a vehicle in the Dokura area along the Amiet road. Two Dinka civilians were killed and three others injured.

Dozens of women from El Mirghaniya and El Matar districts in the Red Sea capital of Port Sudan took to the streets in protest against repeated and long cuts in the water provision. The demonstrators blocked the main road leading to the two districts with stones.
A Darfur boy fell into a coma after a UXO detonated while he was playing at El Khereiga area, five km south of Zamzam IDP camp.
One farmer was killed and three others seriously injured when an unexploded grenade went off in Al-Goz locality in South Kordofan State.
Police disperse water outage protesters in Port Sudan.

Two army soldiers from the garrison east of Deleig, ""suddenly and without any reason"", began to fire at seven civilians in the town. The injuries sustained are not known. The perpetrators were later shot by security forces.

Military forces shot a displaced person after a knife attack at a checkpoint. The reasons for the attack are not known, though the perpetrator initially refused to stop at the checkpoint. The attacker was reported wounded.

column6: SPLM-N-NMLC: Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement (North) (Nuba Mountains Liberation Council Faction)
column17: Three cases of fighting between SPLM-N factions in Blue Nile in July. Dates and circumstances unclear. Battles spread throughout July.

Two army soldiers from the garrison east of Deleig, ""suddenly and without any reason"", began to fire at seven civilians in the town. The injuries sustained are not known. The perpetrators were later shot by security forces.
Two police officers on the evening of 15/07 were killed by unknown gunmen in Zalingei. Following the attack the gunmen stole an ambulance and sped away.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Prison Guards
column9: Prisoners (Sudan); SLM/A-Minnawi: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Minnawi Faction)
column17: Rebels accused prison officers of having subjected the SLM-MM military spokesperson Ahmed Hussain Mustafa (Adorob) to torture in prison since his arrest in May, leaving him severely injured. Adorob was reportedly transferred to the Omdurman military hospital on 17 July as a result.

Market traders close their businesses and demonstrate for two consecutive days in protest over the kidnapping of fellow trader. The protesters held a sit-in protest at the home of the abducted victim on the third day, and market traders refused to open their businesses on the fourth, leading security forces to make arrests. The abduction was believed to have economic motive.

Market traders close their businesses and demonstrate for two consecutive days in protest over the kidnapping of fellow trader. The protesters held a sit-in protest at the home of the abducted victim on the third day, and market traders refused to open their businesses on the fourth, leading security forces to make arrests. The abduction was believed to have economic motive.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Arrests: National Intelligence and Security Services arrested the former head of the SCP and the party's political secretary after they had circulated a letter about government corruption. They were detained without charge for a month, until 13 August.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Students of University of Bakht El Rida in El Duweim in White Nile protest the incarceration of a fellow student. Intent on travelling to Khartoum to continue their protest, National Intelligence and Security Services denied the group bus services to the city. Several of the students became stranded in White Nile area and Sheikh El Yagout.
Market traders hold a sit-in protest against the abduction of a trader following two days of demonstrations.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: After several days of demonstrations against the abduction of a trader, several businesses remain closed in protest of the act. On the fourth day, security agents began making arrests of those business owners who refused to open their shops.
On 20 July, armed Fallata in military attire attacked 20 Salamat and killed 5 of them, in Hashabah valley, 16 km south-west of Graida, as the latter were moving with their livestock towards Nyala.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Arrests: Nearly 30 people were arrested by NISS agents across northern and eastern Sudan on the week of 14 July on charges of leading or participating in anti-dam campaigns.

column16: Radio Dabanga; UNAMID; Radio Tamazuj; Sudan Tribune
column17: A series of clashes between the Ma'alia and Rizeigat tribes on 21 July in El Mejlid and Esharaya in East Darfur as Ma'alia tribesmen were pursuing stolen cattle left 14 Rizaygat killed. Fighting continued on 23 and 24 July in Al Sahab village, 37 km north-west of Abu Karinka, and in Hasab Ala, 17 km north-east of Ed Daein, and resulted in the deaths of two Ma'aliya and 25 Rizeigat. The state government deployed security forces on 24 and 28 July.
Unknown gunmen on horses attacked displaced women farming near Zalingei in Central Darfur, injuring them with bullet wounds.

column16: UNSC; Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: Unidentified gunmen ambushed civilians along the highway of Goli to Todach, some 27km from Abyei town, leaving eight killed and one injured. The victims were all Misseriya.

Armed Abala militants on camels attacked IDPs from Kalma camp as they were planting at Hegair Tono area in South Darfur, killing six people instantly and injuring at least five others. The attack was in retaliation for the injury of one of their tribe member earlier in unclear circumstances. The Sudanese police deployed reinforcements to the area and arrested two suspects.

Militants attacked farmers in Kori and Lali, west of El Hassahissa IDP camp in Zalinger, leaving at least three injured. The assailants torched IDP tents and drove livestock onto the farms, forcing people to flee.

Residents of Um Kati area in Khartoum threw stones at police to protest the sale of a land to a foreign investor around. Police fired tear gas in response, while a police vehicle ran over a resident, killing him instantly. Ten others were injured.

Students at the University of Kassala held marches, discussions and vigils in and out of their university for three days in a row between 23-25 July in protest against the incidents in White Nile state. Police arrested several protesters. Police prevented students of Bakht El Rida University in White Nile state from delivering a collective resignation to protest the expulsion of 14 students following clashes with police in May.
Militants beat a woman with sticks at her farm in Mara, west of Zalingei in Central Darfur. She later succumbed to her injuries.

Gunmen on camels attacked and attempted to rape three displaced women working on their farms two kilometres south of the Hashaba camp in Mershing locality in South Darfur, leaving one severely injured as she tried to resist them.

column16: Sudan Tribune; Radio Tamazuj; Radio Dabanga; UNAMID
column17: A series of clashes between the Ma'alia and Rizeigat tribes on 21 July in El Mejlid and Esharaya in East Darfur as Ma'alia tribesmen were pursuing stolen cattle left 14 Rizaygat killed. Fighting continued on 23 and 24 July in Al Sahab village, 37 km north-west of Abu Karinka, and in Hasab Ala, 17 km north-east of Ed Daein, and resulted in the deaths of two Ma'aliya and 25 Rizeigat. The state government deployed security forces on 24 and 28 July.

Hundreds of students of the University of Sennar took to the streets in the capital of Singa in a short protest march against the incidents in White Nile state. Police prevented students of Bakht El Rida University in White Nile state from delivering a collective resignation to protest the expulsion of 14 students following clashes with police in May.

Students at the University of Kassala held marches, discussions and vigils in and out of their university for three days in a row between 23-25 July in protest against the incidents in White Nile state. Police arrested several protesters. Police prevented students of Bakht El Rida University in White Nile state from delivering a collective resignation to protest the expulsion of 14 students following clashes with police in May.

column16: Radio Dabanga; UNAMID; Radio Tamazuj; Sudan Tribune
column17: A series of clashes between the Ma'alia and Rizeigat tribes on 21 July in El Mejlid and Esharaya in East Darfur as Ma'alia tribesmen were pursuing stolen cattle left 14 Rizaygat killed. Fighting continued on 23 and 24 July in Al Sahab village, 37 km north-west of Abu Karinka, and in Hasab Ala, 17 km north-east of Ed Daein, and resulted in the deaths of two Ma'aliya and 25 Rizeigat. The state government deployed security forces on 24 and 28 July.

Students at the University of Kassala held marches, discussions and vigils in and out of their university for three days in a row between 23-25 July in protest against the incidents in White Nile state. Police arrested several protesters. Police prevented students of Bakht El Rida University in White Nile state from delivering a collective resignation to protest the expulsion of 14 students following clashes with police in May.

Renewed clashes between Salamat and Misseriya tribes in Central Darfur's Salayle village (Umm Dukhun locality) around end July forced 1,000 people to flee to El Sirleaf. The last clashes between the two tribes were in May.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Teachers in El Gedaref protested to demand financial dues to authorities. NISS arrested a journalist while he was covering the protest.

Students at the University of Khartoum demonstrated in solidarity with their colleague charged with the murder of a police officer in April 2016 ahead of the court's verdict. The court delayed the judgement.

On 26 and 27 July armed Arabs shot and wounded a girl and raped two women, respectively, all of whom were returning from Hajar Tono village to the Kalma camp in South Darfur owing to the deterioration in the security situation in the return area.
On 27 July, a suspected Misseriya stagged two Ngok Dinka men at the Amiet market, leaving them injured.
Ngok Dinka assailants killed three Misseriya herders and stole 141 cows in an attack between Goli and Todach, Sector North, on 27 July.

On 26 and 27 July armed Arabs shot and wounded a girl and raped two women, respectively, all of whom were returning from Hajar Tono village to the Kalma camp in South Darfur owing to the deterioration in the security situation in the return area.
Clashes between residents of Gamayer district in Omdurman and police as police attempted to demolish a popular market in the district. The protesters destroyed four stalls.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column17: A suspected member of the military intelligence abducted and killed a boy in Sinkat, Red Sea state. The suspect led police to a place where his body was buried in Port Sudan, where the remains of another unidentified person were also found.

In West Darfur, on 29 July, a group of Arab herders attacked a police station in Terbiba village, 20 km south-west of Masteri, killing two and injuring three others, including a civilian, in retaliation for the Sudanese police having chased livestock away from a farming area in Terbiba. The Government security forces were deployed to the area to contain the situation.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Arrests: Police summoned 13 Rizeigat and 7 Misseriya leaders in Keleikil and Mejlid near Ed Daein in East Darfur on 29 July over the renewed communal clashes in East Darfur the week prior. They were transported to Khartoum the following day to meet with the presidency and released. An additional 130 tribesmen, including at least 25 omdas, were arrested throughout East Darfur between 29 and 31 July, including in RSF raids, striped off of their weapons and transported to prisons in Khartoum and Port Sudan, where the majority were handed prison sentences from 3-6 months.
In the Dawis area, 14 km north-east of Kass, armed Huttiya Arabs clashed with Tunjur over farmland ownership on 30 July, and five Tunjur were reportedly killed.

Two Sudanese soldiers have been shot dead and six others wounded, including two civilians, after a dispute between two soldiers escalated in Deribat market in Darfur's East Jebel Marra, resulting in two groups of soldiers exchanging heavy fire. The initial dispute was personal.
Looting: A pro-government militia sent to recover stolen cattle at Sargilla village, Talas Locality in South Darfur, reportedly looted civilian properties in the area. No casualty.

Dozens of residents of Sinkat in Red Sea state burnt tyres on the Sinkat-Port Sudan road and staged a sit-in to protest authorities' silence after the kidnapping of a boy the week prior. Authorities intervened and the protesters were dispersed. The residents maintained their sit-in for at least the following six days as the case had still not been solved by authorities.

Dozens of residents of Sinkat in Red Sea state burnt tyres on the Sinkat-Port Sudan road and staged a sit-in to protest authorities' silence after the kidnapping of a boy the week prior. Authorities intervened and the protesters were dispersed. The residents maintained their sit-in for at least the following six days as the case had still not been solved by authorities.

column6: SPLM-N-NMLC: Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement (North) (Nuba Mountains Liberation Council Faction)
column17: The SPLM-N led by al-Hilu (NMLC faction) declared a six-month unilateral cessation of hostilities, starting from 31 July 2017 up to 31 Jan 2018.

column6: SPLM-N-NMLC: Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement (North) (Nuba Mountains Liberation Council Faction)
column17: Three cases of fighting between SPLM-N factions in Blue Nile in July. Dates and circumstances unclear. Battles spread throughout July.

column9: Aid Workers (Sudan); Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan); Teachers (Sudan); Women (South Sudan)
column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); AFP; Sudan Tribune
column17: South Sudanese refugees at Khor Al-Waral Camp went on rampage after a refugee died in police custody in unclear circumstances. The rioters set fire to tents and looted stores and humanitarian buildings. Four Sudanese women teachers were also reportedly raped. Authorities arrested 150 refugees during or after the riot and accused SPLA of being behind the riot after finding a card belonging to an officer.

column7: Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan); Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-)
column16: Sudan Tribune; Eye Radio (South Sudan); AFP
column17: South Sudanese refugees at Khor Al-Waral Camp went on rampage after a refugee died in police custody in unclear circumstances. The rioters set fire to tents and looted stores and humanitarian buildings. Four Sudanese women teachers were also reportedly raped. Authorities arrested 150 refugees during or after the riot and accused SPLA of being behind the riot after finding a card belonging to an officer.

Families and supporters of two leading SCoP members staged a sit-in in front of NISS headquarters in Khartoum to demand their release. They have been detained without allowing their families to visit them since 19 July. The party said its members would continue its advocacy activities through phone calls and vigils until the detainees are released. They were release on 13 August.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Suspected RSF militiamen ambushed a group of four commercial vehicles on their way from Fanga in Tawila to the Zamzam IDP camp in North Darfur, at the Guwa Gouno area. They beat the passengers with their rifle butts and robbed them of their property.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column9: Prisoners (Sudan); SPLM-N: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North)
column17: Members of the military intelligence of Hajana reportedly executed an SPLM-N commander at the El Obeid prison and refused to hand over his body to his family. He had been captured in Abu Karshola in South Kordofan on 9 December 2014.

Herders kidnapped two farmers at Dubbo El Omda in north-west Tawila. They accused them of stealing their camels. The families of the abductees gathered in front of the Dubbo El Omda army garrison, demanding the troops to hunt down the kidnappers.
Militiamen riding horses fired at farmers working in Donki Abeer Raghib, 30km from Gireida in South Darfur, leaving three farmers injured and stealing their horse.

Herders kidnapped two farmers at Dubbo El Omda in north-west Tawila. They accused them of stealing their camels. The families of the abductees gathered in front of the Dubbo El Omda army garrison, demanding the troops to hunt down the kidnappers.
On 5 August, two Ngok Dinka were killed and one was injured in Dungoup, Sector Centre in Abyei, allegedly by a group of Misseriya.

column9: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-); Aid Workers (Sudan)
column17: Looting: Unidentified gunmen threatened and robbed a UN peacekeeping mission employee in El Fasher of her vehicle and phones at gunpoint on 6 August. Similar incident the following day, when gunmen hijacked an aid vehicle in the town. The Vice-President was present in the city to launch a campaign to collect weapons and arrest criminals who exploit four-wheel-drive unlicensed vehicles. A week later, on 13 August, masked gunmen raided a charity centre in Kabkabiya in North Darfur, seizing an ambulance and a number of devices.
A camel herder and two camels were killed when a UXO detonated in Jinga, 25km south of Tabit, North Darfur.
Unidentified gunmen opened fire on a foreign aid food truck on its way from Nyala to Gireida in South Darfur, at Tabeldiyat area, 40 km south of Nyala. One person was seriously wounded.
Residents of Baria, south of Kassala, clashed with members of an anti-smuggling force who raided the house of a suspected smuggler during the week of 7 August.

Movement of forces: A group of 17 armed herders surrounded Gargos village in East Jebel Marra and fired live ammunition into the air for two hours in search of cattle that they accused the villagers of stealing. They gave the villagers 24h to provide a financial compensation. The residents fled in fear.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Security agents arrested five more members of the Maaliya tribe from Adilla in East Darfur, as they are suspected of involvement in recent tribal conflicts. They were taken to Ed Daein and later, to Khartoum. They have reportedly been beaten in detention.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Arrests: RSF arrested seven members of the Revolutionary Awakening Council (RAC) in Darfur headed by the tribal leader, Musa Hilal, upon their return from Libya. They were taken to Nyala and later to Khartoum. Authorities accused them of recruiting Darfurians to fight alongside the Libyan military commander Khalifa Haftar. The following day, RAC and the Border Guards militia (mainly made up of elements of the Hilal group) confirmed the militia's refusal to have their forces merged with the RSF. The Sudanese Defence Minister had announced in July a plan to reorganise the forces supportive of the Sudanese army.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column17: Arrests: Military intelligence arrested the head of the Falata tribe after he left evening prayers in Nyala along with 13 other tribe members. The move came after he criticised the large-scale search operations launched a few weeks prior by the force against members of his tribe accused of stealing cattle. He was released around 10 days later, on 23 August.

column8: SPLM-N-NMLC: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North) (Nuba Mountains Liberation Council Faction)
column17: SPLM-N Nuba faction leader al-Hilu claimed SPLM-N forces led by Agar attacked a village in the Greater Yabus area in Blue Nile on 13 August, killing four residents and looting property. A humanitarian worker from the South Kordofan and Blue Nile Coordination Unit appeared to have been one of the victims. Fighters led by al-Hilu chased and clashed with the attackers, resulting in at least 20 killed and 30 injured.
