As Agar sent reinforcements the following day, the two factions clashed again in the Ghafa area, leaving an additional seven SPLMN-Agar fighters killed. Other sources put the total fatality numbers at 43.

SPLM-N Nuba faction leader al-Hilu claimed SPLM-N forces led by Agar attacked a village in the Greater Yabus area in Blue Nile on 13 August, killing four residents and looting property. A humanitarian worker from the South Kordofan and Blue Nile Coordination Unit appeared to have been one of the victims. Fighters led by al-Hilu chased and clashed with the attackers, resulting in at least 20 killed and 30 injured. As Agar sent reinforcements the following day, the two factions clashed again in the Ghafa area, leaving an additional seven SPLMN-Agar fighters killed. Other sources put the total fatality numbers at 43.

column8: SPLM-N-NMLC: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North) (Nuba Mountains Liberation Council Faction)
column17: SPLM-N Nuba faction leader al-Hilu claimed SPLM-N forces led by Agar attacked a village in the Greater Yabus area in Blue Nile on 13 August, killing four residents and looting property. A humanitarian worker from the South Kordofan and Blue Nile Coordination Unit appeared to have been one of the victims. Fighters led by al-Hilu chased and clashed with the attackers, resulting in at least 20 killed and 30 injured. As Agar sent reinforcements the following day, the two factions clashed again in the Ghafa area, leaving an additional seven SPLMN-Agar fighters killed. Other sources put the total fatality numbers at 43.

Gunmen abducted an Eritrean refugee in Kassala during the week of 14 August and later demanded a ransom. The incident came amid reports of rising cases of attacks targeting refugees and asylum seekers in Red Sea state.

Herders attacked Bambani village, 15km west of Katur in Tawila locality, North Darfur, leaving four people wounded, abducting two villagers and stealing a large number of livestock. The attack appeared to be in retaliation for an earlier cattle theft.

Non-violent activity: The nazir of El Hadadwa and about 800 members of his tribe have announced freezing their membership of the ruling National Congress Party in protest against disregard by the Kassala governor for an earlier agreement where the Hadadwa tribe was to be included in the formation of the Council of Ministers in Kassala.
Report of several incidents of beatings of farmers who refused to let herders' cattle graze on their lands in Mershing, South Darfur, in August.
Militiamen shot dead a farmer inside his farm at Dolo area in Tawila locality, after he tried to prevent them from stealing his donkeys. The militants took the cattle upon fleeing.

Unknown gunmen shot and killed a construction worker over unclear reasons in Damrat El Gubba near Kutum in North Darfur. In a separate incident on the same day, a goat keeper was injured by armed robbers in the area of Desa, north-west of Kutum.

A group of five masked and armed members of the Janjaweed militias gang-raped for several hours a displaced girl in the area of Hijeir Tono, south of Kalma IDP camp in South Darfur, in front of her father, whom they tied to a tree. The victims are from the Zaghawa tribe.
Two militants ambushed and repeatedly raped at gunpoint a woman at her farm in the Beer Jongo area north of Kabkabiya, North Darfur.
Militiamen ambushed and abducted two displaced men on their way from Barda to the Sortony IDP camp in North Darfur.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: An RSF soldier killed a woman in Um Baru locality in North Darfur when she rode her donkey and led her seven cows out to pasture.

Political newspaper delegates in the Omdurman parliament boycotted the parliament's activities in solidarity with a colleague who was denied access to the premises without clear reasons. The incident came amid reports of rising press freedom limitation in the country.
Non-violent activity: ""Militants"" enter Khor Ramla and Kore, firing weapons into the air, causing residents to flee. No reported injury.
Non-violent activity: ""Militants"" enter Khor Ramla and Kore, firing weapons into the air, causing residents to flee. No reported injury.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Fighting between RSF and an unknown militant group from Chad at the Adkong border area, West Darfur, left an RSF officer killed and three others injured. The incident led to the closure of the border between the two countries for around ten days.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: NISS opened fire at the gate of the University of the Holy Koran in Omdurman before arresting the former head of the university's Darfur Students Association and taking him to an unknown destination. In December, it was reported that the student suffered severe injuries in his legs and lost vision in one of his eyes as a result of beatings by members of the security service.
NCP student supporters reportedly attacked SLM student supporters at a rally at El Fasher university, leaving two injured.
A farmer was shot dead by ""militants"" inside his farm at Dolo area, 10 kilometres north of Fanga in Tawila locality (eastern Jebel Marra) on 23/08.

A large group of militants opened fire over the Northern Nerteti IDP camp, leaving one displaced man seriously injured. The militiamen had gathered at the Khor Ramla, Kory and Kibe areas of Nertiti since 20 August, claiming one of their men went missing in these areas, firing shots in the air and forcing residents to flee.
Security forces shot dead a fourth-year student at the Faculty of Economics at Zalengi University who was also a member of the UPF in Nertiti locality (Central Darfur).

column16: Radio Dabanga; Humanitarian Aid Relief Trust
column17: Two herders shot dead a farmer after he refused to let their cattle graze on his land in Umdarfi near Kumbar, Kordofan.
On 26 August, in Jok Jul, near Agok in Sector South, Abyei area, one Ngok Dinka individual was shot dead by unknown assailants.
On 26 August, a Nuer language assistant at a hospital run by an INGO in Agok in Sector South, Abyei area, was shot by three unidentified assailants; he died in hospital a few days later.
Unknown assailants shot and killed a woman inside her house in Tur in Central Darfur, in unclear circumstances.
Exchange of fire between unknown gunmen and herders in Tullus, South Darfur, during the week of 28 August, leaving one killed and one seriously wounded.

Dozens of the opposition activists rallied in front of the North Khartoum Criminal court to denounce the conviction of a Khartoum university student of first-degree murder for killing a police officer during protests at the university in April 2016. The rally had been called by Sudan Call two days prior and was dispersed by police. A SCoP party cadre attending the ruling was arrested by NISS and released shortly thereafter.
Four unidentified militiamen kidnap a tuktuk driver in Nierteti, Central Darfur. The victim was taken to an unknown location. The reason for the abduction is not known.

Ppolice and security forces stormed the Omdurman Islamic University dormitory in large numbers and used excessive force and firearms to evacuate the premises. More than 25 students were injured during this attack. This comes after a clash between NCP and UPF students that left three dead.
Unknown militants opened fire at the market in Mershing, leaving one civilian wounded. Police later arrested several suspects.

column16: Darfur Relief and Documentation Centre; Sudan Tribune
column17: Clashes reported at the Omdurman Islamic University after NCP student supporters armed with knives and machetes attacked rooms of Darfur students belonging to the United Peoples Front (UPF). The attack led to a clash between the two groups. Two deaths reported initially, a third succumbed to injuries days later. After the clash, security forces carried out a violent raid of the university dormitories, injuring 25 students and robbing some of their belongings.
A group of six unknown gunmen attacked a displaced couple at their house in Kabkabiya, beating them with sticks and hitting them with knives, which left them severely injured.
Unknown gunmen raped a young woman near the Aribo valley as she made her way from camp Hamidiya to Zalingei, Central Darfur.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column9: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: SLM-AW accused police and RSF forces of conducting a joint violent raid on the movement's former spokesperson in Zalingei, leaving three of his relatives wounded.

Egyptian soldiers reportedly opened fire on and abducted 41 Sudanese gold prospectors in the Wadi Al-Alaki area of Red Sea state. A week later, Egyptian soldiers arrested another 16 Sudanese gold prospectors from the area.
Change to armed group: Former Darfur rebel commander Abbas Ahmed Aseel (aka Jebel Moon) joined SLM-MM, which the group underlined as an important step towards a unified fight against the regime.

Clashes between the Kassab IDP camp gate guards and militants between Kassab and Kutum, North Darfur, lasted from 3-6 September. On the fourth day of clashes, a child was severely injured in the crossfire.

Armed pastoralists reportedly killed a farmer and looted his food in Bau locality in Blue Nile during the week of 4 September. Residents have complained of continuous attacks by pastoralists grazing livestock on their farms in the area.

Clashes between the Kassab IDP camp gate guards and militants between Kassab and Kutum, North Darfur, lasted from 3-6 September. On the fourth day of clashes, a child was severely injured in the crossfire.

Four gunmen riding camels opened fire on a farmer and his son working in a farm in the Dolo area in Eastern Jebel Marra. The father died instantly while the son was seriously wounded. The assailants stole their cattle.

Gunmen shot dead a civilian at Mat Keru village west of Kabkabiya in North Darfur who came to rescue his neighbour, whom the gunmen were attempting to abduct. Bystanders arrested one of the alleged perpetrators while the other two escaped.

Clashes between the Kassab IDP camp gate guards and militants between Kassab and Kutum, North Darfur, lasted from 3-6 September. On the fourth day of clashes, a child was severely injured in the crossfire.
A Sudanese soldier stabbed a civilian at El Salam district of Gireida, South Darfur as he refused to hand over his possessions. The victim later died of his injuries.

Clashes between the Kassab IDP camp gate guards and militants between Kassab and Kutum, North Darfur, lasted from 3-6 September. On the fourth day of clashes, a child was severely injured in the crossfire.
Camel herders attacked farmers at Krukuli village in Kass, South Darfur, leaving five injured. The farmers refused to let the herders' cattle graze on their lands.

column6: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: A number of rebel groups have accused UNAMID of handing over two of its former bases in Maleet and Malha areas of North Darfur to the RSF, breaching the Status of Forces Agreement (SOFA) signed between the Government of Sudan (GoS) and the UN mission. The UNSC has recently agreed to scale down UNAMID's operations in Sudan.
Movement of forces: Militiamen surrounded Tur in Nerteti locality, Central Darfur, for four days in a row, accusing the villagers of raiding their livestock.
Unknown militants shot and killed a displaced farmer when he was tilling his farm in Kullu, near Tawila, in North Darfur.
Unknown militants ambushed and raped two girls on their way back from collecting hay near Jumeizaya in Tawila locality, North Darfur.

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: SLM-MM claimed to have repulsed an attack by RSF and PDF forces in Diffra area of south western Kordofan state, inflicting ""heavy losses of life and equipment"". The group also admitted to casualties on its side.

Demonstrations broke out in El Jareif West, Khartoum, after a death sentence was issued against four people accused of killing the former director of the Sudan Cotton Company three years ago. Police slapped and violently arrested a journalist covering the protest. She was later beaten and verbally abused in detention by NISS officers.

column7: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Demonstrations broke out in El Jareif West, Khartoum, after a death sentence was issued against four people accused of killing the former director of the Sudan Cotton Company three years ago. Police slapped and violently arrested a journalist covering the protest. She was later beaten and verbally abused in detention by NISS officers.

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF militiamen opened fire and killed a member of the Sudanese army who refused to let them enter Murnei in West Darfur with their motorcycles. The soldiers retaliated, injuring one and capturing another RSF militant.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF militiamen attacked Tambasi village, Al-Salam locality in South Darfur, killing two residents and injuring several others before fleeing. As a group of residents formed to pursue them, the assailants ambushed the villagers again, killing another eight and injuring another seven. The attack came against the backdrop of a marriage refusal.

Pro-United People's Front (UPF) students demonstrated at the Bahri and El Sug El Arabi markets in Khartoum against NISS' detention of their fellow students a few days earlier at markets in Omdurman after debates organised by the group. Police arrested eight students involved in the demonstration. They were released on bail five months later, on 19/02, but re-detained soon after on new charges. The students were allegedly subjected to a variety of physical and psychological torture while in detention.

SPLM-N faction led by Malik Agar claimed to have repulsed a government attack on its positions at Taga area in the Ingessana Hills, Blue Nile state, inflicting human as well as material damage. Agar had accused government troops of breaching the cessation of hostilities a day earlier by advancing towards their positions. The Sudanese army denied the clashes.
SPLM-N faction led by Malik Agar claimed that government forces attacked their positions at Taga in the Ingessana Hills, Blue Nile state.

Unknown gunmen attempting to loot cattle in Jaber area of Kutum, North Darfur, fired at the herders who were trying to resist them, leaving one killed and four injured. The assailants looted 110 heads of cattle and fled towards Fata Borno.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Two leading members of the Alternative Port Workers Union staged a protest against the visit of representatives of the Dubai Ports Company to the Southern Container Port in Port Sudan. NISS briefly arrested the two protesters.

A group of gunmen riding on camels and horses stormed the Tur Eastern IDP Camp in Central Darfur, firing shots in the air, and beating and stabbing camp residents. 13 displaced people were injured, while eight homes were looted.

IDPs at Kalma camp outside Nyala, South Darfur, staged demonstrations and dug trenches around the camp over 19-22 September to protest a planned presidential visit at the camp. On the fourth day of the protests (corresponding to the day of the president's visit), officials accused some IDPs, including infiltrated rebel SLM-AW elements, of firing at Sudanese forces, leading to a violent response by the government forces and RSF militia that left at least five killed and 29 injured, including a government soldier.

Unknown gunmen ambushed a convoy of at least 10 vehicles on the road between Guldo and Golo in Central Darfur, hijacking four of the vehicles along with 47 of their occupants. One passenger managed to escape and sound the alarm. A week later, a relative said they were held in the area of Tringa but that the assailants had not yet made demands and authorities not yet intervened.

IDPs at Kalma camp outside Nyala, South Darfur, staged demonstrations and dug trenches around the camp over 19-22 September to protest a planned presidential visit at the camp. On the fourth day of the protests (corresponding to the day of the president's visit), officials accused some IDPs, including infiltrated rebel SLM-AW elements, of firing at Sudanese forces, leading to a violent response by the government forces and RSF militia that left at least five killed and 29 injured, including a government soldier.

IDPs at Kalma camp outside Nyala, South Darfur, staged demonstrations and dug trenches around the camp over 19-22 September to protest a planned presidential visit at the camp. On the fourth day of the protests (corresponding to the day of the president's visit), officials accused some IDPs, including infiltrated rebel SLM-AW elements, of firing at Sudanese forces, leading to a violent response by the government forces and RSF militia that left at least five killed and 29 injured, including a government soldier.
IDPs at camps in Zalingei, Central Darfur, gathered in mass protest in solidarity with other IDPs in South Darfur protesting president Bashir's visit to their camp.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column9: Kababeesh Ethnic Militia (Sudan); Zayadiya Ethnic Militia (Sudan)
column17: RSF forces clashed with members of the Musa Hilal's SARC and Zayadiya and Kababish tribesmen involved in some of the largest human trafficking operations on the Sudanese-Egyptian-Libyan border, leaving 19 killed, including 17 pro-RAC members, and six injured. RSF arrested seven of the ""gang leaders"" along with 48 international illegal migrants.
A group of four armed men opened fire on the home of a displaced man at the Nierteti IDP camp in Central Darfur, leaving his son killed.

column6: Twic East Area Youth Militia (South Sudan)
column9: MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Aid Workers (International)
column17: Suspected gunmen from Twic state shot at two MSF employees while returning to their home in Abyei, leaving one killed and the other injured. Date unclear - report dated 21 September.

column7: Refugees/IDPs (Sudan); SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column9: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: IDPs at Kalma camp outside Nyala, South Darfur, staged demonstrations and dug trenches around the camp over 19-22 September to protest a planned presidential visit at the camp. On the fourth day of the protests (corresponding to the day of the president's visit), officials accused some IDPs, including infiltrated rebel SLM-AW elements, of firing at Sudanese forces, leading to a violent response by the government forces and RSF militia that left at least five killed and 29 injured, including a government soldier.
A group of seven militiamen ambushed a car near Wadi Gargash, 25 km from Buram town in South Darfur, leaving a medical assistant killed and two injured. The assailants seized the vehicle and fled.

Hundreds of students and members of the SCoP demonstrated outside the Khartoum Court to protest the death sentence given to a university student for allegedly killing a policeman during protests last year. They later marched to the university of Khartoum. Police dispersed the protesters with teargas and arrested dozens.
Militiamen raided Sousawa village, north of Tabit in Tawila locality, shooting and injuring at least two seriously, abducting a child, and stealing 84 heads of cattle.
Unidentified gunmen opened fire on a lorry transporting miners south of Tokar in the Red Sea state, leaving one killed and two injured. Reasons unclear.
Unknown gunmen abducted a pregnant woman from the Kundebe IDP camp in West Darfur. Her body was found the following day in a valley east of Ardamata. Reasons are unclear.
Militiamen opened fire on a passenger lorry en route from Tawila to El Fasher, in the area of Tundabaya, and forced the passengers out of the bus, striping them of their valuables. Two were injured.
Militiamen raided Tamboul village in eastern Jebel Marra, shooting dead four people, stealing about 150 livestock along with property, and setting fire to 50 houses. People fled to mountain caves.
Militants severely beat and injured at least two IDPs from the Garsila IDP camp while they were tilling their farm at Yangusai, east of Garsila. The attackers tried to kidnap them, but they resisted.

Clash between the family of a displaced deceased girl and members attending her burial near the Bindisi camp in Central Darfur. The family claimed the girl had been raped before dying while doctors said she had been struck by lightning. The clash left one killed and another wounded. This is believed to have led to a retaliatory attack the following day, as tribesmen abducted seven in the camp. The gunmen allegedly set fire to houses and stole camp resident's properties. The abductees were released a few days later.
Police fired teargas and set fire to homes in El Salam district of Kassala to disperse demonstrators protesting against the planned destruction of their houses by the police.

Clash between the family of a displaced deceased girl and members attending her burial near the Bindisi camp in Central Darfur. The family claimed the girl had been raped before dying while doctors said she had been struck by lightning. The clash left one killed and another wounded. This is believed to have led to a retaliatory attack the following day, as tribesmen abducted seven in the camp. The gunmen allegedly set fire to houses and stole camp resident's properties. The abductees were released a few days later.

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Unidentified gunmen killed an RSF soldier near the Khamssa Dagayg IDP camp outside Zalingei, Central Darfur, at an unclear date. RSF attacked the camp in revenge over night and in the early hours of 1 October, killing a displaced person, injuring another nine and abducting one. Soldiers intervened to disperse the attackers.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Suspected members of the security services abducted a civilian from his shop at Libya market in western Omdurman over unclear reasons.

Militants led by Osman Abdellatif carried out revenge campaigns against IDPs in camp Fata Borno, Kutum locality, North Darfur, after farmers refused to pay the royalties they had imposed to protect IDP farms. They looted people's goods, hampered access to Kutum and beat some IDPs between 28 September and 1 October. It is not clear when the violence precisely occurred.
Gunmen shot and killed a man after he refused to hand them over his cattle in Yaw, north of Tawila.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column17: Military intelligence beat and arrested four brothers at a family's home whom they accused of associating with SPLM-N early October in Elfaid Um Abdalla, 50km south of Abu Kershola in South Kordofan. One was injured on his face. A fifth brother was also arrested and slapped as he came to visit them a few days later.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Unidentified gunmen killed an RSF soldier near the Khamssa Dagayg IDP camp outside Zalingei, Central Darfur, at an unclear date. RSF attacked the camp in revenge over night and in the early hours of 1 October, killing a displaced person, injuring another nine and abducting one. Soldiers intervened to disperse the attackers.
Militiamen raided a village in Fogali area of East Jebel Marra locality in South Darfur, leaving three people killed. One person was abducted but managed to escape soon after.
Armed herders shot and killed a man after he refused to hand them over his cattle in Daba Naira, 15km east of Dobo El Omda.

column7: NCF: National Consensus Forces; SCP: Sudanese Congress Party; Sudanese Baath Party; SPLM-N: Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement (North)
column17: Several Sudanese opposition forces (including members of the National Consensus Forces (NCF), SCoP, Sudanese Ba'ath Party (SBP) and the SPLM-N) protested near the UN headquarters in Khartoum to call for the release of all political detainees in the country and the dropping of the death sentence against a college student recently accused of killing a police officer in protests in 2016.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: NISS arrested the head of SCoP in Karrari, Khartoum, beating some members of his family. No reason was given for his arrest.
Unknown gunmen attacked and raped four girls collecting straw in Susuwa near the Rwanda IDP camp in Tawila locality.
Unidentified gunmen opened fire on an ambulance carrying a sick person from Malha to El Fasher in Mellit locality, leaving the driver killed.

NCP student supporters attacked fellow students staging a sit-in outside the Faculty of Education of the En Nahud university in West Kordofan with live bullets and metal bars, leaving 18 students injured, including one seriously. The protesters were demanding improvements to the university provision of transportation from the boarding houses to the university. Police fired teargas to disperse the groups.
Report of at least four militia raids on farms and roads in Gereida over 3-4 October. On 4 October, gunmen attacked three displaced women from Gereida camp, leaving them severely injured.
An ERW explosion left one person killed along with his camel in Mashrou Abuzeid in eastern Jebel Marra.
Armed men shot and killed a displaced man working on a farm east of the Fata Borno IDP camp in North Darfur's Kutum locality. The assailants stole his money, property and his donkey.

Gunfire exchange between militiamen attempting to break into shops and guards at the Kabkabiya market in North Darfur left a militia member killed and a policeman injured in the exchange of gunfire between militiamen and guards of the market.

A group of nine militiamen abducted a merchant from the market in Kabkabiya, North Darfur. It is unclear if this incident happened before or after a clash reported on the same day at the market between police and militiamen attempting to loot a shop.
Militiamen attacked two displaced women working on their farms in Um Asal, west of Gireida, leaving them injured.
A bomb blast at Umjak village of Al-Odeiya locality, West Kordofan left a female university student dead. Circumstances unclear.

Armed herders opened fire on two farmers in Dulo, north of Fanga, eastern Jebel Marra, as they tried to keep the herders from entering cattle onto their farms. One of the farmers died on the spot, while the other one was left injured. Date unclear - report dated 6 October.
Unknown gunmen abducted a Swiss humanitarian worker from her home in downtown El-Fasher, North Darfur. She was released on 14 November.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: A UXO from an abandoned RSF ammunition store in Nyala detonated as a boy played with it. The boy sustained head wounds and his fingers were amputated.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: An RSF member reportedly harassed and tried to rape a woman in Sakali district of Nyala. As she resisted, he shot and severely wounded her.
The Sudanese president extended a unilateral cessation of hostilities in Blue Nile and South Kordofan states for three months, until 31 December 2017
Gunmen ambushed and shot dead a trader driving in his vehicle at the Sarbin market in Nyala, South Darfur. Reasons unclear.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Border Guards
column17: Clash between RSF and paramilitary border guards in Kasora, Niteaga locality, South Darfur left two killed. The clash came as RSF members conducted search operations in Kasora.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Movement of forces: A force of 10,000 RSF militiamen was deployed to Kabkabiya district to enhance security and stability in the state, and to implement the second phase of the arms collection process starting this month. A week later, another 2,500 RSF forces were deployed to El Fasher to assist with arms collection and vehicle control. The deadline for the voluntary collection of weapons is 19 October; force will be used after this deadline to collect the remaining illegal arms in circulation. Several groups have rejected the process. The RAC denounced the disarmament process in Darfur as targeting Sheikh Musa Hilal and his tribe.

Angry residents gathered at El Jiraif neighbourhood in Khartoum as police had come demolish brick factories and forced them to withdraw. No report of clash. The residents reject the sale of the land to investors and claim ownership of the land for themselves.
A group of ten militiamen opened fire in the market in Kutum, leaving six people wounded. This followed an altercation between a merchant and one of the militiamen.
Gunmen opened fire on villages around Amiet common market in Abyei, leaving at least two people killed and six others injured. Local officials blamed pro-government militias for the attack.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: An RSF member killed a mini-bus driver in Nyala in unclear circumstances. Drivers of mini-buses in public transport launched a strike after the incident to protest the killing of the driver and demand the arrest of the perptrator.
Unknown assailants fired on a policeman on his way to work in Kabkabiya locality in North Darfur, leaving him severely injured and stealing his weapon.

A gunman fired live bullets at security officers who came to check his identity in a park in El Fasher and engaged in running battles with the security officers as they pursued him. The gunman fired and attempted to throw a grenade at the officers but the grenade exploded in his hand. The assailant died and several security officers were injured.

Three armed herders opened fire on Um Tjona village in Kereinik, West Darfur, seriously wounding three women an burning four houses in the village. The herders had just brought their livestock to graze at the farms near Um Tjona chased the farmers out of the farms.
Three suspected local militiamen opened fire on a commercial vehicle in the general area of Banton, eight km south of Abyei town, leading to the death of one woman and injury to two others.
Two children were reportedly abducted by militia groups at Tagalei in Abyei. They were found unharmed two days later.
Militiamen abducted a displaced man in Tawila locality in North Darfur and took him to Damrat El Gubba.

Change to armed group: The former SLM rebel group led by Nour al-Din Zorgi (SLM-Zorgi) - a breakway faction of SLM-AW that joined the Doha Document for Peace in Darfur in February 2016 - suspended the peace accord signed with the government of North Darfur, denouncing the government's failure to meet its commitments (failure to implement development projects; poor representation of the movement in the government; failure to grant the leader of the SLM-Zorgi military rank as agreed in the security component of the accord).

A group of six allegedly drunken gunmen opened fire on Um Deidan police station in Abu Jabra locality in East Darfur on the week of 16 October and stole a number of weapons and ammunitions, leaving two policemen injured. Police gave chase and managed to apprehend two of the alleged perpetrators.

Between 16 and 19 October, subclans of the Rizeigat (Awlad Id, Awlad Zaid and Ereigat) clashed with the Zaghawa over cattle near Kulbus town, West Darfur. 16 Zaghawa and 11 Rizeigat dead. The Sudan-Chad joint border forces along with the state forces and UNAMID were deployed to contain the violence.

Between 16 and 19 October, subclans of the Rizeigat (Awlad Id, Awlad Zaid and Ereigat) clashed with the Zaghawa over cattle near Kulbus town, West Darfur. 16 Zaghawa and 11 Rizeigat dead. The Sudan-Chad joint border forces along with the state forces and UNAMID were deployed to contain the violence.

A group of about 400 women tea sellers held a vigil in front of the headquarters of the Social Responsibility Forum in the Friendship Hall of Khartoum. Police dispersed the vigil by force and arrested several activists. There were no report of clash or injury. The tea sellers were protesting a ban against their work in a number of key sites in Khartoum.

Police forcibly dispersed a sit-in organised by students at the Faculty of Education of the University of Khartoum who were protesting the administration's dismissal of three of their colleagues who had earlier called for reform of the university environment. Police forced the students to return to their exam and injured at least four students in the process, while a number of others were arrested.

Unknown gunmen killed two members of the Mahariya tribe and stole their motorcycles, five km north of Kabkabiya. The following day, a group of Mahariya following the trail of the assailants ended up at Um Delwa village and exchanged fire with the border guards led by Seifu, leaving six dead and three wounded. RSF intervened to separate the parties.

Unknown gunmen killed two members of the Mahariya tribe and stole their motorcycles, five km north of Kabkabiya, North Darfur. The following day, a group of Mahariya traced the perpetrators to Umm Laota village (9km northwest of Kabkabiya towan), where to Mahariya and two Tama were killed during the ensuing clashes. RSF intervened to separate the parties.

Between 16 and 19 October, subclans of the Rizeigat (Awlad Id, Awlad Zaid and Ereigat) clashed with the Zaghawa over cattle near Kulbus town, West Darfur. 16 Zaghawa and 11 Rizeigat dead. The Sudan-Chad joint border forces along with the state forces and UNAMID were deployed to contain the violence.

Unknown gunmen killed two members of the Mahariya tribe and stole their motorcycles, five km north of Kabkabiya, North Darfur. The following day, a group of Mahariya traced the perpetrators to Umm Laota village (9km northwest of Kabkabiya towan), where two Mahariya and two Tama were killed during the ensuing clashes. RSF intervened to separate the parties.

Between 16 and 19 October, subclans of the Rizeigat (Awlad Id, Awlad Zaid and Ereigat) clashed with the Zaghawa over cattle near Kulbus town, West Darfur. 16 Zaghawa and 11 Rizeigat dead. The Sudan-Chad joint border forces along with the state forces and UNAMID were deployed to contain the violence.
Two armed herdsmen intercepted two boys on their way to collect firewood near Fallujah in East Jebel Marra, and kidnapped one of them as the other escaped.

Youth in Kologi protested the health impacts of the use of cyanide in gold extraction after officials travelled to Kadugli to persuade mining companies to come and work in the area. A curfew was imposed on the town on 20 October after tensions mounted in the area. Date of the protests unclear.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: A clash took place in Feina, north-east of Kass in South Darfur, when SLA/AW reportedly encroached an area controlled by a splinter group. It is unclear of what group the second actor is a splinter of.

column9: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: An unidentified assailant allegedly killed SPLM-IO spokesperson Lam Kuei Lam in Khartoum. A suspect was later arrested but the circumstances of Lam's death remain unclear.

Unidentified assailants in military uniforms attacked a shop at a gold mine in El Liri north in Talodi locality, South Kordofan, leaving one killed, another seriously injured, and stealing large sums of money and gold.

Herders beat two farmers with sticks and an axe after driving their camels onto their farm in the Khazan Tunjur area of Tawila locality, North Darfur, causing one of the two's miscarriage. The herders also stole sorghum.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Clashes between RSF and a militia force led by Ali Rizgallah that tried to attack Kutum from Kabkabiya. RSF said it repulsed the rebels.

Militants opened fire on a rickshaw at Bargo valley in Birkat Seira, Saraf Omra locality, North Darfur, leaving three members of a child immunisation team wounded. The health team was returning from the Malika area east of Birkat Seira after the completion of a vaccination campaign for nomadic children.

Militants opened fire in Fogni village north of El Malam in East Jebel Marra, leaving a number of people wounded, including three seriously. The gunmen seized money, property and livestock of the villagers. Villagers were displaced to El Malam and Dubo El Omda.
Militants attacked Fara village in Tullus locality, South Darfur, leaving three people shot dead and three others wounded.
Clashes between the Salamat and the Fallata over cattle rustling in the Dejaj area (55 km west of Graida, south Darfur) left four Fallata, including two women, and five Salamat men killed.
A clash between herders and farmers at Azum area of Western Darfur left a number of farmers injured.

The families of detained Darfuri students held a vigil outside the US embassy in Khartoum and handed over a memorandum with the names of student detainees, native administrations and hostages, as well as the ongoing human rights violations in the province. Police cordoned the protesters. The activists said the aim of the vigil was to draw the US' attention at the continued human rights violations in Sudan in general and in Darfur in particular.
Unknown militants abducted two people from a coal mine near Dubet Neira, 7km south of Dubo El Omda in North Darfur. The motives are unclear.

Militiamen attacked the area of Leiba in East Jebel Marra, leaving at least five people wounded and many others missing. The assailants also stole around 1,000 heads of cattle and villagers' belongings. Government troops stationed in the area reportedly fired into the air but did not come to the rescue.

column9: Al-Falata Ethnic Group (Sudan); Fur Ethnic Group (Sudan)
column17: A group of armed nomads attacked Fallata and Fur returnees in Funguli village, 54 km north-west of the team site at Menawashei, in East Jebel Marra locality, killing five and injuring several others.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Non-violent activity: RSF militiamen shaved a girl's head when they learned that she belonged to the Mahameed clan, headed by Musa Hilal. The girl was taking livestock for grazing near Damrat El Sheikh in Kutum locality. The incident raised significant tensions. Three days later, RSF opened fire on a vehicle carrying the girl and her father from Damrat El Sheikh, as they were on their way to Kutum to complain about the incident. Two people were wounded.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF opened fire on a militant in Ghurra area, North Darfur, as he refused to cooperate during the RSF' disarmament campaign and drew a knife at them. The militant was wounded in the leg. Date unclear - report dated 27 October.
Unknown gunmen shot dead a police officer at Al-Siteb area of West Kordofan after the officer refused to hand them his keys and money.

A group of around 20 herders opened fire on displaced farmers who were trying to remove the herders' livestock from their land near Mershing, leaving two shot dead. The herders exchanged fire with the military after a search team later found them at a nomad settlement in the area of Kerengo. Traders closed their shops at the mershing market in protest against herder violence.

A group of around 20 herders opened fire on displaced farmers who were trying to remove the herders' livestock from their land near Mershing, leaving two shot dead. The herders exchanged fire with the military after a search team later found them at a nomad settlement in the area of Kerengo. Traders closed their shops at the mershing market in protest against herder violence.
A group of Chadian soldiers abducted a student of the Holy Koran Institute in West Darfur's Sirba locality. Reasons unclear. They also raided the premises.
A gunman raided the shelter of a displaced woman in Kutum camp and shot and injured her when she resisted his attempt to rape her.
A group of herders in military uniform fired shots in the air and beat and injured two women who were trying to chase the herders' livestock from their farms near Gereida.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF defeated a SARC force in clashes in Shearia, East Darfur.

Agreement: Leaders of the Habaniya and Salamat tribes signed a reconciliation and peaceful coexistence agreement in Buram. They agreed to hand over 1,420 weapons to the regular forces. They also called for pasture tracks and markets to be re-opened and for the establishment of a mechanism to deter the outlaws in the area and secure the voluntary return of displaced to their home villages.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF militiamen shaved a girl's head when they learned that she belonged to the Mahameed clan, headed by Musa Hilal. The girl was taking livestock for grazing near Damrat El Sheikh in Kutum locality. The incident raised significant tensions. Three days later, RSF opened fire on a vehicle carrying the girl and her father from Damrat El Sheikh, as they were on their way to Kutum to complain about the incident. Two people were wounded.

Dozens of angry West Darfur farmers gathered in front of the office of the Commissioner of Sirba locality to demand compensation for damage they claim was caused to their harvest by herders' livestock. The commissioner denied any damage.

Two incidents of shootings by unknown gunmen on 31 October and 4 November at the Leha Mining Company in the Baloula area of South Kordofan. It is unclear if the gunmen exchanged fire with another group. No casualties were reported. The company stopped its operations as a result. There have been tensions recently over gold production in the area.
Four gunmen attacked two brothers on their way from camp Kalma to camp El Salam near Nyala to visit relatives; one was shot dead; the other's hand was cut-off.

Herders shot dead a resident of Kassab IDP camp in Kutum locality, North Darfur, as he resisted when they tried to take his grain at his farm at Jumbo area north of the camp. Incidents have reportedly increased since the herders have been driven out of Kutum by the RSF.

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Agreement: Some 300 Darfur rebel fighters defected from Ali Rizgallah faction in SARC to the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia and joined them in El Fasher.
Herders opened fire on a woman while she was trying to drive their camels away from her farm at Guldo in Jebel Marra in Central Darfur, leaving her seriously wounded.
Armed herders abducted two villagers from their farms near Timo village, 10km west of Khazan Tunjur in North Darfur's Tawila locality.

Two incidents of shootings by unknown gunmen on 31 October and 4 November at the Leha Mining Company in the Baloula area of South Kordofan. It is unclear if the gunmen exchanged fire with another group. No casualties were reported. The company stopped its operations as a result. There have been tensions recently over gold production in the area.
Militiamen attacked a number of farmers in Kombo Umbera in Mukjar locality, Central Darfur, firing shots in the air, looting property and beating a woman who resisted, breaking her hand as a result.

Non-violent activity: Unknown gunmen attacked a government delegation at Al-Hameedh area in South Kordofan, 20km north of Kadugli town. No casualties. There are currently tensions over gold production in the area.

Military intelligence officers beat a merchant in a military garrison in Sirba, West Darfur, after he gave them high pricing on women's clothing at the Sirba IDP camp. He was severely injured in the head. He was only released after a group of people protested his detention in front of the garrison and the headquarters of the locality.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column17: Military intelligence officers beat a merchant in a military garrison in Sirba, West Darfur, after he gave them high pricing on women's clothing at the Sirba IDP camp. He was severely injured in the head. He was only released after a group of people protested his detention in front of the garrison and the headquarters of the locality.
Sudan President Al Bashir declared a state of emergency and dissolved the Legislative Council of El Gezira state after a political conflict. The move was condemned as violating the law.
Armed herders in military uniforms attacked farmers in Gireida. Two women were injured.
Militiamen raped a young woman at gunpoint as she harvested crops in Mershing locality in South Darfur.
A herder severely beat and injured a displaced woman in Kabkabiya locality in North Darfur as she was trying to stop camels from entering her farm.
Five children were injured, some of them seriously, when a grenade they found at Sham El Naseem district in Nyala detonated.

column7: WFP: World Food Programme; Aid Workers (Sudan)
column17: Dozens of former Sudanese staff at the World Food Programme (WFP) protested in El-Fasher, North Darfur demanding payment of financial dues that amounts to $20 million.
Unknown gunmen stormed the dormitory for teachers of a school east of Muglad town in West Kordofan, killing two teachers.

Unknown gunmen fired shots in the air at the Gereida IDP camp in South Darfur as young people were gathering building materials from the Abola area to re-construct buildings that had burned in the camp fire two days prior. Three displaced students were wounded.
Armed men beat and raped four displaced farming women from Abu Suruj in Sirba, West Darfur, causing them varying injuries.
Armed herdsmen opened fire on a group of farmers as they attempted to chase away the herders' cattle from their farms south of Gireida in South Darfur, wounding two.

Dozens of residents from El Tirtir and El Tadamon gathered for a vigil in front of the house of the Kologi locality commissioner to protest mining activities in the region. A delegation of the Sudanese Company for Mining had just held a symposium to persuade residents to allow them to operate, but the protesters refused.

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Bloody clashes between RSF and SARC forces of Ali Rizgallah at Amari Gadid, Kaila, Niro and Eshbara in Korma area of North Darfur. RSF said they defeated the rebels, killing ""several"" and capturing 9 fighters.

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Bloody clashes between RSF and SARC forces of Ali Rizgallah at Amari Gadid, Kaila, Niro and Eshbara in Korma area of North Darfur. RSF said they defeated the rebels, killing ""several"" and capturing 9 fighters.

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Bloody clashes between RSF and SARC forces of Ali Rizgallah at Amari Gadid, Kaila, Niro and Eshbara in Korma area of North Darfur. RSF said they defeated the rebels, killing ""several"" and capturing 9 fighters.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Four children died and another was injured in their family's house when an ammunition storage exploded in Nyala, South Darfur. The storage is believed to belong to RSF - a bigger explosion had occurred last May, killing 12.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Clash between former rebel troops led by El Sadig El Fakkah (operating within SLM-AW) and militants who beat and forced IDPs away from their farms at Teo, 2km east of Sortony camp in North Darfur. UNAMID was unable to confront the attackers due to lack of ground troops. One man was wounded and another of El Fakkah's force went missing during the fighting.

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: In an operation to arrest the SARC leader, Ali Rizgallah, RSF ambushed SARC forces at Al-Malha area in Jibal Moro, east of Kabkabiya in North Darfur. One RSF fighter died and another was injured in the clash, while the SARC leader was indeed arrested.

Clash between former rebel troops led by El Sadig El Fakkah (operating within SLM-AW) and militants who beat and forced IDPs away from their farms at Teo, 2km east of Sortony camp in North Darfur. UNAMID was unable to confront the attackers due to lack of ground troops. One man was wounded and another of El Fakkah's force went missing during the fighting.

Hundreds of protesters burned the house of the commissioner of Kalogi, South Kordofan and locality buildings to protest the use of cyanide by the gold mining companies in the area. Police shot and wounded three protesters, including a higher secondary school student who succumbed to his injuries.

Brick factory employees and residents in El Jireif East district of Khartoum protested against the arrest of the owner of the factory and three employees as they resisted police's intervention in the factory to prevent people from working there. Police intervened and used sticks, tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse the demonstrators, injuring at least two children.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: NISS launched with RSF a ""professional security operation"" in a mountainous area of North Darfur to free a Swiss aid worker abducted a month prior from her captors. It is unclear if there was a clash but the aid worker was freed and several of the captors were arrested.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Dozens of journalists gathered in a vigil in front of the Press and Publications Council in Khartoum to protest against draft amendments to the 2009 Press and Publications Act, which they say puts greater restrictions on the freedom of the press. NISS prevented the protesters from continuing their vigil before the press council and detained two, whom were released later in the day. The protesters moved into another nearby area and continued their chants.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Report of intra- group fighting among SLA/AW members in Deribat in East Jebel Marra in November and December 2017, resulting in the killing and injury of civilians, destruction of houses, looting of community assets and in the displacement of hundreds of people.

column8: SPLM-SM: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (Silent Majority)
column17: Change to armed group: SPLM-N leader Malik Agar announced the merger of his group with the SPLM-Silent Majority led by Ismail Jalab, jointly calling for the self-governance for the Two Areas within a democratic and united Sudan. In a separate joint statement on the same day, Agar announced the merger of SPLM-N with the Darfur Front (now SLM/A), forming a new political, military and administrative body in the group for the Darfur region.

Government forces severely beat and opened fire on a group of people in Tullus and El Salam localities in South Darfur while carrying out the disarmament campaign on or around 19 November, leaving two killed and six injured. It is unclear if the people were armed and violent at the time of the incident.
Gunmen opened fire on a farmer working in Farok area north of Kutum in North Darfur, killing him instantly, on or around 19 November. The motive of the shooting is unclear.

Arrests: The community security police of Dongola in Sudan's Northern state arrested 83 youths during the week of 20 November, most of them students, for odd shaving and wearing inappropriate uniforms.

Policemen allegedly beat and tortured three herders from Rabak in Sudan's White Nile State in detention. They were detained for 20 days on suspicion of stealing cattle. Date of arrest unclear - report dated 7 December.
Two armed herders raped a young girl working on a farm in Daba Naira, north of Tawila, and stabbed to death her mother as she tried to intervene.
10 armed herders opened fire on a group of farmers at Sagor area of Gireida in South Darfur, leaving one killed and one seriously injured.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Clashes between a suspected dormant cell of JEM and Sudanese Armed Forces/Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in Birkat Saira area, 25 km east of Saraf Omra, in the context of the weapons collection campaign, which resulted in the capture of 16 rebels.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 22 November, suspected SLM/AW elements fired at a commercial truck near Golo, Central Darfur. One civilian killed and six injured.
Three unknown gunmen shot and killed a man in a gold mine at Hashaba, east of Kutum in North Darfur. Circumstances unclear.
Eight gunmen fired at and hijacked a Land Cruiser belonging to collectors of the locality of East Jebel Marra on the road between Deribat to Kator in South Darfur. A man was shot.

Police fired tear gas and beat protesters who had gathered against the demolition of brick factories in El Jireif East in Khartoum city. A man was arrested and two demonstrators sustained injuries. Residents regrouped after the withdrawal of police forces to protest along the main road linking the district to the bridge.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF raided the house of the leader of the Berti tribe in Mellit locality in North Darfur, beating one of the leader's guards, and going on a rampage inside the house. The head of the Berti youth denounced the search for being carried out in a ""humiliating manner"".

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Clashes between RSF and SARC elements in Mistiriyha in North Darfur left at least 14 RSF and 9 border guards killed. RSF captured 50 SARC members, including the movement's leader, Musa Hilal, his sons and several of his aides. One of Hilal's aides and tribal leader of the Awlad Eid Rizeigat clan died in detention the following day, allegedly from torture. The leaders of other rebel groups including the SPLM-N and SLM-MM denounced the arrest of the SARC members and accused RSF of burning homes in the area and killing further civilians, which authorities denied.

The residents of El Jireif clashed with police while protesting the planned demolition of brick factories in their neighbourhood of Khartoum. A joint security and police force fired tear gas to disperse the crowds and hit demonstrators with batons. 18 people were injured.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: NISS arrested and detained two students from Alsalam University at a student hostel of Babanoosa over engaging in political activities on campus. The students were released the following day. They were reportedly subjected to torture and/or ill-treatment whilst in NISS custody. They had wounds on their bodies from beatings with a solid object.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Prison Guards
column9: JEM: Justice and Equality Movement; Prisoners (Sudan); SLM/A-Minnawi: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Minnawi Faction); SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction)
column17: The leaders of the SLM-MM and SLM-TC accused the government of subjecting the 243 members of their groups captured during clashes in May to physical and verbal violence at El Huda prison in Omdurman. Two prisoners reportedly died as a result while others were amputated (though it is unclear if the amputations are from the conflict or from the violence in prison). Date unclear - report dated 27 November.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Non-violent activity: Police launched an eight-day campaign of newspaper confiscation in the capital, repeatedly seizing the copies of El Taghyeer, El Jareeda, El Watan, and Akhir Lahza newspapers. The seizures have been described as a massacre of the press resulting in huge financial losses. A one day strike called by the Sudanese Journalists Network was followed by 70% of journalists on 5 December.

Unknown militiamen opened fire on a group of returnees in the Katur area of Tawila locality, leaving two children seriously injured. The group was returning in the framework of the voluntary repatriation. Troops stationed in Katur intervened opening fire in the air, which forced the militiamen into retreat.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Security Measures: The RSF Commander in North Darfur gave a 48h ultimatum to all armed groups to hand in their weapons as part of the illegal weapon collection campaign launched a few months prior in the region. The news came a day after they clashed with SARC forces, arresting their leader, whom had been among the main opponents of the campaign.
On 29 November, government forces clashed with suspected gunmen coming from South Sudan at Mihelid village, 46km north-east of Shaeria in Darfur.

column6: SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction)
column7: SLM/A-Minnawi: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Minnawi Faction); JEM: Justice and Equality Movement
column17: The Sudan Liberation Movement - Transitional Council (SLM-TC), the Justice and Equality Movement (JEM) and the SLM-Minni Minnawi extended their unilateral cessation of hostilies across Blue Nile, South Kordofan, and Darfur from 30 November 2017 to 31 January 2018. For the first time, the three groups made the announcement in a joint statement.
Unknown gunmen shot and killed a man at his home in El Wehda district, Nerteti town in Central Darfur. Date and reason unclear - report dated 1 December.
Unknown gunmen wearing military uniforms shot and killed a displaced man from Nierteti North camp in Central Darfur. Circumstances unclear.
Unknown gunmen killed a displaced woman on her way from camp Hamidiya to camp Khamsa Dagayeg in Central Darfur.
SPLM-N led by Agar claimed to have repulsed a government attack on its positions in Kakr area north-west of Baw district in Blue Nile, leaving four soldiers killed and capturing material.

column7: Unidentified Armed Group (Egypt); Unidentified Armed Group (Syria)
column17: Arrests: Explosion at a residential building as an explosive device made by a suspect detonated in Khartoum, injuring one of the suspects. Police uncovered base ingredients for fabricating a bomb and arrested 26 foreigners from Arab countries (mainly Egypt and Syria) and 1 Sudanese in connection with the event.
A UXO detonation left a man killed and a woman with both hands blown off at Kaja area north of Shangil Tobaya in Dar El Salam locality in North Darfur.
Policemen reportedly beat and assaulted a blind man in El Gedaref after he criticised the financial and administrative corruption at the Union of the Blind. Date unclear report dated 3 December.
Herders from Chad shot and killed a farmer in Jebel Moon locality in West Darfur as he tried to protect his farm against cattle grazing.

Non-violent activity: The Sudanese opposition umbrella National Consensus Forces (NCF) announced its boycott of the planned 2020 general elections, stressing its rejection of any calls to a political settlement that keeps in place the regime and its political and economic policies, and calling for popular uprising against the current government

SPLM-N led by Agar claimed to have destroyed a government convoy at Jabal Badoba and Khour Zaroug areas, northeast of Jebel Tora in Baw district in Blue Nile, leaving seven soldiers killed and 28 injured.
An unknown criminal stabbed to death a retired South Sudanese soldier in Al-Obeid town in North Kordofan. Circumstances unclear.
University students in western Kordofan held protests on 6 and 7 December against the deterioration of services at El Fula University. Police did not interfere.

Renewed clashes between residents of El Jireif in Khartoum and police over the demolition of brick factories in the area. Six people were injured and seven others arrested. Police also later arrested a member of the Sudanese Congress Party (SCP) in relations to the protest.
University students in western Kordofan held protests on 6 and 7 December against the deterioration of services at El Fula University. Police did not interfere.
Hundreds of people protested in the Sudanese capital Khartoum against the decision of U.S. President to recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital.
Armed herders beat and raped at gunpoint two girls collecting firwood in Foro Baranga in West Darfur.
Armed herders assaulted and injured six displaced women who were collecting straw in Tawila locality in North Darfur.

Members of the Bishareen tribe led a peaceful demonstration to protest the activities of a government-contracted mining company to search for gold in a number of archaeological sites in Wadi El Alagi in Halayeb a an area contested by both Sudan and Egypt. Two activists were then summoned to NISS offices in Port Sudan. They were released soon after but arrested again a week later on their way to the archaeological site.
A group of six armed herders attacked two displaced women who were collecting firewood north of Nierteti in Central Darfur for several hours. One of the women was pregnant.

column6: SPLM-N-NMLC: Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement (North) (Nuba Mountains Liberation Council Faction)
column17: SPLM-N led by Agar claimed that the forces of the other SPLM-N faction led by al Hilu recently killed one of their army major in Blue Nile, leading to renewed fighting between the two factions. Date unclear - report dated 15 December.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Report of intra- group fighting among SLA/AW members in Deribat in East Jebel Marra in November and December 2017, resulting in the killing and injury of civilians, destruction of houses, looting of community assets and in the displacement of hundreds of people.
Two armed herders repeatedly raped a displaced girl collecting firewood north of Nierteti in Central Darfur.

On 17 December, the Mahadi and Birgid communities clashed in Hash area, resulting in one fatality on each side. In 2017, the two communities had disputes over land ownership on the border between Graida and Yasin localities. On 18 December, government forces were deployed to contain the situation and RSF was mandated to collect weapons from the parties. On 21 December, four umdas and seven youth were arrested.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF forces raided the Dato market in Dito unit, Gereida locality in South Darfur under the pretext of arms collection, beating residents indiscriminately with sticks that left three injured, 16 arrested and a quantity of cash and goods stolen. The RSF siege - including the beatings - was continuing as of two days later. RSF continued beating the residents with rifle butts, sticks and directing verbal and racist insults.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Residents of Tullus locality in South Darfur reported being assaulted by RSF members as part of the disarmament campaign, with 11 people subjected to beatings on the week of 18 December.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF forces raided the Dato market in Dito unit, Gereida locality in South Darfur under the pretext of arms collection, beating residents indiscriminately with sticks that left three injured, 16 arrested and a quantity of cash and goods stolen. The RSF siege - including the beatings - was continuing as of two days later. RSF continued beating the residents with rifle butts, sticks and directing verbal and racist insults.
On 19 December, three police personnel reportedly gang raped a female IDP while in detention in Nyala, South Darfur.
Hundreds of citizens of the disputed area of Abyei held a peaceful protest demanding that UNISFA recruits locals in various job vacancies.

A group of 12 armed herders affiliated to Omda Dagahsh attacked displaced women collecting firewood near Tabit in North Darfur. They beat them with rifle butts, sticks and whips and severely injured eight of them. They claimed that the land was a grazing area, not a land for collecting firewood.
On 20 December 2017, unidentified gunmen opened fire on the residents of Shuru village near Balila in El Salam locality (West Kordofan state) killing two.

On 20 December 2017, and following an attack in Shuru village near Balila in El Salam locality (West Kordofan state) leaving two killed, a local rescue team set up after the incident to apprehend the alleged killers (coded as West Kordofan Communal Militia) hunted down a boy and killed him.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Arrests: Between 16-20 December, RSF arrested 45 people in the framework of the campaign to collect weapons in North, Central and West Darfur, including students, Omdas, sheikhs, mosque imams and traders.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF forces raided the Dato market in Dito unit, Gereida locality in South Darfur under the pretext of arms collection, beating residents indiscriminately with sticks that left three injured, 16 arrested and a quantity of cash and goods stolen. The RSF siege - including the beatings - was continuing as of two days later. RSF continued beating the residents with rifle butts, sticks and directing verbal and racist insults.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF militiamen stormed the Abola IDP camp in the Sadoun area of Gireida locality, beating people and sheiks with whips and sticks, leaving nine people injured, robbing them of their belongings and arresting 20.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Border Guards
column17: Three members of the paramilitary Border Guards repeatedly raped two girls at gunpoint south of Nierteti in Central Darfur as they were collecting firewood. Army and police forces arrested one of the perpetrators.
25 December. Four civilian clothed armed men tried to rape three IDP women in Balda area, 7km north of IDP Hamidya camp
On 26 December, four women were severely beaten by three armed militiamen at Dankoj, east of Zalingei.

SPLM-N under the leadership of Malik Agar extended its unilateral cessation of hostilities for six months in Blue Nile state. In parallel, the group declined to join an initiative launched by the Popular Congress Party (PCP) for peace and constitutional reforms based on the recommendations of the National Dialogue Conference.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF attacked the Abuja market at camp Aradeiba in Garsila, Wadi Saleh locality in Central Darfur, beating displaced people, including wounding one with a bullet, and stealing their property. Date unclear - report dated 28 December.

Angry students broke-down walls at the Shambat Agricultural Complex and another faculty at the University of Khartoum in protest against the dismissal of students a year prior after their alleged involvement in protests against the sale of the university buildings in central Khartoum. They also reportedly broke the doors of a nearby mosque.

President al-Bashir declared a six-month state of emergency in North Kordofan and Kassala states to support the launch of a disarmament campaign and to combat other criminal activities in these states. The following week, thousands of RSF troops were moved to Kassala and by 9 January, 70 had been arrested. Activists have denounced the government's attempt to control protests in the country through this measure, amid harsh economic conditions.

column9: Aid Workers (International); UN: United Nations; Women (International)
column17: ""One female UN international staff member was walking to work in the Al Riyadh area of Khartoum when she was attacked by two men on a motorcycle. The men dragged her behind the motorcycle for a distance and then physically assaulted her, biting off her thumb in the attack. The aid worker had to be medically evacuated to Nairobi to receive treatment for extensive injuries. Robbery is the suspected motive for the attack.""

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Relatives of political detainee Radwan Daoud staged a protest vigil in front of NISS' Information Office in Khartoum II. During the vigil, NISS officers briefly detained two. Date unclear - report dated 31 December. Daoud was arrested early December for leading protests with the SCP against the demolition of brick factories in the capital.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Clashes between RSF elements who had refused to pay for a meal at Otash camp near Nyala, South Darfur, and a group of IDPs. One report says the IDPs beat and injured the RSF militiamen, arrested them and handed them over to the authorities; other report says RSF opened fire on people when an IDP confronted them after they raided the Komboi market, seriously injuring two.

Unidentified gunmen opened fire on a state medical supply vehicle, wounding the director of a hospital and his driver in Hijer Jabir, Um Keddada locality. They were on an official mission for periodic supervision and to open pharmacies in Hijer Jabir and El Taweisha hospitals.
Armed herders beat and injured seven displaced women collecting firewood north of Otash camp, South Darfur. Date unclear - report dated 3 January.
Armed herders shot and killed two men working at a brick factory in El Adradib El Ashara in North Darfur's Tawila locality. Reasons unclear.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Looting: RSF carried out a surprise raid on the Kass market, demolishing dozens of stalls owned by displaced people and subejcting the IDPs to abuses such as ripping a man's trousers deemed indecent, seizing of property and ripping the ID cards of some people. Date unclear - report dated 4 January.
Protests in Atbara over increased consumer prices following the implementation of new budget measures.

Limited demonstrations over increased consumer prices following the implementation of new budget measures hit several neighbourhoods of Khartoum (Al-Sahafa, Al-Kalakla, Burri, El Jereif, Jabra). The protesters burned car tires to block some streets. Members of the security apparatus, the police and the paramilitary Central Reserve Police used tear gas and batons to disperse the demonstrators. Some threw tear gas canisters inside houses, which caused breathing problems to the residents, in particular the children and the elderly.

Limited demonstrations over increased consumer prices following the implementation of new budget measures hit several neighbourhoods of Khartoum (Al-Sahafa, Al-Kalakla, Burri, El Jereif, Jabra). The protesters burned car tires to block some streets. Members of the security apparatus, the police and the paramilitary Central Reserve Police used tear gas and batons to disperse the demonstrators. Some threw tear gas canisters inside houses, which caused breathing problems to the residents, in particular the children and the elderly.

Dozens of demonstrators gathered spontaneously in front of the vegetable market in Halfa El Jadida in Kassala after Friday prayers to protest the increased consumer prices following the implementation of new budget measures.
Protests in Sennar over increased consumer prices following the implementation of new budget measures.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF members raided the Amarjadeed market in Wadi Saleh locality, Central Darfur, and severely beat the merchants and crop owners who opposed their order to limit crop prices and to keep them in the area. Date unclear - report dated 5 January.

Limited demonstrations over increased consumer prices following the implementation of new budget measures hit several neighbourhoods of Wad Medani in Gezira state ( Al-Mazad, Shendi Foug, Al-Hilla Al-Jadida, Al-Dibaga, El Asheer, and Banat). Some of them set fire to tyres to close the roads. Police used tear gas and batons to disperse the protesters, leaving some injured, and arrested several protesters.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF militiamen raided the area of Fallujah in South Darfur's East Jebal Marra, and severely beat and detained two community leaders, whom they accused of being behind the disappearance of a number livestock in the area ten days prior.

Limited demonstrations over increased consumer prices following the implementation of new budget measures hit several neighbourhoods of Wad Medani in Gezira state ( Al-Mazad, Shendi Foug, Al-Hilla Al-Jadida, Al-Dibaga, El Asheer, and Banat). Police used tear gas and batons to disperse the protesters, leaving some injured, and arrested several protesters. Some of them set fire to tyres to close the roads.

Limited demonstrations over increased consumer prices following the implementation of new budget measures hit several neighbourhoods of Khartoum (Al-Sahafa, Al-Kalakla, Burri, El Jereif, Jabra). The protesters burned car tires to block some streets. Members of the security apparatus, the police and the paramilitary Central Reserve Police used tear gas and batons to disperse the demonstrators. Some threw tear gas canisters inside houses, which caused breathing problems to the residents, in particular the children and the elderly.

Limited demonstrations over increased consumer prices following the implementation of new budget measures hit several neighbourhoods of Khartoum (Al-Sahafa, Al-Kalakla, Burri, El Jereif, Jabra). The protesters burned car tires to block some streets. Members of the security apparatus, the police and the paramilitary Central Reserve Police used tear gas and batons to disperse the demonstrators. Some threw tear gas canisters inside houses, which caused breathing problems to the residents, in particular the children and the elderly.

Limited demonstrations over increased consumer prices following the implementation of new budget measures hit several neighbourhoods of Khartoum (Al-Sahafa, Al-Kalakla, Burri, El Jereif, Jabra). The protesters burned car tires to block some streets. Members of the security apparatus, the police and the paramilitary Central Reserve Police used tear gas and batons to disperse the demonstrators. Some threw tear gas canisters inside houses, which caused breathing problems to the residents, in particular the children and the elderly.
Three armed herders attacked a group of four women collecting firewood in Tawila locality in North Darfur. One was abducted while the three others managed to flee.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Movement of forces: The Sudanese government deployed thousands of RSF troops along its border with Eritrea in Kassala State, closed its border with Eritrea, and formed a higher committee for popular mobilization, as result of perceived military threats from Eritrea and Egypt. Sudan recalled its ambassador to Cairo after criticism in the government media later December and reports have claimed that Egyptian troops were amassing in the Sawa region, near the Sudanese border.
Protests continued for a second day in Sennar over increased consumer prices following the implementation of new budget measures.
Protests continued for a second day in Khartoum over increased consumer prices following the implementation of new budget measures.
Protests continued for a second day in Atbara over increased consumer prices following the implementation of new budget measures.

People protested in Ed Damazin over increased consumer prices, burning down two houses in El Zuhour district. Police used tear gas and force to break up the demonstrations, arresting dozens of demonstrators, among them a number of students of the Blue Nile University.

Unknown gunmen on horses opened fire on a displaced couple collecting firewood near Niertiti camp, Central Darfur, leaving one killed and the other injured. The camp residents protested in front of the police against their inaction after the incident was filed. Police fired teargas and shots in the air to disperse them.
Protests continued in Ed Damazin over increased consumer prices.

Unknown gunmen on horses opened fire on a displaced couple collecting firewood near Niertiti camp, Central Darfur, leaving one killed and the other injured. The camp residents protested in front of the police against their inaction after the incident was filed. Police fired teargas and shots in the air to disperse them.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Protests continued for a second day in Ed Damazin over increased consumer prices. NISS arrested at least one activist.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Protests continued for a third day in Khartoum over increased consumer prices. Some threw stones at the police. Police fired teargas to disperse a demonstration of students of the University of Khartoum, leaving some students wounded and dozens arrested. NISS arrested and detained three SCoP leaders (the party's chairman, former chairman and human rights secretary) in connection with the protests in Khartoum and North Kordofan on that day, as well as confiscated a number of copies of newspapers reporting on the bread price hikes.

column9: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Students demonstrated in Nyala, South Darfur, over increased consumer prices and blocked three major streets by setting car tires alight. Police and RSF fired teargas and batons to disperse the rioting students.

Students demonstrated in El Geneina, West Darfur, over increased consumer prices and set fire to the local headquarters of the ruling NCP in the city. Police opened fire on the students, leaving one killed, eight injured and dozens detained. From eight to 15 teachers were arrested on charges of inciting the demonstrations, with four released soon after.

Female students at the Ahfad University for Women in Khartoums twin city of Omdurman protested against increased consumer prices. Police arrived but the university administration closed the univerity doors to protect the women students.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
