column17: Students from the University of Khartoum continued to protest the price hikes over 8-10 January. On the 8th, police fired teargas to disperse them and arrested several, leading some students to throw stones at them. At least three students belonging to the student arm of the opposition Sudanese Congress Party (SCoP) were arrested during the wave of protests.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: NISS detained a pharmacy employee and five other employees of the Gireida hospital in South Darfur, over allegedly illegally selling medicines from the hospital's pharmacy. One of the workers died a week later in detention from torture.
Clashes between armed herders and police over grazing land in Sergaila area, Tullus County, South Darfur, left two police officers killed.

Students from the University of Khartoum continued to protest the price hikes over 8-10 January. On the 9th, some students threw stones at police while police fired teargas to disperse them and arrested several. At least three students belonging to the student arm of the opposition Sudanese Congress Party (SCoP) were arrested during the wave of protests.

Students protested at the Kosti Technical School in White Nile state against expensive breakfasts amid increased consumer prices. Police arrested and held 34 students before releasing them the same evening.

Students from the University of Khartoum continued to protest the price hikes over 8-10 January. On the 9th, some students threw stones at police while police fired teargas to disperse them and arrested several. At least three students belonging to the student arm of the opposition Sudanese Congress Party (SCoP) were arrested during the wave of protests.

Female students at the Ahfad University for Women in Omdurman protested against increased consumer prices. The Dean of the university slapped and kicked the young women to punish them. No report of injury. He later apologised for his behaviour.
A UXO explosion near El Mawashi market in El Fasher, North Darfur, left a child killed.

Armed herders killed a factory worker in Dulu west of Tawila in North Darfur. Armed herders have threatened to beat or kill anyone who comes to this area to collect wood or go farming. Similar attacks occurred the week before in the Tawila area.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019)
column17: A joint force of RSF, police and military officers raided the Nertiti IDP camp in Central Darfur as part of the disarmament campaign and beat and injured at least three displaced people, accuding them of supporting the rebels and hiding their weapons.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: A force of RSF soldiers searched the area of Tur in Nierteti, Central Darfur, for illegal weapons and beat a number of residents.

A soldier shot and killed two students at the Delling University in South Kordofan, before shooting himself. Reasons are unclear. Delling university students demonstrated against the violence at the police station and the morgue where the bodies were brought the same day.

A soldier shot and killed two students at the Delling University in South Kordofan, before shooting himself. Reasons are unclear. Delling university students demonstrated against the violence at the police station and the morgue where the bodies were brought the same day.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Arrests: On 11 January, RSF arrested 8 Fur and 20 Arab sheikhs at the North and Straha IDP camps in Central Darfur to gather information about people possessing weapons and hiding places.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019)
column17: Students from the University of Delling, South Kordofan, blocked the university entrance and set fire to university buildings in protest against the killing of two of their colleagues by a soldier the day before. NISS along with police and military forces detained 117 students. A majority were charged and released soon after, but five students have remained in detention incommunicado, raising fears for their safety.
Unknown militiamen beat seven displaced women from the Hamidiya IDP camp, Zalingei locality in Central Darfur, and raped two of them.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF members abducted three girls from their family houses in Birkatuli village in Abu Ajura, El Salam locality. They released them the following evening. Residents demonstrated against the repeated abductions in the area over farms, water resources and roads. It is unclear if the protest occurred on or after 13 January.

column7: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column16: Sudan Tribune; Radio Dabanga; Reporters Sans Frontieres
column17: Hundreds of Sudanese took the streets in Khartoum to protest against the recent price hikes. They managed to penetrate a cordon of security forces deployed to prevent the march from taking place. Police used tear gas and batons to disperse them. NISS arrested more than 50 protestors including two members of the SCP Central Committee as well as 13 independent local media and international correspondents covering the protests. At least one journalist was beaten and injured during his arrest.
A journalist is targeted and assaulted by security forces while covering protests. The journalist was then detained for several days where reports of torture occurred.

column7: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Hundreds of Sudanese led by opposition parties held a vigil in the streets in Omdurman to protest against the recent price hikes. Police arrested two SCoP and NUP members as well as some of their family members before the protest. During the protest, police fired teargas to disperse the protesters and arrested another 35 people including two Reuters and AFP correspondents. The following day, the head of NUP was also arrested for calling out the vigil.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 18 January, RSF and SLM-AW clashed in Kurmul village, north-east of Golo in Jebel Marra and near Kati village, 15 km south-east of Golo during a weapons collection campaign in the area. One RSF officer killed and one injured.

University students and residents in Port Sudan held public speeches and demonstrations against the recent price increases and calling for overthrowing the regime. Police broke up the rally and arrested three students.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 18 January, RSF and SLM-AW clashed in Kurmul village, north-east of Golo in Jebel Marra and near Kati village, 15 km south-east of Golo during a weapons collection campaign in the area. One RSF officer killed and one injured.
Police fired teargas to disperse worshippers at Al-Ansar mosque in Rabak, White Nile State, who staged a demonstration against the price hikes. No reported injury.
Police fired teargas to disperse worshippers at Burri neighbourhood, in eastern Khartoum, who staged a demonstration against the price hikes after Friday prayers. No reported injury.
Police fired teargas to disperse worshippers at Al-Ansar mosque in Wad Nubawi neighbourhood of Omdurman who staged a demonstration against the price hikes. No reported injury.

On 19 January 2018, clash between pro-government militiamen who raided the Hasahisa camp market in Zalingei, Central Darfur and camp residents who went to arrest them left four people wounded. After the skirmish, the camp residents staged a protest march against the rampant insecurity in the area. Security forces and militiamen fired live bullets at the protesters, leaving at least one killed and 26 injured (camp coordinators claimed two were killed). Some of the protesters reportedly threw stones at the forces.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column17: Looting: Members of the Sudanese military intelligence raided a man's house in Tur in Central Darfur, beat him and took him to the Nierteti military garrison. The following day, another man was arrested. No mentioned injuries in both cases. The two men were suspected of supporting the rebel SPLM-N.

Clash between pro-government militiamen who raided the Hasahisa camp market in Zalingei, Central Darfur and camp residents who went to arrest them left four people wounded. After the skirmish, the camp residents staged a protest march against the rampant insecurity in the area. Security forces and militiamen fired live bullets at the protesters, leaving at least one killed and 26 injured (camp coordinators claimed two were killed). Some of the protesters reportedly threw stones at the forces.
On 20 January, Fur IDPs clashed with IDPs from the Beni Halba host community in Zalingei. Four IDPs and one Beni Halba killed, 38 injured.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: A suspected RSF member raped a young girl near Um Jahara village, north Saraf Omra in North Darfur.
Pro-government militia members beat residents from the Hasahisa camp at their farms in Wadi Zur and Grash, two km northeast of the camp near Zalingei, Central Darfur, leaving four wounded.

Residents in Abyei staged a peaceful demonstration against discrimination in UNISFA's selection of projects in the area. They claimed the peacekeepers focused road renovations only in areas inhabited by the Misseriya tribesmen. Date unclear - report dated 24 January.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 24 January, RSF clashed with suspected JEM-Gibril members entering from South Sudan at the border village of Kalabah, 250 km south of Ed Daein. Three fatalities.

Reports that the military police has carried out a campaign of arbitrarily extra-judiciary flogging of women and girls for days in the markets and the public streets of El Fasher on charges of wearing indecent clothing. Date unclear - report dated 24 January.

A gathering of young people to discuss the government's economic policies at a bus station near the Khartoum Stadium in the evening turned into a demonstration. The protesters called upon the Sudanese 'to revolt and uproot the regime'.

NUP activists staged a protest in front of El Hijra Mosque in Omdurman after the midday prayers, calling on the people to join resistance committees in the Khartoum neighbourhoods and to participate in a mass demonstration scheduled for the following week.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Report that some activists detained in the last wave of protests against increased consumer prices in January were subjected to torture and ill-treatment while in NISS detention. At least 306 political opponents were arrested during the wave of protests and as of 27 January, 79 remained detained incommunicado.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Sudanese riot police (NISS) used tear gas and batons to disperse large protests against price hikes and deteriorating living conditions at several areas in Khartoum North. Police made several arrests.

On 31 January, Fur IDPs from the Hamidiya camp in Zalingei clashed with the Beni Halba host community as the latter prevented them from collecting wood in Boronka area. Police created a buffer zone around Hasahisa camp as a result.

column7: DUP-UM: Democratic Unionist Party-Unionist Movement; NUP: National Umma Party; SCP-Democratic Front: Sudanese Communist Party-Democratic Front
column17: In Singa in Blue Nile state, 13 people were detained on January 31 during a violent demonstration aimed against the high prices for basic goods following the higher taxes in the country, The detainees include leading members of the Umma Party, the Communist Party and the Democratic Unionist Party.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Rapid Support Forces reportedly beat and torture six detainees in the Saraf Omra Prison 'last week.' Source dated 07/02.

Unidentified gunmen on 1/02 kidnapped a resident of East Darfur State capital, Ed-Daein from his home and took him to an unknown destination. He was released a week later, while the abductors were arrested in West Darfur.

South Sudanese and Misseriya tribesmen clashed over cattle on three occasions between 01/02 and 22/02 at El Darab, Um Geroun, and Um Kadma areas of El Dibab locality, West Kordofan. More than 46 people were killed in these clashes.

column9: NUP: National Umma Party; SCP-Democratic Front: Sudanese Communist Party-Democratic Front
column17: Arrests: Sudanese security agents have arrested the deputy head of the country's main opposition Umma Party and a leader of the Sudanese Communist Party after it held anti-government rallies to protest.
Unidentified gunmen attacked and killed a police officer and sacked a village at Bulbul Dalal El Angara, 56 km southwest of Nyala on 03/02.

Change to armed group: A militant gunman named 'Aheimer', together with 27 men from the Shatta created a kind of administrative rule in the area of Abu Ajura by force of arms. The group set up a court system to impose fines and punishments.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: A North Darfur restaurant owner has allegedly been 'tortured to death' by paramilitaries of the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) after his wife was beaten until she miscarried. The reason for the attack is not known.

On February 4, in Khartoum city (Khartoum), the Sudan Revolutionary Front (SRF) led by Minni Minnawi and the Sudan People's Liberation Movement (SPLM-N) agreed to reunite the umbrella of the armed opposition groups and to reinvigorate the Sudan Call alliance.
El Obeid witnessed a peaceful demonstration carried out by university students against the rise of prices.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Arrests: Sudanese security agents in Western Kordofan State arrested a leader of the opposition Sudanese Congress Party, Ahmed Issa Bakhit on orders of the governor.

Armed herders have abducted a man and four women, raping several of them near Tabit (at Kondro and Keila) in North Darfur. Two herders attacked three women on their way to Keila, 12 kilometres west of El Malam, after collecting firewood. The women later reported that the assailants attempted to rape them, a sheikh in El Malam told Radio Dabanga.
Protests continue in El Obeid for a second day.

Sudanese anti-riot police forces filled the streets of Al-Jeraif east suburb, 7.83 km from Khartoum to prevent a planned demonstration against the rising prices organized by the opposition Unionists Alliance. The police arrested activists who tried to reach the square.
Armed herders raided a farmer's land in Shataya locality in South Darfur on 08/02, shooting him dead and severely injuring two of his relatives.
Unidentified gunmen abducted a civilian at the Shaabi market in Omdurman on 08/02 evening. Reasons unclear.
Agreement: Sudan released one of the leaders of the Justice and Equality Movement (JEM), Jibril Tiya, after eight years in detention on Friday.

Gunfight between armed herders and a rapidly formed search group of IDPs near Nertiti in Central Darfur left a displaced boy killed on 09/02. The herders had earlier attacked the IDPs as they were returning home after collecting firewood west of Nierteti, seizing their donkeys and crops.

South Sudanese and Misseriya tribesmen clashed over cattle on three occasions between 01/02 and 22/02 at El Darab, Um Geroun, and Um Kadma areas of El Dibab locality, West Kordofan. More than 46 people were killed in these clashes.
A group of three armed herders shot at a farmer while he was collecting firewood near Dolo village north of Fanga, Tawila locality in North Darfur, on 11/02, leaving him injured
Agreement: Members of the Ziyud and Awlad Omran clans of the Misseriya tribe in West Kordofan reached a peace and reconciliation agreement in Al-Fula on 11/02.

Students at the Shambat complex of the University of Khartoum clashed after those supporting the ruling NCP attacked a student speaking to fellow students about the alleged rigging of the students' union elections by the NCP students. Police fired teargas and live bullets to disperse the rioters, leaving four injured and two arrested. A number of students went missing. 17 students were evicted from their dorms by the National Students Support Fund two days later over their participation in the clash. A number of university students went on strike in support over 14/02 and 15/02, demanding the return of the evicted students and an investigation into the events.

Zaghawa militiamen from Chad attacked the village of Mistry in Beida locality, West Darfur, leaving nine people killed from the Rizaigat tribe, eight injured, stealing 460 heads of cattle, and heading back to Chad.
Civil society organizations in Abyei staged protests against UNISFA on 12/02 for failing to replace the head of the UNISFA engineering unit. Similar protests had occurred a month prior.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF militiamen shot dead a merchant at his house in Kassala on 12/02 as he sought to protect a group of youth that the militiamen were pursuing after seizing their belongings.

Militiamen beat, stabbed and robbed an unknown number of displaced people who had returned to Marla in Bielel locality, South Darfur, on 13/02, leaving five seriously wounded. In total, 600 displaced people had left Kalma, Dereig and El Salam camps in South Darfur to return to Marla in Bielel locality. 14 militiamen were later arrested in connection with the attack.

South Sudanese and Misseriya tribesmen clashed over cattle on three occasions between 01/02 and 22/02 at El Darab, Um Geroun, and Um Kadma areas of El Dibab locality, West Kordofan. More than 46 people were killed in these clashes.
An unknown gunman shot dead a resident of the Kendebbe IDP camp in West Darfur's Sirba after he refused to hand over his belongings to him on his way home from prayers with a group of other IDPs.
Militiamen raped a displaced girl as she was collecting straw with three boys near an IDP camp at Tagali Wamagali, west of Shangil Tobaya, North Darfur on 16/02.

The camp residents marched to the UNAMID base in Sortony after militiamen shot dead and mutilated a boy as he was collecting firewood with three other boys near the Sortony IDP camp in North Darfur on 17/02.

column8: SPLM-N-NMLC: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North) (Nuba Mountains Liberation Council Faction)
column17: Clashes between the SPLM-N faction led by Agar and that led by al-Hilu at Gouz Al-Bagar area in Blue Nile on 17/02 as Agar's forces moved from Ras Al-khor to Tanfona. The clashes continued at least until the next day. Dozens killed and thousands of people displaced.

Militiamen shot dead and mutilated a boy as he was collecting firewood with three other boys near the Sortony IDP camp in North Darfur on 17/02. On the same day, militiamen also kidnapped two brothers south of the same camp - the body of one of them was found two days later while the other remained detained. The camp residents marched to the UNAMID base in Sortony following the incidents to call for better protection.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: A clash between RSF militiamen and people at the Ed El Fursan market in South Darfur left seven injured. Reasons and date are unclear - report dated 18 February.

South Sudanese gunmen attacked a Misseriya cattle camp in in Keilik in northern Abu Kadma area, West Kordofan, on 18/02, leaving at least six people killed, dozens injured and thousands of heads of cattle stolen. The Misseriya chiefs accused South Sudanese SPLA soldiers of conducting the raid. Other sources put the number of fatalities at 36.

column8: SPLM-N-NMLC: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North) (Nuba Mountains Liberation Council Faction)
column17: Clashes between the SPLM-N faction led by Agar and that led by al-Hilu at Gouz Al-Bagar area in Blue Nile on 17/02 as Agar's forces moved from Ras Al-khor to Tanfona. The clashes continued at least until the next day. Dozens killed and thousands of people displaced.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Abu Tira
column17: A joint NISS/Abu Tira force raided the Hijeirat market in West Kordofan on 20/02, arresting eight youths on charge of vehicle theft. One of the youths died in detention a few days later from beatings and torture, while another was left in critical condition.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Abu Tira
column17: Unknown gunmen shot an Abu Tira member south of Keilik in West Kordofan on 22/02. After the incident, members of the Abu Tira reserve force raided the Keilik market, beating people with rifle butts and batons and setting dozens of shops on fire. Several people were injured. A curfew was placed on Keilik after the incidents.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Abu Tira
column17: Unknown gunmen shot an Abu Tira member south of Keilik in West Kordofan on 22/02. After the incident, members of the Abu Tira reserve force raided the Keilik market, beating people with rifle butts and batons and setting dozens of shops on fire. Several people were injured. A curfew was placed on Keilik after the incidents.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column9: DUP-UM: Democratic Unionist Party-Unionist Movement; NUP: National Umma Party; SCP: Sudanese Congress Party; Sudanese Baath Party
column17: Arrests: NISS detained the vice-president of the Sudanese Congress Party (SCP) in Khartoum on 23/02. The following day, seven other opposition leaders from the Communist Party of Sudan (CPoS), the National Umma Party, the Democratic Unionist Party, the Socialist Baath Party, and the Sudanese Baath Party were held in El Obeid, the North Kordofan capital. Six were released soon after.

The families of opposition leaders and political activists who have remained in detention since the last wave of protests over increased bread prices gathered at the opposition National Umma Party (NUP) headquarters in Khartoum on 24/02 carrying pictures and banners denouncing the detention of their relatives and calling on president Bashir to release them. Hundreds are believed to remain in detention without charge.
Military forces stationed at the Deribat base reportedly shelled the Tala village, west of Dubo El Omda in Tawila locality, on 26/02, leaving a child killed.
A UXO blast left a woman who was collecting firewood in the area amputated of one led south of Fanga, in Eastern Jebel Marra on 26/02.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF militiamen opened fire on people at the Misteriya market in Kabkabiya locality, North Darfur, on 27/02, killing one person and leaving ten people wounded.
Unidentified gunmen opened fire on people in the area of Libei in Tawila locality, North Darfur, on 27/02, leaving three dead, two wounded and stealing 300 heads of cattle.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Fashoda state officials in South Sudan claimed that the rebel SPLA-IO clashed with Sudanese forces in North Kordofan on or around 27/02.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: RSF militiamen beat people with rifle butts and sticks as they came looking for three men at the Gireida IDP camp in South Darfur on 28/02. Several people were seriously injured, while the RSF militiamen also stole cash and other property.
Armed herders intercepted a number of villagers north of Nierteti in Central Darfur on 01/03, beating them with whips and stealing all their belongings.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: 01 March. The RSF captured the commander of Sudan Liberation Army-Historical Leadership (SLA-Historical Leadership), Suleiman Marjane and two fighters in Jebel Isa area in North Darfur.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 3 March, RSF forces ambushed a villager returning from Tur market in Central Darfur, beating him severely and stealing his property. The villager was injured.
On 3 March, the SPLM-N Agar faction claimed government forces attacked their positions in Alrom area, Blue Nile state. Injuries mentioned on the government's side, though unclear if any fatalities.

The SPLM-N Agar announced a unilateral cessation of hostilities in the Blue Nile State from 03/03, after recent clashes with the rival faction led by Al Hilu, and accepted a mediation proposed by the UN special envoy for Sudan and South Sudan to end inter-SPLM-N factions hostilities.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Border Guards
column17: On 4 March, three Border Guards militiamen ambushed a villager returning after having collected firewood in Niertiti in Central Darfur and beat him severely. The villager was injured.

column7: WFP: World Food Programme; Aid Workers (Sudan)
column17: On 4 March, more than 260 former WFP employees carried out a vigil in El Fasher, North Darfur, to protest their dismissal and demand the payment of their allowances.
On 4 March, an unexploded ordnance exploded in Tobo county in the Nuba mountains while policemen were on a demining mission. Two policemen injured.
On 5 March, unknown gunmen shot at a villager collecting firewood near Sharfa village, south of Tabit in North Darfur. The villager was injured.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On the week of 5 March, a joint military-RSF force beat civilians from the Fur tribe with sticks, whips and rifle butts during a weapons collection exercise in Artala, Central Darfur.

On 5 March, police clashed with rioters from Berber locality at a foreign mining company in Singeir, River Nile. One dead and at least six injured. The clash was sparked by a dispute over ownership of the site, recently attributed to a Russian company. The rioters attempted to remove people from the site, burned vehicles and engaged the policemen at the site.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Arrests: On 6 March, RSF forces captured a former SLM commander (Suleiman Marjan) near Jabel Issa of Malha district in North Darfur. He had been relieved from his functions as chairman of the SARC in November 2017 and confessed to recruiting youths for JEM in Libya.
On 7 March, armed herders shot dead the head Sheikh of the Munei IDP camp while he was working on his farm in Arum area, west of Murnei, West Darfur.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 9 March, government and SLM-AW forces clashed in the Jawa area, 15km south of Deribat in East Jebel Marra. Three civilians wounded in the crossfire.

On 10 March, armed herders attacked civilians at Tuma village east of Kutum in North Darfur. Several injured and three kidnapped who were released two days later. The civilians had returned to Tuma village the previous month as part of the voluntary repatriation programme.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 10 March, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) attacked a camp of the Military Forces of Sudan in Jawa, South Darfur. The clashes between the SLM/A-Nur and the Military Forces of Sudan on 10-11 March in Jawa and near Dirbat left five soldiers and three SLM/A-Nur combatants dead and several civilians injured.

On 11 March, new settlers assaulted a group of 400 displaced people returning to their village in Areit in Asalaya locality, East Darfur through the voluntary repatriation programme. At least two injured. The displaced poeple were sent back to the Neem camp the following day.
On 11 March, Sudanese forces beat people with rifle butts and daggers at the Deribat weekly market in Darfur. Six injured and eight arrested.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 11 March, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) ambushed a military convoy near Bumuye, about 8km north-east of Dirbat. The clashes between the SLM/A-Nur and the Military Forces of Sudan on 10-11 March in Jawa and near Dirbat left five soldiers and three SLM/A-Nur combatants dead and several civilians injured.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 13 March, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) exchange fire with Nawaiba Ethnic Militia in Durgo, Central Darfur. The day before, the SLM/A-Nur had rustled camels from Nawaiba nomads. The Nawaiba militia burned down the village and population fled to Boori, Dar al-Salam and Golo. Three civilians were killed in the crossfire.
""Recently"", militiamen led by Abdallah Ganga killed at least three people at the fate of Umm Laota, wets of Kabkabiya. Parts of the village were burnt down. Report dated 13 March.

On 14 March, three armed herders stabbed a farmer and chopped-off his hand while he was tiling his farm in Suri area in Tawila locality, North Darfur. The farmer was sent to the hospital in a critical condition.
On 14 March, police beat and injured six boys with eletrict wires while in custody in Ghebeish, West Kordofan. The boys were arrested after a confrontation at a soccer game.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) University Police
column17: On 15 March, a clash broke out between two students from the University of Sennar (Abu Naama Faculty of Agriculture) and one of the university police guards. The two students were arrested while another seven were dismissed for holding a public speech after the incident to denounce the police behaviour.
On 17 March, cattle raiders killed two people and injured two in Goko village, north of Nyala.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 17 March, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) killed two members of the Nawaiba ethnic group in Durgo, Central Darfur. No injuries.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On or around 17 March, members of the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia beat with whips two market traders in Sagadir, leaving them severely injured. RSF accused one merchant of selling shoes with too high a price and another of supplying sorghum to armed movements.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 17 March, members of the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia beat and abducted the Sheikh of Dimo village. No fatalities.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On or around 18 March, protestors were beaten and assaulted with batons and whips by the police and Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia in Mellit, North Darfur. Teitel residents in Mellit protested the redistribution of their land for a housing plan. Eleven people were arrested.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Over 21-22 March, SLM-AW forces led by Abdel-Wahid al-Nur and the military forces of South Sudan clashed in Feina, Fuguli and Leiba areas in Jabal Marrah, as the government forces had been deployed there on 17-19 March. Witnesses said the state forces regained these territories, while SLA/AW claimed to have repulsed them. The sources indicate ""dozens of deaths and injuries"", including at least 3 civilians, and thousands displaced. The villages were burnt down in the clashes.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 21 March, Military Forces of Sudan and the SLM/A Nur engaged in battles in Dalo and Dulda in the Jebel Marra area. According to the source, dozens of government troops and militiamen were killed in the battles.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 21 March, Military Forces of Sudan and the SLM/Nur engaged in battles in Dalo and Dulda in the Jebel Marra area. According to the source, dozens of government troops and militiamen were killed in the battles.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Over 21-22 March, the military forces of Sudan attacked the positions held by the SLM-AW forces led by Abdel-Wahid al-Nur in Feina, Sina and Dawa areas in south and east Jebel Marrah. Witnesses said the state forces regained these territories, while SLA/AW claimed to have repulsed them. The sources indicate ""dozens of deaths and injuries"", including at least 3 civilians in Sina, and thousands displaced. The villages were burnt down in the clashes.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Arrests: Around 21 March, the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) claimed to have captured the intelligence chief of the Justice and Equality Mouvement (JEM) Salah Abdalla Rahma in Malha. The JEM denied the claim.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Over 21-22 March, SLM-AW forces led by Abdel-Wahid al-Nur and the military forces of South Sudan clashed in Feina, Fuguli and Leiba areas in Jabal Marrah, as the government forces had been deployed there on 17-19 March. Witnesses said the state forces regained these territories, while SLA/AW claimed to have repulsed them. The sources indicate ""dozens of deaths and injuries"", including at least 3 civilians, and thousands displaced. The villages were burnt down in the clashes.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Over 21-22 March, the military forces of Sudan attacked the positions held by the SLM-AW forces led by Abdel-Wahid al-Nur in Feina, Sina and Dawa areas in south and east Jebel Marrah. Witnesses said the state forces regained these territories, while SLA/AW claimed to have repulsed them. The sources indicate ""dozens of deaths and injuries"", including at least 3 civilians in Sina, and thousands displaced. The villages were burnt down in the clashes.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 22 March, SLM-Nur forces fought against the Military Forces of Sudan in the area west of Deribat, South Darfur. The SLM/A-Nur forced the Military Forces to return to Deribat.

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 22 March, Rapid Support Forces (RSF) entered Libei in the Tawila area in North Darfur trying to loot the local people but the Military Forces of Sudan confronted and expelled them.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Over 21-22 March, SLM-AW forces led by Abdel-Wahid al-Nur and the military forces of South Sudan clashed in Feina, Fuguli and Leiba areas in Jabal Marrah, as the government forces had been deployed there on 17-19 March. Witnesses said the state forces regained these territories, while SLA/AW claimed to have repulsed them. The sources indicate ""dozens of deaths and injuries"", including at least 3 civilians, and thousands displaced. The villages were burnt down in the clashes.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 22 March, Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and the Police Forces of Sudan clashed in Umjadwal village, 20km from Radom in South Darfur. Two RSF members and one police were killed and two police were injured. The reasons for the gunfire remain unclear.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Over 21-22 March, SLM-AW forces led by Abdel-Wahid al-Nur and the military forces of South Sudan clashed in Feina, Fuguli and Leiba areas in Jabal Marrah, as the government forces had been deployed there on 17-19 March. Witnesses said the state forces regained these territories, while SLA/AW claimed to have repulsed them. The sources indicate ""dozens of deaths and injuries"", including at least 3 civilians, and thousands displaced. The villages were burnt down in the clashes.

Non-violent activity: On 23 March, the Government of Eritrea accused Qatar and Sudan of actions destabilizing the regime of President Isaias Afewerki. According to Eritrea, Sudan has allowed the followers of the radical Islamic Cleric, Mohammed Jumma to open an office in Kassala and to establish training camps near the border. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Sudan denied the accusations.

On 24 March, members of the Kawahala and Kaja clans of the Hamar tribe clashed in the Umm Keddada area over the ownerhip of a new mine at the border between North Darfur, North Kordofan and West Kordofan. Seven killed and 10 injured among the Kaja; 17 injured among the Kawahala.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 24 March, Rapid Support Forces (RSF) reportedly attacked villagers on their way to the weekly market of Kara, South Darfur. The RSF shooted around people, beat them, plundered shops and robbed customers. Two people were wounded.
On 25 March, residents of Kirfis district of Gedaref in Kassala protested against the interruption of water distribution.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Border Guards
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 26 March, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) exchanged fire with the Military Forces of Sudan supported by the border guards in Gubbo and Gur Lambung, near Gulobei, South Darfur. Some civilians moved to Kidingir due to the incident.

Movement of forces: On 26 March, the Military Forces of South Sudan denounced the builiding-up of Military Forces from Sudan along the border between the two countries, near Kuek in the Melut area of South Sudan's Upper Nile state, heightening fears of a renewed confrontation between the two countries.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Border Guards
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 26 March, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) exchanged fire with the Military Forces of Sudan supported by the border guards in Gulobei, South Darfur. Some civilians moved to Kidingir due to the incident.

On 26 March, police broke up a demonstration by students from the University of East Kordofan in Abu Jubaiha, South Kordofan. Students protested against the faculty administration that prevented students from Darfur from forming associations. 14 students were injured.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Border Guards
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 26 March, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) exchanged fire with the Military Forces of Sudan supported by the border guards in Gubbo and Gur Lambung, near Gulobei, South Darfur. Some civilians moved to Kidingir due to the incident.
Around 27 March, two groups of youth from Karo, Bahr El Arab in East Darfur, fought with knives and machetes. 12 people were killed or injured.
On 27 March, an unexploded ordnance detonated in Jawa, South Darfur, killing one person and injuring another.
Around 27 March 2018, cattle raiders and a ""local rescue team"" clashed in Dimsu, South Darfur. Two people were killed and four injured.

On 27 March, a suspected supporter of the radical Islamist group Al-Takfir wal Hijrah stabbed people in a mosque in Kassala town. He killed two people and injured five others. The worshippers defended themselves and killed him.
Around 27 March, unidentified gunmen opened fire on two vehicles in Dimsu, South Darfur. One person was killed and three others injured.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 28 March, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) clashed with the Military Forces of Sudan in Khormaley, North Darfur.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 28 March, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) clashed with the Military Forces of Sudan in Sabun, North Darfur.

On 28 March, residents of Abbasiya, Kirfis and Wadelkabir districts of Gedaref protested against the continuing interruption of water services demanding authorities to expedite solution. The protest was peaceful.

On 28 and 29 March, students of El Imam Mahdi University in El Gezira Aba, White Nile, clashed. The fighting started, when militant student members of the National Congress Party (NCP) attacked the students listening to a speech of student Amir Daoud on the poor conditions in student dorms. One student was injured and three others were detained.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 29 March, Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid alNur Faction) forces reportedly began to set base in Malam and Umm Elgora in South Darfur after the state forces recovered territory in battles against them in East Jebel Marra.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 29 March, Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid alNur Faction) forces reportedly began to set base in Malam and Umm Elgora in South Darfur after the state forces recovered territory in battles against them in East Jebel Marra.

On 28 and 29 March, students of El Imam Mahdi University in El Gezira Aba, White Nile, clashed. The fighting started, when militant student members of the National Congress Party (NCP) attacked the students listening to a speech of student Amir Daoud on the poor conditions in student dorms. One student was injured and three others were detained.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 30 and 31 March, the Military Forces of Sudan clashed with fighters of the SLM-AW at their strongholds in the Sawani and Rokona areas of East Jebel Marra. SLM-AW claimed to have repulsed the state forces inflicting heavy human and material casualties, while four died on their side, including a commander.

On 30 March, cattle raiders killed two people and injured five others in in the area of Barkorou, 15km west of Dobo Umda, in North Darfur. They managed to steal dozens of livestock from the villagers.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 30 and 31 March, the Military Forces of Sudan clashed with fighters of the SLM-AW at their strongholds in the Sawani and Rokona areas of East Jebel Marra. SLM-AW claimed to have repulsed the state forces inflicting heavy human and material casualties, while four died on their side, including a commander.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Looting: On 31 March, Rapid Support Forces (RSF) looted villages in the area of Terongafogi and Owru, near Libei, East Jebel Marra, set fire to houses and stole livestock, causing displacement.
On 31 March, unknown militiamen shot at the residents of Turbo village in Tawila, North Darfur. Two people were injured and cattle were stolen.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 30 and 31 March, the Military Forces of Sudan clashed with fighters of the SLM-AW at their strongholds in the Sawani and Rokona areas of East Jebel Marra. SLM-AW claimed to have repulsed the state forces inflicting heavy human and material casualties, while four died on their side, including a commander.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 31 March, Rapid Support Forces (RSF) attacked several villages in the area of Sawani, East Jebel Marra in South Darfur. They killed 11 people and injured 21. They plundered houses, stole livestock and set houses on fire.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 30 and 31 March, the Military Forces of Sudan clashed with fighters of the SLM-AW at their strongholds in the Sawani and Rokona areas of East Jebel Marra. SLM-AW claimed to have repulsed the state forces inflicting heavy human and material casualties, while four died on their side, including a commander.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 1 April, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) clashed with the Military Forces of Sudan in Katur, North Darfur. One person was killed and one injured. In addition, 73 houses were burnt down.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Property destruction: In the beginning of April, Rapid Support Forces (RSF) burned the villages of Vina and Duwa and other areas in southern Jebel Marra according to the Transitional Council Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Transitional Council).
On 2 April, cattle raiders killed one person near Rabkona, 15km south of Dobo Umda, North Darfur. The attackers managed to seize livestock. No injuries.
On 2 April, unidentified gunmen kidnapped one person in Zalingei. No injuries.

On 4 April, unidentified militias carried out attacks in the Feina area, South Darfur. They destroyed 16 villages and killed civilians. The arrival of the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) on the same day put a stop to the attacks. No injuries.

On 7 April, five gunmen ambushed a group of displaced people from the Gereida IDP camp, when they were returning to Um Balola village. The attackers fired at the voluntary returnees, injuring a communty leader, and then stole their money and mobile telephones.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 7 April, Rapid Support Forces (RSF) killed one person in the area south of Dorta in Tokar, Kassala. The RSF had stopped many vehicles on their way to Garora in Agig and the victim had approached the RSF to ask what was going on.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 7 April, Rapid Support Forces (RSF) arrested two people at Gurni market, Nertiti, Central Darfur. The same day, these two people were transferred to Nertiti hospital in poor condition, for they were beaten by the RSF in an unknown place. No fatalities.
On 8 April, Zaghawa Ethnic Militia clashed with Awlad Zaid Ethnic Militia over a cattle in Kirkir, Central Darfur. One person from each side died in the incident.

Property Destruction: On 8 April, armed herders burned charcoal sacks and stole donkeys at a charcoal factory in El Aradeib El Ashara, eastern Jebel Marra. They opened fire into the air before they set the charcoal sacks in fire. No fatalities or injuries.

On 9 April, the headquarters of the Military Forces of Sudan in Deribat, Darfur, fired a rocket-propelled grenade killing one person and injuring another. It is not clear why the government forces launched the grenade to the mountains where many civilians had taken refuge during the fighting in East Jebel Marra. They could have mistaken a flashlight for gunfire and responded by firing bombs to that direction for half an hour.

On 10 April, armed herders attacked residents of Abujidad area of Karnoi in North Darfur. The Arab herders wanted to prevent the Zaghawa tribe members from drawing water from a well and opened fire on them. They injured ten people.

On 11 April (the date remains uncertain), Military Forces of Sudan allegedly tortured sheikh Mousa Osman to death in Libei area near Tawila in North Darfur. Sheikh was arrested for an unknown reason and and beaten to death in custody.

On 11 April, unidentified armed group kidnapped omda Hasoun Mangali, head of the Popular Court of Mesteriya, and his companions in Omdurman, near Khartoum. Mangali was in Khartoum to mediate between the Government of Sudan and Musa Hilal, chairman of the Revolutionary Awakening Council. He had received prior threats to stay away from Musa Hilal's case and his son had already been kidnapped.
On 12 April, a remnant of war detonated in Dolo, 15km north of Feina in Darfur. The explosion killed two people and injured one.

Agreement: On 12 April, the leaders of the Falata and Salamat ethnic groups signed a peace agreement in South Darfur. The groups have fought over water sources and pastures for years. They agreed to pay compensation for the lossess on both sides.

On 12 April, dozens of teachers protested in front of the Ministry of Education in Khartoum. They demanded that their delayed salaries would be paid. They handed over a memorandum to the Minister of Education and the minister promised to pay the salaries.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 12 April, Military Forces of Sudan claims to have captured the area of Srounq in Jabal Marrah from the Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur). No fatalities or injuries.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 14 April, members of Rapid Support Forces (RSF) reportedly tortured an elderly person while he was grazing his cattle near Rokona, East Jebel Marra, South Darfur. The RSF questioned him about rebel commanders in the area. When he denied knowing anything, the RSF beat him heavily and took him to El Malam.
On 15 April, armed herders shot at farmers in Sankta, southern Kass locality in South Darfur. Nine farmers injured.
On 16 April, unidentified armed group shot at a man collecting firewood near Mashrou Abu Zeid, east of Dobo Umda in Tawila locality, North Darfur. The man was injured.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 18 April, the Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army claims to have killed 27 Sudanese military in a clash that took place in Torong Tura, Jebel Marra.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 18 April, Sudan's Arab Baath Party claims that Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) killed camel herders and stole their cattle in Tawa, Jebel Marra. No exact information on fatalities or injuries.

On 19 April, Military Forces of Sudan burned several villages in Jebel Marra, including Boli and Arua, according to the Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur). The SLM/A-Nur claims to have fought with the government forces in Torong Tura the day before, and the government forces burned the villages after their defeat.

On 19 April, Military Forces of Sudan burned several villages in Jebel Marra, including Boli and Arua, according to the Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur). The SLM/A-Nur claims to have fought with the government forces in Torong Tura the day before, and the government forces burned the villages after their defeat.

On 19 April, unidentified armed group ambushed a group of residents of Jamra village in Katayla locality, South Darfur. Victims had earlier returned from a refugee camp through the Voluntary Return Programme. Four people were killed and six injured.

On 19 April (date is not certain), unidentified armed group abducted two people, a civilian and a soldier, during an attack in a charcoal factory south of Katur, North Darfur. No fatalities or injuries.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 19 April 2018, during two days of attacks, RSF paramilitaries torched a number of villages in Jebel Marrah in Rokoro locality (Central Darfur state), with rebel forces listing Lugo, Aro, Hilla Hajja Madina, Sankara, Loki Warrro, Ja'ahora, Gharab Waffir, Malmal, Saliya, Tukmah, Kaya, Sankara, Kitti, and Durkuru as the targeted villages. Around 30,000 have been displaced; the sources do not mention fatalities or injuries. Conflicting accounts suggest that the attacks are in retaliation for SLM/A-Nur activity in the area, which is disputed by the group.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Around 19 April 2018 (from 19 - 20 April), RSF paramilitaries torched the village of Aro in Rokoro locality (Central Darfur state), amid a spate of attacks against civilian villages in the Jebel Marrah area. The sources do not mention whether there were fatalities or injuries.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Around 19 April 2018 (from 19 - 20 April), RSF paramilitaries torched the village of Lugo in Rokoro locality (Central Darfur state), amid a spate of attacks against civilian villages in the Jebel Marrah area. The sources do not mention whether there were fatalities or injuries.
On 19 April (date is not certain), unidentified armed group shot dead two people in Katur, Tawila locality, North Darfur. They also stole camels from the victims. No injuries.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 20 April 2018, during two days of attacks, RSF paramilitaries torched a number of villages in Jebel Marrah in Rokoro locality (Central Darfur state), with rebel forces listing Lugo, Aro, Hilla Hajja Madina, Sankara, Loki Warrro, Ja'ahora, Gharab Waffir, Malmal, Saliya, Tukmah, Kaya, Sankara, Kitti, and Durkuru as the targeted villages. Around 30,000 have been displaced; the sources do not mention fatalities or injuries. Conflicting accounts suggest that the attacks are in retaliation for SLM/A-Nur activity in the area, which is disputed by the group.

""One INGO driver was killed and three aid workers injured when they were attacked in the Taalei-Mabek area in Abyei by armed men, suspected to be Misseriya. The team was on a vaccination campaign. The injured aid workers were taken to a hospital in Abyei and then evacuated to an INGO hospital in Agok.""

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 20 April, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) claims to have been attacked by Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in Gulik, Abulkheirat, Sedda, Luo and Terela in Jebel Marra. According to the government, these operations sought to secure routes and stop harassment of civilians by the holdout rebels.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 22 April, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) claims that they fought with the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in Kati, Jaldo area in North Darfur. According to the government, these operations sought to secure routes and stop harassment of civilians by the holdout rebels.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 23 April, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) claims to have clashed with the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in Wadi Toro, Jebel Marra, Central Darfur. According to the government, these operations sought to secure routes and stop harassment of civilians by the holdout rebels. RSF lost 11 members and SLM/A-Nur two while 5 were injured according to the SLM/A-Nur.
""One INGO national male aid worker was fatality stabbed outside of his residence. The perpetrator pulled out a knife and stabbed the staff member in the chest. He died in Kulbus hospital.""
On 24 April, a group of herders attacked farmers who were cleaning their farms in Klu, Tawila in North Darfur. They killed one person.
On 25 April, during the demolition of houses in Kombo Aftas in El Hasahisa, Blue Nile, police used excessive force and tear gas to force the inhabitants out of the houses, leaving seven injured.
On 25 April, a group of herders beat farmers at Kator area in North Darfur near the border of South Darfur. Three of the farmers were injured.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 25 April (date is not certain), a faction of the Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement-North (SPLM-N) claimed to have repulsed attacks by the Rapid Support Forces in Sulta and Angesina, Blue Nile. According to the SPLM-N, eight RSF combatants were killed while four SPLM-N combatants were wounded.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 25 April (date is uncertain), Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement-North (SPLM-N) claims that its troops were attacked by the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in Taka and Kalkoa/Kalgo, Ingessana Hills, near Blue Nile state capital Ed Damazin. According to the SPLM-N, the RSF wish to regain the control of the gold-rich mountains.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 25 April, Police Forces of Sudan together with the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) clashed with herders at Klu area in Tawila, North Darfur. The police and RSF were tracing perpetrators of an attack against farmers in Klu on 24 April and got ambushed by the herders. There were no fatalities, but seven police and RSF members were injured and three others went missing.

column8: SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction)
column17: On 26 April, Transitional Council Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Transitional Council) claims to have clashed with the Military Forces of Sudan in the north and east of Jebel Marra.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 28 April, Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement-North (SPLM-N) claims that its troops were attacked by the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in Soda and Al-Jaghb in Jebel Ban, Blue Nile. The SPLM-N claims to have repelled the attacks killing 8 people. A large number of civilians were forced to flee according to the SPLM-N.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 28 April, Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement-North (SPLM-N) claims that its troops were attacked by the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in Soda and Al-Jaghb in Jebel Ban, Blue Nile. The SPLM-N claims to have repelled the attacks killing 8 people. A large number of civilians were forced to flee according to the SPLM-N.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 28 April, Rapid Support Forces (RSF) claims that it has liberated with the Military Forces of Sudan areas from the Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement-North (SPLM-N) in Blue Nile, including Gola al-Jadida, Gola al-Gadima, Kabadaik and Jeko. The SPLM-N confirmed the attack. According to the RSF, government forces inflicted ""heavy losses in lives and equipments"".

column8: SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction)
column17: On 28 April (date remains unclear), Transitional Council Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Transitional Council) claims to have clashed with the Military Forces of Sudan in Jebel Marra. According to the SLM/A-Transitional Council, the government forces attacked their positions but they managed to repulse them.

On 2 May, Islamist students, backed by the police forces, attacked protesting students at the University of the Holy Koran in Omdurman, Khartoum. Students held a sit-in protesting the poor services and university environment, when they were attacked. Police used tear gas while Islamist student militias and mujahedeen brought in from other universities in Khartoum beat students evicting them from the university. 14 students were injured.

On 2 May, an ethnic militia of 20 people attacked the village of Abu Jabra, South Darfur, targeting returned IDPs. The returnees are from the Mahadi ethnic group and the militia attacked them on the grounds that the area belongs to the Falata ethnic group. One person was killed, two others injured and two children went missing following the incident.
On 4 May (date remains unclear), unidentified armed group abducted a farmer in Saga, Nertiti, Central Darfur.

column8: SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction)
column17: Agreement: On 7 May, Minnawi Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Minnawi), Justice and Equality Movement (JEM) and Transitional Council Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Transitional Council) extended their unilateral ceasefire for three months, until 6 August 2018. It applies throughout the conflict areas of Darfur. In the declaration, the three armed groups condemn the government for the violations of its own unilateral ceasefire in Jabal Marrah.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Change to armed group: On 7 May (date remains unclear), Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) and Sudan Liberation Force Alliance (SLFA) merged into one movement that they call Sudan Liberation Movement/Army. The meetings were held in an undisclosed location. Abdul Wahid al-Nur comes from Zalingei.
On 8 May, teachers protested the non-payment of their salaries outside the Ministry of Education in Khartoum. Police detained an unknown number of protesters.

On 8 May, hundreds of residents protested against the fuel crisis, rise of prices and lack of basic commodities in the streets of the Geziratelfil district of Wad Madani, Blue Nile. No fatalities or injuries.

On 9 May, 35 armed militiamen attacked 25 displaced people collecting firewood in Dugwa area, west of Tabit, North Darfur. The attackers threatened to kill the victims if they return the area saying that it had become a pasture for herders rather than an area for collecting straw and firewood. The attackers beat the victims with sticks injuring at least two people.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On 10 May (date is uncertain), National Intelligence and Security Service of Sudan violently dispersed a student protest and detained 13 protesters in Gedaref. Students of the University of El Gedaref (and a number of other people) protested against the absence of security, deteriorating conditions in the dormitories and the increase in prices, when the police forces broke up the demonstrations ""using excessive violence"" according to witnesses and injuring 15 people.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 11 May, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) clashed with the Military Forces of Sudan in several areas of Jabal Marrah, including Gundi Too, Tori and Tuli. According to the SLM/A-Nur, the government forces attempted to attack their positions but they were repelled. The SLM/A-Nur claims to have inflicted on the government forces ""heavy losses in lves"" and captured seven government troops (10 fatalities spread over three events).

On 11 May, an unidentified armed man wearing a military uniform shot dead the head of police of Dibebad, South Kordofan, while he was touring the western part of the town. The reasons for the attack are unknown. No other fatalities or injuries.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 11 May, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) clashed with the Military Forces of Sudan in several areas of Jabal Marrah, including Tortura, North Darfur. According to the SLM/A-Nur, the government forces attempted to attack their positions but they were repelled. The SLM/A-Nur claims to have inflicted on the government forces ""heavy losses in lves"" and captured seven government troops (10 fatalities spread over three events).
On 11 May, unidentified communal militia raided cattle from herders grazing in Katur, North Darfur. They shot at the herders and two of them were injured. No fatalities.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 11 May, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) clashed with the Military Forces of Sudan in several areas of Jabal Marrah, including Kara, South Darfur. According to the SLM/A-Nur, the government forces attempted to attack their positions but they were repelled. The SLM/A-Nur claims to have inflicted on the government forces ""heavy losses in lves"" and captured seven government troops (10 fatalities spread over three events).

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 11 May, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) clashed with the Military Forces of Sudan and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in and around Tara, Tarantara and Kalokitting, South Darfur. Two people were killed and four injured. In addition, people from the neighbouring village Gobo fled the flighting.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 11 May, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) clashed with the Military Forces of Sudan and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in and around Tara, Tarantara and Kalokitting, South Darfur. Two people were killed and four injured. In addition, people from the neighbouring village Gobo fled the flighting.

On 12 May, Dinka Ngok ethnic militia from South Sudan attacked Misseriya herders in Luo near Abyei town in Abyei PCA Area. They killed three herders and injured two others. They took a large number cattle with them.
On 12 May, unidentified armed group attacked a vehicle on the road between a gold mine in El Bereesa and El Naim in Umm Keddada, North Darfur. Three gold miners were killed.

On 13 May, more than 500 car owners and drivers demonstrated in front of a petrol station in El Obeid. Their protest blocked the highway connecting El Obeid and Khartoum for an hour. The spontaneous protest erupted when the owner of the petrol station told the car owners that he had received instructions from the authorities to sell fuel only to government agencies. The protest ended when the governor ordered the owner to sell fuel again.

On 13 May, dozens of vehicle owners staged a peaceful march against the lack of fuel in Babanusa, South Kordofan. Police followed the demonstrators after the march, beat them and detained some according to the protesters. A number of demonstrators were injured.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Movement of forces: On 13 May (date is not certain), Military Forces of Sudan and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) deployed more than 1500 troops to Kass locality, South Darfur, in order to attack the positions of the Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur). A similar deployment occurred in Zalingei the same day. No clashes yet reported.

On 15 May, residents in the districts of Hasib, Rumeila and Ushar in El Obeid, Kordofan, demonstrated against the interruption of water services. They blocked the road for two hours. Governor came to the site and promised to restore water services. One demonstrator was arrested and the security forces reportedly prevented residents from filming the protest.

On 16 May (date is not certain), residents of El Guba district in El Obeid, Kordofan, demonstrated against the interruption of water services. They closed the road linking the district to the grand market. Government officials promised to solve the water crisis.
On 17 May, the security and military forces allegedly tortured and beat a human rights activist in Gereida, South Darfur. He was severely injured.

On 19 May, a resident and a Captain officer of the Economic Security Service clashed over the distribution of fuel at a petrol station in El Geneina, West Darfur. The officer was killed and the resident injured.

On 20 May, hundreds of West Kordofanis protested against the authorities' manipulation of the fuel and sugar quotas and the power outages in Abu Zabad, South Kordofan. They erected tents in the centre of the town and crowded in front of fuel pumps.

On 20 May, dozens of secondary school exams correctors protested in Khartoum against the decrease of their payments. They staged a sit-in in front of of a school that functioned as a correction centre earlier. The Teachers Union told the correctors that the security forces would disperse them if they did not stop the vigil.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 21 May, Military Forces of Sudan and Rapid Support Forces (RSF) stationed in the area of Kara in East Jabal Marrah bombed the areas of Gorolang Banje, Sara and Sabun El Fagur in Jabal Marrah according to the Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army. The Ministry of Defense acknowledged the outbreak of fighting in Jabal Marrah against ""sleeper cells"" of the Wahid al-Nur Faction the day before but did not mention any specific event. The bombardment led to the flight of civilians. Two known injuries for all the three places.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 21 May, Military Forces of Sudan and Rapid Support Forces (RSF) stationed in the area of Kara in East Jabal Marrah bombed the areas of Gorolang Banje, Sara and Sabun El Fagur in Jabal Marrah according to the Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army. The Ministry of Defense acknowledged the outbreak of fighting in Jabal Marrah against ""sleeper cells"" of the Wahid al-Nur Faction the day before but did not mention any specific event. The bombardment led to the flight of civilians. Two known injuries for all the three places.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 21 May, Military Forces of Sudan and Rapid Support Forces (RSF) stationed in the area of Kara in East Jabal Marrah bombed the areas of Gorolang Banje, Sara and Sabun El Fagur in Jabal Marrah according to the Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army. The Ministry of Defense acknowledged the outbreak of fighting in Jabal Marrah against ""sleeper cells"" of the Wahid al-Nur Faction the day before but did not mention any specific event. The bombardment led to the flight of civilians. Two known injuries for all the three places.

On 21 May, young people organized a protest rally condemning the rise of prices and lack of water and fuel in El Khawi, South Kordofan. The protesters marched through the town and the market. Police broke up the demonstration and arrested four youths who were reportedly released the next day.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 21 May, Rapid Support Forces (RSF) attacked the Khamsa Degaig camp for displaced in Zalingei, Central Darfur, killing one person and injuring two others. According to the authorities of Central Darfur, however, the incident was a result of a mistake: the RSF members accidentally entered the camp on their way to El Geneina and were treated with hostility by the camp residents.

column9: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On or soon after 21 May, residents of the Khamsa Degaig IDP camp in Zalingei, Central Darfur, demonstrated to protest the killing of one of theirs by the RSF in an earlier attack on the camp. Police, military and/or RSF responded with live ammunitions to the protest, triggering clashes that left at least five state forces and nine civilians injured.

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On or soon after 21 May, Rapid Support Forces (RSF) exchanged fire with the military police near the Khamsa Degaig camp for displaced in Zalingei, Central Darfur. This took place after the RSF had attacked the camp. Three military troops were injured.

""Seven INGO staff members traveling in one INGO vehicle were ambushed and kidnapped in Western Equatoria between Lanyi and Gado. Their whereabouts are unknown and further details about this incident are unavailable at this time.""

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 22 May, Rapid Support Forces (RSF) opened fire on the displaced people at Abuja market in the Ardayba camp in Garsila, Central Darfur, because the RSF tried to prevent them from looting their belongings. According to the camp residents, the police and security forces were present during the shooting. Another shooting occurred the following day. Three killed and 12 injured in total.

On 22 May, Sudanese Air Forces bombarded the areas of Turung Tawra and Tugut Turti in southern Jabal Marrah according to the Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army. The bombardment caused ""great losses"" and forced residents to flee to other areas.
On 22 May, unidentified armed group raided cattle in Talodi, South Kordofan. They killed three people.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 23 May, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) claims to have repelled a government attack in Kara Gobo area in the southern part of Jabal Marrah in Central Darfur. The fighting resumed on 24 May. The SLM/A-Nur claims to have killed 37 government forces in the two days of fighting.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 23 May (date is not certain), Rapid Support Forces (RSF) attacked the Jeddah IDP camp in Wadi Salah locality, Central Darfur. Several people were injured in several attacks on camps on that day.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 23 May, Rapid Support Forces (RSF) clashed with the residents of the Ardayba camp for displaced in Garsila, Central Darfur. The RSF backed by security forces attacked the camp, when the residents were mourning the victims killed the day before in another shooting in the camp. The RSF killed three and injured 12 displaced people during the two shootings on 22-23 May.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 24 May, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) claims to have repelled an attack by the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and government forces in Kara Gobo area in the southern part of Jabal Marrah in Central Darfur. The SLM/A-Nur claims to have killed 14 government forces and injured 28 others.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 24 May (date is not certain), Military Forces of Sudan and Rapid Support Forces (RSF) clashed with Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A-Nur) in Sabun El Fagur, Kobo, Kuru, Jarku and Kor in Jabal Marrah. The fighting followed the bombardment of Sabun El Fagur by the pro-government forces on 24 May.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 24 May, Military Forces of Sudan and Rapid Support Forces (RSF) bombarded Sabun El Fagur in Jabal Marrah according to the Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army. Three civilians were injured.

On 24 May, unidentified armed group clashed with Misseriya herders after the armed group had stolen cattle from the Misseriya. They exhanged fire in Abyei area, near the border between South Sudan and Sudan. Two people were killed.
On 25 May, armed herders opened fire on civilians collecting straw near Artutogo, 10km from Khazan Tunjur, North Darfur. One person was injured and another kidnapped.
On 25 May, Military Forces of Sudan bombarded Sabun El Fagur. One person was injured.
On 27 May, unidentified militia opened fire on the residents of Gereida camp for displaced near Ibdos village, 5km from Gereida, South Darfur. One person was killed and four people injured.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 27 May, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement (SLM/A-Nur) clashed with Military Forces of Sudan and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in Alnagi, Gogo/Gubo and Kor, near Kass, South Darfur, and the border between South and Central Darfur. According to the SLM/A-Nur, they killed 27 RSF members in total.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 27 May, Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction of the Sudan Liberation Movement (SLM/A-Nur) clashed with Military Forces of Sudan and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in Alnagi, Gogo/Gubo and Kor, near Kass, South Darfur, and the border between South and Central Darfur. According to the SLM/A-Nur, they killed 27 RSF members in total.
On 27 May, unidentified militia opened fire on farmers in eastern Jabal Marrah. Two people were injured.

On 30 May, ten armed herders shot at a group of farmers in Jabal Ari, West Darfur. The herders claimed that the farmers were plowing at their property and opened fire after a dispute. Seven farmers were injured.
On 31 May, government forces bombarded the Gobu area located 30km from Kass, South Darfur. Two people were killed.

On 2 June, relatives and friends of a detainee gathered outside the El Shuwak police station in Kassala as the detainee fell ill and the police were slow to issue documents required for his hospitalization. Police fired shots to disperse them. One policeman and four relatives were injured by the shots.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Border Guards
column17: On 2 June, security authorities at the Khartoum airport reportedly tortured and robbed a Sudanese citizen, leaving him injured.
On 2 June, 20 militiamen attacked a group of displaced farmers near Um Gubeisha village, 7km from Gereida, South Darfur. One farmer was killed and three others injured.

On 4 June, unidentified armed group shot at people at the market of Hijeir Tongo/Higair Tunu village of voluntary returnees, 29km from Nyala, South Darfur. There are several interpretations of the event: the SPLM-N accuses the government forces but the government officials say it is a quarrel between a market seller and four gunmen that escalated into shooting. Eight people were killed and five others were injured.
