On 4 June, unidentified armed group opened fire on a group of displaced people in Edeltigil village, 15km from Gereida, South Darfur. The displaced people were coming to the village for farming purposes. One person was killed.
On 5 June (date is not certain), ""government authorities"" arrested and beat an American citizen of Sudanese origin in Murnei, West Darfur. He died later at the hospital.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 5 June, unidentified armed group and Rapid Support Forces (RSF) clashed in Nyala, when the armed group tried to storm a military headquarters. Security forces arrested the perpetrators after violent pursuits in the street. One RSF soldier was killed and another injured.

On 7 June, unidentified armed men attacked a group of displaced people near Rizeig, 10km west from Gereida in South Darfur. The displaced people near UNAMID camp had gone out to track down stolen goats. Two people were killed and eight others were injured. There were several attacks against returnees around that date in Gereida by seemingly local militias.

On 7 June, Falata tribesmen assassinated the village leader in Eldan village for voluntary returnees in Greda locality, South Darfur. Victim's relatives followed perpetrators to arrest them but were ambushed. The Falata militias attacked the village because they do not accept the return of the displaced to their villages. In addition to the village leader, two people were killed and seven injured.

On 7 June 2018, Falata tribesmen assassinated the village leader in Eldan village for voluntary returnees in Greda locality, South Darfur. Victim's relatives followed perpetrators to arrest them but were ambushed. The Falata militias attacked the village because they do not accept the return of the displaced to their villages. In addition to the village leader, two people were killed and seven injured.

On 7 June (date is not certain), militiamen killed two sheperds in Eldan village for voluntary returnees in Greda locality, South Darfur. The killings are related to the assassination of the village leader on 7 June.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column17: On June 7th, a trader from El Abbasiya South Kordofan was released from the custody of the Sudanese military intelligence. He was a former member of the SPLM-N, and was initially arrested on 5th March. He showed signs of severe physical and psychological torture.

On 7 June, unidentified armed group attacked the village of Idan, South Darfur. In Idan, there are displaced people who had returned from camps in Gereida to go farming. One person was killed and another injured.

On 8 June, 13 armed herders wearing military uniforms ambushed a group of people fetching water in the area of Sawani, north of Malam in South Darfur. The attackers stole goats and donkeys. Three people were injured.
On 8 June, herders militia attacked farmers in Dobo Madrasa, North Darfur. The militia beat farmers threatening to kill them if they were to return to their farms. Two people were injured.

On the weekend of the 9th/10th June, a passenger lorry was ambushed by unknown gunmen, around Karnoi, North Darfur. After shooting the lorry and forcing it to stop, then gunmen beat the passengers, and seriously injured the driver of the lorry. The gunmen stole approximately SDG 300,000, according to a passenger.
On 10th June, gunmen ambushed herders en route to El Fasher and stole their cattle. The attack took place at Jebel Kolge, 5km north of Tabit. No direct physical violence.
On 11th June, gunmen fired shots near Dubo El Omda, injuring a woman who was collecting straw in a field.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column17: On 11th June, a civilian working in a charcoal factory in Tawila, North Darfur, was allegedly tortured to death by Military Intelligence, who had arrested him the previous day. According to relatives of the victim, soldiers delivered the body to villagers, who refused to receive the body and reported the death to local authorities. The Tawila comissioner and police have sent the body to El Fasher to be autopsied.

On 12th June, protests broke out in Port Sudan (specifically, the Korea district), over problems with the supply of power and electricity. Police were reported to have used teargas against protestors.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column16: Radio Dabanga; Local Source; Sudan Tribune
column17: On 12th June, SLM/A Nur accused government soldiers retreating from clashes against their forces in the Nertiti area of raping six girls in Limo area, south of Jebel Marrah.

column6: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: UNAMID mandate extended by one year. The forces will be reduced from 8,735 to 5,470 military personnel by the end of 2018, and down to 4,050 by June 30th 2019. The remaining forces will be limited to the greater Jebel Marrah area. The headquarters of the mission will also shift from El Fasher (North Darfur) to Zalingei (Central Darfur).

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column16: Sudan Tribune; Local Source; Radio Dabanga
column17: On 12th June, clashes between the government and SLM/A-Nur broke out in various villages amd sites in Nertiti locality, Central Darfur. According to a government official, the SLM/A-Nur regained control of positions in the Jebel Kali and Badia areas, though the same source claimed that the Rapid Support Forces mobilised by the government enabled them to retake these positions. Fighting also occurred in Golol, Kujo and Jariya areas. Rebels claimed to have repulsed government attacks and destroyed nine Land Cruisers, whilst accusing retreating government soldiers of raping six girls in Limo area, south of Jebel Marrah. Approx 7,000 civilians reported to have fled according to local refugee representative, which he attributed to government shelling.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column16: Radio Dabanga; Local Source; Sudan Tribune
column17: On 12th June, clashes between the government and SLM/A-Nur broke out in various villages amd sites in Nertiti locality, Central Darfur. According to a government official, the SLM/A-Nur regained control of positions in the Jebel Kali and Badia areas, though the same source claimed that the Rapid Support Forces mobilised by the government enabled them to retake these positions. Fighting also occurred in Golol, Kujo and Jariya areas. Rebels claimed to have repulsed government attacks and destroyed nine Land Cruisers, whilst accusing retreating government soldiers of raping six girls in Limo area, south of Jebel Marrah. Approx 7,000 civilians reported to have fled according to local refugee representative, which he attributed to government shelling.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column16: Local Source; Sudan Tribune; Radio Dabanga
column17: On 12th June, clashes between the government and SLM/A-Nur broke out in various villages amd sites in Nertiti locality, Central Darfur. According to a government official, the SLM/A-Nur regained control of positions in the Jebel Kali and Badia areas, though the same source claimed that the Rapid Support Forces mobilised by the government enabled them to retake these positions. Fighting also occurred in Golol, Kujo and Jariya areas. Rebels claimed to have repulsed government attacks and destroyed nine Land Cruisers. Approx 7,000 civilians reported to have fled according to local refugee representative, which he attributed to government shelling.
On 13th June, protests in Port Sudan continued for a second day.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 13th June, fighting continued between SLM/A-Nur and the Sudan Armed Forces (with RSF support), in southern areas of Jebel Marrah, South Darfur. Rebels claimed to have killed 89 RSF fighters, and seized small arms, following two RSF assaults on Saboon El Fag and Shrinkil. Local sources stated that six civilians were killed on Wednesday fighting, in Fuju, Berbera, Kuweila, and Saboon El Fag (Sabun El Fagur), with a further twelve villagers wounded, and two students arrested. Rebel spokesman further alleged that RSF fighters burned six villages following their defeat.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 13th June, fighting continued between SLM/A-Nur and the Sudan Armed Forces (with RSF support), in southern areas of Jebel Marrah, South Darfur. Rebels claimed to have killed 89 RSF fighters, and seized small arms, following two RSF assaults on Saboon El Fag and Shrinkil. Local sources stated that six civilians were killed on Wednesday fighting, in Fuju, Berbera, Kuweila, and Saboon El Fag (Sabun El Fagur), with a further twelve villagers wounded, and two students arrested. Rebel spokesman further alleged that RSF fighters burned six villages following their defeat.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 13th June, fighting continued between SLM/A-Nur and the Sudan Armed Forces (with RSF support), in southern areas of Jebel Marrah, South Darfur. Rebels claimed to have killed 89 RSF fighters, and seized small arms, following two RSF assaults on Saboon El Fag and Shrinkil. Local sources stated that six civilians were killed on Wednesday fighting, in Fuju, Berbera, Kuweila, and Saboon El Fag (Sabun El Fagur), with a further twelve villagers wounded, and two students arrested. Rebel spokesman further alleged that RSF fighters burned six villages following their defeat.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: 13 June. Battle between Sudanese army and SLA Abdul Wahid faction on the Tarantara-Gur Lumbung axis in Jebel Marrah from 13 to 16 June. 16 soldiers and three SLA fighters reported dead. Fatalities split between 4 events.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On the 13th June, following fighting with SLM/A-Nur in Saboon el Fag area, SLM/A claimed RSF fighters burned six villages after their defeat.

On 14th June, government forces detained and beat three civilian male youths near Golol, Central Darfur, who were en route to the market of Tur. One was severely injured, and donkeys and fruit belonging to the youth were taken by government forces. One source referred to the soldiers as 'militiamen'.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: 14 June. Battle between Sudanese army and SLA Abdul Wahid faction on the Tarantara-Gur Lumbung axis in Jebel Marrah from 13 to 16 June. 16 soldiers and three SLA fighters reported dead. Fatalities split between 4 events.
On 14th June, protests in Port Sudan continued for a third day.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 14th June, fighting between government forces with RSF allies and SLM/A-Nur rebels continued in Tur and other locations in southern and western Jebel Marrah, including Awatim.

Over 14-16 June, conflict between members of the Kenana tribe occurred in El Jangur and Fatatat villages (both villages are in Abu Jubaiha locality, South Kordofan). The fighting involved firearms and blades. Across three days of fighting, a witness reported that 2 killed (on 15 June), 43 people were injured, 12 critically. On the third day, the state security forces intervened, arresting dozens, and conducting a disarmament exercise later on, on 21st June.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 14th June, fighting between government forces with RSF allies and SLM/A-Nur rebels continued in Tur and other locations in southern and western Jebel Marrah, including Awatim.

Over 14-16 June, conflict between members of the Kenana tribe occurred in El Jangur and Fatatat villages (both villages are in Abu Jubaiha locality, South Kordofan). The fighting involved firearms and blades. Across three days of fighting, a witness reported that 2 killed (on 15 June), 43 people were injured, 12 critically. On the third day, the state security forces intervened, arresting dozens, and conducting a disarmament exercise later on, on 21st June.

Over 14-16 June, conflict between members of the Kenana tribe occurred in El Jangur and Fatatat villages (both villages are in Abu Jubaiha locality, South Kordofan). The fighting involved firearms and blades. Across three days of fighting, a witness reported that 2 killed (on 15 June), 43 people were injured, 12 critically. On the third day, the state security forces intervened, arresting dozens, and conducting a disarmament exercise later on, on 21st June.
On June 15, protests in Port Sudan continued for a fourth day. The protests are in response to problems with water and electricity supplies.

Over 14-16 June, conflict between members of the Kenana tribe occurred in El Jangur and Fatatat villages (both villages are in Abu Jubaiha locality, South Kordofan). The fighting involved firearms and blades. Across three days of fighting, a witness reported that 2 killed (on 15 June), 43 people were injured, 12 critically. On the third day, the state security forces intervened, arresting dozens, and conducting a disarmament exercise later on, on 21st June.

On 15th June, unidentified gunmen raided a settlement near the village of Delo, 5km north of Fanga, in Tawila locality, North Darfur. One herder was wounded by gunfire during the attack, and 300 head of livestock were stolen.
On 15th June, government forces shelled villages in the Fuju area, near Golo in Central Darfur. Three civilians were killed in the artillery strikes.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: 15 June. Battle between Sudanese army and SLA Abdul Wahid faction on the Tarantara-Gur Lumbung axis in Jebel Marrah from 13 to 16 June. 16 soldiers and three SLA fighters reported dead. Fatalities split between 4 events.
On June 15th, two separate protests took place in El Obeid, North Kordofan. The protestors were demonstrating against water outages and the rising prices of water.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: 16 June. Battle between Sudanese army and SLA Abdul Wahid faction on the Tarantara-Gur Lumbung axis in Jebel Marrah from 13 to 16 June. 16 soldiers and three SLA fighters reported dead. Fatalities split between 4 events.

Over 14-16 June, conflict between members of the Kenana tribe occurred in El Jangur and Fatatat villages (both villages are in Abu Jubaiha locality, South Kordofan). The fighting involved firearms and blades. Across three days of fighting, a witness reported that 2 killed (on 15 June), 43 people were injured, 12 critically. On the third day, the state security forces intervened, arresting dozens, and conducting a disarmament exercise later on, on 21st June.
On June 16, protests in Port Sudan continued for a sixth day. The protests are in response to problems with water and electricity supplies. Police intervened, arresting dozens.

Over 14-16 June, conflict between members of the Kenana tribe occurred in El Jangur and Fatatat villages (both villages are in Abu Jubaiha locality, South Kordofan). The fighting involved firearms and blades. Across three days of fighting, a witness reported that 2 killed (on 15 June), 43 people were injured, 12 critically. On the third day, the state security forces intervened, arresting dozens, and conducting a disarmament exercise later on, on 21st June.

On June 16th, clashes between villagers from Deshisha and displaced farmers based in Kalma camp occurred in eastern Bielel locality, South Darfur. 17 people were injured in fighting involving knives, before government police forces separated the groups.
On June 17, protests in Port Sudan continued for a seventh day. The protests are in response to problems with water and electricity supplies.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On June 17th, near Karti village (5km north of El Geneina, West Darfur, approximate coordinates used for Karti) Rapid Support Forces paramilitaries prevented displaced civilians from challenging new settlers who were allegedly preventing the displaced from farming in the area. RSF forces fired upon the displaced, killing one, and injuring 17.

On June 17th, near Karti village (5km north of El Geneina, West Darfur, approximate coordinates used for Karti) Rapid Support Forces paramilitaries prevented displaced civilians from challenging new settlers who were allegedly preventing the displaced from farming in the area. RSF forces fired upon the displaced, killing one, and injuring 17.

On June 18-19, and following conflict the previous week between members of the Kenana tribe in villages in Abu Jubaiha locality (South Kordofan), two members of the Kenana ethnic group were killed. One killing took place in the Abu Jubai locality, and the other in Rashad locality (the source suggests the Abu Jubai killing took place on the 18th, and the Rashad killing on the 19th, although this is not directly specified).

On June 18th, unidentified gunmen shot at displaced civilians in the Tuma area of Kutum locality. 19 civilians were wounded in the attack, 8 seriously. The local MP stated that the attackers were around 70 in number, and had three Land Cruisers with them.
On June 19th, a local leader of a refugee camp was killed at his house in northern Nertiti camp (Central Darfur) by unidentified gunmen, who entered his house and shot the victim five times.

On June 18-19, and following conflict the previous week between members of the Kenana tribe in villages in Abu Jubaiha locality (South Kordofan), two members of the Kenana ethnic group were killed. One killing took place in the Abu Jubai locality, and the other in Rashad locality (the source suggests the Abu Jubai killing took place on the 18th, and the Rashad killing on the 19th, although this is not directly specified).

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On June 20th, protests over water outages continued in El Obeid, North Kordofan, following previous demonstrations on June 15th. State security forces arrested 20 protesters. Demonstrators gathered again later on to protest these arrests, after which one more person was arrested and taken to the NISS offices in El Obeid.
On June 20th, a militia group attacked displaced farmers, seriously injuring two women.

On June 21st, protests were held in New Amri (geo-cordinates for Amri used), Northern state. The protests were in response to a lack of drinking water, substandard services, and inadequate resettlment options for those affected by the construction of Merowe Dam.
On June 23rd, unidentified gunmen attacked two farmers in El Sunta, 5km west of Gereida (approx. Coordinates used). The farm owner was killed, and his co-worker wounded.

On June 24th, government soldiers entered the SPLM-N controlled area around Kubla, Dulami locallity (coordinates provided for Nuba Mountains, South Kordofan). They shot at farmers in the vicinity, killing two.
On June 24, in Wad Medani city (Gazira), security services arrested 15 teachers who staged a protest against the government plan to shut down 200 schools.

On or after 24th June, a group of herders rounded up farmers from Wad Tamra, Arbabuyout, Badi, and Beni Mansour villages in Kabkabiya locality, who had returned to their farms. They severely beat the farmers, and warned them not to stay on the land they had returned to.

On June 25th, three armed men wearing military uniforms entered Korli refugee camp south of Kass (South Darfur, coordinates for Kass used). They shot Fatima Abakar, killing her, and then beat several other civilians.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On or after 26th June, three SPLM-IO politicians were allegedly abducted by NISS agents in Khartoum, according to the spokesman of South Sudanese VP Taban Deng. The three Nuer politicians - Mustapha Kuma Muon, Mach Yak Dau, and Kiir Gatluak Lim -were part of the (now defunct) SPLM-IO Taban Deng faction, and were in Khartoum for the peace talks between President Salva Kiir and SPLM-IO leader Riek Machar, which included a meeting with various Nuer representatives.

On June 26th, herders attacked a police station in Hamida, Sirba locality, West Darfur (coordinates for Sirba used). Two policemen were wounded in the attack, which was in response to a dispute between herders and farmers, which police had resolved in favour of the farmers.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column17: On June 26th, military intelligence searching for potential collaborators of armed movements abducted a civilian in Jamira, north of Kass (South Darfur, coordinates for Kass used).

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On June 28th, retreating RSF soldiers shelled four villages in northern Jebel Marrah (Central Darfur), according to the spokesman of SLM/A-Nur. The spokesman said the villages were Keila North, Keila South, Biraka Tousi and Hillet Sofi. There were no reported casualties.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On June 28th, RSF forces attacked SLM/A-Nur areas of Aja and Buli in northern Jebel Marrah, Central Darfur (coordinates for Jebel Marrah used in lieu of information on Buli). According to the rebel spokesman, 79 RSF soldiers were killed, and several vehicles destroyed. The RSF then shelled several nearby villages as they retreated.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On June 28th, RSF forces attacked SLM/A-Nur areas of Aja and Buli in northern Jebel Marrah, Central Darfur (coordinates for Jebel Marrah used in lieu of information on Buli). According to the rebel spokesman, 79 RSF soldiers were killed, and several vehicles destroyed. The RSF then shelled several nearby villages as they retreated.
On June 29th, protests restarted in Port Sudan, Red Sea state, over water outages and problems with electricity.
On 29th June, government forces shot dead a student in Kass (South Darfur), and injured his wife. Note that RSF forces were active in the Kass area on the same date.

On June 29th, protests broke out in Gebeit, Red Sea state, over the decision of the commissioner of Sinkat locality to close water pipes running from Gebeit El Ashraf Dam to Gebeit, whilst opening water pipes to Sinkat town.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 29th June, RSF paramilitaries abducted four farmers and the sheikh of Yama, near Yama in Kass locality (coordinates for Nyama used).
On 1st July, herders shot a farmer in Galab, east of Tabit (North Darfur, coordinates for Tabit used), after he refused to recognise their claims to his land. The victim survived.
On 1st July, unidentified gunmen killed a civilian at the Dukra-Amieth market in Abyei.
On 4th July, gunmen shot and killed a civilian in Marai Jangei, Kass locality, South Darfur (coordinates for Morya Jangi South used).
On 4th July, gunmen from Ethiopia abducted three farmers at El Lagadi in El Gedaref, Kassala state (coordinates for Gedaref used)
On 4th July, gunmen shot a civilian dead in Umadrasaya village, east of Nyala, South Darfur (coordinates for Nyala used).

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 5th July, fighting between RSF paramilitaries and SLM/A-Nur forces took place in Fundug Badiya near Golol, Niertiti locality, Central Darfur (coordinates for Golol used). According to the rebel spokesman, 45 RSF fighters were killed, and one rebel. He also alleged that RSF forces burned a school, and attacked civilians whilst retreating.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 5th July, upon retreating from fighting with SLM/A-Nur, rebels claimed that RSF paramilitaries burned a school, and attacked civilians near Golol, Niertiti locality, Central Darfur.

On 5th and 6th July, violence between gunmen and members of the Beni Halba group took place in Sarfaya area of Edd Al Fursan locality, South Darfur (coordinates for Solwong used). According to a local source, the gunmen opened fire at the market following a verbal altercation with youths, causing the death of two members of the community. The following day, at the Halayeb area, Beni Halba militiamen killed three of the gunmen, and captured one.
On 6th July, Sudanese soldiers attacked and killed two herders (one of whom was a 12 year old boy) near Dalami, South Kordofan. They then stole cattle.

On 5th and 6th July, violence between gunmen and members of the Beni Halba group took place in Sarfaya area of Edd Al Fursan locality, South Darfur (coordinates for Solwong used). According to a local source, the gunmen opened fire at the market following a verbal altercation with youths, causing the death of two members of the community. The following day, at the Halayeb area, Beni Halba militiamen killed three of the gunmen, and captured one.

On 6th July, an armed group from around Dalami pursued Sudanese soldiers who had killed two herders and stolen cattle earlier that day. In the exchange of fire, one Sudanese soldier was killed and another injured, whilst two of the communal militia were wounded. The cattle was recovered, although soldiers were reported to have stolen three motorbikes.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: From 9th-16th July, RSF paramilitaries were reported to have abused civilians around Turr, Nertiti locality (Central Darfur, coordinates for Nertiti used). In addition to beating civilians, they looted property.

On 9th July, an unidentified gunman attacked a civilian Barkendi area (also known as Bar Kendi), close to the north of Katur in Tawila locality, North Darfur (coordinates for Katur used). The civilian was wounded in the attack.
09 July. Continued presence of of SLA Abdul Wahid forces in the Golo area led to further troop deployment of Sudanese armed forces to Golo.
On 9th July, armed herders attack a civilian on the road between Korma and Kokali, North Darfur (coordinates for Korma used). The civilian was wounded in the attack.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: From 9th-16th July, RSF paramilitaries were reported to have abused civilians around Turr, Nertiti locality (Central Darfur, coordinates for Nertiti used). In addition to beating civilians, they looted property.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On 11th July, NISS agents detained and severely beat a Darfuri student at the University of Khartoum, in Khartoum.
On 11th July, unidentified gunmen attacked displaced farmers who were returning to their area, near Janga, North Darfur. Two farmers were shot and wounded.

On 11th July, unknown gunmen killed a civilian, and wounded her husband (a local administrator), who died of his wounds whilst in hospital on the 18th July. The event took place at Digris, 15km west of Nyala, South Darfur (approximate coordinates used).

Agreement: On or before 11th July, the governor of South Darfur announced that a peace accord had been reached between the Masalit and Falata tribes, who had been engaged in conflict for some years. The agreeement appears to pave the way for a release of prisoners; an arrest of 'outlaws'; and the reorganisation of loaclities in the state.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: From 9th-16th July, RSF paramilitaries were reported to have abused civilians around Turr, Nertiti locality (Central Darfur, coordinates for Nertiti used). In addition to beating civilians, they looted property.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: From 9th-16th July, RSF paramilitaries were reported to have abused civilians around Turr, Nertiti locality (Central Darfur, coordinates for Nertiti used). In addition to beating civilians, they looted property.

On 12th July, security forces dispersed protests in Khartoum ""using force"". The protesters were demonstrating against the construction of two dams, and the failure to investigate the deaths of protestors in 2007.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On 12th July, NISS agents detained and severely beat another Darfuri student at the University of Khartoum, in Khartoum. Another Darfuri student was detained and severely beaten the day before. He was later released.
On 12th July, students from the Islamic Movement attacked the chairman of the Darfur Students Association at the University of Khartoum, Khartoum, breaking his teeth.

On 12th July, masked gunmen entered the house of a communal leader of Digrais village 25km south of Nyala, South Darfur (approximate coordinates used). The leader and one his children were wounded, and his wife killed.

On 12th July, President Bashir announced a unilateral ceasefire between the government and rebels fighting in Darfur, Blue Nile, and Southern Kordofan. He stated the ceasefire would last until the end of December 2018.

column6: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: UNSC approves the extension of UNAMID mandate by one year, as well as the controversial reduction of personnel (from 8,735 to 4,050 personnel, with police being unchanged at 2,500 personnel). Most UNAMID sites to close in Darfur, and HQ will be transferred to Golo. However, troop reductions are contingent on improving security.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: From 9th-16th July, RSF paramilitaries were reported to have abused civilians around Turr, Nertiti locality (Central Darfur, coordinates for Nertiti used). In addition to beating civilians, they looted property.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: From 9th-16th July, RSF paramilitaries were reported to have abused civilians around Turr, Nertiti locality (Central Darfur, coordinates for Nertiti used). In addition to beating civilians, they looted property.
On 15th July, around 40 gunmen attacked Abu Hashiem locality (South Kordofan), killing one person, and stealing 425 head of cattle. The attackers were believed to have come from Kadugli.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: From 9th-16th July, RSF paramilitaries were reported to have abused civilians around Turr, Nertiti locality (Central Darfur, coordinates for Nertiti used). In addition to beating civilians, they looted property.

On 15th July, three camel herders entered a farm in Faluja, Tawila locality (North Darfur, coordinates for Tawila used). When verbally challenged by the farmers, the herders shot two farmers, injuring both.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: From 9th-16th July, RSF paramilitaries were reported to have abused civilians around Turr, Nertiti locality (Central Darfur, coordinates for Nertiti used). In addition to beating civilians, they looted property.
On 17th July, unidentified militiamen beat a farmer with whips and sticks before robbing him of his belongings at Kombo Sendu village in Mukjar locality (Central Darfur, coordinates for Mukjar used).
Looting: On 18th July, unidentified militiamen looted cattle from farmers at Keredu and Kombo Saraf Majin villages in Mukjar locality (Central Darfur, coordinates for Mukjar used).

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 18th July, RSF paramilitaries shot and killed a man in Kalu, north of Tur, in Nertiti locality (coordinates for Nertiti used).

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column9: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 19th July, SLM/A-Al Nur rebels attacked government soldiers and RSF paramilitaries outside of Golo (Central Darfur). The claimed to have killed and wounded a number of soldiers, including three officers, and destroyed three vehicles (unknown fatalities coded as 10).

On or before 19th July, the SLM/A-Al Nur rebel spokesman accused government forces of attacking civilians (and raping women) at Dubo Naira, one and half kilometres from Golo (Central Darfur, coordinates for Golo used).

On 19th July, gunmen attacked the village of Tamra, Tawila locality (North Darfur, coordinates for Tawila used). One civilian was killed in the attack, and another injured. The attackers also stole cattle.

Weapons seizure: On or before 20th July, the governor of South Darfur announced that the second, forcible, phase of the disarmament programme in the area would now begin. A number of weapons, uniforms and vehicles were seized during the first (voluntary) phase.
On 22nd July, unknown gunmen killed one policeman and wounded three others in a shootout in Burum (South Darfur). The police were tracking cattle raiders.

On 22nd July, Sudanese forces stationed in Gog (South Darfur, coordinates for Kass used) shelled several areas in southern Jebel Marra. Two civilians were killed in the shelling, along with six livestock.
On 23rd July, militiamen shot and killed a pregnant woman near Tendy (Central Darfur). A suspect was later arrested by the police.

column8: El Jawamis El Lahaween Ethnic Militia (Sudan)
column17: On 23rd and 24th July, clashes between members of the El Jawamis El Lahaween ethnic group and Hausa (Sudan) ethnic group took place in the area of El Hamra (Gedaref region), following reports of disputes over grazing. 11 people were reported to have been killed in the clashes, and 13 tractors were burned. Dozens were reported to have been injured.
On 23rd July, herders attacked and killed a farmer at his farm close to Abu Jou village, El Radoom locality (South Darfur, coordinates for Buram used).
On 24th July, gunmen abducted two farmers from Dobo Umda (North Darfur). The whereabouts of the victims is unknown.

column8: El Jawamis El Lahaween Ethnic Militia (Sudan)
column17: On 23rd and 24th July, clashes between members of the El Jawamis El Lahaween ethnic group and Hausa (Sudan) ethnic group took place in the area of El Hamra (Gedaref region), following reports of disputes over grazing. 11 people were reported to have been killed in the clashes, and 13 tractors were burned. Dozens were reported to have been injured.

25 July. Salamat and Fellata militias clashed in Nadeif and Dangol villages west of Buram. 2 Fellata and 3 Salamat killed. Military deployed to prevent further clases, but clashes erupted again two days later.

Agreement: On or before 26th July, two factions of the SRF agreed to reconcile following their split in October 2015, spurred by a dispute over the chairmanship of the consortium of rebel and dissident groups. The agreement establishes a committee to establish the rules under which the two factions will be reuinted. The two SRF factions called on SPLM-N Abdel Aziz to rejoin the group.

column7: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Agreement: On 26th July, Sheikh Matar Younis - a partially-sighted religious scholar and human rights activist who had been arrested by NISS in Central Darfur on April 1st - was released in Khartoum, along with his co-accused (a merchant named Adam Haroun). His detention had drawn international condemnation.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: 26 July. Sudanese armed forces attacked SLA-Abdul Wahid troops in Komi village, east of Golo. SLA Informants got arrested in the operation

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: 27 July. RSF forces attacked Kebe village (close to Deribat) and killed five civilians and injured 1-4 for allegedly supporting rebels. They stole dozens of livestock and burned down houses. Another source reported the assailants as unidentified militiamen.
27 July. Renewed clashes between Salamat and Fellata militias in Nadeif and Dangol villages west of Buram. 1 Salamat killed

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column9: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 27th July, SLM/A-Nur rebels stated that they had repulsed an attack by government forces and militia allies (recorded here as RSF), in the area Barfara, East Jebl Marra (coordinates for East Jebel Marrah, Central Darfur, used). The rebels claimed to have killed 11 soldiers in the battle.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: 29 July. SLA Abdul Wahid forces clashed with Sudanese armed forces in Golol and tried to recapture the village but were unable to regain the position

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: 30 July. Sudanese armed forces fired artillery south and south east of Golo against suspected SLM/A-Nur positions. No information on damage or casualties provided.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: 30 July. Sudanese armed forces clashed with SLA Abdul Wahid troops in Wadi Toro

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: 30 July. Sudanese armed forces clashed with SLA Abdul Wahid troops in Mara

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: 30 July. SLA Abdul Wahid forces clashed with Sudanese armed forces in Golol and tried to recapture the village but were unable to regain the position

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: 30 July. Sudanese armed forces clashed with SLA Abdul Wahid troops in Karo (south east of Golo)

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: 01 August. Sudanese armed forces assaulted residents of Kuilla for supporting rebels

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: 01 August. Sudanese armed forces assaulted residents of Kaiya for supporting rebels

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: 01 August. Sudanese armed forces assaulted residents of Kawara for supporting rebels

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: 01 August. Sudanese armed forces assaulted residents of Tarantara for supporting rebels

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Weapons seizure: On 2nd August, the governor of West Darfur state announced that the military and RSF paramilitaries had undertaken a number of raids in the state since early July, and seized large amounts of weapons, ammunition and military equipment.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: 02 August. Sudanese armed forces fired artillery south and south east of Golo against suspected SLM/A-Nur positions. No information on damage or casualties provided.

On 3rd August, a brother and sister were killed by an unexploded grenade which they were believed to have been playing with, in the vicinity of Jinga, south of Tabit (coordinates for Tabit, North Darfur, used).

On 4th August, gunmen shot and killed a husband and wife in Kambo Di (Central Darfur, 5km west of Zalingei, approximate coordinates used), before looting and burning down dwellings in the village. The two victims were IDPs.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: 07 August. Sudanese armed forces clashed with SLA Abdul Wahid troops in Sabanga

On August 7th, 12 herders shot dead a civilian and wounded four others on farms south of Tabit (North Darfur). All the victims were female. The herders had allowed their livestock to graze on the farms, and when the farmers attempted to remove the livestock, they were attacked by the herders.

column7: JEM: Justice and Equality Movement; SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction)
column17: On 8th August, three Darfuri rebel groups - SLM/A-Minnawi, JEM, and SSLM-Transitional Council - extended their unilateral ceasefire by another three months.
09 August. Fur farmers clashed with a group of nomads in Hebry village, close to Feina. Four people killed, several injured and 100 head of livestock stolen

Weapons seizure: On or before August 10th, government security forces seized large amounts of weapons in the South Darfur region (coordinates for state capital Nyala used), in addition to arresting a number of ""outlaws"", and confiscating unregistered motorcycles. This weapons sweep is part of a government disarmament campaign applied to restive parts of Sudan.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Arrests: On 13th August, RSF paramilitary forces arrested associates of the detained former janjaweed and Revolutionary Awakening Movement leader Musa Hilal, at the Gurrat El Zawiya area (North Darfur, coordinates for state capital of El Fasher used). The arrested include Omda Ahmed Hamdan Bahar, Mohamed Omar Tagadem and Abdelnasir Omar, alongside an unspecified number of other associates.

column7: SAC: Students Against the Coup; Students (Sudan)
column17: On August 14th, police and protestors clashed following a peaceful demonstration by students against deteriorating conditions at the University of Gedaref (Gedaref state), and a poor quality of education. Police arrested 146 students, accusing them of rioting, damaging public property, and assaulting a public official. The University also subsequently suspended all classes in the faculties of Agriculture and Education.

column9: Prisoners (Sudan); SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction)
column17: On or before August 15th, Abdelsalam Mohamed Siddig - a prisoner of war - died in El Huda prison (Omdurman), whilst another three PoWs associated with SLM/A-TC died around this time. According to a statement issued by SLM/A-Minawi and SLM/A Transitional Council, their deaths were related to torture and maltreatment by their captors (note that no actor is specified as being responsible for his death. Police Forces of Sudan have been coded until further information is made available).

Weapons seizure: On and before August 15th, the authorities in South Kordofan state announced that they had so far seized 5,000 firearms (and registered 2,500) as part of a national disarmament campaign, targetting unstable areas of Sudan.

Agreement: On August 16th, the Joint Sudanese-Ethiopian Military Commission met in Khartoum, and concluded an initial agreement on a series of border disputes between the two countries (relating the movement of smugglers and people traffickers, as well as rebels, in addition to violent disputes over farmland between citizens in the border region). According to the agreement, both armies will withdraw from the border, and establish a joint patrol force by December. Discussion of outstanding issues over demaracation and land ownership will be ""accelerated"".

On August 16th, dozens of women met at the Ministry of Education in Khartoum to protest the death of 22 schoolgirls and 1 woman who drowned in a boat accident the previous day, as well as the deaths of 3 girls who died in Omdurman following the collapse of a wall.
On August 18th, a displaced Darfurian was shot dead by an unidentified gunmen as he travelled to Um Halab camp, in the area of Gereida (South Darfur).

On August 20th, unidentified gunmen shot and wounded the Nazir of Awlad Janoub. The event took place El Tadamon district (coordinates for Saraf Omra, North Darfur, used). The attackers shot him in the legs and destroyed his vehicle.

On or before August 26th, herders attacked Gubba village in Eastern Jebel Marrah (East Darfur), killing four civilians, wounding an unspecified number, and displacing around 500 individuals. The herders (some of whom were riding in vehicles, others on horse or camelback) then proceeded to loot money, property and animals.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: 26 August. Sudanese armed forces clashed with SLA Abdul Wahid troops in Gobbo. 1 soldier and two SLA fighters killed

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Around 27th August, an RSF paramilitary soldier beat two female doctors at the El Obeid hospital over a disagreement. Doctors at the hospital went on a three day strike after the incident to call for his arrest.
On August 27th, a displaced farmer was shot and killed by a herder, as a group of herders were passing his farm in Fata Borno (North Darfur).

From 27th to 30th August, students staged a sit-in protest at the University of El Gedaref (Gedaref state), following protests earlier in the month. The students were demonstrating against deteriorating conditions in the Faculty of Medicine. On 30th August, university administrators announced the indefinite suspension of classes in the faculty.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Looting: On or before August 27th, RSF paramilitaries stormed a police station in Tabit locality (North Darfur) and seized 150 camels which had been confiscated by the police. The camels had been confiscated following complaints by farmers that the camels had been destroying their farmland.

From 27th to 30th August, students staged a sit-in protest at the University of El Gedaref (Gedaref state), following protests earlier in the month. The students were demonstrating against deteriorating conditions in the Faculty of Medicine.Ten students were arrested by security services (recorded here as Police Forces) on the 28th August, before being released that night, amidst reports of security forces beating protesters, on or around the same day. On 30th August, university administrators announced the indefinite suspension of classes in the faculty.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Non-violent activity: On or around 29th and 30th August, RSF paramilitaries have been detaining secondary school students in the town of Mellit (North Darfur), and shaving their heads. The motivations behind these actions are unclear.
On August 29th, unknown gunmen shot and killed two IDPs who were travelling from Zalingei to their home in Hasahisa camp (coordinates for Zalingei, Central Darfur, used).
On August 30th, a herder shot and wounded a woman who was farming at Khazan Tungur (North Darfur).

On September 1st or 2nd, gunmen riding on motorbikes fired on a vehicle travelling to Rabkona from Mershing (coordinates for Mershing, South Darfur, used), killing a local Sheikh, and wounding four passengers. The gunmen then looted the vehicle, before seizing four passengers to use as hostages, beating them before releasing them four hours later (note that the source does not specify whether the abducted passengers and the same as those who were wounded in the gunfire).
On September 2nd, armed herders attacked displaced farmers at Kurfla, 5km west of Tabit (North Darfur, approximate coordinates used). Five civilians were injured in the attack.

On September 2nd, unknown gunmen shot dead a local butcher as he was making his way to Shurab from Wedhajam market in El Radoom locality (South Darfur, coordinates for Shurab used). The attackers then looted the victims body.

On or before September 2nd, gunmen robbed a house in Block 7 of Otash camp (South Darfur), stabbing a 17 year-old girl in the process. Another woman was stabbed in Block 6, though it is unclear whether or not the two incidents occurred at the same time.

On September 4th, two groups of students clashed at the University of Sennar at Singa (Blue Nile state). One group was in support of the Faculty of Education, and the other were supporters of the NCP. The NCP students then returned and attacked the pro-Faculty students with machetes and metal bars, wounding seven. The source does not specify the reason for the clashes.

On September 4th, a number of gunmen riding camels attacked a vehicle in the area of Dobo Umda in Tawila locality (North Darfur). The driver was killed, and his assistant seriously wounded. The gunmen then beat and whipped the survivors, before robbing them.

On or around September 5th, eight gunmen on camels attacked a vehicle in the area of Dobo Umda in Tawila locality (North Darfur). Four people were wounded (one seriously), and the gunmen proceeded to rob the passengers.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Prison Guards
column9: Prisoners (Sudan); SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction)
column17: On September 5th, the SLM-TC announced that a fifth member of the group - Yacoub Mohamed Hassan Deldoum - had died in Huda Prison (Omdurman). The group accused the government of deliberately failing to provide medical treatment.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: 05 September. RSF forces assaulted an IDP civilian in Nertiti for alleged support for rebels
On or around September 5th, police shot dead a man during a riot at a football match in Koka (Northern state). Several others - both rioters and police - were wounded in the clashes.
On or around September 5th, a female student was murdered by unknown assailants in El Rahad (North Kordofan), who had reportedly attempted to rape her.

On 6th and 7th September, protesters gathered in Delgo (Northern state), to demonstrate against the killing of a man during riots at a football game the previous day. The killing had raised concern among the Nubian community.

On September 6th, a teacher was shot and killed by a group of armed men in the area of Jeref (South Darfur, coordinates for Mershing used). The teacher attempted to stop the gunmen from raping young women on a farm, and was killed by the men immediately. Authorities have arrested six suspects.

On 6th and 7th September, protesters gathered in Delgo (Northern state), to demonstrate against the killing of a man during riots at a football game the previous day. The killing had raised concern among the Nubian community.

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On September 7th, a dispute between to RSF paramilitaries and an army officer escalated into violence in Kutum market (North Darfur). At least three people were killed (two RSF members, and a civilian), though a subsequent statement from the local Commissioner noted that 11 people were killed and wounded, including three regular soldiers, three RSF, and five civilians, without specifying the precise death toll (three fatalities have been coded for now).

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column17: On September 8th, a civilian died of wounds sustained when he and five others were arrested by Military Intelligance forces. He and the others were beaten for over a week. The incident took place in Abbasiya (South Kordofan), although the dates of the initial arrest are unclear (the source mentions that they took place after Eid El Adha in the third week of August. The men were arrested after criticising Military Intelligence for their invovlement in a road accident involving a motorbike driver.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column17: On September 8th, a trader was arrested by Military Intelligence in Bout (Blue Nile state), allegedly for not paying a bribe. He was released on September 17th after paying a fine; during his time in detention he had been beaten and kept in a metal container.

On September 8th, 12 armed herders attacked a police vehicle in the Nue area of Tawila locality (coordinates for Tawila, North Darfur, used). Police and an unspecified security force (coded here as the Sudanese military) gave chase, killing two herders, wounding three, and arresting two The police were guarding farmers in the area.

On September 9th, two groups of students clashed at the University of Sennar at Singa (Blue Nile state). One group was in support of the Faculty of Education, and the other were supporters of the NCP. Five people were wounded, though it was uunclear which faction they belonged too. It is likely these events are a continuation of a clash from the previous week (which has been vaguely attributed by the source to a dispute relating to membership forms for the NCP party).

On September 12th, a group of three armed herders raped two sisters (aged 15 and 17) for over three hours at gunpoint. The attack took place at a farm in Tayarat, close to the Zanzam refugee camp (coordinates for Zamzam, North Darfur, used). The victims were IDPs who were working on the farm. The perpetrators fled south after being chased by relatives and those living in the IDP camp, and the victims were taken to hospital.

""One national INGO staff member was assaulted at Daya village in Golo area. The staff member was admitted to Golo hospital for treatment. The assailants were reportedly part of the SLA/AW. Further information about the reason behind this attack is not available at this time.""

On September 12th, protesters gathered at the police station in Talodi (South Kordofan), following the arrest of five activists in the area on Sunday 9th September (the activists had been accused of filming prisons and military installations in the area). Two activists were released on bail later that afternoon.
16 September. Armed men in four trucks attacked two farmers in Jebel Marrah. After shooting one and beating the other, the attackers abducted them.

16 September. Armed herders abducted three IDPs from the Selo displacement camp in Mershing while they were collecting firewood. The perpetrators later released the IDPs but held their possessions for ransom.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Between September 16th-18th, SLM/A-Nur rebels clashed with the Sudanese army ""militiamen"" (coded here as RSF paramilitaries) at Gubbo (South Darfur). The fighting claimed the lives of 16 RSF soldiers, 6 SLM/A-Nur rebels, and 10 civilians (fatalities spread across three days of fighting).
On September 16th, unknown gunmen stabbed a female student from El Geneina University.

17 September. Herders reportedly brought their animals to graze on a farm in Arashu. When two farmers objected to this the herders beat them with sticks. The coordinates are approximate (based on reports that Arashu is 40 KM south of Tabit).

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On September 17th, protesters gathered again at El Geneina, this time to protest against detiorating conditions at the University. NISS forces entered the University premises and attacked the demonstrators, using tear gas, batons, and firing bullets. Dozens were reported to have been injured (four or five students seriously), and 15 were later arrested (six of whom were released).
17 September. Military officials detained three IDPS from the Tur camp in Nierteti. Family members have inquired at the local military garrisons, but they deny holding the detainees.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Between September 16th-18th, SLM/A-Nur rebels clashed with the Sudanese army ""militiamen"" (coded here as RSF paramilitaries) at Gubbo (South Darfur). The fighting claimed the lives of 16 RSF soldiers, 6 SLM/A-Nur rebels, and 10 civilians (fatalities spread across three days of fighting).

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Between September 16th-18th, SLM/A-Nur rebels clashed with the Sudanese army ""militiamen"" (coded here as RSF paramilitaries) at Gubbo (South Darfur). The fighting claimed the lives of 16 RSF soldiers, 6 SLM/A-Nur rebels, and 10 civilians (fatalities spread across three days of fighting).

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: 19 September. SLM/A-Nur declared a unilateral cessation of hostilities to allow humanitarian access to those affected by landslides earlier in the month. The ceasefire was declared to be in effect for three months (until 18/12/2018).

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On September 20th and 21st, the Sudanese army clashed with SLM/A-Nur rebels at a number of locations in South Darfur, including Sabun El Fagur, Gur Lumbung, Kuilla and Amrain. Three rebels were killed (deaths spread over events), and a rebel was injured.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On September 20th and 21st, the Sudanese army clashed with SLM/A-Nur rebels at a number of locations in South Darfur, including Sabun El Fagur, Gur Lumbung, Kuilla and Amrain. Three rebels were killed (deaths spread over events), and a rebel was injured.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On September 20th and 21st, the Sudanese army clashed with SLM/A-Nur rebels at a number of locations in South Darfur, including Sabun El Fagur, Gur Lumbung, Kuilla and Amrain. Three rebels were killed (deaths spread over events), and a rebel was injured.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On September 20th and 21st, the Sudanese army clashed with SLM/A-Nur rebels at a number of locations in South Darfur, including Sabun El Fagur, Gur Lumbung, Kuilla and Amrain. Three rebels were killed (deaths spread over events), and a rebel was injured.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On September 20th and 21st, the Sudanese army clashed with SLM/A-Nur rebels at a number of locations in South Darfur, including Sabun El Fagur, Gur Lumbung, Kuilla and Amrain. Three rebels were killed (deaths spread over events), and a rebel was injured.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On September 20th and 21st, the Sudanese army clashed with SLM/A-Nur rebels at a number of locations in South Darfur, including Sabun El Fagur, Gur Lumbung, Kuilla and Amrain. Three rebels were killed (deaths spread over events), and a rebel was injured.
22 September. Members of the Hausa and Rufaa ethnic groups clashed, resulting in two fatalities and twelve injuries. The conflict reportedly stemmed from two men harassing a woman.

23 September. Armed men wearing military fatigue attacked a group of people on their way home from the Tur market. The attackers, who arrived on horseback, shot and wounded two civilians. The perpetrators then robbed the group.
24 September. Two armed men attempted to rape a woman in Deleig. When she and her mother resisted they stabbed the woman, killing her.
On or before September 24th, herders shot and injured a 13 year-old girl at Kebe (north of Nertiti camp, Central Darfur. Coordinates for Nertiti used), as she and three other IDPs gathered firewood.

On September 25th, armed herders attacked Umm Baji village in Tawila locality (North Darfur). One civilian was wounded in the gunfire, and the attackers proceeded to loot the village. (Note: An eye-witness described the attackers as ""janjaweed"", but they have been coded here as an unidentified communal militia of herders, rather than as a paramilitary force).
On September 25th, gunmen attacked a commercial vehicle in the Hashaba area in Tullus locality (South Darfur) as it was travelling to Gereida. Two passengers were wounded by the gunfire.

On September 25th, around 20 gunmen riding camels attacked three commercial vehicles on the road south of Gereida (South Darfur). One civilian was killed in the attack, and ten were injured (three seriously). The attackers were reported to have beaten the passengers with whips and their rifles, and stole their possessions alongside the three vehicles.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: 25 September. The RSF began forcibly shaving the heads of men with ""deviant hair styles"" in the areas of El Haj Yousef, El Tawidat, El Karton, and El Radmiyat in northern Khartoum.

26 September. Herders brought their cattle to graze on land in Umm Baji. When local farmers confronted them they killed one and abducted the other. Coordinates are approximate (based off of humanitarian map).
27 September. Soldiers reportedly shot at a farmer who was tending to his field east of Thur. The farmer was seriously injured.
27 September. Two men wearing military fatigues killed a civilian when he objected to them stealing his donkey in Galab.

28 September (no precise date given). Soldiers, who reportedly appeared intoxicated, shot at residents of a displacement camp in Thur. The soldiers then robbed two IDPs. Two civilians were injured during the attack.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column17: On September 30th, another trader was arrested by Military Intelligence in Bout (Blue Nile state), allegedly for not paying a bribe. He was released on October 3rd after paying a fine; during his time in detention he had been beaten and kept in a metal container. This is the second case of its kind reported in September.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: End September-early October: RSF arrested and detained nearly 30 IDPs accused of having connections with rebel movements Jebel Marra at Sortony IDP camp (North Darfur), and taken them to their nearby base at Kobe.

On October 1st, the Sudanese Armed Forces were reported to have shelled several villages in south-western Jebel Marrah (West Darfur), according the SLM-AW. The locations mentioned by the group were Baladunq, Galol, Torung Toura and Sorong. The spokesperson for the group said that ""some"" civilians were killed, without specifying the number (low estimate of 3 fatalities have been coded).

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Prison Guards
column9: Prisoners (Sudan); SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction)
column17: On October 3rd, Asim Omar was tortured by guards at Kober prison, Khartoum. He was severely beaten and whipped, and was hospitalised as a result of the torture.

column6: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: On October 4th and 8th, UNAMID forces handed two IDP sites in Al Salam and El Sereif (South and North Darfur) to the Sudanese government. The Al Salam site, which was being used as a centre for community police, will retain this function under the control of the Sudanese police (in conjunction with local elders), whilst the El Sereif site will assume a new role as a community centre and technical college. Further team sites will be transferred over the remainder of 2018.

On October 4th, a local Omda of the Lira tribe was shot dead by unknown gunmen close to the Military Intelligence building in Um Brambeta, Abu Kershola locality (South Kordofan). Nearby soldiers did not respond to the gunshot.
On October 4th, a civilian was killed when his donkey stepped on an unspecified UXO as he travelled to his farm at Mashrou Abuzeid (coordinates for Tawila, North Darfur, used).

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On October 4th, unspecified government forces (coded here as SAF) attacked SLM/A-Nur rebels at Lango, close to Golo (Central Darfur, coordinates used). There are no reports of casualties.

On October 6th, a group of men, believed to be herders, raped three girls (ages 9, 12 and 14) in the area of Aishbara west of Murnei (coordinates for Murnei, West Darfur, used). One suspect was apprehended by a local rescue team.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On October 6th, unspecified government forces (coded here as SAF) again clashed with SLM/A-Nur rebels at Lango, close to Golo (Central Darfur, coordinates used). One SLM/A-Nur fighter was killed, and a civilian belonging to the Fur ethnic group.

On October 6th, three herders shot a farmer who was trying to drive their animals off his land. The event took place in the area of Donki Abyad in Gereida locality (coordinates for Gereida, South Darfur, used).
On October 9th, herders shot and wounded two female farmers after they tried to clear their cattle from their farm near Tabit (North Darfur). The victims were taken to hospital.
On October 9th, a male farmer was shot dead by herders near Kakero village, Tawila locality (North Darfur). The herders then stole the victims' camel.
On October 9th, students at El Gezira University (at Wad Madani, Al Jazirah) clashed with NCP students, in which the NCP students were driven from the dormitory.
On October 9th, two camel herders attempted to rape a woman in Tirbo, Tawila locality (North Darfur). The woman resisted, and was beaten with an axe, causing serious injuries.

On October 10th, police dispersed student protesters with tear gas and batons at El Gezira University (at Wad Madani, Al Jazirah) a day after fighting between students and NCP student supporters. A number of students were injured and at least 24 students were arrested (20 of whom were acquited).

On October 11th, renewed clashes took place between students supporting the NCP and those aligned with other political parties, at the University of El Gezira. A number of buildings at the University of El Gezira were set ablaze during the violence.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Between 12th October to 31st October, SLM/A-Nur rebels fought amongst themselves on at least four occassions, in Daya, Dar Al Aman, Jokosti and Jebel Gheit (all in Central Darfur, the last two being near Golo). Eight fighters were reported to have been killed in the clashes. Four events coded at time precision 2 throughout the month, with two fatalities apiece.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On October 12th, unspecified government forces (coded here as SAF) attacked SLM/A-Nur rebels in the area of Gur Lambung (South Darfur state). There are no further details.

On October 13th, a man was shot and seriously wounded by unknown assailants in the vicinity of Kali Koten (coordinates for Jebel Marrah, Central Darfur used). The attackers robbed his belongings, as well as his donkey.

On October 13th, herders attacked the Tabit police station (North Darfur state), after police had confiscated their animals (which had been taken after they had caused damage on nearby farms). One police constable was wounded in the attack, and the herders made off with the confiscated animals.

On October 13th, twelve Christians were arrested by security forces in Nyala (South Darfur). Three worshippers from a Nuba ethnic group were released, though eight Darfuri worshippers as well as the priest were reported to have been detained and tortured. On October 21st the eight worshippers were released after they reconverted to Islam; the priest was released the following day on bail (he has been charged with apostasy, after refusing to reconvert).

On October 13th, herders attacked a woman in the area of Jebein (to the west of Tabit, coordinates for Tabit, North Darfur, used). The victim had both her arms broken in the assault. The woman had tried to move the herders' animals from her farm.

On October 14th, the Sudan Armed Forces based in Kara shelled Wadi Tremel in southern Jebel Marrah (coordintes for Kara, South Darfur, used), according to the SLM/A-Nur. Two civilians were killed in the shelling, and three were wounded. SLM/A-Nur forces are based in the area, but it was unclear if the event was part of fighting between rebels and government forces.

On October 14th, teachers throughout West Kordofan state announced they were going on strike, due to unpaid salaries for the month of September (coordinates for El Fula used). In Abu Zabad locality, a three-day general strike by all civil servants went into effect the following day. This follows teacher strikes in Northern state the previous week.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On October 14th, journalists protested outside the parliament building in Omdurman, over a journalist being prevented from entering the parliament. NISS dispersed the protest, and arrested 9 journalists.

On October 15th, ten herders riding camels attacked a commercial vechicle between Gereida and Sirgeila (coordinates for Geredia, South Darfur, used). Two civilians were killed, and four wounded in the gunfire. The herders then robbed the surviving passengers.

On October 15th, herders tortured several IDPs who were collecting firewood north of Murnei IDP camp (West Darfur). The victims were detained and beaten for an entire day, with four being severely beaten. After releasing them the following day, the herders threatened to kill the IDPs if they returned to collect firewood.

At an unspecified time between 26th September to 30th October (coded here as Oct 15th, at precision 3), the Sudanese army attacked the areas of Rabkona and Airri in southern Jebel Marrah (Central Darfur), killing 25 (15 in Rabkona, and 10 in Airri). The information was provided by the SLM/A-Nur.

At an unspecified time between 26th September to 30th October (coded here as Oct 15th, at precision 3), the Sudanese army attacked the villages of Koor, Gubbo, Touri, Borbasi, Jonglei, Fusu, Argda, Wira, Jedoua Kani and Berifga. According to the SLM/A-Nur, at least 25 civilians were killed in the assaults, and farms in the areas were destroyed. Fatalities spread over seven locations for which coordinates were found.

At an unspecified time between 26th September to 30th October (coded here as Oct 15th, at precision 3), the Sudanese army attacked the villages of Koor, Gubbo, Touri, Borbasi, Jonglei, Fusu, Argda, Wira, Jedoua Kani and Berifga. According to the SLM/A-Nur, at least 25 civilians were killed in the assaults, and farms in the areas were destroyed. Fatalities spread over seven locations for which coordinates were found.

At an unspecified time between 26th September to 30th October (coded here as Oct 15th, at precision 3), the Sudanese army attacked the villages of Koor, Gubbo, Touri, Borbasi, Jonglei, Fusu, Argda, Wira, Jedoua Kani and Berifga. According to the SLM/A-Nur, at least 25 civilians were killed in the assaults, and farms in the areas were destroyed. Fatalities spread over seven locations for which coordinates were found.

At an unspecified time between 26th September to 30th October (coded here as Oct 15th, at precision 3), the Sudanese army attacked the villages of Koor, Gubbo, Touri, Borbasi, Jonglei, Fusu, Argda, Wira, Jedoua Kani and Berifga. According to the SLM/A-Nur, at least 25 civilians were killed in the assaults, and farms in the areas were destroyed. Fatalities spread over seven locations for which coordinates were found.

At an unspecified time between 26th September to 30th October (coded here as Oct 15th, at precision 3), the Sudanese army attacked the villages of Koor, Gubbo, Touri, Borbasi, Jonglei, Fusu, Argda, Wira, Jedoua Kani and Berifga. According to the SLM/A-Nur, at least 25 civilians were killed in the assaults, and farms in the areas were destroyed. Fatalities spread over seven locations for which coordinates were found.

At an unspecified time between 26th September to 30th October (coded here as Oct 15th, at precision 3), the Sudanese army attacked the villages of Koor, Gubbo, Touri, Borbasi, Jonglei, Fusu, Argda, Wira, Jedoua Kani and Berifga. According to the SLM/A-Nur, at least 25 civilians were killed in the assaults, and farms in the areas were destroyed. Fatalities spread over seven locations for which coordinates were found.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On October 15th, students at El Nilein University (Khartoum) protested in solidarity with fellow students at El Gezira University. NSS agents attacked the protesters (many of whom appeared to belong to Darfuri student associations), beating the demonstrators and arresting an unspecified number.

At an unspecified time between 26th September to 30th October (coded here as Oct 15th, at precision 3), the Sudanese army were reported to have raped several women during their attacks in southern Jebel Marrah (Central Darfur), including a 14 year-old girl in the village of Liba. The information came from the SLM/A-Nur rebellion.

On October 15th, herders shot and seriously wounded a farmer in Susawa, north of Tabit (coordinates for Tabit, North Darfur, used). The farmer had attempted to clear the herders and their animals from his farm.
On October 17th, a protest organised by a women's campaign was staged in front of the Human Right Commission in Khartoum, over the detention and torture of the activists Asim Omar and Hisham Ali.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Between 12th October to 31st October, SLM/A-Nur rebels fought amongst themselves on at least four occassions, in Daya, Dar Al Aman, Jokosti and Jebel Gheit (all in Central Darfur, the last two being near Golo). Eight fighters were reported to have been killed in the clashes. Four events coded at time precision 2 throughout the month, with two fatalities apiece.

On October 18th, gunmen attacked a commercial vehicle in the area of Khor Talba near Turr (coordinates for Nertiti, Central Darfur, used). Three passengers were killed in the gunfire, and two injured. The attackers proceeded to rob the victims.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On October 18th, SLM/A-Nur rebels were reported to have assaulted farmers of the Fur ethnic group at Kurambe (North Darfur), and stole some of their produce.

On October 19th, two herders shot a farmer near Falouha in East Jebel Marrah, after she attempted to prevent them from stealing her sorghum. She sustained severe injuries (the source indicates she was shot several times, and survived).
On October 20th, three gunmen killed a trader at El Dumma market (Mershing locality, South Darfur), following a dispute. The attackers fled the market immediately afterwards.

On October 20th, a teacher was shot and killed by gunmen as he attempted to protect two of his female pupils from being attacked on their farm in Mershing locality (South Darfur). The attackers fled afterwards.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On or before October 21st, RSF paramilitaries forcibly seized gold-bearing rocks from Jebel Amer goldmine (North Darfur). They stole four truck-loads of the rock, and forced local mine mill owners to grind the rock to extract the gold. Local mining officials and police have ordered all regular staff to leave the mine.

On October 22nd, herders attacked farmers (who had confronted the herders when they moved their animals onto the farmers' land) in the area of Hshaba (North Darfur). The herders beat the farmers with sticks, injuring four, some seriously.

On October 24th, a man died in police custody (note: the location given by the source is Alobid, North Kordofan. However, there is no information on a location matching this name, so the location is recorded here as El Obeid, on the assumption that Alobid is a mistranslation of the El Obeid). According to the source, the victim was severely beaten by the police, and died when his head was hit against a concrete floor. The victim had been arrested along with others the previous day, on suspicion of drinking alcohol, and the source indicates that the other detainees (since released) were also beaten by police.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Between 12th October to 31st October, SLM/A-Nur rebels fought amongst themselves on at least four occassions, in Daya, Dar Al Aman, Jokosti and Jebel Gheit (all in Central Darfur, the last two being near Golo). Eight fighters were reported to have been killed in the clashes. Four events coded at time precision 2 throughout the month, with two fatalities apiece.

During the week beginning 22nd October, an Ethiopian Shifta militia attacked a farm by El Mudiriya village in El Quresha (coordinates for Gedaref, Kassala, used). One farmer was killed and another wounded in the attack, which comes amidst tensions in the border region.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On October 25th, a 39 year-old man died in NISS custody in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile state), reportedly due to torture and neglect. The man had been arrested on August 9th, and accused of smuggling fuel to South Sudan. Note: the victim's maltreatment took place in But (Blue Nile), although his captors are not specified, and have been coded here as NISS, given his transfer to the NISS facility at the time of his death.

On October 25th, a herder militia was reported to have raped seven women and girls, and wounded twelve other women with machetes and rifle butts. The attack took place at Aliba Taringa (South Darfur), and the attackers proceeded to rob the victims after the attack.

October 25th, around 20 armed herders attacked a farm at Jemmeza Nabagaya. Eight farmers (three of whom were women) were wounded in the attack, which followed from a previous incident of crop destruction in which the herders were ordered to pay compensation to the farmers. Police have made one arrest in connection with the incident.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
