column17: On October 25th, students protested at Al Neelain University in Khartoum, in support of their fellow students at El Gezira University. NISS police, alongside student supporters of the NCP, broke up the protest, with police using tear gas, and beating the students with assorted objects.

On October 26th, gunmen riding horses and camels attacked civilians at Dandi near Rakuna in the eastern Jebel Marrah area (coordinates for East Jebel Marrah, Central Darfur used. Note that the source mentions the attack took place within South Darfur). Two civilians were killed (including a local sheikh), and two were wounded. The source notes that the gunmen were intending to loot from the area.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On October 26th, SLM rebels (of an unspecified faction, coded here as SLM/A-Nur) engaged with gunmen riding horses and camels, who had earlier attacked civilians in the area of Dandi. The source indicates the clash took place at or nearby the area of the earlier incident, in Eastern Jebel Marrah (coordinates for East Jebel Marrah, Central Darfur, used). Five gunmen were ""killed or captured"" (coded as 3 fatalities) and the remainder fled the area.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On October 26th, an RSF paramilitary attempted to rape a woman in Muzbat (North Darfur), but was prevented from doing so after civilians came to her rescue.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On October 26th, angry residents in Muzbat (North Darfur) stormed the base of RSF paramilitaries after one of them attempted to rape a woman. RSF fired upon them, leaving one killed and arresting two.
On October 27th, a 16 year-old IDP was shot and killed by unknown gunmen between the villages of Amar and Darisa in Wadi Saleh (Central Darfur).

On October 28th, an armed group - suspected to be herders - attacked a police station in Darmuga, Foro Baranga locality (coordinates for Bondetto, West Darfur, used). A policeman was shot dead in the attack, and the herders stole weapons and ammunition from the station.
On October 29th, three armed men riding camels raped a girl and held her mother at gunpoint, at their farm in Shangil Tobay (North Darfur). The attackers then fled the scene.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) University Police
column17: During the week beginning October 29th, a student was beaten by university police at the University of Sennar (Blue Nile state). The event comes amidst tensions between parts of the student community and the University over registration status and a ban on political activity, and earlier clashes in September between NCP students and non-NCP students.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Between 12th October to 31st October, SLM/A-Nur rebels fought amongst themselves on at least four occassions, in Daya, Dar Al Aman, Jokosti and Jebel Gheit (all in Central Darfur, the last two being near Golo). Eight fighters were reported to have been killed in the clashes. Four events coded at time precision 2 throughout the month, with two fatalities apiece.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On November 1st, witnesses saw approximately 600 trucks carrying RSF personnel moving from El Fasher (North Darfur) to Kafout, before travelling to El Tina via Kutum on November 4th. The reason for their movement has not been confirmed, though an RSF commander said Nov 3rd that troops would be deployed to the Libyan border to track down armed groups operating from Libya.

On November 3rd, a soldier fired at civilians in El Faw market (Kassala), killing a trader and wounding six other civilians. The motivation for the attack is unclear, and the solider has been arrested.
On November 3rd, a herder shot and wounded a civilian in the Falluja area south of Dobo Umda (coordinates for Dobo Umda, North Darfur, used). The herder then robbed the victim, and stole his donkey.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Prison Guards
column17: On November 3rd, two prisoners were shot by prison guards at Omdurman Prison. One prisoner was killed and another wounded, and detained. The prisoners were alleged to have attempted to escape, although no further details are available.

On November 5th, five gunmen described as ""pastoralists"" attacked a farm at Hamir al-Digel village in An Nahud locality (North Kordofan), killing two South Sudanese farm workers, and a Sudanese bystander. The motive for the attack appears to be theft of farm produce on the part of the attacking group.

On Nov 7th, RSF paramilitaries abducted 35 people at an unspecified location in Central Darfur state (coordinates for the state capital, Zalingei, used). 16 of the abducted were reported to be IDPs. On 15th Feb 2019, all but three of the abductees were released.

column7: JEM: Justice and Equality Movement; SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction)
column17: On November 9th, three Darfuri rebel groups - SLM/A-Minnawi, JEM, and SSLM-Transitional Council - extended their unilateral ceasefire by a further three months, until February 8th, 2019.

""Near Agok Sector South, a security guard working for an INGO was shot by an unknown gunman from behind at Wunpeth town while off duty. He died at the hospital. The incident is being investigated by police with UNISFA assistance.""

On November 10th, a group of five gunmen shot and wounded a farmer in the area of Silokandro, to the west of Shangil Tobay (North Darfur state). He had attempted to protect women working on a farm from the five gunmen, who were attempting to rape the women. The women were able to escape during the shooting. The gunmen then burned crops belonging to the farmer they had shot.

On November 11th, an unidentified group of gunmen attacked a commercial vehicle in the vicinity of Salili, 10km north of Umm Dukhun (approximate coordinates used). One passenger was wounded after the gunmen fired at the vehicle, forcing it to stop. The attackers then robbed the passengers, before fleeing the scene.
On November 11th, a female farmer was assaulted with a machete on her farm in Umm Baji (North Darfur state), and was taken to hospital in El Fasher. There are no further details about the incident.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On November 11th, SLM/A-Nur rebels ambushed RSF paramilitary forces in the area of Jawa (South Darfur), killing 7 RSF soldiers and woundig seven and destroying a vehicle. There were no reports of casualties on the side of the rebels. RSF forces withdrew from the area the following day.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On November 12th, RSF paramilitaries shelled areas to the south and west of Deribat (South Darfur state), wounding seven civilians. The source suggests the violence was in response to the large numbers of casualties inflicted on the RSF in an event the previous day.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On November 12th, RSF paramilitaries attacked Deribat market (South Darfur state). Five civilians were killed in the gunfire, six went missing (reported on November 18th) and dozens were injured. RSF soldiers then beat civilians and looted goods in the market. The source suggests the violence was in response to the large numbers of casualties inflicted on the RSF in an event the previous day.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column17: On November 12th, SLM/A-Nur rebels were reported to have abducted three members of the SAF Military Intelligence in the area of Manabu near Golo (Central Darfur). The rebels reportedly killed two of the abductees, though it is unclear whether the killings were part of the abduction operation, or occurred at a later time (coded as one battle, pending further information).

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On November 12th, ten members of the Sudanese Awakening Revolutionary Council were arrested in Omdurman, including several senior figures within the group. This is the latest in a series of periodic arrests of figures associated with the group founded by ex-Janjaweed leader Musa Hilal.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On November 13th, RSF paramilitaries based in Deribat (South Darfur state) shelled nearby areas, with two children killed and another child wounded when their home to the east of Deribat was hit by a projectile. A fire broke out as a result of the shelling, burning the surrounding two acres of farm land.

On November 14th, police clashed with relatives of Asim Omar (a student on death row, who was charged with the murder of a police officer in April 2016) outside Khartoum Criminal Court North, where a hearing related to the charges against Omar was taking place. The lawyer representing the accused was also assaulted by a police officer.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On November 15th, SLM/A-Nur rebels shelled SAF soldiers based in Deribat (South Darfur), killing one and injuring a further two. The attack was in response to violence by government forces against a civilians in the same area on Nov 12th, according to the source.
On or around November 15th, herders shot and killed a man in the area of Dola (North Darfur), and then robbed the deceased of his money as well as his donkey.
On November 15th, a police officer shot a man dead and wounded his wife at Umm Dukhun (Central Darfur). There are no further details.
On or around November 15th, armed men shot dead a civilian at Umm Dukhun (Central Darfur), and then robbed the deceased.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On November 15th, SLM/A-Nur rebels and SAF clashed at Kauri (coordinates for Jebel Marrah, Central Darfur, used). One government soldier was killed in the fighting and two injured.

On November 17th, seven armed herders fired at farmers in Zuroug village (approximate coordinates 5km west of Gereida, South Darfur, used), after the farmers attempted to clear them from their land. One farmer was wounded in the gunfire.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On November 17th, RSF forces herding camels trespassed onto farms in Korofata (Central Darfur). When farmers protested, the RSF paramilitaries fired into the air, and then beat the farmers, wounding several.

On November 17th, seven armed herders clashed with police forces in Zuroug village (5km west of Gereida, South Darfur, approx. coordinates used), following an earlier incident where the herders had attacked farmers at the same location. Two police killed and one of their vehicles destroyed. Three herders were arrested.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On November 18th, RSF paramilitaries abducted 21 civilians east of Kalinga (coordinates for Kedilnye, Central Darfur, used). They offered to release the hostages on return of the camels, or cash compensation.

On or around November 18th, eight gunmen beat and robbed four IDPs near Abata (Central Darfur). The source indicates the victims were beaten with sticks, though one was seriously injured after being attacked by an axe.

On November 18th, armed herders attacked female farmers at an unspecified location in west Mershing locality (South Darfur). Two of the women were seriously injured, in an attack which involved beating and whipping.
On November 18th, the Sudan Air Force dropped bombs in several areas of Jebel Marrah, including Kuweila (South Darfur). RSF forces arrested six civilians in the areas which had been bombed.

On November 18th, the Sudan Air Force dropped bombs in several areas of Jebel Marrah (Central Darfur), including Beringo, Kody, and Berbera. RSF forces arrested six civilians in the areas which had been bombed (four male, two female).

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On November 18th, SLM/A-Nur rebels accused RSF paramilitaries (potentially alongside regular SAF soldiers) of attacking their positions at Tibein, in northern Jebel Marrah.
On November 18th, the Sudan Air Force dropped bombs in the area of Kutrum (Central Darfur), killing a female civilian. RSF forces arrested six people in areas under bombardment that day.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On November 21st, SLM/A-Nur rebels accused RSF paramilitaries of attacking their positions at Fujo and Hillet Ateem in western Jebel Marrah (coordinates for Jebel Marrah, Central Darfur, used). According to the rebels, 14 RSF paramilitaries were killed in the fighting, and one civilian was killed and three injured in the crossfire. The rebels also said they seized a number of SALW, and fourteen motorbikes from RSF forces.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On November 22nd NISS agents beat two students (one seriously) outside the University of Dongola (Northern state), after the students had reportedly written a letter to the Dean of the Faculty of Arts, outlining a number of demands aimed at improving the ""university environment"".

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On November 24th, fighting between RSF paramilitaries and SLM/A-Nur rebels was reported in the areas of Kara, Saboon El Fag and Sina in southern Jebel Marrah (South Darfur). One civilian was killed and two injured (no location for the fatality has been specified; the death has been coded as being in Kara).

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On November 24th, fighting between RSF paramilitaries and SLM/A-Nur rebels was reported in the areas of Kara, Saboon El Fag and Sina in southern Jebel Marrah (South Darfur). One civilian was killed and two injured (no location for the fatality has been specified; the death has been coded as being in Kara).

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On November 24th, SLM/A-Nur forces reported being attacked by a group of 400 RSF paramilitaries in 18 armoured vehicles in the area of Feina in south-east Jebel Marrah (South Darfur state). SLM reported 18 RSF soldiers dead and 18 wounded in the battle. Sources note one civilian also killed and 40 injured in total. The South Darfur government authorities confirmed that the incident had taken place, and alleged that soldiers were sent in to protect civilians and herders against raiding by the rebels.
On November 25th, herders attacked farmers at an unspecified location in Mershing locality (South Darfur), after herders encroached on the farmers' land. There are no further details.
On November 25th, unspecified government forces (recorded here as SAF) attacked Daya village (Central Darfur). There is no further information.

On November 26th, around 20 herders attacked farmers at farms close to Sagur village (South Darfur) after the farmers had attempted to clear the herders from their land. One farmer was shot and wounded in the attack.

On November 26th, herders attacked three female farmers who were working on farms in an area between Tabit and Hashaba (coordinates for Tabit, North Darfur state, used). The herders attacked the women with sticks and axes. The motive for the attack is not specified in the source.

On November 27th, representatives from communities of herders and farmers based in and around Dobo Umda (North Darfur) signed an agreement regulating water access, and for herders to return wells they had been occupying to local farmers.

On November 27th, representatives from the Rizaygat and Maaliya ethnic groups signed ""a declaration of peaceful coexistence"" in Khartoum, under a government-brokered deal. This follows serious fighting between the two groups in East Darfur in July 2017, and subsequent arrests of various leaders of the groups at the end of that month. 13 omdas from both groups have been released, though dozens from both groups are still being held in prisons in Khartoum and Port Sudan.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On or before November 27th, SLM/A-Nur rebels accused RSF paramilitaries of burning farmland in parts of south-eastern Jebel Marra (including in Feina and Kadineer; coordinates for Feina, South Darfur, used), and also of denying access to nearby marketplaces to civilians living in the area. The rebels claim that the RSF are punishing civilians in the area, after they incurred substantial losses at a battle in the area of Feina on Nov 24th.

On or before November 29th, an armed group from Ethiopia shot dead a farmer and wounded four others in an attack that took place west of E Qallaba (Kassala state). The wounded are being treated in hospital.

On November 29th, armed men (described as herders, but wearing military uniform) attacked a farm in Gemiza Kuroma valley (South Darfur). The source indicates that the gunmen first attacked women on the farm (who they were allegedly preparing to rape), before several male farmers intervened. The gunmen then opened fire at the male farmers, wounding three, before fleeing the scene.

On November 30th, an armed group described as ""militiamen"" wearing military uniforms burned down a mosque which was under construction in Labous village (coordinates for Kutum, North Darfur, used). The mosque was being built by residents and some IDPs, and the source states that the militiamen torched the mosque in protest at the imminent return of IDPs from nearby camps. Reports emerged of the same group preventing returnees from entering the village around the same time.

On November 30th, four armed herders fired at farmers attempting to clear them from their land, near Kobe village (South Darfur, approximate coordinates used based on Kobe at 4km from Gereida according to media source). One farmer was wounded in the attack.

On December 1st, armed herders shot and wounded 11 farmers (five seriously) in Kombo Denko village (Central Darfur, approximate coordinates used based on location 20km east of Zalingei according to media source). The farmers had been attempting to chase away the herders and their livestock from their farms.

On or before December 1st, six police officers opened fire on a vehicle in Omdurman, wounding a businessman and one passenger. The businessman was suspected of conducting illicit arms deals, and two weapons were found in the vehicle (note that it later transpired that the businessman had a license for the firearms).

On December 2nd, herders shot dead four civilians and wounded one other at the village of Argud (coordinates for Kulbus, West Darfur used). The herders accused nearby villagers of being responsible for killing a herder in the vicinity of the village (recorded as a separate event). When villagers refused to hand over the accused individual the herders opened fire.

On December 2nd, protesters from the Sudanese Awakening Revolutionary Council were arrested at an unspecified location in Darfur (coordinates for Adilla, East Darfur used, due to President al-Bashir speaking at this location on the date of the protest). The demonstrators were calling for Musa Hilal and other members of the SARC to be released from prison.

On or before December 2nd, a herder was killed in unclear circumstances, near the village of Argud (coordinates for Kulbus, West Darfur used). The herders accused nearby villagers of being responsible for the killing. There are no further details.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On or before December 4th, RSF paramilitaries assaulted the driver of a government official of East Darfur state at an unspecified point on the road between Adilla and Ed Daein (coordinates for Adilla, East Darfur, used), allegedly for failing to make way for the RSF soldiers. The RSF captain intervened to stop the assault, and apologised to the official.

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On or before December 4th, an unknown armed group attacked RSF paramilitaries at Tadwa (coordinates for Zalingei, Central Darfur, used), killing an RSF soldier and wonding another. The attackers then stole 140 camels, which the source indicates were being guarded by the RSF troops.
On December 4th, herders shot and killed a farmer in the area of Jokhana (coordinates for Gereida, South Darfur, used). The farmer had been attempting to clear the herders from his land.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On December 5th, RSF paramilitaries shot dead a trader in El Obeid (North Kordofan) after attempting to rob him. The state police chief said three suspects had been arrested, and assured the public that three other suspects would be arrested too.

On December 6th, a farmer shot two herders in the Abul area of Heiban locality (South Kordofan, coordinates for Jabal Abul used at precision 2), killing one and wounding the other, after he accused the herders of allowing cattle to graze on his land. The farmer was arrested.
On December 6th, protesters gathered in El Obeid (North Kordofan) to demonstrate against the killing of a trader by RSF paramilitaries the previous day.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On December 6th, the deputy co-leader of the NUP (Bashir Hamid) was arrested by NISS in southern Khartoum. He had been hanging posters to spread word about the return of NUP leader Sadig El Mahdi. Bashir Hamid was released later that day. Separately, on Dec 10th NISS arrested and detained the political activist Akram Ahmed in Omdurman.
On or before December 7th, school children demonstrated in the town of Maiurno in Sennar (Blue Nile), at the surging price and unavailability of bread.

column9: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On December 7th, SPLM-N (Agar faction) fighters clashed with Sudanese army and ""militia"" forces (the latter coded here as RSF paramilitaries) at Bau locality (Blue Nile). According to the rebels, five government troops and two rebels were killed in the fighting, and a number of government troops and two rebels were wounded. The rebels also announced that they had seized weapons and ammunition from government forces.

On December 7th, farmers were attacked by herders on their way to Kutum (North Darfur), with two farmers wounded. A security force (coded here as police) then arrested the seven farmers as they approached Kutum, releasing them the following day after they had paid bail.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On December 8th, SLM/A-Nur forces accused ""militamen"" (coded here as RSF paramilitaries) of killing 16 villagers at an unspecified location in southern Jebel Marrah (Central Darfur). The attackers also looted property and livestock.
On December 9th, three female farmers were attacked by herders at thire farms around Umgai (North Darfur, approximate coordinates used 20km east of Tabit). There are no further details.
On December 9th, herders shot dead a farmer at the village of Kidinir west of Malam (coordinates for Malam, South Darfur, used). The herders had been trespassing on his land.

On or before December 10th, hospital workers went on strike at hospitals in Khartoum North (coordinates used), El Hasahisa (El Gezira state), and El Gedaref. The staff were striking against shortages of essential equipment, and government plans to ""liberalise"" the price of medicine, raising fears of soaring prices. Separetely, health workers went on strike in El Nahud (West Kordofan) on December 10th or 11th, following the decision of officials to expel a senior doctor from his residency.

On or around December 11th, cattle raiders clashed with armed residents of Alubi (South Kordofan, coordinates for Jabal Abul used). The raiders killed member of the Alubi militia, and wounded another, and stole 30 head of cattle.

On December 13th, herders riding in two Land Cruisers and upon camels attacked government forces in Tabit (North Darfur). Police and military forces repelled the attack; no casualties were reported. The herders were attempting to retreive cattle which had been confiscated.

On December 13th, secondary school students in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile) protested against soaring prices and economic decline. Police dispersed protesters using tear gas and sticks, and arrested several.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On December 13th, Sudanese soldiers and militiamen (the latter coded here as RSF) shelled the village of Karwa in Central Darfur (approximate coordinates used, based upon the source stating the village is located 5km south of Rokoro). Three children died when a house was hit by a shell, which had been fired by troops stationed in Rokoro.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On or before December 13th, an RSF paramilitary shot and killed his brother in the area of Dilling (South Kordofan), over an unspecified dispute.

On 14th December, demonstrators gathered in El Obeid (North Kordofan state) to protest deteriorating economic circumstances and the recent withdrawal of subsidised flour (leading to shortages and price increases of bread). 22 protesters were arrested (actor 2 recorded as Police).

On 14th December, demonstrators gathered in Khartoum to protest deteriorating economic circumstances and the recent withdrawal of subsidised flour (leading to shortages and price increases of bread). Demonstrators burned tires. Police have been deployed.

On 15th December, demonstrators once again gathered in Khartoum to protest deteriorating economic circumstances and the recent withdrawal of subsidised flour (leading to shortages and price increases of bread).

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: During the month of December 2018, three miners working at the Rasarees mine in El Tadamon were apprehended for alleged anti-government activities by NISS agents. All three men were subsequently tortured at a NISS facility in Al Abbasiya (South Kordofan), with two of the prisoners dying as a result of their torture. Note that there is no specific dates given for when these men died (the source is dated April 17th 2019; Dec 2018 coded as time precision 3 given that this was the time of the arrest).
On 15th December, demonstrators gathered in the Burri area east of Khartoum, to protest against the arrest of demonstrators in El Obeid the previous day.

On 16th December, student demonstrators gathered in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile) to protest deteriorating economic circumstances and the recent withdrawal of subsidised flour (leading to shortages and price increases of bread). One source indicates that the protests in Ed Damazin may also be related to non-payment of salaries in the city. Police dispersed the protesters using tear gas, batons, and live rounds.

On 16th December, student demonstrators gathered at the Universities of El Nilein and Khartoum in Khartoum (coordinates for Shambat, the location of the University of Khartoum, used) to protest deteriorating economic circumstances and the recent withdrawal of subsidised flour (leading to shortages and price increases of bread). The demonstrators burned tires to block roads.

column9: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 16th December, student demonstrators gathered in El Fasher (North Darfur) to protest deteriorating economic circumstances and the recent withdrawal of subsidised flour (leading to shortages and price increases of bread). The students blocked roads with burning tires; police (and possibly RSF) responded using batons and tear gas. One woman was reported to have been injured, and an unspecified number of demonstrators arrested.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On December 16th, SLM/A-Nur rebels clashed with an SAF patrol in the area of Daya village (Central Darfur), resulting in two government soldiers being killed.

On 17th December, student demonstrators gathered in Wad Medani (El Gazira state) to protest deteriorating economic circumstances and the recent withdrawal of subsidised flour (leading to shortages and price increases of bread).

On 17th December, student demonstrators gathered in Atbara (Northern state) to protest deteriorating economic circumstances and the recent withdrawal of subsidised flour (leading to shortages and price increases of bread).

On 17th December, student demonstrators gathered in Port Sudan (Red Sea state) to protest deteriorating economic circumstances and the recent withdrawal of subsidised flour (leading to shortages and price increases of bread). Police dispersed the protesters with tear gas.

On 17th December, several hundred student demonstrators gathered at the University of Khartoum in Shambat (Khartoum) to protest deteriorating economic circumstances and the recent withdrawal of subsidised flour (leading to shortages and price increases of bread). Note that these were the first of the demonstrations in which an explicitly anti-NCP agenda was reported as being advanced by demonstrators.

On 18th December, student demonstrators gathered in Gebeit to protest deteriorating economic circumstances and the recent withdrawal of subsidised flour (leading to shortages and price increases of bread). Police dispersed the demonstrators with teargas.

On 18th December, student demonstrators once again gathered in Atbara (Northern state) to protest deteriorating economic circumstances and the recent withdrawal of subsidised flour (leading to shortages and price increases of bread).

On 18th December, student demonstrators gathered again in Port Sudan (Red Sea state) to protest deteriorating economic circumstances and the recent withdrawal of subsidised flour (leading to shortages and price increases of bread).

On 18th December, demonstrators gathered in Fadasi (Blue Nile) to protest deteriorating economic circumstances and the recent withdrawal of subsidised flour (leading to shortages and price increases of bread). The demonstrators briefly blocked the Khartoum-Wad Medani road with burning tires.

On 18th December, student demonstrators gathered again in Wad Medani (El Gazira state) to protest deteriorating economic circumstances and the recent withdrawal of subsidised flour (leading to shortages and price increases of bread).

column9: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On 19th December, demonstrators gathered once again in El Obeid (North Kordofan), blocking roads in the city. Police and NISS used ""excessive force"" (according to the source) to disperse the demonstrators, and arrested 38.

On 19th December, student demonstrators gathered in Dongola (Northern state) to protest deteriorating economic circumstances and the recent withdrawal of subsidised flour (leading to shortages and price increases of bread).

column9: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); NCP: National Congress Party
column17: On 19th December, demonstrations continued in Atbara (Northern state). Student demonstrators torched the NCP headquarters in the town; the Sudanese police intervened to disperse protesters, and the army was reportedly mobilised. A dusk-to-dawn curfew was imposed.

On 19th December, demonstrations continued in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), at the same time as President al-Bashir was in the city. The student demonstrators were joined by non-student members of the public, and demands for regime change were made. The demonstrators barricaded roads, and were dispersed by police using teargas. Two students were reported to have been arrested.

On 19th December, demonstrators gathered in An Nahud (West Kordofan) to protest deteriorating economic circumstances and the recent withdrawal of subsidised flour (leading to shortages and price increases of bread).

On December 20th, security forces (coded here as police) shot dead a demonstrator at Abu Jubaiha (South Kordofan). There is no further information. Actor 1 has been coded as Protesters, pending further information.

On December 20th, security forces (coded here as police) shot dead two student demonstrators at Karima (Northern state). There is no further information. Actor 1 has been coded as Protesters, pending further information.
On December 20th, demonstrators torched the NCP headquarters at 'Abidiya (River Nile state).

On December 20th, several hundred demonstrators (including students) marched in Khartoum, and were dispersed by police forces using tear gas and (according to the source) ""excessive violence"". Police also prevented students from the southern branch of the University of Sudan from leaving the campus to join demonstrations.

On December 20th, demonstrators gathered in Ed Damer (River Nile state), as part of nation-wide protests against economic decline, soaring prices, and the withdrawal of subsidies on flour (leading to shortages of bread, and increases in prices). Some of these presents have an explicitly anti-NCP agenda.

On December 20th, demonstrators gathered in El Bauga (River Nile state), as part of nation-wide protests against economic decline, soaring prices, and the withdrawal of subsidies on flour (leading to shortages of bread, and increases in prices). Some of these presents have an explicitly anti-NCP agenda.

On December 20th, demonstrators (including students) gathered in Sennar (Sennar state), as part of nation-wide protests against economic decline, soaring prices, and the withdrawal of subsidies on flour (leading to shortages of bread, and increases in prices). Some of those present have an explicitly anti-NCP agenda. 32 students were arrested after the demonstration, and accused of being rebels belong to the SLM/A-Nur group (note that the rebels have disputed claims they are involved in the demonstrations).

On December 20th, demonstrators gathered in Shendi (River Nile state), as part of nation-wide protests against economic decline, soaring prices, and the withdrawal of subsidies on flour (leading to shortages of bread, and increases in prices). Some of these presents have an explicitly anti-NCP agenda.

On 20th December, demonstrators gathered in Kosti (Blue Nile) to protest deteriorating economic circumstances and the recent withdrawal of subsidised flour (leading to shortages and price increases of bread). Students and women (including mothers of the students) were reported to comprise the bulk of protesters.

column9: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On 20th December, riots continued in El Obeid (North Kordofan). Seven demonstrators were wounded by security forces whilst NISS forces were reported to have been actively arresting people in the area.
On 20th December, demonstrations continued in Dongola (Northern state). Rioters set fire to government buildings, and the NCP headquarters.

column9: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column16: Al Rakoba; Amnesty International; Radio Dabanga
column17: On 20 December 2018, demonstrations continued in Atbara (River Nile state), with around 2,000 demonstrators active. Demonstrators attempted to burn down the offices of the Taxation Bureau. Police and NISS fired above the heads of the crowd to disperse the demonstrators (coded here as police and military). Three demonstrators (including a student) were killed by NISS forces (two of whom died an hour after being shot), and a child was injured. Note that one source suggests that the military prevented paramilitary forces from entering the city at an unspecified time. [size=around 2000]
On December 20th, demonstrations continued in Port Sudan (Red Sea state)
On December 20th, demonstrations continued in Wad Medani (El Gazira state)

column7: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On 20th December, police and NISS forces assaulted students at the University of Sennar, injuring several. This followed a demonstration earlier that same day.

column16: Al Rakoba; Sudan Tribune; Radio Dabanga
column17: On December 20th, riots erupted in Berber (River Nile state). Demonstrators torched the local NCP headquarters and the Legislative Council offices. Security forces (coded here as police) shot dead one person (a prominent local athlete) and wounded sixteen (note that some sources say two or three were killed, one fatality coded here).

column16: Sudan Tribune; Radio Dabanga; Al Rakoba
column17: On December 20th, riots erupted in Gedaref (Gedaref state). Demonstrators (including students) torched the NCP headquarters, municipal buildings, and security vehicles. Demonstrators clashed with police, who used tear gas and live bullets to disperse the crowds, killing 12 and wounding dozens (including students). Dusk-to-dawn curfew imposed; state government agrees to reduce the price of bread.

On December 20th, dozens of demonstrators (including students) were reported to have been active in Omdurman, and closed down roads (though the means with which they closed roads are not specified, accordingly the demonstrators have been recorded as protesters).

column6: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: On December 20th, UNAMID announced that it had completed the withdrawal of its forces from the ten sites in Darfur it had earmarked for closure (with the final site to be closed being in Gereida, South Darfur). The sites are to be transferred to the government of Sudan, for non-military purposes. This move comes as the UN mission draws down the number of personnel it has stationed in Darfur.
On December 21st, protests continued in Omdurman.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On 21st December, demonstrations continued in El Obeid (North Kordofan). NISS forces fired tear gas and used ""force"" against demonstrators (coded here as rioters), and arrested an unspecified number. There are no further details at this time.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On December 21st, demonstrators (coded as rioters) returned to the streets in Atbara (River Nile). NISS forces were reported to have shot into the crowd, killing two students. One of the students was reported to be Palestinian.

On December 21st, demonstrators gathered in El Gazira Aba (coordinates for Aba Diqin, El Gazira, used), as part of nation-wide protests against economic decline, soaring prices, and the withdrawal of subsidies on flour (leading to shortages of bread, and increases in prices). Some of these presents have an explicitly anti-NCP agenda.
On December 21st, protests continued in Kosti (Blue Nile).
On December 21st, demonstrators assembled again in Atbara (River Nile), at the funeral of a student protester killed earlier that day.
On December 21st, demonstrators blocked roads with fire smoke in Khartoum. One source indicates there may have been multiple protests in different suburbs of the capital.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On December 21st protested demonstrated in Ed Daein (East Darfur), as part of a wave of protests sweeping Sudan. There is little further information, although NISS agents were reported to have detained a teacher and interrogated journalists. As of Dec 23rd, schools were closed in Ed Daein for one week.
On December 21st, demonstrations began in Rabak (River Nile state) as part of nation-wide protests. Demonstrators torched the NCP headqaurters in the town.
On December 22nd, protests continued in Wad Medani (El Gazira state).
On December 22nd, demonstrations broke out in El Rahad (North Kordofan), as part of nation-wide protests. The NCP headquarters was torched.
On December 22nd, between 14 and 18 members of the National Consensus Forces opposition coalition were arrested in Omdurman, including its leader, Farouk Abu Issa.
On December 22nd, protests continued in Khartoum.

On December 22nd, students and residents of Buram (South Darfur) demonstrated as part of a wave of national protests. The demonstrators (coded as rioters) attempted to attack the NCP headquarters in Buram, but were prevented from doing so when police and other (unspecified) security forces fired over the heads of the demonstrators.

On December 23rd, demonstrations occurred following a football match in Omdurman, in which anti-government slogans were shouted. The demonstrations continued after the match, and were suppressed by police, who beat the demonstrators, and used tear gas against them. An unspecified number were arrested.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On December 23rd riots broke out in El Tirtir (El Tadamon locality) in Blue Nile (coordinates for Bout, Blue Nile, used). Demonstrators burned NISS building; the local administrative building, and the Muslim alms (Zakat) bureau.

On December 23rd students demonstrated in Dibebad (South Kordofan). Note that it is possible that two protests occurred (one over the indefinite closure of schools in the area, the other over economic conditions), though the source does not clearly specify this (one event recorded).

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On 23 December 2018, around 30 civilians (at least some of whom were Darfuri students) were arrested by NISS agents and tortured in Sennar (Sennar state), accused of being members of the SLM/A-Al Nur rebellion. The same day they were transferred to Khartoum, where they continued to be tortured, and were forced to confess to being rebels in front of TV cameras.

column7: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column9: Communist Party; Journalists (Sudan); Labour Group (Sudan); NUP: National Umma Party; SCP: Sudanese Congress Party; Sudanese Baath Party
column17: During the week commencing 23rd December, at least 10 opposition political leaders (largely from the Sudanese Congress Party, as well as the Communist Party and Baath party) as well as journalists and students were detained and/or imprisoned in response to the nation-wide demonstrations taking place. Arrests occurred in North and West Kordofan states (coordinates for El Obeid, North Kordofan, used), with NISS involvement, and in Khartoum. Arrests also occurred in El Gezira Aba (including the president of the Farmers Union, and a leader of the National Umma Party was detained), and lawyers were also detained in East Darfur

On December 23rd, police and other (unspecified) security forces used tear gas, batons and live rounds against protesters in Um Rawaba in North Kordofan. Three civilians, including a child, were shot and wounded. Several people were detained by security forces.
On December 24th, protesters gathered in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). Police dispersed protesters using what the source described as 'excessive violence', including tear gas and batons.
On December 24th, demonstrations broke out El Managil (El Gezira) and in other (unspecified) parts of El Gezira state (two events recorded) as part of nation-wide protests.
On or before December 24th, demonstrations broke out in Jabalaulia (Khartoum), as part of nation-wide protests.

At an unspecified time during the week beginning 24th December, two demonstrators were killed in El Gezira Aba (coordinates for Aba Diqin, El Gezira, used). Police arrested 260 people in El Gezira Aba and Rabak, according to the state governor of White Nile.

On December 24th, doctors went on strike in multiple parts of Sudan (including Khartoum (coordinates used), El Gedaref and Kassala), covering 38 hospitals by the end of the week. The following day, pharmacists joined the general strike, with all pharmacies closed in Khartoum (except in the event of medical emergencies). On 27th Dec, journalists went on strike in response to attempts by the state to prevent journalists from covering demonstrations. On Dec 31, lawyers also joined the strike.
On December 24th, demonstrations occurred in Babanusa in West Kordofan state as part of nation-wide protests. Five activists were arrested.
On or before December 24th, demonstrations broke out in Buram (South Darfur state), as part of nation-wide protests.
On or before December 24th, demonstrations broke out in Kamlin (El Gezira state), as part of nation-wide protests.
On or before December 24th, demonstrations broke out in the El Souq El Arabi neighbourhood of Khartoum, as part of nation-wide protests.
On December 24th, demonstrations broke out in Rufaa (El Gezira state), as part of nation-wide protests.
On or before December 24th, demonstrations broke out in Sulaymaniyah (River Nile state), as part of nation-wide protests.
On or before December 24th, demonstrations broke out in Um Dawanban (El Gezira state), as part of nation-wide protests.

At an unspecified time during the week beginning 24th December, protests occurred in Rabak (White Nile state). Police arrested 260 people in El Gezira Aba and Rabak, according to the state governor of White Nile.

On or before December 24th students demonstrated in Kass (South Darfur). Police and RSF paramilitaries dispersed the demonstrators with tear gas and batons, making several arrests. The source describes authorities as using 'excessive force'.
On December 24th, demonstrations broke out El Managil (El Gezira) and in other (unspecified) parts of El Gezira state (two events recorded).

column9: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On December 25th large demonstration occurred in Khartoum, with support from workers movements and trade unions. Police used live gunfire, tear gas and rubber bullet; police and 'security forces' (including plain clothes officers, coded here as NISS) blocked Abu Jinzeer square to prevent demonstrations there. Sharpshooters were also reported to have been shooting demonstrators from rooftops. At least nine protesters wounded, between one and four critically, and a reportedly large number of arrests were made (note there are multiple, unverified figures as to the number wounded and arrested, lowest estimates used). NISS forces blocked reporters from operating in the city.

column9: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On December 25th, a demonstration occurred in El Fula (West Kordofan) as part of nation-wide protests. Police and NISS were reported to have injured seven protesters, two seriously, using tear gas and live ammunition.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On December 25th, and during demonstrations in Khartoum, journalists from multiple networks were assaulted by plain clothes security agents (coded here as NISS). Additionally, journalists had mobile phones confiscated, and pictures were deleted.

In the morning of December 25th, doctors protested in front of Port Sudan hospital (Red Sea state), calling for President el-Bashir to stand down. The protesters were dispersed with tear gas by police forces.
On December 25th, demonstration occurred in El Hilaliya (El Gezira state) as part of nation-wide protests.

In the afternoon of December 25th, lawyers protested in front of courthouse in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), calling for President el-Bashir to stand down. The protesters were dispersed with tear gas by police forces.
On December 26th, demonstrations occurred at Wadi Halfa (Northern state), as part of nation-wide demonstrations.
On December 26th, doctors and medical students demonstrated at El Gedaref teaching hospital (El Gedaref). The protest was dispersed by police and unspecified 'security forces'.
On December 26th, demonstrations continued in Khartoum, as part of nation-wide demonstrations.
On December 26th, demonstrations continued in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), as part of nation-wide demonstrations.
On December 27th, demonstrations continued in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), as part of nation-wide demonstrations.

On December 27th, doctors and medical students demonstrated at the hospital in El Gedaref (El Gedaref). The source notes that a number of doctors were beaten and detained by unspecified actors (coded here as police), before being released (note that the source is not explicit in stating that the beatings and arrests took place at the same time as the protest).

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On 27 December 2018, NISS officers raided a student dorm in the El Durushab neighbourhood of Khartoum North. During the raid, a Darfuri student was killed, and at least eight students were arrested. The students were reported to have been taken to the NISS detention facility in Khartoum North and subjected to torture.
On December 28th, demonstrators gathered in Dinder (Sennar state), as part of continued nation-wide protests.

On December 28th, demonstrators gathered once again in Khartoum. Police attempted to disperse the protesters ; PDF paramilitaries were reported to be active in the city (albeit in a low-key role at these demonstrations).
On December 28th, another protest occurred in Rufa'ah (El Gezira state) as part of nationwide protests.

On December 28th, a small protest occurred in Medani (El Gazira state; note that the source states the protests were in 'Mandani', though there is no location matching this name. Coordinates for Wad Medani used on the assumption that this is a typo). There is no further information.
On December 28th, demonstrators gathered in Sennar (Sennar state), as part of continued nation-wide protests.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On 28 December 2018, NISS agents arrested three men near Terter (note: there are several locations of the same name in South Kordofan state; coordinates for Terter, El Abassiya locality, South Kordofan state used at geoprec2), accusing them of being rebels. Two were tortured to death the same day, whilst a third was tortured (but survived), and was ultimately released from prison in Khartoum on April 12 2019.

On December 28th, demonstrators gathered in Halfa (unclear if in Northern State (Wadi Halfa) or in Kassala state (New Halfa); coordinates for Northern State used as a previous demonstrations took place at Wadi Halfa), as part of continued nation-wide protests.
On December 28th, demonstrators gathered in Aba Island (White Nile), as part of continued nation-wide protests.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On December 28th, auhtorities arrested Omer al-Digair the leader of the Sudanese Congress Party amidst nationwide anti-govt protests. He was released two months later, on March 4th.
On December 28th, demonstrators gathered in Atbara (River Nile), as part of continued nation-wide protests.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column9: Health Workers (Sudan); NUP: National Umma Party
column17: On December 30th, NISS prevented protesters from demonstrating in El Obeid (North Kordofan), and assaulted and detained doctors outside the teaching hospital. Several politicians, including two senior North Kordofan NUP figures, were also detained.
On December 31st, demonstrations were reported in the El Sawra district of Omdurman as part of nationwide protests.
On December 31st, lawyers demonstrated in Wad Medani (El Gazira), as part of nation-wide demonstrations.
On December 31st, demonstrations were reported in the Kober area of Khartoum North as part of nationwide protests.

On December 31st, protesters demonstrated in New Halfa (Kassala state), as part of nation-wide demonstrations. According to the source, police used ""excessive violence"" against the protesters, including the use of tear gas and batons.
On December 31st, lawyers demonstrated in Sennar (Sennar state), as part of nation-wide demonstrations. Police dispersed the demonstrators with batons and tear gass.

column7: Militia (Pro-Government); PDF: Popular Defence Forces; Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column16: Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Dabanga
column17: On December 31st, large demonstrations - including a march to the Presidential Palace - took place in Khartoum. A heavy security presences (consisting of police and police reservists, alongside NISS, PDF, and ""irregular militias"" (coded here as pro-governmen militias)) obstructed demonstrators, and used tear gas and live ammunition against them. An unspecified number of injuries are reported, and an unspecified number have been arrested. South Sudanese officials claimed four South Sudanese were killed by stray bullets, and ten were injured. No date (or dates) has been specified for the deaths (four fatalities have been coded for the 31st, pending more specific information on the dates).
On December 31st, demonstrations were reported in El Obeid (North Kordofan) as part of nationwide protests.

On January 1st, several hundred demonstrators were reported to have marched in Medani (El Gazira state; note that the source states the protests were in 'Mandani', though there is no location matching this name. Coordinates for Wad Medani used on the assumption that this is a typo).

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On January 2nd, a peaceful demonstration was reported to have taken place in El Gandoul square in Khartoum. Security agents (coded here as NISS) arrested three civil society activists.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On 2 January 2019, NISS agents arrested a student who had participated in a demonstration earlier that day in Khartoum, beating him, before taking him to a detention centre in Mayo (southern Khartoum), where he was also beaten by NISS agents.
On January 3rd, demonstrations occurred in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), which were reported to have been violently dispersed by police, including a ""heavy"" use of tear gas.

On January 4th, demonstrations resumed in Khartoum after Friday prayers, in several parts of the city. The demonstrations were reported to have experienced lower levels of attendance than in previous protests.
On January 4th, demonstrations resumed in Khartoum North after Friday prayers. The demonstrations were reported to have experienced lower levels of attendance than in previous protests.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On January 4th, SLM/A-al Nur rebels clashed with SAF soldiers at Boulay (Central Darufr). The source indicates there are fatalities, though does not specify a number (3 fatalities coded).

On January 4th, demonstrations resumed in Omdurman after Friday prayers. The demonstrations were reported to have experienced lower levels of attendance than in previous protests, though several hundred worshippers were reported to have attended. Riot police dispersed the protesters using tear gas.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces; Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services; Unidentified Armed Group (Sudan)
column9: Journalists (Sudan); PCP: Popular Congress Party; Teachers (Sudan)
column17: During the week beginning January 6th, numerous arrests were made by security services in the midst of nation-wide demonstrations, with the Interior Minister stating on Jan 7th that 817 had been arrested (the opposition NUP has provided a figure of around 2,000). In addition to various post-demonstration arrests, 20 professors from the University of Khartoum and 3 journalists were arrested in Khartoum (coordinates used) on Jan 6th; an MP with the PCP was reportedly detained on Jan 9th, after she participated in a demonstration in Omdurman. Elewhere, an activist was rearrested in El Gedaref on January 8th, prompting a social media campaign calling for his release, whilst a nurse (who is also an activist) was arrested in El Obeid on Jan 9th.

On January 6th, large demonstrations occurred in Khartoum, involving several processions of protesters coordinating their actions (note the demonstrations were called for by the Sudanese Professional Association). Police prevented protesters from marching to certain parts of the city, and dispersed the protesters (though the source does not specify how).

On January 6th, demonstrations occurred once more in Atbara (River Nile state). Ther demonstrations were said to be large in size, and were dispersed by police using tear gas. Police also detained an unspecified number of protesters.
On January 6th, very large demonstrations were reported in Wad Madani (El Gazira state). Police dispersed the protesters with tear gas and batons, and arrested an unspecified number.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On January 7th, protesters gathered inside and around the Grand Bosque in the Burri district of Khartoum. NISS agents fired tear gas into the mosque, and were reported to have shot and wounded a protester.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On January 7th, demonstrations - led by secondary school students - occurred once more in Atbara (River Nile state). As the demonstrators marched, police ""confronted"" demonstrators with batons and tear gas.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On January 7th, protesters gathered once more in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). Police used tear gas, batons, and a water cannon against the demonstrators, before detaining dozens of protesters.

On January 8th, large demonstrations were reported in El Gedaref (Gedaref state) against the NCP government, and calling for those responsible for deaths of protesters in the town in December to face justice. Police and unspecified security forces used tear gas and ""excessive violence"" against the protesters.

column9: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On January 8th, protests spread to Abri (Northern state). Police used batons and tear gas to disperse the crowds, wounding three. The following day, NISS agents arrested a number of demonstrators, as well as an activist. Note that RSF paramilitaries have been reported to have arrived in the town.
On January 8th, protesters gathered again in Atbara (River Nile state), before being dispersed by police using tear gas.

column16: Radio Tamazuj; Radio Dabanga; Sudan Tribune
column17: On January 9th, in the context of large demonstrations in Omdurman, police entered a hospital and used tear gas within the building, wounding a number of doctors and injured protesters.

column16: Radio Dabanga; Radio Tamazuj; Sudan Tribune
column17: On January 9th, large demonstrations broke out in Omdurman, leading to a violent response by multiple branches of the security service (including police, army, NISS, and RSF, with masked plain-clothes agents also said to be active (the latter coded as UAG)). Three protesters were shot dead, whilst police injured an unspecified number with tear gas and live ammunition (police reports indicate a minimum of twelve were injured). A number of people were also arrested.

On January 9th, around 100 lawyers gathered in Nyala (South Darfur) to demonstrate their opposition to the NCP government, and the violent handling of nation-wide protests. Several lawyers were arrested by unspecified security forces after the protest (coded here as Police).

On January 9th, protesters gathered again in Atbara (River Nile state), before being dispersed by police using tear gas and what the source describes as ""excessive force"". Dozens were reported to have been arrested.
On January 9th, protests occurred in the Burri district of Khartoum, prompting police to fire tear gas at the demonstrators.
On January 11th, demonstrations broke out in Atbara (River Nile state) as part of nationwide protests.
On January 11th, demonstrators gathered in Bara (North Kordofan), as part of nation-wide protests. Police dispersed the protesters with tear gas and what the source describes as ""excessive force"".
On January 11th, demonstrations broke out in Omdurman following Friday prayers as part of nationwide protests.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On January 11th, NISS agents detained a number of people (the source suggests these were primarily students) in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile), after allegedly setting up a fake call for protests on social media, in order to arrest any who showed up.
On January 11th, protesters gathered in Rabak (White Nile state), and were dispersed by police using tear gas and batons.
On January 11th, demonstrations broke out in Khartoum following Friday prayers as part of nationwide protests. Police dispersed protesters using tear gas.
On January 11th, demonstrations broke out in Khartoum following Friday prayers as part of nationwide protests. Police dispersed protesters using tear gas.
On January 11th, demonstrations broke out in Kassala (Kassala state) as part of nationwide protests.
On January 13th, demonstrations spread to El Faw (Gedaref state). Police dispersed protesters using ""excessive force"" and tear gas. A number of arrests were made.
On January 13th, police dispersed protesters in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), using batons and tear gas. A number of arrests were made.
On January 13th, gunmen ambushed a commercial vehicle at an unspecified location along the Nyala-Rokoro road. One civilian was killed and three wounded by gunfire.

On January 13th, farmers attempted to clear herders from their farms at Sani (coordinates for Kutum, North Darfur, used). Three vehicles with mounted machine guns arrived; in the ensuing attack, one farmer was killed and two were wounded. A further two were abducted.
On January 13th, protests broke out in El Fasher (North Darfur) as part of nationwide protests.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column9: UPF: United Peoples Front; Students (Sudan); Prisoners (Sudan)
column17: On 13 January 2019, NISS agents arrested and tortured a 26 year-old activist linked to the UPF student political movement in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile state). The victim was released on 31 Oct. NISS agents also arrested a university student, before beating him and forcing him to stand in the heat for a long stretch of time. The victim was released on 25 Jan

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On 13 January 2019, protests broke out in Nyala (South Darfur) as part of nationwide anti-government protests. NISS agents arrested an unspecified number of protesters. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On January 13th, NISS agents - as well as masked men in plain clothes (recorded here as UAG) - were reported to have beaten three journalists covering protests in Khartoum North. One journalist was also detained, but was released later the same day.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On 13 January 2019, NISS agents arrested three civilians (including a doctor) in Nyala. They were brought to the NISS facility, and were tortured and humiliated alongside people who had been arrested during an anti-government demonstration.
On January 13th, demonstrators marched in Amri (Northern state) as part of nation-wide protests. Protesters also demanded the release of a local teacher who had been arrested prior to the march.
On January 13th, police dispersed protesters in Sennar (Sennar state), using batons and tear gas.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On January 13th, security agents (coded here as NISS) raided a house in the Burri neighbourhood of Khartoum, beating one man, and detaining twenty others.
On January 13th, protests broke out in Khartoum North. Police beat demonstrators, and used tear gas and live rounds against the protesters, and made a number of arrests.

On January 13th, protests occurred once more in Khartoum. Police were reported to have used ""excessive force"" against protesters, and fired tear gas into a school, injuring a number of students. Note that at an unspecified time in the week beginning January 13th three South Sudanese civilians were killed at a protest in Khartoum. Three fatalities have been recorded for this event, although there is no information on the precise day that they were killed, nor of the circumstances.
On January 13th, demonstrations were reported in El Gedaref as part of nationwide protests.
On January 13th, protests broke out in Wad Medani (El Gazira) as part of nationwide protests.. Police used tear gas and ""excessive force"" against protesters, and made a number of arrests.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On January 14th, NISS agents arrested 28 journalists in Khartoum, to prevent them from staging a sit-in by the NISS headquarters. Some of the journalists were reportedly beaten, though have now been released. Separately, a doctor was arrested in Nyala (South Darfur) the same day, and another doctor was arrested in Omdurman on 11th Jan. A student activist was also arrested in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile) on the 13th Jan.
On January 15th, police dispersed protesters with tear gas, batons and live ammunition, in the Kalakla suburb of Khartoum.

Between January 15th and 17th, Awlad Zaid Riziegat clashed with Misseriya Jabal near Jijleahjah (West Darfur), causing an unspecified number of fatalities (coded as 10 across three events) and injuries, and displacing many. The clashes were in response to the killing of an Awlad Zaid by a member of the Jabal group.

On January 15th, demonstrators gathered once more in Omdurman. Some of the demonstrators ignited tires around the bus station and market, prompting police and unspecified security forces to use ""excessive violence"" against the crowd, using rubber bullets, tear gas and batons.

On January 16th, security forces (some who were plan-clothes officers (recorded as UAG), and one wearing a military uniform, recorded as army) forced their way into the house of a journalist in Omdurman, after threatening to fire tear gas into it. After the journalist let the men in, they beat her in front of her children.

At an unspecified time during the week beginning 14th January, a protest took place in Babanosa (West Darfur). A South Sudanese civilian was reported to have been killed in the event, in unclear circumstances.

Between January 15th and 17th, Awlad Zaid Riziegat clashed with Misseriya Jabal near Jijleahjah (West Darfur), causing an unspecified number of fatalities (coded as 10 fatalities each day of the battle across three events) and injuries, and displacing many. The clashes were in response to the killing of an Awlad Zaid by a member of the Jabal group.

On January 17th, ""inter-communal conflict"" occurred at several locations in Jebel Moon (West Darfur, coordinates used), specifically areas in which IDPs had recently returned to ( Chilchil, Girji Girji, Bir, Bateha, Dileibaya and Khom). Approx 3,500 people were displaced due to the clashes. There is no further information on the event, including the number of fatalities.
On 17th January, protesters reportedly numbering in their thousands gathered in Kauda (South Kordofan), as part of nation-wide demonstrations.
On January 17th, protests spread to Um Odam near El Hasahisa locality (El Gazira, coordinates used), as part of nation-wide protests.
On January 17th, demonstrators gathered once more in El Managil (El Gazira). Police forces dispersed the protesters with rubber bullets, live ammunition, as well as mass arrests.
On January 17th, protesters gathered once more in New Halfa (Kassala state). Security forces (coded here as police) dispersed the demonstrators.

On January 17th, protests occurred again in Omdurman. The source quotes a witness who says that security forces (coded here as police) used ""extreme violence"" against the demonstrators, and arrested a number of people. Note that one South Sudanese civilian was reported to have been killed in Omdurman during the week beginning 13th January; one fatality has been recorded for this event, although it is unclear when precisely the death occurred.

On January 17th, demonstrations occurred in the Burri neighbourhood of Khartoum. Police and armed men in plain clothes (recorded here as UAG) attacked a hospital and killed a doctor and an elderly man who had let protesters shelter in his house. Dozens were reported to have been injured, eight with serious wounds from firearms. UPDATE: after initial confusion, the death of a student during the protests has been confirmed.
On January 17th, protests were reported in Ed Duweim (Northern state) as part of nationwide demonstrations.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On January 17th, an unspecified number of journalists were arrested in Khartoum whilst covering protests. They were reported to have been taken to two different detention centres in Khartoum and were beaten by unspecified security services (coded here as NISS).

On January 17th, protests were reported in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). Security forces (recorded here as police) were reported to have used ""excessive force"" against the protesters and arrested a number of people.

On January 17th, severa protests took place in El Gedaref (Gedaref state). In one, students staged a protest inside a school, and were dispersed by police, who were reported to have beaten the students. Other marches in the city were dispersed by police and unspecified security forces, using tear gas.

column9: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces; PDF: Popular Defence Forces
column17: On January 17th, demonstrators gathered in Ed Daein (East Darfur). Police - alongside RSF and PDF paramilitaries - used ""excessive violence"" against the protesters (including tear gas), and made a number of arrests, including of three journalists, and seven youth. [size=200]

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Between January 17th and March 26th, internal fighting within the SLM/A-Nur rebel group (over the plans of one faction to sign a peace accord with the government) killed 22 and wounded 9 fighters associated with the faction intending the sign the agreement (headed by Mubarak Aldouk, and coded as splinter faction), plus 20 killed and 15 wounded fighters in the group headed by Salih Borsa (coded as regular SLM/A-Nur). The events took place in the area of Daya (Central Darfur). Six events coded (four at time prec3, two at time prec1), with fatalities distributed across events.

On January 16th or 17th, demonstrators gathered in Kassala (Kassala state). The protest was violently dispersed by police alongside plain-clothes officers (recorded as UAG), who used tear gas, live ammunition and beatings to disperse the crowd. Large-scale arrests also took place.
On January 17th, protests spread to Shour near Gali locality (White Nile, coordinates for Rabak used), as part of nation-wide protests.
On January 17th, protests were reported in El Obeid (North Kordofan) as part of nationwide protests.
On January 17th, protesters marched in El Geneina (West Darfur). Police were reported to have made a number of arrests.
On January 17th, protests were reported in Atbara (River Nile state). Police dispersed the protesters with tear gas.
On January 17th, protesters gathered in Rabak (White Nile state). There was a ""heavy security deployment"" in Rabak, though it is unclear if they intervened.
On January 17th, protesters gathered once more in Sennar (Sennar state). Security forces (coded here as police) dispersed the protesters with tear gas.

Between January 15th and 17th, Awlad Zaid Riziegat clashed with Misseriya Jabal near Jijleahjah (West Darfur), causing an unspecified number of fatalities (coded as 10 fatalities each day of the battle across three events) and injuries, and displacing many. The clashes were in response to the killing of an Awlad Zaid by a member of the Jabal group.
On January 17th, students protested in Amri (Northern state). Police arrested two students, sparking a further demonstration from the town's residents (one event coded).
On January 17th, protesters (comprising lawyers and jurists) gathered in front of the court in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile), to protest violence by state forces against protesters.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On January 17th and 29th, SLM/A al Nur rebels attacked SAF soldiers at Manabu (Central Darfur), killing four (Fatalities split across two events).
On January 18th, demonstrators gathered in Dinder (Sennar state). Police used tear gas and sticks to disperse the crowds.
On January 18th, protesters marched from Jaddi to Kajbar in Northern state (no information on the locations found; coordinates for Dongola, Northern state, used at precision 3).

On January 18th, demonstrators gathered once more in Khartoum North, as part of nation-wide protests. The demonstrators to have burned several cars along the main roads running through the area. There were reported to have been thousands of protesters in the Greater Khartoum area.
On January 18th, demonstrators gathered in An Nahud (West Kordofan). Police used tear gas, live ammunition and batons to disperse the protesters, and made a number of arrests.
On January 18th, demonstrators gathered once more in Omdurman as part of nation-wide protests. There were reported to have been thousands of protesters in the Greater Khartoum area.

On January 18th, demonstrators gathered in Burri (Khartoum) following the killing of an elderly man by security forces the previous day. The demonstrators attacked a police car and threw stones at police, who responded by firing live ammunition.
On January 18th, demonstrators gathered in Gedaref (Gedaref state). Police used batons and sticks to disperse the crowds.
On January 19th, police and unspecified security forces broke up demonstrations at two University campuses in Khartoum, using tear gas to disperse the demonstrators.
On January 20th, demonstrators gathered in El Managil (El Gazira), as part of nation-wide protests.
On January 20th, doctors protested outside the teaching hospital in El Fasher (North Darfur), following the arrest of their colleague.

On January 20th, demonstrators gathered in Wad Medani (El Gazira). Security forces (coded here as police) used ""excessive force"" and tear gas against the protesters, and prevented students from El Gazira University from leaving campus to attend the protests.

column9: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On 20 January 2019, demonstrators attempted to march to the Parliament complex in Omdurman. Security forces (coded here as police) dispersed protesters with tear gas and live rounds. An unspecified number were reported to have been injured. Additionally, plain clothes men beat a demonstrator with plastic hoses before taking him to NISS offices (assoc actor2 coded as NISS) (the victim was released as part of a presidential pardon on 29 Jan). [size=no report]
On January 20th, demonstrators gathered in El Kameer (El Gazira state. Note there is no information on this location; coordinates for El Kamlin used at precision 2), as part of nation-wide protests.
On January 20th, doctors protested outside of the teaching hospital in Kassala (Kassala state), against the violence deployed against protesters by state security organs.
On January 20th, doctors protested outside of Singa hospital (Sennar state), against the violence deployed against protesters by state security organs.
On January 20th, hundreds of protesters (including doctors) gathered in the Kafouri neighbourhood of Khartoum North to mourn the killing of a doctor in protests on January 17th.
On January 20th, demonstrators gathered in El Hasahisa (El Gazira), as part of nation-wide protests.

On January 21st and 22nd, demonstrators gathered in Omdurman, to mourn the killing of a protester the previous week. Security forces (recorded here as police) used live bullets and tear gas to disperse the crowds, although it is not clear whether they did so on both days (event on Jan 22nd features the police as actor 2).

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On January 21st, eight workers were abducted at a traditional brick factory west of Katur (North Darfur). The abductors were believed to be members of the RSF. There is no clear motivation at this stage for the abduction.
On January 21st, demonstrators gathered once more in Wad Medani (El Gazira). Police dipersed the protesters using tear gas and live ammunition.
On January 22nd, protests were reported at an unspecified location in El Gazira (coordinates for Wad Medani used). There is no further information on these demonstrations.
On 22 January 2019, students demonstrated at the National University in Khartoum, as part of nationwide anti-government demonstrations. Police dispersed the students with tear gas. [size=no report]

On January 22nd, demonstrators gathered once more in Kassala (Kassala state). Security forces (recorded here as police) dispersed the protesters with ""excessive violence"", and made a large number of arrests.
On January 22nd, demonstrators gathered once more in Khartoum North. Security forces (recorded here as police) dispersed the protesters using tear gas and live ammunition.

On January 21st and 22nd, demonstrators gathered in Omdurman, to mourn the killing of a protester the previous week. Security forces (recorded here as police) used live bullets and tear gas to disperse the crowds, although it is not clear whether they did so on both days (event on Jan 22nd features the police as actor 2).
