On January 22nd, students demonstrated at the National University in Khartoum, in part to protest against the dismissal of a number of students. Police used tear gas to disperse the students.

On January 23rd, engineers protested in Khartoum outside of the Sudanese Engineers Union, in solidarity with protesters who had been attacked by government forces. Police were reported to have dispersed the demonstrators with batons and tear gas.
On January 23rd, students protested in Meheiriba (El Gazira state), as part of nation-wide demonstrations.

On January 23rd, unknown gunmen (wearing military uniforms) attacked Kura village in Jebel Moon (coordinates for Kuru Kuru, West Darfur, used at precision 2), killing two civilians. The attackers stole 180 head of cattle and torched 47 dwellings.

On January 23rd, doctors protested in Rabak (White Nile state), and announced they were going on strike. Security forces (coded as police) dispersed the doctors with ""excessive violence"" and tear gas.
On January 23rd, members of a group known as the Central Darfur Revolutionaries Association conducted a sit-in protest in Zalingei, as part of nation-wide demonstrations.
During the week beginning January 21st, a mob formed and killed a police officer who shot dead his wife and child for unknown reasons. The mob torched the police station.
On January 23rd, dozens of youth demonstrated in El Mazmoum (coordinates for Singa, Sennar state, used), as part of nation-wide demonstrations.

On January 23rd, it was reported that soldiers clashed with security forces (coded here as police) in Port Sudan. One member of the security forces was killed in the fighting, and several injured on both sides. There are no further details.

On January 23rd, demonstrations broke out in Al Kalakla (Khartoum). There is no further information at this time, and it is unclear whether police were involved (the wording in the soruce is ambiguous).

On January 24th, very large demonstrations rocked Khartoum, with two people reported to have been killed (one by gunfire, the other by torture, seemingly during the protests; police recorded as actor 2). Note that demonstrations also occurred in Omdurman and the Burri suburb of Khartoum; one fatality has been recorded as part of this event, and the other in Omdurman (where a student was confirmed to have been killed). Eleven people were injured throughout the city.
On January 24th, protesters march in El Hasahisa (El Gazira state). Note that the source says several demonstrations occurred simultaneously in El Gazira state, but does not specify any locations.
On January 24th, protests broke out in Wad Medani (El Gazira). Nine demonstrators were injured by security forces (recorded here as police).
On January 24th, three armed men (wearing military uniforms) killed a farmer near Karu village (coordinates for Tawila, North Darfur, used). There is no further information.
On January 24th, protesters demonstrated once again in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). Security forces did not intervene.
On January 24th, large demonstrations took place in the Burri neighbourhood of Khartoum The protests were dispersed with tear gas and live ammunition.

column9: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column16: Amnesty International; Radio Dabanga; Sudan Tribune
column17: On 24 January 2019, large anti-government demonstrations took place in Omdurman. The protests were dispersed by police and NISS agents with tear gas and live ammunition. A Darfuri student was reported to have been killed in the demonstrations, whilst a group of women were specifically targeted by NISS agents, beaten and verbally abused. [size=large]

On January 24th, demonstrators marched in Deim Bakr (El Gazira state). Police attempted to stop demonstrations through the use of teargas, which was followed by clashes between demonstrators and police.
On January 24th, SAF were reported to have shelled the village of Saboon El Fag (South Darfur state). There are no reports of injuries or fatalities.
On January 24th, demonstrators gatherd in Abri (Northern state). There were no security forces present.
On January 24th, unknown gunmen killed a man as he was gathering firewood near Katur (North Darfur). There is no further information.
On January 25th, mourners gathered in Khartoum to commemorate the death of two people in demonstrations the previous day. Security forces (coded as police) fired tear gas at the crowds.
On January 25th, demonstrations broke out once more in Khartoum. Demonstrators set fire to several vehicles on the main roads.
On January 25th, demonstrations broke out once more in Omdurman. Security forces (coded here as police) used tear gas to disperse the demonstrators.

On January 25th, protests broke out in Nyala (South Darfur), following the killing of a Darfuri student the previous day in Omdurman. Unspecified security forces (recorded here as police) dispersed the students with batons and air guns.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column9: Journalists (Sudan); Lawyers (Sudan); NUP: National Umma Party; SCP: Sudanese Congress Party
column17: A number of arrests were made by NISS agents on January 26th and 30th, in Khartoum and Omdurman. On Jan 26th, authorities arrested several politicians and affiliated journalists working with the Sudanese Communist Party; the spokesperson of the Ba'ath party; on Jan 30th a prominent human rights lawyer was arrested, and on or around the 30th Jan the co-president of the NUP was detained under questioning for several hours, before being released. Additionally, on Jan 30th the newspaper El Jareeda was banned from publishing for 18 days. On 29th Jan, NISS released 186 protesters who had been involved in the demonstrations (although those released do not appear to include more senior activists and political figures).
On January 27th, a large sit-in protest occurred in Wad Medani (El Gazira). Police dispersed the protesters with tear gas and batons.
On January 27th, sit-in protests occurred at various parts of Greater Khartoum (three events coded in Khartoum, Burri, and Omdurman). Police dispersed the protesters with tear gas and batons.
On January 27th, sit-in protests occurred at various parts of Greater Khartoum (three events coded in Khartoum, Burri, and Omdurman). Police dispersed the protesters with tear gas and batons.
On January 27th, sit-in protests occurred at various parts of Greater Khartoum (three events coded in Khartoum, Burri, and Omdurman). Police dispersed the protesters with tear gas and batons.

On January 28th, demonstrators gathered in Rameitab (coordinates for El Hosh, El Gazira state, used at precision 2), as part of nation-wide protests. Note that demonstrators in El Gazira state closed down the Wad Medani-Khartoum highway, though the location is not specified in the source.
On January 28th, demonstrators gathered in Fadul (coordinates for Fadl, El Gazira state, used at precision 2), as part of nation-wide protests.

On January 28th, demonstrators gathered in Al Bagair (coordinates for Kamlin, El Gazira state, used at precision 2), as part of nation-wide protests. Note that demonstrators in El Gazira state closed down the Wad Medani-Khartoum highway, though the location is not specified in the source.
On January 28th, demonstrators gathered in an unspecified part of Sennar state (coordinates for Sennar used at precision 3). There is no further information.
On Jan 28th, Beni Halba and Beni Hussein groups clashed in the area of Korare (Central Darfur), causing several injuries. The dispute was later peacefully resolved.

On January 28th, demonstrators gathered in Hantub (El Gazira state), as part of nation-wide protests. Note that demonstrators in El Gazira state closed down the Wad Medani-Khartoum highway, though the location is not specified in the source.
On January 28th, demonstrators gathered in Barsi (El Gazira state), as part of nation-wide protests.
On January 29th, demonstrations continued in two neighbourhoods of Khartoum North.
On January 29th, protesters marched in Abri (Northern state), as part of nation-wide demonstrations.

On or around January 29th, demonstrators set fire to cars in El Sajana nieghbourhood of Khartoum. A group of masked men chased some of the demonstrators into a nearby house, where they beat them and the residents of the property.

On January 29th, protesters gathered in Port Sudan to commemorate the 14th anniversary of the death of 22 demonstrators from the Beja ethnic group. Anti-government slogans were called and anti-government banners were also present. Police and unspecified security forces contained the protesters in Beja Square, but otherwise did not intervene.
On January 29th, demonstrators gathered in Burri (Khartoum), and blocked roads with logs and rocks. Police used tear gas and batons against the demonstrators.
On January 29th, demonstrations continued in several parts of Omdurman. Security forces (coded as police) used tear gas and batons to disperse the crowds.
On January 29th, protesters gathered in Sennar (Sennar state), as part of nation-wide demonstrations.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On January 17th and 29th, SLM/A al Nur rebels attacked SAF soldiers at Manabu (Central Darfur), killing four (Fatalities split across two events).

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On January 30th, SLM/A al Nur rebels clashed with SAF soldiers at Daya (Central Darfur), killing one rebel.
On January 30th, around 300 lecturers and professors staged a sit-in protest at the University of Khartoum, as part of nation-wide demonstrations.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Between January 17th and March 26th, internal fighting within the SLM/A-Nur rebel group (over the plans of one faction to sign a peace accord with the government) killed 22 and wounded 9 fighters associated with the faction intending the sign the agreement (headed by Mubarak Aldouk, and coded as splinter faction) and killed 20 and wounded 15 fighters in the group headed by Salih Borsa (coded as regular SLM/A-Nur). The events took place in the area of Daya (Central Darfur). Six events coded (four at time prec3, two at time prec1), with fatalities distributed across events).

On January 31st, demonstrators gathered in multiple parts of Greater Khartoum (coded as three events in Khartoum, Omdurman and Khartoum North). Security forces (recorded here as police) used tear gas, batons and cables against the protesters, and made a large number of arrests.

On January 31st, demonstrators gathered in multiple parts of Greater Khartoum (coded as three events in Khartoum, Omdurman and Khartoum North). Security forces (recorded here as police) used tear gas, batons and cables against the protesters, and made a large number of arrests.
On January 31st, demonstrators gathered once more in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). Security forces (recorded here as police) used tear gas against the protesters, and made a large number of arrests.

On January 31st, protesters gathered once more in Wad Medani (El Gazira), blocking the highway (note that the source does not specify any methods used to do so; actor 1 recorded as protesters rather than rioters).
On January 31st, demonstrators gathered in Karmah an Nuzul (Northern state), as part of nation-wide demonstrations.
On January 31st, demonstrators gathered in Tibein (River Nile state, coordinates for Ed Damer used), as part of nation-wide demonstrations.

On January 31st, Ngok Dinka residents of Abyei protested outside the UN compound, over what they regarded as unfair hiring practices by a contractor employed by the UN (specifically, that the contractor was using labour from Khartoum and Kadugli, rather than from the Abyei area).

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Jan 31st: a 36 year-old teacher from Khashm Al Girba was taken (along with three others) to a NISS detention centre in Kassala (coordinates used). He died in detention a few days later. Relatives of the victim said the teacher showed signs of severe beating and torture. Officials deny the accusation.

On January 31st, students demonstrated at the railway station in El Gedaref (El Gedaref state). Security forces (coded as police) were reported to have been making arrests, including of an activist leader.

On January 31st, demonstrators gathered in multiple parts of Greater Khartoum (coded as three events in Khartoum, Omdurman and Khartoum North). Security forces (recorded here as police) used tear gas, batons and cables against the protesters, and made a large number of arrests.
On February 2nd, around 300 mourners gathered in Khashm Al Girba (Kassala state) following the death of a teacher from the town who died in NISS custody. The mourners shouted anti-government slogans.

On 3 February 2019, demonstrators gathered in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile state) as part of nationwide anti-govt protests. The following day, three attendees were arrested by NISS, although the report does not mention the presence of state forces at the protest itself. [size=no report]

column9: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On Feb 3rd, demonstrators gathered in Abri (Northern state). Police and security forces (the latter coded here as NISS) dispersed protesters with live ammunition, batons and tear gas.

On Feb 3rd, pastoralists in land cruisers shot dead three farmers and wounded two or three in Ragwa (North Darfur, coordinates for Tabit used). The farmers had confronted the herders for trespassing on their land, and had killed one of the pastoralists' camels.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column9: Journalists (Sudan); Lawyers (Sudan); NUP: National Umma Party
column17: During the week beginning Feb 3rd, NISS arrested a number of politicians from the NUP (and one from the Republic Party of Sudan); several journalists (mainly in Khartoum, but also in Port Sudan and South Darfur); and a number of lawyers and activists. They also prevented two newspapers from being printed on Feb 5th.

On Feb 3rd, armed pastoralists killed three farmers at Tamel Daheash (North Darfur; no geographic information found, coordinates for El Fasher used at prec3). The farmers had been trying to stop the pastoralists from grazing their animals on their land.

On Feb 3rd, demonstrations occurred in the Greater Khartoum area (coded as three events in Khartoum, Khartoum North, and Omdurman) likely as part of nationwide protests against the government. Security forces (recorded here as police) dispersed protesters using tasers, tear gas and batons.

On Feb 3rd, demonstrations occurred in the Greater Khartoum area (coded as three events in Khartoum, Khartoum North, and Omdurman) likely as part of nationwide protests against the government. Security forces (recorded here as police) dispersed protesters using tasers, tear gas and batons.

On Feb 3rd, demonstrations occurred in the Greater Khartoum area (coded as three events in Khartoum, Khartoum North, and Omdurman), with academics also protesting in Khartoum at recent violence against students. Security forces (recorded here as police) dispersed protesters using tasers, tear gas and batons.
On Feb 3rd, youth gathered in Wad Sulfab (El Gazira) to demonstrate against violent acts carried out by state forces in the course of protests.
On Feb 4th, two demonstrations were staged in Kassala by teachers, following the death of a colleague who was detained by NISS around one a half weeks ago.

column9: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On Feb 4th, demonstrations occurred once again in various parts of Khartoum likely as part of nationwide protests against the government. Youth erected barriers to block security forces (coded here as police and NISS) from using the roads, and clashes were reported between demonstrators and security forces.

On Feb 4th, herders attacked civilians as they gathered firewood in the area of Hashaba (North Darfur). They beat two boys, and abducted two women and three girls, raping them repeatedly throughout the day. The victims were taken to hospital, and the police mobilised to pursue the attackers.
On Feb 4th, demonstrations occurred in El Hasahisa (El Gazira) likely as part of nationwide protests against the government. There is no further information.

On Feb 4th, teachers held a protest in Khartoum following the killing of a teacher in Kassala state a week and a half ago (coded as a separate event to riots which took place the same day in Khartoum).
On Feb 4th, herders shot and wounded a civilian at Faluja (South Darfur). The victim was taken to hospital.

On Feb 4th, five gunmen wearing military uniforms (coded here as UAG allied to military forces) attacked a vehicle carying merchants as it travelled to Terter market (South Kordofan). One merchant was wounded in the leg by the gunfire, and the attackers proceeded to loot the passengers of money and mobile phones.
On Feb 5th, demonstrations from labourers on the El Gazira scheme took place at Magharba (El Gazira).
On Feb 5th, striking doctors marched in Singa (Sennar state), against the use of force by the government during nation-wide protests.
On Feb 5th, striking doctors marched in Kassala (Kassala state), against the use of force by the government during nation-wide protests.
On Feb 5th, protesters (including academics) gathered in Omdurman. Protesters blocked roads, but the means by which they did so are not specified (coded as protesters rather than rioters).

On February 5th, several demonstrations occurred in Khartoum, involving students, lawyers, professors and doctors. Police used tear gas and batons to disperse students close to the University of Khartoum.
On Feb 5th, striking doctors marched in El Hasahisa (El Gazira state), against the use of force by the government during nation-wide protests.
On Feb 5th, protesters gathered in Shukkaba (El Gazira), likely as part of nation-wide anti-government protests.
On Feb 5th, striking doctors marched in El Geneina (West Darfur), against the use of force by the government during nation-wide protests.
On Feb 6th, protesters (described as ""dramatists"" by the source, implying they are actors) gathered outside the National Theatre in Omdurman, to protest against the government.
On Feb 6th, doctors protested outside the hospital in Kosti (White Nile), against the use of force by the government during nation-wide protests.
On Feb 6th, demonstrators gathered in Khashm Al Girba (Kassala state), in protest at the government and the killing of a teacher in the state around two weeks ago.
On Feb 6th, doctors protested outside the hospital in Sennar (Sennar state), against the use of force by the government during nation-wide protests.
On Feb 6th, demonstrators gathered in Karmah an Nuzul (Northern state), likely as part of nationwide anti-government demonstrations.
On Feb 7th, lecturers and striking labourers gathered in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), as part of nationwide demonstrations.

column9: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On Feb 7th, very large demonstrations occurred in Khartoum likely as part of nationwide anti-government protests. Security agents (coded here as police and NISS) dispersed the crowds with tear gas and batons, and made a number of arrests.
On Feb 6th or 7th, demonstrators marched to the NISS offices in Kassala, following the killing of a teacher who was detained by NISS two weeks ago.
On Feb 7th, demonstrations occurred in Burri (Khartoum) likely as part of nationwide anti-government protests. Police dispersed the crowds with tear gas.
On Feb 7th, demonstrators gathered once again in Khashm Al Girba (Kassala state), in protest at the government and the killing of a teacher in the state around two weeks ago.

On Feb 8th, multiple demonstrations occurred in the greater Khartoum area, likely as part of nationwide anti-government protests (coded as four events in Omdurman, Khartoum, Khartoum North, and Burri).
On Feb 8th, protests occurred in Muglad (West Kordofan), as part of nationwide anti-government protests

On Feb 8th, multiple demonstrations occurred in the greater Khartoum area, likely as part of nationwide anti-government protests (coded as four events in Omdurman, Khartoum, Khartoum North, and Burri).
On Feb 8th, protests broke out in Sugdan (Northern state; no geographical information found, coordinates for Dongola used at precision 3), as part of nationwide anti-government protests
On Feb 8th, large demonstrations occurred in Kassala (Kassala state). Protesters marched to the police station, in protest at the death of a teacher who was detained by NISS agents several weeks ago.
On Feb 8th, protests occurred in Abu Jubaiha (South Kordofan), as part of nationwide anti-government protests. Police dispersed the protesters.

On Feb 8th, multiple demonstrations occurred in the greater Khartoum area, likely as part of nationwide anti-government protests (coded as four events in Omdurman, Khartoum, Khartoum North, and Burri).

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On Feb 8th, a group of ""government-backed militiamen"" (coded here as RSF) attempted to rape nine women north of the Kassab IDP camp (North Darfur). The women resisted, and four were seriously wounded by the attackers (two were stabbed with knives). The vicitms are being treated in hospital.
On Feb 8th, protesters gathered at the traditionally pro-NUP mosque in Omdurman. Police beat the protesters, and used tear gas against them.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On Feb 9th and 11th, SLM/A al Nur rebels clashed with SAF soldiers at Manabu (Central Darfur), killing four (three rebels, and one government soldier) (Fatalities split across two events).

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On Feb 10th, pharmacists protested in Wad Madani (El Gazira) as part of nation-wide anti-government demonstrations. A pharmacist and an engineer were arrested and tortured by NISS agents following the protest, and are in hospital suffering from renal failure.

On Feb 10th, protesters (mainly comprising women) marched in Omdurman towards the Women's Prison. Police and unspecified security forces used tear gas against the demonstrators (and fired tear gas into a nearby hospital); beat protesters and used live ammunition against them; and made a large number of arrests.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column9: Health Workers (Sudan); Journalists (Sudan); Lawyers (Sudan); Sudanese Baath Party; Teachers (Sudan)
column17: Over Feb 9-14th, over 40 people were arrested as nationwide anti-government protests continued. A prominent lawyer and member of the Baath party, alongisde five doctors, as well as a female journalist, were arrested in Khartoum and Omdurman (actor 1 coded as NISS). On Feb 12th, 16 academics as well as ""dozens"" of journalists and those working in the media were arrested, again in Khartoum. On Feb 14th, two journalists were arrested whilst covering protests in Khartoum. On Feb 9th, four men were arrested in Port Sudan, and taken to Khartoum, in unclear circumstances. In addition, a number of journalists were reported to have been released from detention this week.
On Feb 10th, doctors and other medical staff protested in El Obeid (North Kordofan), as part of nation-wide anti-government demonstrations.
On Feb 10th, doctors protested in Khartoum North, as part of nation-wide anti-government demonstrations.
On Feb 10th, protests - led by teachers - occurred in Kassala (Kassala state), likely as part of nationwide anti-government protests.
On Feb 10th, multiple demonstrations occurred in and around Khartoum, including one sit-in by doctors at Khartoum Teaching Hospital, likely as part of nationwide anti-government protests.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On Feb 12th, doctors and other health workers protested in Wad Medani (El Gazira), in support of nation-wide anti-government demonstrations. NISS agents detained two doctors.

On Feb 12th, protests broke out in Amri among those displaced by the construction of the Merowe Dam, at the lack of water services for the previous 10 days. The residents have been forced to resort to drinking untreated water.
On Feb 13th, protesters gathered in El Geneina (West Darfur), as part of nation-wide anti-government demonstrations.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On Feb 13th, SLM/A al Nur rebels clashed with SAF soldiers at Jadeed (Central Darfur), killing one government soldier.

On Feb 14th, protesters gathered in Wad Medani (El Gazira) as part of anti-government demonstrations. Five protesters were wounded when unspecified security forces (coded here as police) used rubber bullets and tear gas against them.
On Feb 14th or 15th, protests occurred in several parts of Khartoum. Security forces (coded here as police) used ""excessive violence"" and tear gas against protesters, and made a number of arrests.

On Feb 14th, protesters gathered in Zamzam IDP camp (North Darfur), to demonstrate against the government, as well as the rape of five girls and women the previous week. Security forces (coded here as police) dispersed the demonstrators with tear gas, plastic wires and batons. The protesters also occupied the Nyala-El Fasher road, though the means through which they blocked the road are not specified (coded as protesters rather than rioters).

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Between January 17th and March 26th, internal fighting within the SLM/A-Nur rebel group (over the plans of one faction to sign a peace accord with the government) killed 22 and wounded 9 fighters associated with the faction intending the sign the agreement (headed by Mubarak Aldouk, and coded as splinter faction) and killed 20 and wounded 15 fighters in the group headed by Salih Borsa (coded as regular SLM/A-Nur). The events took place in the area of Daya (Central Darfur). Six events coded (four at time prec3, two at time prec1), with fatalities distributed across events).

On Feb 14th, protesters gathered once more in the Burri neighbourhood of Khartoum as part of nationwide anti-government demonstrations. The source is unclear as to whether there was a police presence during the protest.

On Feb 14th, protesters gathered once more in Khartoum. Police and unspecified security forces prevented the demonstrators from marching to the Presidential Palace, and fired tear gas. They arrested a number of protesters, and two journalists.
On Feb 15th, anti-government demonstrations occurred in several areas of greater Khartoum (coded as three events in Omdurman, Khartoum, and Khartoum North).
On Feb 15th, anti-government demonstrations occurred in several areas of greater Khartoum (coded as three events in Omdurman, Khartoum, and Khartoum North).

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Between January 17th and March 26th, two rival SLM/A-al Nur factions attacked Fur civilians in the area of Daya (Central Darfur), killing 5, wounding 5, and abducting 15. It is not clear which factions are responsible for the specific deaths. Three events coded at time prec3, with fatalities distributed across three events. Two events coded with regular SLM/A-al Nur rebels as actor1, one with splinter faction as actor1.
On Feb 15th, anti-government demonstrations occurred in several areas of Omdurman. Security forces (coded here as police) fired tear gas into a mosque, and beat and chased protesters.
On Feb 15th, anti-government demonstrations occurred in Kassala (Kassala state).

On Feb 17th, armed raiders (implied to be pastoralists in the source, and coded accordingly) attacked settlements in the area of Martalat 5km west of Tunjur (North Darfur, coordinates used). Three farmers were wounded in the gunfire, and over 100 animals were looted.

On Feb 17th, anti-government protests took place in Khartoum North. Security forces (coded here as police) used tear gas and batons against demonstrators, injuring dozens, and arresting many. One elderly fruit vendor died as a result of tear gas fired by police.
On Feb 17th, anti-government protests took place in the Burri neighbourhood of Khartoum.

On Feb 17th, anti-government demonstrations were held in Wad Medani (El Gazira state). Academics from the University also held a rally to protest the regime and the government's violent response to the protests at the same time (coded as one event).
On Feb 17th, anti-government demonstrations were held in Port Sudan (Red Sea state).

On Feb 15th, a pastoralist militia attacked a group of civilians who were gathering firewood and other materials in the Hashaba area south of Tabit (North Darfur, coordinates used). Two civilians were wounded, and the pastoalists told the group that they should not come back to gather firewood.
On Feb 17th, anti-government protests took place in Omdurman.

On Feb 18th, anti-government demonstrations were held in Khartoum (coded as a separate event to the earlier demonstration involving a labour group). Demonstrators blocked a main road by burning tires.
On Feb 18th, anti-government demonstrations were held in Sai Island(Northern state).
On Feb 18th, workers from the Murouj food packing company protested against the government in Khartoum North.
On Feb 18th, anti-government demonstrations were held in Omdurman. Demonstrators blocked a main road by burning tires.
On Feb 18th, anti-government demonstrations were held in Burri and other areas of Khartoum.
On 19th Feb, three gunmen attacked a young farmer in Khor El Daliab (South Kordofan), shooting him once in the thigh, before leaving.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On Feb 7th, 19th and March 3rd, SLM/A-al Nur rebels again clashed with SAF soldiers near Manabu (Central Darfur), killing six rebels (fatalities split across three events).
On or around Feb 19th, doctors and other health workers carried out anti-government protests in Omdurman.
On or around Feb 19th, students and health workers carried out anti-government protests in Khartoum.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On Feb 18th or 19th, lawyers held a sit-in protest at the court complex in Nyala (South Darfur), in opposition to the regime's handling of the protests, and demanding the release of a previously arrested lawyer. NISS agents arrested five lawyers.
On Feb 19th, RSF paramilitaries abducted two civilians in the area of Falujah (North Darfur, coordinates for Dobo Umda used). There is no clear motivation behind the abduction.

column7: Government of Sudan (1989-2019); Health Workers (Sudan); Labour Group (Sudan)
column17: On Feb 20th, health workers as well as governments employees working for the Ministry of Animal Resources carried out sit-in protests in Khartoum (coded as one event). Doctors were protesting against violence deployed against protesters, whilst the Ministry employees were explicitly anti-government, and calling for the release of their colleague.

On Feb 21st, anti-government protests took place in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). In addition, protesters (including students) demonstrated against the privitisation of the port in the city. Security forces (coded here as police) dispersed demonstrators using tear gas, and used ""excessive violence"" against protesters.
On Feb 21st, anti-government protests took place in Arbaji (El Gazira state).

column9: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On Feb 21st, a number of anti-government protests took place in the Greater Khartoum area (coded as three events in Khartoum, Burri, and Omdurman). Security forces (including police, plain-clothes officers, and men wearing military uniforms; coded as police, military and NISS) dispersed protesters at various locations in Khartoum, using tear gas, and beating demonstrators. Seven people were confirmed to have been injured, including one person who was hit by a Land Rover driven by unspecified security forces.
On Feb 21st, anti-government protests took place in Al Halawiyin (El Gazira state).

On Feb 21st, a pastoralist militia attacked a group of women who were collecting firewood close to Mashrou Abu Zeid, east of Dubo El Omda (North Darfur, coordinates used). One woman was wounded by gunfire (which hit her in the hand), and another woman was hit in the head with an axe. There is no clear motivation for the attack.
On Feb 21st, anti-government protests took place in Atbara (River Nile state).

On Feb 21st, a pastoralist militia attacked a group of six women at a well in the vicinity of Koto, 5km south of Tabit (North Darfur, coordinates used). The militiamen detained them for four hours, and beat them with whips. There is no clear motivation for the attack.

On Feb 21st, anti-government protests took place in Wad Medani (El Gazira state). Six people were reported to have been injured after unspecified security forces (coded here as police) attacked them with tear gas and batons.

On Feb 21st, two groups of porters (reported to be Nuer and Ngok Dinka) clashed in Amiet market in Abyei, under unclear circumstances. One person was killed, and 23 were injured. UNIFSA peacekeepers separated the groups, and one was injured in the process.
On Feb 21st, a number of anti-government protests took place in the Greater Khartoum area (coded as three events in Khartoum, Burri, and Omdurman).
On Feb 21st, a number of anti-government protests took place in the Greater Khartoum area (coded as three events in Khartoum, Burri, and Omdurman).

column9: Communist Party; NUP: National Umma Party; SPA: Sudan Professionals Association; Students (Sudan); Sudanese Baath Party; Teachers (Sudan)
column17: On Feb 21st, authorities (recorded here as NISS) arrested around 26 politicians (one of whom is also a university professor) in addition to student activsits in Khartoum, including members of the Sudanese Professionals Associations, senior figures from the NUP, Communist Party and Baath Party. Six of the detained were released that night. On Feb 18th, NISS also detained a Darfuri student activist in Khartoum.

On Feb 22nd, anti-government protests broke out in Karma El Balad (Northern state; no geographical information found, coordinates for Dongola used at precision 3), as part of nationwide anti-government protests. Security forces (coded here as police) used tear gas and sticks to disperse the demonstrators.
On the morning of Feb 22nd, multiple anti-government protests were held in Khartoum (coded as a separate event to the evening protests in the city).

On Feb 22nd, anti-government protests broke out in Sugdan (Northern state; no geographical information found, coordinates for Dongola used at precision 3), as part of nationwide anti-government protests. Security forces (coded here as police) used tear gas and sticks to disperse the demonstrators.

On Feb 22nd, multiple demonstrations occurred in the evening in the Greater Khartoum area (coded as three events in Omdurman, Khartoum, and Khartoum North), in response to the announcement of a one year-long state of emergency by President Bashir that evening. In Khartoum, a doctor's residence was stormed by an unspecified security force (coded here as police), who fired tear gas into the residence, and arrested a doctor.

On Feb 22nd, multiple demonstrations occurred in the evening in the Greater Khartoum area (coded as three events in Omdurman, Khartoum, and Khartoum North), in response to the announcement of a one year-long state of emergency by President Bashir that evening.

On the morning of Feb 22nd, anti-government protests were held in Omdurman (coded as a separate event to the evening protests in the city). Police dispersed protesters with tear gas, which was also fired into a mosque.

column16: BBC News; Sudan Tribune; Radio Tamazuj; Radio Dabanga
column17: On Feb 22nd, President Bashir announced that a one year-long state of emergency was being introduced (on March 11th, this was revised to six months); that legislation permitting him to run for re-election had been postponed; and that he dissoled his cabinet whilst removing all state governors. Defence Minister Awad Ibn Ouf was announced as the new Vice-President the following day, the former governor of Gazira state - Mohamed Tahir Eila - became the new Prime Minister; seven new ministers were later appointed on 1 APril. New governors are all from military, intelligence and/or police backgrounds. On 26th Feb, Bashir reshuffled the senior commanders of the Sudan Armed Forces (though retained the Chief of General Staff), and announced a new Minister of Defence. On Feb 28th, controversial former governor of North Kordofan - Ahmed Haroun - (who is indicted by the ICC in connection with war crimes in Darfur) was appointed interim Chairman of the NCP, after President Bashir stepped down from the role.
On Feb 23rd, unspecified security services (coded here as police) stormed a doctor's residency in Khartoum, and beat doctors who were on strike.

On Feb 24th, large numbers of demonstrators gathered in multiple parts of Greater Khartoum (coded as three events in Khartoum, Burri, and Omdurman), as part of nation-wide anti-government protests. Police and unspecified security services (actor1 coded as police) dispersed protesters via beatings, and made a number of arrests. Students from the University of Medicine and Technology were reported to have been forced to leave the University premises, and several students were filmed being beaten by security services. Additionally, sescurity services were reported to have fired tear gas into at least one campus experiencing protests on that day (either in Khartoum or Omdurman). [size=large]

On Feb 24th, large numbers of demonstrators gathered in multiple parts of Greater Khartoum (coded as three events in Khartoum, Burri, and Omdurman), as part of nation-wide anti-government protests. Police and unspecified security services (actor2 coded as police) dispersed protesters via beatings, and made a number of arrests. Security services used live ammunition in Omdurman, wounding three protesters (one of whom was shot in the head). Students also protested, and security services were reported to have fired tear gas into at least one campus (either in Khartoum or Omdurman). [size=large]

On Feb 24th, large numbers of demonstrators gathered in multiple parts of Greater Khartoum (coded as three events in Khartoum, Burri, and Omdurman), as part of nation-wide anti-government protests. [size=no report]

column16: International Crisis Group; Radio Tamazuj; Sudan Tribune
column17: On Feb 25th, President Bashir issued five decrees, one of which banned protests and public gatherings, and another which granted sweeping powers to search and arrest to security forces. Hundreds were reported to have been arrested under the measures by the end of the week. Additionally, decrees were issued targetting those hording goods, as well as on financial transactions.
On Feb 26th, doctors protested at three unspecified hospitals in El Gazira state (one event coded at Wad Medani, at precision 3) as part of nationwide anti-govt demonstrations. [size=no report]

On Feb 26th, pharmacists carried out an anti-government protest in Omdurman, following the accidental killing of a child and the wounding of another by a runaway NISS vehicle in Khartoum North. [size=no report]

On Feb 26th, a woman who was gathering straw north of Tabit (North Darfur) was gang-raped by three armed pastoralists over the course the night. She was released the following day, and was taken to El Fasher hospital. Police arrested one suspect, whilst the two other suspects fled.
On Feb 26th, doctors protested in El Fasher (North Darfur) as part of nationwide anti-govt demonstrations. [size=no report]

column7: Health Workers (Sudan); Lawyers (Sudan); Journalists (Sudan); Labour Group (Sudan); Students (Sudan)
column17: On March 5th, strikes occurred in Khartoum, Gadref, White Nile and Kassala states. A number of labour groups - including lawyers, pharmacists, doctors (many of whom have already been engaged in a partial strike), journalists and high-skilled private sector companies - participated in the strike, with Khartoum reportedly coming close to dead-city levels of general inactivity. Secondary school students also joined the strike in Omdurman and one location in the Nuba Mountains.

On March 5th, security forces (coded here as police) stormed the house of the NUP leader, Amir Nugdallah, firing tear gas at the residents as they fled. The event occurred in Omdurman. Several such raids have occurred recently, allegedly to intimidate members of the party.
On March 6th, academics working for El Ahliya University in Omdurman staged an anti-government protest, amidst nationwide demonstrations. [size=no report]

On March 7th, large demonstrations occurred throughout Greater Khartoum (coded as four events in Khartoum, Khartoum North, Omdurman and Burri). The demonstrations were part of nationwide anti-govt demonstrations, as well as highlighting the injustices faced by women, on the eve of International Women's Day. Security forces (coded here as police) dispersed crowds with tear gas, and beat protesters with batons and plastic wires, and made a large number of arrests. [size=large]

Security forces (coded here as police) dispersed crowds with tear gas, and beat protesters with plastic wires and batons, and made a large number of arrests. Several hundred students also demonstrated at the National University; security forces fired tear gas into the campus, causing injuries, and made a number of arrests. [size=large]

On March 8th, female detainees in Omdurman prison staged a hunger strike in protest at their continued arrest. They were joined by activists in Khartoum. [size=72] On March 12th, NISS released a large number of female prisoners, following an order by Bashir on March 8th (note that it is unclear whether all of the estimated 150 female detainees were released). Additionally, the Court of Appeal quashed convictions of a number of demonstrators, including 11 women who were scheduled to be lashed.

column17: On March 10th, militiamen (coded as RSF paramilitaries) abducted a man as he gathered firewood near Rogli village (North Darfur, approximate coordinates used based on location 7km south of Dobo Umda). There is no further information.

The IDPs then killed three of the RSF soldiers and injured two, whilst the RSF wounded two IDPs.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On Feb 26th and March 13th, SLM/A-al Nur rebels clashed with SAF soldiers at Dursa (Central Darufr), killing three government soldiers (fatalities distributed across two events).

On or after March 13th, residents of El Geneina (including shopkeepers) as well as IDPs from the Ardamata camp demonstrated in El Geneina (West Darfur), against the actions of the RSF paramilitaries on March 13th (see two other events coded on this day). The source also notes that the demonstrators were protesting against the regime, amidst nationwide demonstrations. [size=large]

On March 13th, members of the Riziegat Alwad Eid clashed with Masalit IDPs in the area of Arafah (West Darfur, coordinates for Djedid used at prec2) in what is described as a livestock dispute. Three Masalit and two Awlad Eid were killed in the clash.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On March 13th, three IDPs were executed by RSF paramilitaries, following an earlier incident in which RSF soldiers clashed with residents of Ardmita camp who were gathering firewood at Arafa in West Darfur. The IDPs (who had reportedly killed three of the RSF earlier that day) had turned themselves into the police, when the RSF returned in two trucks in an apparent revenge attack.

column7: SPA: Sudan Professionals Association; Labour Group (Sudan); Health Workers (Sudan); Teachers (Sudan)
column17: On March 13th, and following a call from the Sudanese Professionals Association, doctors, lecturers and various labour groups went on strike in several parts of Sudan (including Khartoum, Omdurman, El Obeid, Sennar, and unspecified parts of El Gedaref state), as part of nationwide anti-govt demonstrations. Pedestrian and vehicle traffic was reported to be low in Khartoum.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: During the week beginning March 11th, four women (at least one of whom was a young teenager) were abducted at gunpoint by ""militiamen"" (coded as RSF) in the vicinity of Sananat near Kutum (North Dafur, approximate coordinates for Masri used). The attackers repeatedly raped three of the victims, and beat another (who was 14 years old).

On March 14th, students from Jebel Marra (who were sitting exams in Zalingei) rioted, and burned down several school buildings in Zalingei (Central Darfur). The motive is unclear. Security forces (coded as police) arrested four students. [size=no report]

On March 14th, large demonstrations occurred throughout the Greater Khartoum area, as part of nationwide anti-govt protests (coded as four events in Khartoum, Khartoum North, Burri and Omdurman). [size=hundreds]

Police and security forces (coded as NISS) clashed with protesters in Omdurman and Khartoum North, with police using tear gas and security agents making arrests [size=hundreds]

On March 14th, three gunmen abducted three students in Nyala (South Darfur), and attempted to rob them. When one student resisted, he was shot dead, and his two colleagues wounded. It transpired that one of the gunmen was a corporal in the military, whilst the other two were not affiliated with the SAF, despite wearing military uniforms. All have been arrested.

On March 14th, large demonstrations occurred throughout the Greater Khartoum area, as part of nationwide anti-govt protests (coded as four events in Khartoum, Khartoum North, Burri and Omdurman). [size=hundreds]

The events took place in the area of Daya (Central Darfur). Six events coded (four at time prec3, two at time prec1), with fatalities distributed across events).

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Between January 17th and March 26th, two rival SLM/A-al Nur factions attacked Fur civilians in the area of Daya (Central Darfur), killing 5, wounding 5, and abducting 15. It is not clear which factions are responsible for the specific deaths. Three events coded at time prec3, with fatalities distributed across events. Two events coded with regular SLM/A-al Nur rebels as actor1, one with splinter faction as actor1.

During the month of March 2019, the family of a lady who was kidnapped attacked the house of the man suspected of being involved in the kidnapping (the suspect is a PDF paramilitary) in or near Abu Sherola in Rashad locality. The sister of the suspect was wounded in the incident. [size=no report]

At an unspecified time in March, unknown gunmen shot four shepards as they slept, killing one, and wounding the other three. The event occurred in Kamblak village (no geographical info found, coordinates for Kutum used at precision 2).

column17: On or before March 21st, NISS agents beat and shaved the head of a butcher in Golo (Central Darfur), after he refused to authorise the sale of some meat. A strike has been called in response to the attack.

When the victims reported the incident to the police, the paramilitaries beat two senior police officers, and abducted two other police officers (police coded as assoc actor 2).

column17: On March 22nd, RSF paramilitaries beat two senior police officers, and abducted two other police officers after they were accused of earlier attacking traders in Tabit market (police coded as assoc actor 2).

On or around March 22nd, the bodies of two policemen were found at an unspecified location in Western Jebel Marrah (Central Darfur). A police officer who discovered the bodies returned to the police station, though upon returning to the location the bodies had been moved and their weapons taken, without explanation. Event coded as an armed clash between police and UAG, pending further information.

On March 22nd, four pregnant women belonging to the Ngok Dinka group were abducted by an unspecified group which the source strongly implies are northern Sudanese pastoralists (though no ethnic identity is specified) returning to the north. The event occurred at Tol Mach outside Abyei town (coordinates for Abyei used at precision 2), and the victims were rescued by UNIFSA peacekeepers on or before March 26th.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On March 22nd, militiamen (coded here as RSF) attacked IDPs at Hijeir Tongo close to Nyala (South Darfur, coordinates for Tono used), killing one and seriously wounding two. The two are being treated for their injuries.

On March 23rd, seven children died instantly and another shortly afterwards when they were playing with unexploded ordnance found near a military site in El Fateh west of Omdurman (coordinates used at precision 2).

On March 24th, unknown gunmen shot dead two IDPs at Arid (East Darfur), who had returned home as part of an official repatriation process. The source suggests the group were attempting to stop the IDPs from reclaiming their expropriated farmland.

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On 24 March 2019, NISS agents arrested and beat a student at his family home in Umm Rawaba (North Kordofan state), and detained him without charge until 18 April.

On March 24th, demonstrations occurred in Khartoum North, as part of nationwide anti-govt protests. Security forces (coded as police) used tear gas against demonstrators, resulted in the death of an 80 year-old man. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On March 24th, five NISS agents beat a student who had been displaced from South Kordofan, in Um Ruwaba (North Kordofan), using plastic wires and sticks. He was accused of being a rebel, and then taken by the NISS agents to an undisclosed location, where he has not been heard from since.

On March 25th, journalists gathered in Arabi market in Khartoum, as part of nation-wide anti-govt demonstrations; to call for an end to the crackdown on the media; and for the release of newspaper editor Osman Mirghani (who was subsequently released at the end of the week). [size=dozens]

On March 26th, 13 SAF soldiers beat a civilian (who was also a former SAF soldier) in Elfaid Um-Abdalla (South Kordofan, coordinates for Abu Kershola used at precision 2), and then took him to Um-Brembeta, where he is reported to be undergoing torture.

The attackers beat ""several"" civilians inside the camp, claiming that their property had been stolen from them, and said they would set fire to the camp if their property wasn't returned. Police and soldiers were deployed in response.

column17: On April 6th, security agents (coded as NISS) arrested six students in Kabkabia (North Darfur state), they were reportedly beaten and tortured whilst in detention, before being transferred to court for sentencing (the charges are not specified in the source).

column9: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column16: Radio Dabanga; Hudo Centre; Sudan Tribune
column17: On 6 April 2019, very large anti-government demonstrations occurred in Khartoum. Four rioters were killed by security forces (coded as here as police), with a fifth individual (an IDP) dying as a result of their injuries on 19 April. An unspecified number were injured on both sides, with six police vehicles reported to have been destroyed, according to the authorities. Around 2,000 demonstrators were reportedly arrested, with at least 300 detained (and some beaten) by NISS agents. [size=hundreds of thousands]

column9: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On April 6th, residents of the Hasahisa IDP camp in Zalingei (Central Darfur) demonstrated against the regime, as part of nationwide anti-govt protests. Police and unspecified security forces (coded here as NISS) used tear gas to disperse the crowds. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On April 6th, NISS agents detained five journalists working for Al Jazeera in Khartoum (note the nationalities of the journalists are not specified; journalists coded as Sudanese pending further information). The journalists were taken to an undisclosed location and beaten, and were released the following day.

On April 6th, residents of the Kalma IDP camp (South Darfur) demonstrated as part of nationwide anti-govt protests. Security forces (coded here as police) fired tear gas and live ammunition into the crowd, killing one woman, and wounding 2 or 3 others with bullets, and five with tear gas. [size=no report]
On April 6th, demonstrators marched in Kauda (South Kordofan), as part of nationwide anti-govt protests. Demonstrators finished the march at the SPLM-North headquarters in the town. [size=thousands]

column17: On April 7th, a general nationwide strike was announced, across various professional groups. The strike appears to have been coordinated by the Sudanese Professionals Association, and comes amidst mounting anti-govt demonsrations.

Security forces (coded here as police) fired tear gas and live rounds into the crowds, killing a secondary school student, and wounding two others (one of who was a 7 year-old boy). [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On April 8th, a soldier and another individual (likely a protester) were killed in clashes between soldiers and NISS agents, as soldiers were attempting to defend protesters during a large sit-in demonstration outside the army HQ in Khartoum. Four soldiers were injured, as were several demonstrators (one report indicates around 20 were injured).

On April 8th, demonstrations broke out in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile), as part of nationwide anti-govt protests. Security forces (coded here as police) used tear gas, plastic wires and machetes to disperse the protesters, and made five arrests. [size=no report]

column17: On April 9th, soldiers clashed with NISS agents and armed men wearing civilian clothing (the latter coded as UAG), when NISS and irregular forces attacked protesters outside of the army HQ in Khartoum. Several soldiers were reported to have been injured, and two protesters were killed (note one source says three protesters and two soldiers were killed, lower fatality estimate used).

On April 9th, students from El Salam University demonstrated in El Fula (West Kordofan state), as part of nationwide anti-govt demonstrations. Security forces (coded here as police) dispersed the protesters with tear gas, and used batons and plastic wires to beat them. 15 were arrested. [size=no report]
On April 9th, IDPs from Hamidiya and Khamsa Dagayeg camps marched in Zalingei (Central Darfur state), as part of nationwide anti-govt demonstrations. [size=no report]

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On April 11th, demonstrators converged on the NISS office in El Fasher (North Darfur), in a bid to release detainees. NISS agents shot and killed one demonstrator, sparking clashes between demonstrators as NISS forces, causing dozens of people to be wounded (allegiance unspecified), some seriously. SAF soldiers intervened, and took control of the NISS offices, though there is no mention of soldiers clashing with NISS agents. [size=no report]

On April 11th, people gathered in Kadugli (South Kordofan), initially to celebrate the removal of President Bashir. The gathering morphed into a demonstration against the military government which deposed Bashir, as more information reached the crowd. [size=no report]

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces; Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column16: Africa Confidential; Sudan Tribune; Radio Dabanga; Radio Tamazuj
column17: On April 11th, elements of the Sudan Armed Forces announced a coup against President al Bashir, suspending the constitution and establishing a nationwide ceasefire, whilst declaring a new state of emergency and curfew (the coup itself may have taken place on the evening of the 10th). The presidency switched hands from Lt Gen Ahmed Awad Ibn Auf to Lt Gen Abdel Fattah Abdelrahman Burhan between April 11-12th after protests over a two-year military government. RSF paramilitary leader Lt Gen Mohamed Hamdan ('Hemeti') was appointed interim vice-president on April 13th. After the coup, Bashir was placed under house arrest (and then moved to Kober prison on the 16th), a number of his aides as well as senior NCP figures (including the new interim NCP leader, Ahmed Haroun) were arrested, the Army Chief of Staff Kamal Abdel-Marouf was relieved and NISS director Salah 'Gosh' was forced to step down. On April 17th, the military announced that irregular forces (described as Popular Defence, and Popular Police, in the source) were being integrated in the mainstream armed forces; on April 24th three senior figures in the Transitional Military Council stepped down, following accusation that they were 'Islamists'.

On April 12th, demonstrators gathered in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), in a sit-in protest against the military government. The sit-in continued until Feb 18th, outside the Naval Forces HQ. The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. [size=large]

On April 12th, demonstrators gathered in El Obeid (North Kordofan state), in a sit-in protest against the military government. The sit-in continued until April 19th outside the military command. The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. [size=no report]

On April 12th, demonstrators gathered in Kadugli (South Kordofan state), in a sit-in protest against the military government. The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. [size=no report]

From April 12th to 19th, protesters engaged in a sit-in demonstration in Khartoum. The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. [size=very large]

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Police
column17: On April 13th, sit-in continued for a second day in Kadugli (South Kordofan state) against the military government. The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. Military police arrested three protesters, but subsequently released them. Sit-ins in Kadugli continued until April 17th [size=no report]

On April 13th, SPLM-N supporters marched in at least one location under rebel control in Blue Nile state (the source does not specify any locations; coordinates for Ingessana Hills, Blue Nile state, used at precision 2). The marches were in solidarity with the continued sit-in in Khartoum, and against the continuation of regime power. [size=no report]

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
column16: Sudan Tribune; UN Panel of Experts; Radio Dabanga
column17: On 14 April 2019, two groups of IDPs affiliated with different factions of the SLM/A-Nur (one loyal to Al-Nur, and the other coded as splinter faction) clashed (with firearms) in Kalma IDP camp (South Darfur state), killing 16 and wounding 17.

On April 15th, IDPs from camps near Mukjar and Bindisi marched to the military garrison in Mukjar (Central Darfur). In addition to calling for the end of the Bashir regime, the demonstrators demanded the dissolution of militias in Darfur; the payment of compensation for those affected by the conflict in Darfur; and for seized lands to be returned to their original occupants. [size=no report]

On April 15th, demonstrators gathered outside the Second Infrantry HQ in El Gedaref (Gedaref state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and also for the release of prisoners detained in Gedaref during recent protests. [size=large]

On April 16th, academics from the University of Khartoum marched to the site of a sit-in ongoing since April 6th in Khartoum, whilst journalists demonstrated outside of the SUNA offices, calling for press freedom. The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. [size=very large]

On April 16th and 17th, demonstrators continued their sit-on protest outside the Second Infrantry HQ in El Gedaref (Gedaref state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and also for the release of prisoners detained in Gedaref during recent protests. [size=no report]

On April 16th and 17th, sit-in protests were staged by IDPs in Mukjar (Central Darfur). In addition to calling for the end of the Bashir regime, the demonstrators had been demanding that a number of grievances related to the Darfuri civil war be addressed. [size=no report]

Between April 16th-20th, the Timen and Kolfan communities were reported to have clashed at unspecified locations near Habila and Dilling (Southern Kordofan state, coordinates used at prec2). During the violence, 17 were killed and 17 injured, property and livestock looted, and the village of Kalandi (no coordinates found) torched. Fatalities distributed through five days of clashes.

The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and also for the release of prisoners detained in Gedaref during recent protests. A march in support of the sit-in occurred on the 17th April, which also called for justice for citizens of El Gedaref who were killed during the initial protests in December. [size=no report]

On April 17th, journalists and doctors marched in support of a sit-in ongoing since April 6th in Khartoum. The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. [size=very large]

The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for those responsible for war crimes in Darfur to be prosecuted at the ICC. The source notes that the demonstrators marched to a sit-in demonstration that was taking place, but does not specify how long the sit-in had been taking place for (one event coded, pending further information). During the violence, 17 were killed and 17 injured, property and livestock looted, and the village of Kalandi (no coordinates found) torched. Fatalities distributed through five days of clashes.
