The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for justice for the victims of killings in El Gedaref towards the start of the national uprising. After marching in the town, the protesters joined the sit-in protest outside the HQ of the Second Infrantry. [size=no report]

Between April 16th-20th, the Timen and Kolfan communities were reported to have clashed at unspecified locations near Habila and Dilling (Southern Kordofan state, coordinates used at prec2). During the violence, 17 were killed and 17 injured, property and livestock looted, and the village of Kalandi (no coordinates found) torched. Fatalities distributed through five days of clashes.

On April 21st, demonstrators (including teachers and accountants) gathered in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. After marching in the town, the protesters began a sit-in outside the Fourth Infrantry HQ. [size=no report]

On April 21st, demonstrators gathered in Singa (Sennar state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. After marching in the town, the protesters either began a sit-in outside the 17th Infantry Division, or joined an existing one (note that the starting date of the sit-in is not specified). [size=no report]

On April 21st, demonstrators (including displaced persons from the Nuba Mountains) marched in El Obeid (North Kordofan state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. After marching in the town, the protesters began a sit-in outside the Fifth Infrantry HQ. [size=no report]

On April 21st, six marches were organised by demonstrators in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. After marching in the town, the protesters joined the sit-in protest outside the Naval HQ. [size=no report]

On April 20th and 21st, demonstrators marched in El Gedaref (Gedaref state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for justice for the victims of killings in El Gedaref towards the start of the national uprising. After marching in the town, the protesters joined the sit-in protest outside the HQ of the Second Infrantry. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On April 21st, soldiers clashed with NISS agents who were retreating from El Leri (South Kordofan state), after NISS agents had been involved in clashes with PDF paramilitaries, and fired at protesters that same day. Four NISS agents were killed, and ten agents were wounded.

On April 21st, demonstrators gathered at the railway HQ in Atbara (River Nile state), in protest against the employment of corrupt officials at the company. The protesters then took control of a train, and took it to Khartoum the same day, with supplies for protesters at the sit-in at Khartoum. [size=hundreds]

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On April 21st, PDF paramilitaries clashed with NISS agents in El Leri (South Kordofan state), after NISS agents had shot at protesters the same day. Two NISS agents were killed, and four civilians were wounded.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On April 21st, demonstrators gathered in Kutum (North Darfur state). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. During the march, NISS agents fired upon the demonstrators with live rounds. At least 12 people were wounded (several seriously), though the governor of North Darfur said one of the wounded was a police officer (coded as assoc actor 2). The demonstrators then torched the NISS building, and attacked the house of a former local official (although there is no further information on this attack at present). [size=no report]

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On April 21st, protesters marched in El Leri (South Kordofan state). The demonstrators wanted the local military commander to cease gold production in the area, which they alleged was causing environmental damage harmful to human and animal life, whilst contributing nothing to the area. NISS agents were reported to have been opposed to the closure of the facility, and fired into the crowd, wounding five protesters. [size=no report]

On April 21st, demonstrators gathered in Babanussa (West Kordofan state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for the NCP political and security apparatus to be dismantled in West Kordofan. [size=no report]

On April 22nd, demonstrators gathered in El Fasher (North Darfur state) to protest the continued confiscation of their vehicles (which had been seized as part of a security sweep beginning last August, on the grounds that they were unregistered). The demonstrators said they had paid their fines, but the vehicles remained impounded. Customs officials claimed the matter was out of their hands, and was instead the responsibility of RSF paramilitaries. [size=dozens]

On April 22nd, three marches were organised by demonstrators in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. After marching in the town, the protesters joined the sit-in protest outside the Naval HQ. [size=no report]
On April 22nd, bank employees march in Khartoum, in support of the ongoing sit-in outside the Military HQ in the city. [size=hundreds]

On April 22nd, men in SAF uniforms (and coded as such) attacked Kumbur village in Nyukur payam (Southern Kordofan state, coordinates used at prec2), killing one civilian and looting 71 head of cattle.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On April 22nd, six RSF paramilitaries accosted a Darfuri miner at Atagula gold mine in Talodi locality (South Kordofan). One of the RSF soldiers shot the miner dead, following a personal dispute with the man earlier that day. The source notes the mine has experienced problems relating to the presence of RSF soldiers, after the mine was purchased by a company belonging to RSF commander (and de factor VP of Sudan) 'Hemeti' last year.

On April 22nd, demonstrators marched in El Gedaref (Gedaref state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for justice for the victims of killings in El Gedaref towards the start of the national uprising. After marching in the town, the protesters joined the sit-in protest outside the HQ of the Second Infrantry. [size=thousands]

On April 23rd, demonstrators gathered in El Fula (West Kordofan state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for the NCP paramilitary security forces to be dissolved in West Kordofan. [size=no large]
On April 23rd, journalists demonstrated in El Fasher (North Darfur state), calling upon the acting governor to purge state institutions of corrupt individuals. [size=no report]

On April 23rd, demonstrators (including IDPs) marched in Zalingei (Central Darfur state). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for those responsible for war crimes in Darfur to be held to account. [size=no report]

On or around April 23rd, IDP's demonstrated at an unspecified location(s) in Kass locality (South Darfur). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for those responsible for war crimes in Darfur to be held to account. [size=no report]

On April 23rd, demonstrators gathered in Foro Baranga (West Darfur), to stage a sit-in protest (lasting at least three days) outside the SAF headquarters. The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime; for perpetrators of abuses and war crimes in Darfur to be prosecuted; and for paramilitary security organs to be dismantled. [size=no report]

On April 24th three senior figures in the Transitional Military Council stepped down, following accusation that they were 'Islamists', heralding a shift in Sudanese politics, in which purges and crackdowns will be initiated against groups and individuals deemed to be 'Islamists'.

On April 24th, demonstrators marched in Tendelti (White Nile state), against the Bashir regime, and in favour of what the protesters described as the favour shown towards them on the part of the military. Residents of the town also protested against the lack of basic services and their need for food. [size=no report]

On April 24th, lawyers marched in El Fasher (North Darfur). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime; for corruption to be stamped out; and for effective justice mechanisms to be restored. [size=no report]

On April 24th, dock workers as well as custom officials marched in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), in support of the ongoing sit-in outside the Naval HQ in the city, and against precarious employment practices at the docks. The workers also announced a four day-long strike in support of the nationwide anti-govt demonstrations. [size= no report]

On April 25th, demonstrators gathered in El Fasher (North Darfur). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime; for crimes against demonstrators to be investigated; and for state institutions to be purged of associates of the NCP regime. [size=no report]

On April 25th, demonstrators gathered in Nyala (South Darfur). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for political, social, and security institutions in the state which were linked to the NCP regime to be dissolved. [size=no report]

On April 25th, IDP's marched in Zalingei (Central Darfur). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime; for perpetrators of abuses and war crimes in Darfur to be prosecuted; and for paramilitary security organs to be dismantled. [size=no report]

On April 25th, demonstrators marched in Mukjar (Central Darfur). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime; for perpetrators of abuses and war crimes in Darfur to be prosecuted; and for paramilitary security organs to be dismantled. [size=no report]

On April 25th, IDP's marched in Garsila (Central Darfur). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime; for perpetrators of abuses and war crimes in Darfur to be prosecuted; and for paramilitary security organs to be dismantled. [size=no report]

On April 25th, IDP's marched in Bindisi (Central Darfur). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime; for perpetrators of abuses and war crimes in Darfur to be prosecuted; and for paramilitary security organs to be dismantled. [size=no report]

On April 25th, demonstrators marched in Umm Dukhun (Central Darfur). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime; for perpetrators of abuses and war crimes in Darfur to be prosecuted; and for paramilitary security organs to be dismantled. [size=no report]

On April 25th, protesters gathered in Shendi (River Nile state), and staged a sit-in protest. The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. [size=no report]

On April 25th, protesters gathered in Kosti (White Nile state), and staged a sit-in protest. The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. [size=no report]

On April 25th, protesters gathered in Nouri (West Darfur state), and staged a sit-in protest. The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. [size=no report]

On April 25th, protesters gathered in El Managil (El Gazira state), and staged a sit-in protest. The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. [size=no report]

On April 25th, a children's march was organised in Khartoum, in support of the ongoing sit-in outside the Military HQ in the city, which was also the destination of a large rally. Additionally, 40 judges attended the sit-in protest, signing a memorandum calling for a rapid transition to civilian rule. [size=large]

On April 25th, demonstrators marched in West Jagmha (Central Darfur; no geographic information found, coordinates for state capital Zalingei used at precision 2). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime; for perpetrators of abuses and war crimes in Darfur to be prosecuted; and for paramilitary security organs to be dismantled. [size=no report]
On April 26th, SPA members marched in Port Sudan, in support of the ongoing sit-in at the Naval HQ. [size=no report]

On April 26th, demonstrators gathered in Berber (River Nile state), and handed a list of demands to the locality commissioner, which called for accountability for violence committed against protesters, and for individuals associated with the Bashir regime to be removed from office. [size=no report]

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); NUP: National Umma Party
column17: On April 27th, a small youth mob attacked a meeting of the Popular Congress Party in Khartoum. The source indicates the mob (which a PCP source described as chanting NUP slogans, as well as those in support of the Declaration of Freedom and Change (assoc actor 1 coded as NUP)) attacked the attendees due to the PCP's refusal to distance themselves from the NCP regime. 64 PCP members were injured, according to a PCP official. The military intervened to separate the groups, and then arrested 143 PCP members, before releasing them in the evening. [size=hundreds]

On April 28th, protesters demonstrated at an unspecified location in Rashad locality (South Kordofan state; coordinates for Rashad used at precision 2), and delivered a memorandum to military command in the area. The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for the security organs associated with the regime to be dismantled. [size=no report]
On April 28th, four marches were conducted in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), in support of the ongoing sit-in at the Naval HQ. [size=no report]

On April 28th, four PDF paramilitaries raped two girls (aged 15 and 18) at a farm in Elfaid Um-Abdalla (South Kordofan, coordinates for Abu Kershola used at precision 2), and held their grandmother at gun point as they did so. The attackers then fled the scene, though the source suggests the police have not taken action to trace down the attackers.

On April 29th, and in response to calls from the Transitional Military Council for demonstrators to cases occupying main roads and bridges, demonstrators built barricades around the main sit-in outside the army HQ in Khartoum, and burnt tires in the streets of Khartoum North. [size=no report]

On April 29th, and in response to calls from the Transitional Military Council for demonstrators to cases occupying main roads and bridges, demonstrators built barricades around the main sit-in outside the army HQ in Khartoum, and burnt tires in the streets of Khartoum North. [size=no report]

On April 30th, demonstrators marched in Berber (River Nile state), and staged a sit-in protest in the park. The demonstrators are admonishing the authorities to implement a list of demands made to the locality commissioner several days before, and in solidarity with the sit-in protest in Khartoum. [size=no report]

On May 1st, demonstrators affiliated with the SPA marched in Zalingei (Central Darfur), to deliver a petition to the military garrison, before beginning a sit-in. The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for security organs linked to the Bashir regime to be dismantled. [size=no report]

On May 1st, protesters marched in Ed Damazin, in support of the sit-in protest taking place in the city, and on behalf of disabled groups who had joined the sit-in that same day. The demonstrators are calling for a transition to civilian rule in Sudan. [size=no report]

On May 1st, demonstrators marched in Doka (Gedaref state), against the failure of the governor to carry out their demands, including retaining personnel associated with the Bashir regime. [size=no report]

On May 1st, demonstrators marched in Gedaref (Gedaref state), against the failure of the governor to carry out their demands, including retaining personnel associated with the Bashir regime. [size=no report]

On May 1st, IDPs from Zamzam camp marched to the World Food Programme HQ in El Fasher (North Darfur), stating they had not received food rations for the past five months. The protesters then organised a sit-in demonstration outside the HQ. [size=no report]
On or around May 1st, further marches were conducted in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), in support of the ongoing sit-in at the Naval HQ. [size=no report]

On May 1st, protesters gathered for a second time in Delling (South Kordofan), to demonstrate against a lack of water in the locality. The protesters handed a memorandum to the executive director of the locality offices. Note that this is a separate protest to the other protest that took place on the same day in Delling, but the source is unclear as to whether there was an overlap between those doing the protesting at the two events. [size=no report]

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column17: On May 1st, protesters gathered in Delling (South Kordofan state), calling for a transition to civilian rule. Soldiers from Military Intelligence attacked the demonstrators with batons, and made fifteen arrests, including of three of its leaders. [size=no report]
On January 4th, protests occurred once more in Atbara (River Nile state). Unspecified security forces (coded here as police) used tear gas to disperse the crowds.

On May 2nd, protesters began a sit-in protest outside the army base in Nyala (South Darfur), which security forces attempted to disperse three days later (see separate event; note that the sit-in appeared to be continuing as of May 9th). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and in support of the sit-in taking place outside the army HQ in Khartoum. [size=no report]

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On May 2nd, RSF paramilitaries and unspecified security services (coded as police, pending further information) attempted to break the sit-in outside the military garrison in Zalingei (Central Darfur). RSF paramilitaries fired live rounds, and hit a protester with their vehicle, causing several injuries. The security services also hit a protester with their vehicle, causing another injury. Following the attack, additional protesters joined the sit-in in solidarity, and another march was organised in the city. [size=large]
On May 2nd protesters marched in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), calling for a transition to civilian rule along the lines espoused by the Forces for Freedom and Change. [size=no report]
On May 2nd protesters marched in El Obeid (North Kordofan state), calling for a transition to civilian rule along the lines espoused by the Forces for Freedom and Change. [size=no report]
On May 2nd, multiple large demonstrations took place in Khartoum, with protesters calling for a transition to civilian rule along the lines espoused by the Forces for Freedom and Change. [size=large]
On May 2nd protesters marched in Al Azazah (El Gazira state), calling for a transition to civilian rule along the lines espoused by the Forces for Freedom and Change. [size=no report]

On May 2nd, demonstrators gathered in Doka (Gedaref state), calling for individuals associated with the Bashir regime to be removed from office in the area. The protesters blocked roads (note that there is no indication that they barricaded roads, and actor 1 has accordingly been coded as Protesters), and searched vehicles headings towards the border crossing with Ethiopia, on suspicion that joint military patrols were carrying fleeing officials, before releasing the vehicles when it was determined they were not. [size=hundres]

On May 2nd protesters marched in Saukin (Red Sea state), calling for a transition to civilian rule along the lines espoused by the Forces for Freedom and Change, and against the lack of basic services and food in the town. The demonstrators began a sit-in, closing part of the Khartoum-Port Sudan highway, and shutting down Suakin port. [size=hundreds]
On May 2nd protesters marched in El Gedaref (Gedaref state), calling for a transition to civilian rule along the lines espoused by the Forces for Freedom and Change. [size=no report]
On May 2nd protesters marched in Singa (Sennar state), calling for a transition to civilian rule along the lines espoused by the Forces for Freedom and Change. [size=no report]
On May 3rd, residents of Teemteem village demonstrated following the rape of a 14 year-old girl the same day, and demanded that authorities do more to prevent such attacks. [size=small]

On May 3rd, demonstrators continued their sit-in and closure of part of the Khartoum-Port Sudan highway at Suakin (Red Sea state). Soldiers fired above the heads of the demonstrators, in an unsuccesful bid to disperse them. [size=thousands]

On 3 May 2019, a pastoralist attacked a group of five girls close to Teemteem village (North Darfur). Four of the girls fled, though the assailant raped a 14 year-old girl. A group from the village apprehended the perpetrator, and took him to the police station at Kutum.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On May 3rd, RSF paramilitaries attacked miners at Atagula gold mine in Talodi locality (South Kordofan). Five sustained gunshot wounds, with one of the injured dying en route to the hospital in Aby Jubaiha. The source notes the mine has experienced problems relating to the presence of RSF soldiers, after the mine was purchased by a company belonging to RSF commander (and de factor VP of Sudan) 'Hemeti' last year.

column9: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Popular Security Forces (Sudan)
column17: On May 4th, IDPs from the Otash camp marched to the sit-in taking place outside the army base in Nyala. The IDPs were demanding improved rations and facilities in the camp. Security forces used tear gas and live ammunition against the crowds. One person was killed by gunfire and twenty wounded, and the sit-in appeared to be dispersed. [size=5,000]

On May 4th, IDPs from Otash camp marched in Nyala (South Darfur) in solidarity with the sit-in at Khartoum, calling for a transition to a civilian regime. The majority of the demonstrators were reported to be children and women. Disputed accounts of events have followed; doctors and opposition groups said that security forces (implied to be riot police, and coded as Police) attacked demonstrators with batons, tear gas and live rounds, wounding six (two with gunshot wounds) and arresting four. Authorities have accused the demonstrators of instigating the violence, saying that five police were wounded, who responded with tear gas. [size=5,000]

On May 5th, demonstrators marched in Kassala (Kassala state), and presented a memorandum to the acting governor, calling for the Bashir regime institutions to be dismantled. Sources indicate that a sit-in protest began on or after this date. [size=no report]

On May 5th and 6th, demonstrators gathered in Al Bisharayab (Red Sea state), to protest against a lack of basic services, food and water, and to call for the removal of some local officials. [size=no report]

On May 5th and 6th, demonstrators gathered in Sinkat (Red Sea state), to protest against a lack of basic services, food and water, and to call for the removal of some local officials. [size=no report]
On May 5th, a sit-in protest began in El Fula (West Kordofan state), as part of nationwide protests calling for a transition to a civilian govt. There is no further information. [size=no report]

On May 5th, the market and electricity services of Abu Jubaiha (South Kordofan state) were destroyed in a fire. Supporters of the Alliance for Freedom and Changed accused ""shadow brigades"" (paramilitary forces associated with Bashir's NCP regime) of being behind the fire, and denied that their own members were involved.
On May 5th, nine SAF soldiers clashed with Falata pastoralists at Bashir Nugu (Blue Nile state), after the soldiers attempted to rob 500 sheep from them. Two Falata were killed in the exchange.

On May 5th, demonstrators marched to the sit-in at Port Sudan (Red Sea state), to present a list of demands to the acting governor, which called for the removal of individuals linked to the Bashir regime from office. Soldiers initially prevented the demonstrators from reaching the sit-in, but later permitted them to proceed. [size=large]

On May 5th, an army officer attempted to dismantled a barricade established by protesters at the sit-in in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile state). A group of demonstrators attacked the officer for attempting to do so. [size=no report]

On May 5th and 6th, demonstrators gathered in Al Bisharayab (Red Sea state), to protest against a lack of basic services, food and water, and to call for the removal of some local officials. [size=no report]

On May 5th and 6th, demonstrators gathered in Sinkat (Red Sea state), to protest against a lack of basic services, food and water, and to call for the removal of some local officials. [size=no report]

On May 6th, demonstrators gathered in Dinder (Sennar state), to protest against a lack of basic services, food and water; to denounce corruption among officials; and to call for the arrest of figures connected to the Bashir regime. [size=no report]

On or around May 6th, SAF soldiers reportedly attacked protesters at the large sit-in protest outside the army HQ in Khartoum. Details are vague on the incident, though the source implies that a Captain of the Sudanese national football team was injured in the incident. [size=large]

On May 7th, striking dock workers of the Sea Ports Corporation protested outside the offices of the company in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), to pressure the company to fulfil their promise to place temporary workers on permenant contracts, in a bid to resolve precarious employment practices at the port. [size=no report]

On May 7th, striking workers from the Kenana Sugar Company gathered outside the military garrison in Kenana (Sennar state), and staged a sit-in protest. The demonstrators vowed only to leave once labour conditions improved at the plant. [size=hundreds]

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces; Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019)
column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column9: Journalists (Sudan); NCP: National Congress Party; Popular Security Forces (Sudan)
column17: During the week commencing May 6th, official forces made a number of significant arrests. On May 7th, the Transitional Military Council announced that former NISS director Salah 'Gosh' was under house arrest (following reports that he was free to move around Khartoum). On May 7th, RSF paramilitaries announced they had made a number of arrests following a raid on a house containing arms and explosives in Khartoum (with the military subsequently announcing that Popular Security paramilitaries were involved). On or before May 7th, 21 NCP officials were arrested as they tried to flee Nyala in South Darfur, whilst the Governor of North Darfur announced that NCP executives were being purged from the administration in the state. On May 7th, journalist Khalid Taha and activist Mohamed Burri were arrested outside the sit-in protest in Khartoum by unspecified security forces (actor 1 coded as Govt of Sudan; RSF; police; and NISS).

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On May 7th, RSF paramilitaries attacked the large sit-in demonstration taking place outside the army HQ in Khartoum, beating an unspecified number of demonstrators (as well as two commanders the source identifies as belonging to the Sudan Liberation Movement - Kush faction. [size=large]

On May 7th and/or 8th, two South Sudanese Nuer clans (belonging to the Leek and Mayom sections) clashed in Khartoum using bladed weapons. Nine people were reported to have been killed (initial reports said one), and an unspecified number were injured. The violence is appartently linked to a revival of past greivance between the clans. Sudanese police have made a number of arrests.

On May 8th, a meeting between a number of mostly unspecified political parties organised by the Transitional Military Council at the the Friendship Hall in Khartoum descended into a brawl, involving fist fights and chair throwing. NCP and NCP-aligned politicians were involved, though the other political parties are not specified. [size=dozens]

On May 8th, workers at the Petronid Company marched in the Heglig Oil Field (West Kordofan state) to demand that the militart commander for the area relocate a security officer (implied to work for the oil company), who had threatened and forcibly transferred workers linked to ongoing nationwide protests to another oil field. [size=no report]

On May 9th, students and professional groups marched from the hospital in Kassala (Kassala state) to the sit-in protest, as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=hundreds]

On May 9th, demonstrators marched in El Geneina (West Darfur state), as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for a transition to civilian rule, and presented a memorandum to the military governor of the state. [size=thousands]
On May 9th, teachers demonstrated in El Geneina (West Darfur state), as part of nationwide protests calling for a transition to a civilian govt. There is no further information. [size=no report]

On May 9th, SAF soldiers stormed barricades at an anti-govt protest in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), arrested four and wounding an unspecified number of demonstrators with gunfire. Demonstrators captured one of the soldiers before handing him to the military offices in the town. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change; Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column16: Radio Dabanga; Sudan Tribune; Radio Tamazuj
column17: On September 5th, Prime Minister Abdallah Hamdouk announced the new cabinet for the transitional government. The new government is expected to be sworn in on September 8th. Following the announcement, the African Union restored Sudan's membership in the organisation on September 6th.

On September 5th, unknown attackers killed one person and injured four (including a university student and a teacher), in the areas of El Sadaga, El Sadelali and El Sawra (Central Darfur, coordinates for Jeben Marrah used at prec2).
On May 10th, SAF soldiers attacked Deri village (South Kordofan state), looting 65 head of cattle and injuring a teenage pastoralist.

On May 11th and 12th, members of the Nuba and Beni Amir clashed in El Gedaref (Gedaref state), sparked by the death of a woman in a dispute on the 11th. At least 7 people died (fatalities spread across two events), and at least 22 were wounded (one report says 8 dead, and over 50 wounded), and property was torched.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On and around May 12th, large numbers of RSF paramilitaries (including hundreds of armed pick-up trucks) deployed around the main site of the sit-in protest in Khartoum. On May 12th, RSF troops briefly closed Blue Nile bridge, sparking demonstrations.

On May 11th and 12th, members of the Nuba and Beni Amir clashed in El Gedaref (Gedaref state), sparked by the death of a woman in a dispute on the 11th. At least 7 people died (fatalities spread across two events), and at least 22 were wounded (one report says 8 dead, and over 50 wounded), and property was torched.

On May 12th, employees of the Ministry of Infrastructure and Transport and Khartoum state Corporation of Roads and Bridges demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for a transition to civilian rule, and improved pay and work conditions. Separately, demonstrators blocked the Nile Street, following attempts by RSF paramilitarties to clear protesters. [size=hundreds]

On May 12th, residents of Omdurman demonstrated against power and water shortages, blocking the road outside of the Water Corporation in Khartoum (actor 1 coded as protesters, as the means by which they blocked the road are unspecified). [size=no report]

column16: Africa Confidential; Sudan Tribune; Radio Dabanga
column17: In the evening of May 13th, men in RSF paramilitary uniforms attacked the sit-in demonstration at Khartoum, killing six (five protesters (one died the following day, and another on May 24th) and an army captain; the latter was killed by sharpshooters), and around 200 were wounded (76 by gunfire (9 critically)). The TMC and RSF have denied RSF involvement, attributing the attack to 'shadow brigades' linked to the Bashir regime posing as RSF (actor 1 coded as UAG pending further information).
On May 13th, demonstrators marched in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), condemning the killing of demonstrators in Khartoum that same day. [size=very large]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019)
column17: On the morning of May 13th, demonstrators set up additional barricades around the sit-in in Khartoum. Men in police, army and RSF uniforms dismantled the barricades, and cleared demonstrators with batons, whips, tear gas, rubber and live ammunition. At least 8 were wounded, three as a result of live rounds, one when a security vehicle drove into protesters. [size=large]

On May 14th, demonstrators marched at one or more unspecified location(s) in River Nile state (coordinates for Ed Damer used at precision 3), condemning the killing of demonstrators in Khartoum the previous day. [size=thousands]
On May 14th, demonstrators marched to the sit-in at Wad Medani (El Gazira state), condemning the killing of demonstrators in Khartoum the previous day. [size=hundreds]
On May 14th, demonstrators marched in Doka (Gedaref state), condemning the killing of demonstrators in Khartoum the previous day. [size=no report]
On May 14th, demonstrators marched in El Gedaref (Gedaref state), condemning the killing of demonstrators in Khartoum the previous day. [size=no report]
On May 14th, demonstrators marched in Kassala (Kassala state), condemning the killing of demonstrators in Khartoum the previous day. Demonstrators barricaded El Gash bridge. [size=large]

On May 14th, judges as well as range of public sector and private sector workers held multiple demonstrations in Khartoum, condemning the killing of demonstrators the previous day (with judges also calling for an independent and overhauled judiciary). [size=large]
On May 14th, thousands demonstrated in Khartoum North, at the funeral for one of the victims of the attack at the sit-in protest outside the army HQ on May 13th. [size=thousands]
On May 14th, doctors marched in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), condemning the killing of demonstrators in Khartoum the previous day. [size=no report]
On May 14th, demonstrators marched in Nyala (South Darfur state), condemning the killing of demonstrators in Khartoum the previous day. [size=no report]
On May 14th, teachers began a sit-in protest in El Geneina (West Darfur state), calling on the military governor to implement demands they had previously delivered on May 9th. [size=no report]

On May 14th, demonstrators marched at an unspecified location in North Kordofan state (coordinates for El Obeid used at precision 3), condemning the killing of demonstrators in Khartoum the previous day. [size=no report]

column7: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Unidentified Armed Group (Sudan)
column8: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: On May 14th, looters (including police and military personnel) raided the Sector West HQ of UNAMID in El Geneina (West Darfur), which was about to be turned over to local authortities as part of the planned draw-down. Equipment was looted and property vandalised, though there were no reports of injuries (Ethiopian peacekeepers separated UNAMID staff from the looters). On May 12th and 13th, unknown looters (coded as UAG) raided national and international NGOs in Buram town, and again on May 28t in Kalma IDP camp.

On May 15th, men in RSF uniform attempted to remove barricades around the sit-in demonstration outside the military HQ in Khartoum. 14 demonstrators were wounded, seven of whom were shot. RSF soldiers were reported to be attacking those filming the events, including a local journalist working for a Russian news agency, who was beaten. The TMC and RSF have denied RSF involvement, attributing the attack to 'shadow brigades' linked to the Bashir regime posing as RSF (actor 1 coded as UAG pending further information).

On May 15th, labourers held a vigil outside of the post office in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), condemning the killing of demonstrators in Khartoum on May 13th, and calling for institutions to be purged of those associated with the Bashir regime. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On May 15th, RSF paramilitaries deployed to El Gedaref (Gedaref) following tribal clashes were alleged to have beaten a number of residents of the city, including two youth who were publicly beaten with whips and rifle butts.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
column17: During the month of May 2019, SLM/A-Al Nur rebels clashed with breakaway factions in the area of Golo (Rokoro locality, Central Darfur state). The source does not mention whether there were fatalities. One event coded at time prec3.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: During the month of May 2019, and amidst clashes between SLM/A-Al Nur rebels and breakaway factions in the area of Golo (Rokoro locality, Central Darfur state), unspecified rebel forces (coded as regular SLM/A-Nur rebels) torched several villages and property looted. Several instance of rape were reported to have been committed against women and children in the area. One event coded at timeprec3.
On May 16th, South Sudanese demonstrators gathered outside their embassy in Khartoum, calling for the end of the Salva Kiir government in South Sudan. [size=small]

On May 17th, several Islamist groups demonstrated in Khartoum, expressing concern about the prospects of a deal between the Transitional Military Council and the Forces for Freedom and Change. [size=small]

On May 17th, men in military uniform (coded as Sudan Armed Forces) attempted to dismantle barricades near the sit-in in Khartoum. Protesters prevented them from doing so by forming a human wall. [size=no report]
On May 18th, men in SAF uniforms (and coded as such) reportedly attacked doctors at the hospital in Ed Damazin. The motive for the attack is unclear, and there are no further details.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column9: AFC: Alliance for Freedom and Change
column17: On May 18th, RSF paramilitaries dispersed a crowd that had gathered at Zariba market in Ed Daein (East Darufr) to hear AFC representatives speak. RSF used batons and whips against the civilians.
On May 18th, uniformed men (coded as Sudan Armed Forces) removed barricades around the sit-in protest at Ed Damazin (Blue Nile state). [size=no report]

On May 18th, several Islamist groups once again demonstrated in Khartoum (this time outside of the Presidential Palace), expressing concern about the prospects of a deal between the Transitional Military Council and the Forces for Freedom and Change. [size=hundreds]
On May 19th, journalists, bank workers and employees of an energy company protested in Khartoum, in support of the sit-in outside the military HQ in Khartoum. [size=small]

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On May 20th, police attempted to arrest former NISS spymaster Salah 'Gosh' on corruption charges, but NISS agents posted outside his house in Khartoum threatened to shoot police if they did so, claiming they had received no information on the warrant. Seperately, RSF leader 'Hemeti' said May 19th that 15 people were arrested in relation to attacks on protesters in Khartoum the previous week, five of whom had confessed.
On May 20th, workers at the Agricultural Research Authority demonstrated in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), calling for the Director of the authority to step down. [size=no report]
On May 20th, demonstrators marched to the sit-in at El Gedaref, as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for a transition to a civilian government. [size=no report]

On May 20th, employees of the Ministry of Social Planning and Department of Survey protested in Khartoum, as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for a transition to a civilian government. [size=no report]

On May 20th, demonstrators marched to the sit-in at Atbara, as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for a transition to a civilian government. They were joined by members of the Union of the Blind. [size=no report]

On May 20th, engineers and employees of the Ministry of Infrastructure marched to the sit-in at El Fula (West Kordofan state), as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for a transition to a civilian government. [size=no report]

On May 21st, bank employees demonstrated at an unspecified location in Blue Nile state (coordinates for Ed Damazin used at prec2), in a prelude to a potential general strike designed to pressure the government to transfer power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

On May 21st, employees of the Electricity Distribution Company demonstrated at an unspecified location in El Gazira state (coordinates for Wad Medani used at prec2), in a prelude to a potential general strike designed to pressure the government to transfer power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

On May 21st, members of various labour groups (including academics and pharmacists) demonstrated in Khartoum, in a prelude to a potential general strike designed to pressure the government to transfer power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

On May 21st, bank employees and workers at the sugar factory demonstrated in Sennar (Sennar state), in a prelude to a potential general strike designed to pressure the government to transfer power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

On May 21st, bank employees demonstrated in Singa (Sennar state), in a prelude to a potential general strike designed to pressure the government to transfer power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

column16: Al Rakoba; Radio Dabanga; Sudan News Agency
column17: On May 22nd, members of various labour groups across the public and private sectors demonstrated in Khartoum, in a prelude to a potential general strike designed to pressure the government to transfer power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

column9: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service; Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On May 22nd, journalists demonstrated at the national television buildings in Omdurman, as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for a transition to civilian rule. ""Regular forces"" (coded as police) arrested one journalist (who was released from RSF custody the following day), whilst Military Intelligence and RSF personnel detained five other journalists.

On or after May 22nd, residents of Kass demonstrated following an incident on May 22nd in which a child was hit and killed by an RSF paramilitary truck, and the body taken to an unknown location. Demonstrators are demanding justice, and the return of the body. [size=large]

On May 23rd, doctors marched in El Managil (El Gazira state), as part of nationwide protests calling for a transition to civilian rule, and in a prelude to a potential general strike. [size=no report]

On or around May 23rd, academics protested in Gedaref (Gedaref state), in a prelude to a potential general strike designed to pressure the government to transfer power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

On May 23rd, workers and pharmacists belonging to the National Fund for Medical Supplies, as well as academics and a range of labour groups from the public and private sector, demonstrated in Khartoum, in a prelude to a potential general strike designed to pressure the government to transfer power to a civilian administration. [size=large]
On May 23rd, demonstrators marched in Port Sudan, as part of nationwide protests calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=no report]
On May 23rd, demonstrators marched in Rabak, as part of nationwide protests calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=no report]
On May 23rd, five men wearing military uniforms (and coded as SAF) shot and killed a man for resisting their attempts to steal three of his goats. The event occurred near Faluja (South Darfur state).

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On May 25th, armed men in military uniforms (implied by the source to be RSF, and coded as such) shot and killed two farmers and wounded a boy, before stealing 45 head of cattle. The event occurred in Tordi, 10km east of Kahzan Tungur (North Darfur, coordinates used at precision 2).

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On May 26th, armed men in military uniforms (implied by the source to be RSF, and coded as such) shot and wounded a pastoralist in the leg, before stealing 17 head of cattle. The event occurred in the area of Faluja (South Darfur).

On May 27th, employees of the Ministry of Urban Planning protested at an unspecified location in River Nile state (coordinates for state capital Ed Damer used at precision 2), in support of the general strike intended to pressure the military government into transferring power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

column7: Labour Group (Sudan); AFC: Alliance for Freedom and Change
column17: On May 27th, employees of the Ministry of Finance, alongside members of the AFC, demonstrated in Zalingei (North Darfur state), in support of the general strike intended to pressure the military government into transferring power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

On May 27th, lawyers protested in El Gedaref (Gedaref state), in support of the general strike intended to pressure the military government into transferring power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

On May 27th, pharmacists protested in Kassala (Kassala state), in support of the general strike intended to pressure the military government into transferring power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

On May 27th, a range of labour groups (notably including employees of the Military Industrial Corporation) demonstrated in Khartoum, in support of the general strike intended to pressure the military government into transferring power to a civilian administration. [size=large]

On May 27th, employees of the judiciary protested in El Obeid (North Kordofan state), in support of the general strike intended to pressure the military government into transferring power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]
On May 28th, four Dinka women (coded as Ngok Dinka) were abducted in central Abyei, by suspected Misseriya and Nuer gunmen.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On May 28th, RSF and ""other regular forces"" (coded as SAF) stormed the offices of the Central Bank of Sudan and the Electricity Company in Khartoum. At the Central Bank, striking employees were beaten by the forces, and money was stolen.

On May 28th, veterinarians demonstrated in Zalingei (North Darfur state), in support of the general strike intended to pressure the military government into transferring power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

On May 28th, protesters demonstrated in Ed Daein (East Darfur state), in support of the general strike intended to pressure the military government into transferring power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

On May 28th or 29th, teachers and nurses demonstrated in El Gedaref (Gedaref state), in support of the general strike intended to pressure the military government into transferring power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

On May 28th or 29th, a range of labour groups demonstrated in Kassala (Kassala state), in support of the general strike intended to pressure the military government into transferring power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

On May 28th, health workers protested outside of the hospital in El Fasher (South Darfur state), in support of the general strike intended to pressure the military government into transferring power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

On May 28th or 29th, lawyers, journalists and private sector employees demonstrated in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), in support of the general strike intended to pressure the military government into transferring power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

On May 28th or 29th, protesters demonstrated in Sennar (Sennar state), in support of the general strike intended to pressure the military government into transferring power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

On May 28th, protesters demonstrated in Nyala (South Darfur state), in support of the general strike intended to pressure the military government into transferring power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

On May 28th, protesters demonstrated in El Geneina (West Darfur state), in support of the general strike intended to pressure the military government into transferring power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

On May 28th, health workers protested outside the hospital in An Nahud (West Kordofan state), in support of the general strike intended to pressure the military government into transferring power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

On May 28th or 29th, University staff and employees of a health insurance company demonstrated in Kosti (White Nile state), in support of the general strike intended to pressure the military government into transferring power to a civilian administration. [size=no report]

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
column17: Between 25 May 2019 and 1 June 2019, an SLM/A-Al Nur splinter faction under the command of Sadiq al-Fuka (who was reported to have recently integrated with the Rapid Support Forces) attacked several villages to the north and north-east of Sabanga in Rokoro locality (Central Darfur state), including Targay, Omu, Hilat Ahmed, Krakola, Arrow and Faradolow, displacing between 5-9,000 residents. The source does not make any mention of casualties or fatalities.

On May 29th, protesters marched to the sit-in at Um Tajok (West Darfur; no geographic information found, coordinates for Al Kereinik used at precision 2). Forces said to be loyal to the Al Bashir regime (coded as Popular Security Forces) - including 'shadow battalions' - attacked the protesters with sticks and knives, wounding ten. [size=no report]

On May 29th, a pregnant lady selling tea was killed in a gunfight between soldiers, seemingly after being caught in the crossfire (note the event is described differently across sources; there is amgiguity as to whether soldiers are fighting one another, or attacked civilians). Another civilian was shot in the leg, and a soldier was also injured in the leg. The TMC claims the incident was sparked by a drunken soldier.

On May 30th, workers demonstrated outside the governor's office in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), as part of continued efforts to put precariously employed dock workers on full-time contracts. [size=no report]

On May 30th, Haj pilgrims blocked a road in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), in protest against the lack of boats to take them to Saudi Arabia, and the tough conditions they've experienced whilst stranded at the Port. (Note the source does not specify how the road was blocked, actor 1 coded as protesters). [size=hundreds]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column7: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column9: JEM: Justice and Equality Movement; Journalists (International); Journalists (Sudan); SJN: Sudanese Journalists' Network
column17: On May 29th and 30th, Military Intelligence and NISS agents raided the offices of several national and international media outlets, confiscating equipment and detaining three journalists, and closing the offices of Al Jazeera indefinitely. Separately, military intelligence arrested JEM senior leader Ibrahim El Maz Deng at Khartoum North May 30th.

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column16: Sudan Tribune; Amnesty International; Radio Dabanga
column17: On 30 May 2019, RSF and police attacked a large sit-in protest next to the army HQ in Khartoum, initially beating protesters and journalists with whips, before opening fire on demonstrators coming to their assistance. Two protesters were shot dead, and one or two seriously injured. [size=large]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: 30 June. RSF killed one civilians and injured two on the Feina-Kidigir road in Jebel Marra.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column9: Health Workers (Sudan); Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019)
column17: On May 31st, three striking doctors were beaten by plain clothes men at a hospital in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile state). Upon being arrested by the police, it transpired the attackers were RSF paramilitaries out of uniform.

At an unspecified time(s) in June (though implied to be early June, and coded as such), nine South Sudanese refugees were reported to have been killed in Omdurman. Additionally, there are reports of multiple rapes, seven injuries, and two missing persons. The attackers are unclear, although report indicated the refugees faced military aggressions, as are the precise number of events. (Coded as two events with nine fatalities, spread between them).

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: 01 June. SLM/A-Nur launched attacks on RSF positions in Rari and Barbara area in Jebel Marrah. RSF repelled the attacks.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
column17: On 1 June 2019, two groups of IDPs affiliated with different factions of the SLM/A-Nur (one loyal to Al-Nur, and the other coded as splinter faction) clashed (with firearms) in Kalma IDP camp (South Darfur state), resulting in 5 deaths.

column9: Pastoralists (Sudan); SPLM-N: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North)
column17: On June 1st, 14 SAF soldiers raided Abiyat village in Nyukur payam, stealing livestock. A pastoralist militia - which included SPLM-N members in its ranks - pursued and engaged with the soldiers at an unspecified location between Abiyat and Habila (South Kordofan state, coordinates for Nyukur used at prec2). Most of the livestock were recovered, and there are no reports of injuries or fatalities.

At an unspecified date (implied to be in late May or in the month of June, and coded as June 1st at time precision 3) 8 men and 9 children were abducted in central Abyei by suspected Misseriya and Nuer militiamen. 2 of the men were later found dead. One event coded, as the number of events is not specified in the source.

column7: AFC: Alliance for Freedom and Change
column17: 01 June. Protesters in El Obeid launched a marches and demanded a handover of power from military to civilians. [size=no report]

column7: AFC: Alliance for Freedom and Change
column17: 01 June. AFC protesters were attacked by unknown gunmen in Um Tajok. Three protesters were killed. [size=no report]

column7: AFC: Alliance for Freedom and Change
column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: 03 June. The destruction of a protest camp in El Nahud by RSF and Military sparked a mass demonstration. RSF responded with live ammunition and killed a protester. [size=no report]

column7: AFC: Alliance for Freedom and Change
column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: 03 June. RSF dismantled a protest camp in Ed Damazin, burnt tents and arrested protesters. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column7: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services; Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019)
column9: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change; Women (Sudan); Journalists (Sudan); Students (Sudan)
column17: On 3 June 2019, RSF, police and NISS (and possibly members of the army) cleared protesters at the sit-in in Khartoum, and killed at least 100 protesters (some of whom died later of their wounds), and injured around 700 (including at least 4 journalists, one of whom was shot and wounded). 70 rapes were also reported. 40 dead bodies were dumped into a river by RSF and found on June 4. Five women are still missing, as well as at least 15 others. RSF attacked students and security staff at the University of Khartoum, and looted the University. [size=no report]

On 3 June 2019, two communal militias (likely to be members of the Tama and Rizaygat, given their activity in the area) clashed at Hejlij in the Ed Daien area (East Darfur state), reportedly over control of land. 5 were killed and at least 15 wounded.

column7: AFC: Alliance for Freedom and Change
column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: 03 June. A joint team of Military and RSF cleared a protest camp in Sennar that sparked mass demonstrations in the city. [size=no report]

column7: AFC: Alliance for Freedom and Change
column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: 03 June. RSF dismantled a protest camp in Atbara and dispersed the crowd. [size=no report]

column7: AFC: Alliance for Freedom and Change
column17: 03 June. Residents and AFC members of El Obeid protested the clearance of protest camps in Khartoum. [size=thousands]

column7: AFC: Alliance for Freedom and Change
column17: 06 June. Protests in Wad Medani continued on June 6 against the regime. Military forces intervened with live ammunition and teargas. Several protesters were injured. [size=no report]

column7: AFC: Alliance for Freedom and Change
column17: 04 June. Security forces in Rabak opened fire on protesters and killed four people. 20 were injured. [size=no report]

column17: On June 5th, RSF detained the deputy leader of SPLM-N Yasir Arman in Khartoum, and on June 8th SPLM-N secretary general and spokesman were arrested. On June 10th, all three were deported to Juba (South Sudan) by Sudanese authorities.

column7: AFC: Alliance for Freedom and Change
column17: 05 June. Police forces cleared blocked roads in Rabak with live ammunition and teargas. [size=no report]
06 June. Youth in El Gedaraf protested the killing of protesters by Military forces on June 5. [size=hundreds]

column7: AFC: Alliance for Freedom and Change
column17: 06 June. Protests were staged in Dongola throughout the week following the violence against the sit-in in Khartoum. [size=no report]

On June 6th, the African Union suspended Sudan from the organization, in response to the massacre of protesters by RSF paramilitaries on June 3rd. The AU insisted that a civilian government be formed.

column7: AFC: Alliance for Freedom and Change
column17: On June 6th, demonstrators and army forces clashed in Port Sudan (Red Sea state) over the military's attempt to clear the local sit-in against the regime. Reports indicate four demonstrators were killed. [size=no report]
On June 6th, clashes between the Rizeigat and Tama groups broke out in or near Hejlij (East Darfur state), causing displacement in the area. There are no reports of fatalities.

column7: AFC: Alliance for Freedom and Change
column17: 07 June. Protests against the military regime continued after Friday prayers in Khartoum (Arkaweet, El Duyoum, and Jabra neighborhoods) and Omdurman. [size=no report]

column7: AFC: Alliance for Freedom and Change
column17: 07 June. Protests against the military regime continued after Friday prayers in Khartoum (Arkaweet, El Duyoum, and Jabra neighborhoods) and Omdurman. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: From June 7th-9th, paramilitaries (coded as RSF) attacked farms in Bora and Habor (North Darfur, coordinates for Kebkabiya used at precision 2), injuring two female IDPs.

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: 08 Hune. Security Forces arrested two opposition leaders, SPLM-N members Jallab and Ardol and politician Esmat, for taking part in a meeting with the Ethiopian PM.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: From June 7th-9th, paramilitaries (coded as RSF) attacked farms in Bora and Habor (North Darfur, coordinates for Kebkabiya used at precision 2), injuring two female IDPs.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On June 9th, security forces (likely to be RSF paramilitaries) attacked demonstrators in Khartoum North, killing one. Tear gas was also used against the protesters. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On June 9th, security forces (likely to be RSF paramilitaries) attacked demonstrators in Omdurman, killing three. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On June 9th and 10th, an armed group (implied to RSF paramilitaries) attacked multiple villages in the vicinity of Deleig (Central Darfur). 17 civilians were killed, 15 wounded and 100 dwellings torched (fatalities spread over two events). (Note one report says the clashes were between nomads and residents of the area, relating to commodity prices).

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: From June 7th-9th, paramilitaries (coded as RSF) attacked farms in Bora and Habor (North Darfur, coordinates for Kebkabiya used at precision 2), injuring two female IDPs.

column17: On June 9th and 10th, an armed group (implied to RSF paramilitaries, and coded as such) attacked multiple villages in the vicinity of Deleig (Central Darfur). 17 civilians were killed, 15 wounded and 100 dwellings torched (fatalities spread over two events). (Note one report says the clashes were between nomads and residents of the area, relating to commodity prices).

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On or before June 11th, 98 senior NISS officers were forcibly retired, amidst a restructuring of security organs.
On June 13th, demonstrators (including staff from a private company) gathered in Khartoum, as part of nationwide protests calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=no report]
On June 13th, health workers demonstrated in El Fasher (North Darfur), as part of nationwide protests calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=no report]

column6: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column9: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On June 14th, UNAMID announced it was suspending the transfer of its facilities to the Sudanese authorities as part of its withdrawal process, following a govt decree on June 13th that UNAMID camps should be handed over to RSF paramilitaries. Subsequently, the AU agreed to extend the mandate for UNAMID for a further year. UPDATE: On June 26th, the UNSC extended UNAMID until 31st October, and delayed the planned draw-down of the mission.
On June 15th, demonstrators gathered in Omdurmar, calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=large]
On June 15th, demonstrators gathered in Omdurman, calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=large]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: During the month of June 2019, an RSF captain shot a civilian at Kutri (West Darfur state), and prevented an amulance from coming to his rescue, resulting in the death of the civilian. The captain was sentenced to death in December 2019.
On June 18th, protesters (including workers from MTN Communications) protested in Khartoum, as part of nationwide protests calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=no report]

On or around June 18th, teachers marched in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), as part of nationwide protests calling for a transition to civilian rule, and to call for the start of the school year to be postponed. [size=no report]

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On June 18th, security forces (coded here as police) and RSF paramilitaries dispersed anti-TMC demonstrators at Atbara (River Nile state). [size=no report]

column9: Aid Workers (International); WFP: World Food Programme
column17: On June 19th, IDPs demonstrated in Gereida (South Darfur state)  at the poor quality of basic infrastructure in the camp, before a number of demonstrators broke away and looted the offices of the WFP and World Vision International, destroying several structures and vehicles. 11 people were later arrested. [size=no report]
On June 18th or 19th, demonstrators gathered in Greater Khartoum (coded as three events in Khartoum, Khartoum North and Omdurman), calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=no report]
On June 18th or 19th, demonstrators gathered in Greater Khartoum (coded as three events in Khartoum, Khartoum North and Omdurman), calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=no report]

On June 18th or 19th, demonstrators gathered in Kassala (Kassala state), calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=no report]
On June 18th or 19th, demonstrators gathered at an unspecified location close to El Hasahisa (El Gazira state), calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=no report]
On June 19th, demonstrators gathered in Shabasha (White Nile state), calling for justice for the victims of attacks on protesters by organized forces. [size=large]
On June 19th, demonstrators gathered in Atbara (River Nile state), calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=no report]
On June 20th, demonstrators gathered in El Obeid (North Kordofan state), calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=thousands]

On June 20th, demonstrators gathered in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=thousands]

On June 20th, demonstrators gathered in El Gedaref (Gedaref state), calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=large]

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On June 20th, demonstrators - including members of multiple public and private sector groups - protested in Khartoum, calling for a transition to civilian rule, and condemning the killing of protesters in the June 3rd massacre. A number of state employees were detained by RSF, whilst female demonstrators reported being verbally harassed by RSF. [size=large]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On June 20th, RSF forces beat a doctor at Ibrahim Malik Hospital in Khartoum, and threatened his co-workers with their guns, after they refused to falsify a report for them.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On June 20th, an unspecified group (implied to be RSF, and coded as such) detained and beat teaching assistants in Central Khartoum, and released them the same day.
On June 20th, demonstrators gathered in Singa calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=no report]
On June 20th, demonstrators gathered in El Suki (Sennar state), calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=no report]
On June 20th, three demonstrations occurred in Atbara (River Nile state), calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=large]
On June 21st, an intra-communal fight among Nuer living in Abyei occurred at Amiet common market (Abyei area), wounding three. There are no further details. [size=no report]

On June 22nd and/or 23rd, demonstrators gathered in El Obeid (North Kordofan state), to protest against the massacre in Khartoum of June 3rd. Unspecified security forces (coded here as police) violently broke apart the protests, causing a number of injuries. [size=large]

column7: AFC: Alliance for Freedom and Change
column17: On June 22nd, supporters of the AFC gathered in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), calling for a transition to civilian rule, and the restoration of internet services. [size=no report]
On June 22nd, demonstrators gathered in Singa (Sennar state), calling for a transition to civilian rule, and for justice for the victims of the June 3rd massacre in Khartoum. [size=no report]
On June 23rd, lawyers demonstrated in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), calling for a transition to civilian rule, and condemning the massacre and presence of RSF in Darfur. [size=no report]
On June 23rd, demonstrators gathered in Al Halawiyin (El Gazira state), calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=hundred]
On June 23rd, demonstrators marched in Atbara (River Nile state), calling for a transition to civilian rule, and for justice for the victims of the June 3rd massacre in Khartoum. [size=large]

On June 24th, police attempted to prevent a demonstration in Gedaref (Gedaref state), inadvertently increasing its size. Police then use tear gas and what the source describes as ""excessive violence"" to disperse the demonstration, which was calling for civilian rule. [size=large]
On June 24th, demonstrators gathered in Khartoum North, calling for a transition to a civilian government. [size=no report]
On June 24th, demonstrators gathered in Khartoum, calling for a transition to a civilian government. [size=no report]
On June 24th, demonstrators gathered in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), calling for a transition to a civilian government. [size=no report]
On June 25th, students demonstrated in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), calling for a transition to civilian rule, and for justice for the victims of the June 3rd massacre in Khartoum. [size=hundreds]

On June 25th, health workers and students demonstrated in Khartoum, as part of nationwide protests calling for a transition to civilian rule. Police violently dispersed the health workers, though there are no reports as to the numbers injured. [size=no report]

On June 25th, health workers demonstrated in El Geneina (West Darfur), calling for the reinstatement of 25 medical personnel who were dismissed due to their involvement in national anti-govt demonstrations. [size=no report]
On June 25th, health workers demonstrated in Kosti (White Nile state) as part of nationwide protests calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=no report]

On June 25th, supporters of the Transitional Military Council (calling themselves the ""Sudanese National Movement"") demonstrated in front of the Ethiopian embassy in Khartoum, protesting Ethiopian mediation in the current crisis. [size=dozens]

column7: AFC: Alliance for Freedom and Change
column17: On June 26th, SAF soldiers violently dispersed a rally organized by the AFC in Kassala (Kassala state), which was calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On June 26th, RSF paramilitaries beat the driver of the Indian ambassador's car in Khartoum, after it was allegedly involved in a collision with a child. No reports of harm to the ambassador (note: driver coded as a Sudanese civilian, pending further information).

On June 26th, approx. 10 SAF soldiers ambushed two men in or near Sabat payam (South Korodfan state, coordinates for Dalami used at prec2), killing one (who is described as a ""well-known mechanic"" and looting $1,200 in Sudanese pounds.

column7: Health Workers (Sudan); Lawyers (Sudan); Teachers (Sudan); Labour Group (Sudan)
column17: On June 27th, demonstrators (comprising health workers, teachers, lawyers and government employees) gathered in Kassala (Kassala state), calling for a transition to civilian rule, and for justice for the victims of the June 3rd massacre in Khartoum. [size=large]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On June 27th, RSF paramilitaries beat dozens of students at the East Nile University College in Khartoum, before detaining them and taking them to an unknown location (unclear if they were released).

On June 27th, health workers demonstrated in El Fasher (North Darfur state) as part of nationwide protests calling for a transition to civilian rule, and for justice for the victims of the June 3rd massacre in Khartoum. [size=no report]

column7: Teachers (Sudan); UNICEF: United Nations Childrens Fund
column17: On June 27th, University staff demonstrated in Wad Medani (El Gazira state) as part of nationwide protests calling for a transition to civilian rule, and for justice for the victims of the June 3rd massacre in Khartoum. UNICEF employees held a vigil for children killed in the June 3rd massacre in Khartoum. [size=no report]
On June 27th, demonstrators gathered in Khartoum North, calling for a transition to a civilian government. [size=hundreds]

On June 27th, demonstrators (including students and employees of several private companies) held multiple protests in Khartoum, calling for a transition to a civilian government. Security forces (coded here as police) dispersed students near the Presidential Palace. [size=large]
On June 27th, demonstrators (including secondary school students) gathered in Sennar (Sennar state), calling for a transition to a civilian government. [size=no report]
On June 27th, demonstrators gathered in Singa (Sennar state), calling for a transition to a civilian government. [size=no report]

column8: UNISFA: United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (2011-)
column17: On June 28th, unidentified gunmen fired at a UNIFSA patrol at Gung Garang in the Central Sector of Abyei. There were no injuries.

On 28 June 2019, three armed pastoralists attacked four civilians in Tabit (North Darfur state), beating a middle-aged man and woman before raping two female teenagers. The attackers then mutilated the clitoris and labia of the teenagers.

On June 30th, demonstrators gathered in Barah (North Kordofan state) calling for a transition to civilian rule, and justice for the victims of the June 4th Khartoum massacre. Two demonstrators were arrested by unspecified security forces (coded here as police). [size=large]

On June 30th, demonstrators gathered in Kassala (Kassala state) calling for a transition to civilian rule, and justice for the victims of the June 4th Khartoum massacre. Police and military used small arms and anti-aircraft fire against the crowds. [size=very large]

On June 30th, demonstrators gathered in Atbara (River Nile state) calling for a transition to civilian rule, and justice for the victims of the June 4th Khartoum massacre. Unspecified security forces (coded here as police) killed one protesters while dispersing the demonstrations [size=no report]

On June 30th, demonstrators gathered in Rabak (White Nile state) calling for a transition to civilian rule, and justice for the victims of the June 4th Khartoum massacre. Security forces (coded here as police) were reported to have contained protesters, though the source does not state whether violence was used. [size=large]

On June 30th, demonstrators gathered in Port Sudan (Red Sea state) calling for a transition to civilian rule, and justice for the victims of the June 4th Khartoum massacre. Unspecified security forces (coded here as police) were reported to have violently intervened. [size=very large]

column7: AFC: Alliance for Freedom and Change
column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On June 30th, demonstrators gathered in Omdurman, calling for a transition to civilian rule, and justice for the victims of the June 4th Khartoum massacre. RSF and police dispersed crowds. Five people were killed (potentially from sniper fire; note one source indicates AFC committee members were among the dead) and a further three bodies were found in the Nile the following day, and a number were wounded. One RSF soldier was also reported to have been killed, although the details remain unclear and there was no indication it was caused by the demonstrators. [size=very large]

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On June 30th, demonstrators gathered in El Obeid (North Kordofan state) calling for a transition to civilian rule, and justice for the victims of the June 4th Khartoum massacre. RSF paramilitaries fired upon demonstrators using live rounds, injuring ten. [size=large]
