On June 30th, demonstrators gathered in Gedaref (Gedaref state) calling for a transition to civilian rule, and justice for the victims of the June 4th Khartoum massacre. Soldiers (coded as SAF) reportedly entered a hospital and fired shots, as part of counter-protest operations. One person was killed, and 27 injured, whilst a senior SPA figure was among 20 who were detained. [size=very large]

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On July 1st, RSF paramilitaries fired live rounds and tear gas upon crowds mourning the death of a protester in Atbara (River Nile state), injuring several people. [size=large]
On July 1st, demonstrators gathered in Omdurman, protesting against violence against protesters the previous day. Demonstrators barricaded the road leading to White Nile bridge. [size=600]

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On Feb 7th, 19th and March 3rd, SLM/A-al Nur rebels again clashed with SAF soldiers near Manabu (Central Darfur), killing six rebels (fatalities split across three events).

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On July 2nd, demonstrators gathered in Atbara (River Nile state) calling for a transition to civilian rule, and justice for the victims of the June 4th Khartoum massacre. RSF paramilitaries were reported to be dispersing demonstrators with plastic whips and tear gas. [size=no report]
On July 2nd, demonstrators gathered in several districts of Khartoum North, calling for a transition to civilian rule, and justice for the victims of the June 4th Khartoum massacre. [size=large]

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On July 3rd, SLM/A-Al Nur rebel ""elements"" abducted four Sudanese NGO workers (employed by an international NGO) at Karonga (Central Darfur), and looted medical supplies from a nearby NGO clinic. The abductees were released the following day.

column9: Prisoners (Sudan); SLM/A-Minnawi: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Minnawi Faction); SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction)
column17: On July 4th, the TMC government released 235 prisoners of war from the SLM-Minni Minawi and SLM-TC factions from El Huda prison in Omdurman. Note that prisoners belonging to other rebel groups were not released.

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column9: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On July 4th, demonstrators gathered in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), calling for a transition to civilian rule. RSF paramilitaries, police and security agents (coded here as NISS) were active in the city, and RSF troops were reported to be assaulting citizens in the city. (Event coded as protest with intervention, given the simultaneous presence of protesters and RSF violence). [size=large]
On July 4th, demonstrators (including teachers) gathered in Khartoum, calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=large]
On July 4th, demonstrators (including students) gathered in Gedaref (Gedaref state), calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=thousands]
On July 4th, demonstrators (including students) gathered in Sennar (Sennar state), calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=thousands]
On July 4th, demonstrators (including students and teachers) gathered in Sennar (Sennar state), calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=large]
On July 4th, teachers demonstrated in Nyala (South Darfur state), calling for the payment of salary arrears, and the release of detainees held by the TMC government. [size=no report]
On July 4th, demonstrators gathered in Kassala (Kassala state), calling for a transition to civilian rule. [size=no report]

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On July 5th, RSF paramilitaries attacked protesters who were celebrating the agreement on the transitional government in Abu Jubaiha (South Kordofan), using tear gas, live rounds (fired over the heads of the crowds) and beating protesters. One person was seriously injured. [size=no report]

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces; Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019)
column8: AFC: Alliance for Freedom and Change
column17: On July 5th, the Transitional Military Council and the Alliance for Freedom and Change announced they had reached an agreement on a transitional govt, involving a rotating presidency (21 months with a military president, and 18 with a civilian one), and a Sovereign Council comprising 11 members (5 military, 5 AFC, 1 civilian selected by both). An investigation into the Khartoum massacre will also take place.

On July 5th, gunmen (suspected of coming from the disputed Northern Liech state in South Sudan, and coded as such) attacked and killed a deputy chief in Marialachak (Abyei, coordinates for Rumamier county used at prec2). Another man was abducted, and 15 head of cattle stolen.
On July 5th, police dispersed demonstrators who were celebrating the agreement on the transitional government in Atbara (River Nile state), using tear gas. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On July 8th, an RSF affiliate (called El Sadig El Fouka, coded as RSF pending further information on the group) reportedly attacked a Dongola village in Jebel Marrah (Central Darfur, coordinates used at prec2), wounding a civilian and looting 200 head of cattle.
On July 8th, gunmen fired above the heads of villagers at Ared Shoof (North Darfur state, approximate coordinates 24km west of Kebkabiya town used) to prevent the residents from farming.

On July 8th, a suspected communal militia attacked a woman with sticks at her farm close to Wad Tamir (North Darfur, coordinates for Kebkabiya used at prec2). The source does not provide a motive for the attack.
On July 8th, a teenage boy was killed by unexploded ordnance near Dobo Umda (North Darfur state).

On July 9th, lecturers and other staff members of El Gedaref University demonstrated in El Gedaref (Gedaref state), against the reallocation of employees who were involved in anti-govt protests. [size=large]

On July 9th, gunmen riding camels shot and wounded a farmer, who had challenged an alleged rental scam taking place on his land. The event took place near Dade (North Darfur; approximate coordinates based on UN OCHA map of Darfur used at prec2).

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On July 10th, demonstrators gathered in Katayla (South Darfur state), to protest against the locality commissioner, whom they accused of mismanagement of the locality, and of being associated with the Bashir regime. RSF, army and police later arrested five FFC youth who had participated in the demonstrations on July 12th. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: During the week beginning July 8th, two men were shot at an unspecified location in Assalaya locality (East Darfur, coordinates for Assalaya used at prec2). The source implies RSF paramilitaries were responsible. There is no information on whether the victims were injured or killed.

column9: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services; Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On July 11th, the TMC claimed that it had thwarted a coup attempt, and arrested 17 officers and 4 non-commissioned officers from SAF and NISS. Separately, TMC deputy chairman 'Hemedti' announced that unspecified perpetrators of the RSF-led massacre of protesters on June 3rd had been taken into custody.
On July 11th, health workers demonstrated in El Geneina (West Darfur state) against the appointment of a new director general who is associated with the Bashir regime. [size=no report]

On July 12th, demonstrators (including students and teachers) gathered in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), calling for an investigation into the June 3rd massacre, and for power to be handed over to civilians. [size=no report]
On or before July 12th, gunmen riding camels shot dead a man whom they were attempting to rob, at Faluja village (South Darfur).

On July 13th, demonstrators gathered in Greater Khartoum (coded as three events in Omdurman, Khartoum North, and Khartoum) to commemorate the passing of forty days since the June 3rd massacre, and calling for justice for the victims of the attack. Police used barbed wire on several bridges to prevent the movement of demonstrators. Students demonstrated on campsuses in Khartoum and Omdurman. [size=large]

On July 13th, demonstrators gathered in Greater Khartoum (coded as three events in Omdurman, Khartoum North, and Khartoum) to commemorate the passing of forty days since the June 3rd massacre, and calling for justice for the victims of the attack. Police used barbed wire on several bridges to prevent the movement of demonstrators. Students demonstrated on campsuses in Khartoum and Omdurman. [size=large]
On July 13th, protesters marched in El Souki (Sennar state), as part of nationwide protests commemorating the June 3rd massacre in Khartoum. [size=no report]

Police used barbed wire on several bridges to prevent the movement of demonstrators. [size=large]

On July 13th, demonstrators gathered in Atbara (River Nile state), to commemorate the passing of forty days since the June 3rd massacre, and calling for justice for the victims of the attack. [size=large]

On July 14th, ten farmers were killed and five wounded following a land dispute among two groups of farmers near Routrout (North Darfur state, approximate coordinates of 15km south-east of Umm Keddada used at prec2). Security forces intervened arrested suspects from both sides.

On the evening of July 14th, demonstrators attacked the NISS command post (now occupied by RSF) at El Souki (Sennar state), destroying two vehicles in the process. The event came after RSF attacked protesters earlier in the day. [size=no report]

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On July 14th, demonstrators gathered in El Souki (Sennar state), calling for RSF paramilitaries to leave the town. RSF soldiers shot and killed two (note one conflicting report says a protester and an RSF paramilitary were killed), and wounded at least fifteen others, four seriously. [size=no report]

On July 15th, demonstrations occurred in Khartoum (including by University students), following the attack on protesters by RSF paramilitaries in El Souki the previous day. Authorities (coded here as police) used tear gas against the demonstrators. [size=large]

On July 15th, three demonstrations occurred in Singa (Sennar state), following the attack on protesters by RSF paramilitaries in El Souki the previous day. Secondary school students were among the demonstrators. [size=large]
On July 15th, demonstrations occurred in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), following the attack on protesters by RSF paramilitaries in El Souki the previous day. [size=no report]
On July 15th, demonstrations occurred in Kassala (Kassala state), following the attack on protesters by RSF paramilitaries in El Souki the previous day. [size=no report]
On July 15th, two farmers were abducted by armed pastoralists near Martal (North Darfur state). The body of one was found the following day, the whereabouts of the other is unknown.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On July 15th, RSF paramilitaries raided a house in Ed Daein (East Darfur), believing the occupants were responsible for stealing an officer's mobile phone. RSF soldiers tortured one resident to death, and injured two others.

column9: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces; Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019)
column17: On July 15th, protesters demonstrated at the Electricity Company in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), due to problems with power outages. RSF, police and regular soldiers beat the demonstrators, wounding ten. [size=no report]

During the month of July 2019, a drunken SAF soldier assaulted the owner of a commercial taxi vehicle at Sinja Nabak (Blue Nile state), after the driver refused to transport the soldier. The soldier was arrested in October, but the driver had his vehicle confiscated on October 25th, and was informed that it would not be released unless he dropped the case against the soldier.
On July 15th, a farmer was killed in Tina (North Darfur) by armed pastoralists.

column8: UNISFA: United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (2011-)
column17: On July 16th, unknown gunmen attacked Amiet Market (Abyei) killing six civilians, including a baby, and looting a small number of cattle. A UNSIFA patrol intervened, and the gunmen killed one peacekeeper and seriously wounded another. Subsequent reports imply the attackers were cattle raiders from South Sudan, and have been coded as such.

On or around July 16th, demonstrators destroyed buildings occupied by the RSF in Ed Daein (East Darfur), following the murder of a man by RSF paramilitaries on July 15th. RSF were deployed in the streets after the incident. [size=no report]

On July 16th, University students demonstrated in Sennar (Sennar state), following recent RSF violence in Ed Daein and El Souki, and against the resumption of studies at a time of national crisis. [size=no report]

On July 16th, University students demonstrated in Khartoum, following recent RSF violence in Ed Daein and El Souki, and against the resumption of studies at a time of national crisis. [size=no report]

On July 16th, workers at the Electricity Company and Irrigation Ministry protested in Khartoum. The workers were calling for various officials (including those with ties to the Bashir regime) to be removed, and calling for workers who had been transferred for their role in nationwide protests to be returned. [size=no report]

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On July 16th, demonstrators gathered in Omdurman, as part of nationwide anti-government protests. Five protesters were shot and wounded by RSF paramilitaries. [size=no report]

On July 17th, a prominent blogger was assaulted and his equipment and passport confiscated by two security personnel (coded here as police) in Khartoum. The blogger sought refuge in the Ethiopian embassy.

On July 17th, demonstrators (including students) gathered in Khartoum and Burri, calling for justice for the victims of attacks against demonstrators, and for the goals of the uprising to be fulfilled. [size=large]

On July 17th, demonstrators (including students) gathered in Khartoum and Burri, calling for justice for the victims of attacks against demonstrators, and for the goals of the uprising to be fulfilled. [size=large]
On July 17th, demonstrators gathered in Wad Medani (El Gazira state) calling for justice for the victims of attacks against demonstrators. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On or before July 17th, two teenage girls were beaten and raped by five RSF paramilitaries in the area of Arwala (Central Darfur).

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On July 17th, SAF and RSF soldiers were reported to have beaten civilians (as well as forcibly shaving their heads) who were accused of violating a curfew in Port Sudan (Red Sea state).

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On July 17th, a female student had her head forcibly shaved by a man in an RSF uniform in Khartoum, who had accosted her for not wearing a veil.

On July 18th, demonstrators gathered in Khartoum, calling for justice for the victims of violence by state security forces during the uprising. Police dispersed demonstrators with tear gas at one location. [size=tens of thousands]
On July 18th, demonstrators gathered in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), calling for justice for the victims of violence by state security forces during the uprising. [size=large]
On July 18th, demonstrators gathered in Singa (Sennar state), calling for justice for the victims of violence by state security forces during the uprising. [size=no report]

On July 19th, demonstrators (including lecturers) gathered in Khartoum in solidarity with survivors of rape by state security forces during the uprising, including by RSF paramilitaries on June 3rd. [size=no report]

On July 19th, demonstrators gathered in Wad Medani (El Gazira state) in solidarity with survivors of rape by state security forces during the uprising, including by RSF paramilitaries on June 3rd. [size=no report]

On July 19th, demonstrators gathered in Gedaref (Gedaref state) in solidarity with survivors of rape by state security forces during the uprising, including by RSF paramilitaries on June 3rd. [size=no report]

On July 19th, demonstrators gathered in El Obeid (North Kordofan state) in solidarity with survivors of rape by state security forces during the uprising, including by RSF paramilitaries on June 3rd. [size=no report]
On July 19th, IDPs marched in Tawila (North Darfur), against attacks on farmers by armed pastoralists in the area. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On July 20th, RSF paramilitaries fired upon civilians at Kabra (North Darfur, approx coordinates 8km west of Tunjur used at prec2), killing six (including two children) and wounding 7 (4 seriously). The attackers accused the villagers of stealing camels.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column17: On July 20th, military intelligence personnel tortured a soldier to death at a detention facility in Dilling (South Kordofan). The victim had been arrested two weeks earlier with six others in connection to missing weapons.

On July 20th, armed pastoralists beat a farmer at Kulu village near Kassab refugee camp (North Darfur, coordinates used) with their rifles, wounding him. They also prevented other farmers from tilling their land.

On July 20th, unknown gunmen opened fire upon civilians near Gandatu (South Darfur, coordinates for Kass used at prec2), killing five children, and wounding three. Three people were also abducted, and the gunmen then stole donkeys and money from the victims.

On July 21st, men in military uniforms (coded as SAF) attacked Owry/Ouri mine (North Darfur state), wounding an unspecified number (eight seriously) and abducting three men. They also stole cash and money from the miners.

On July 21st, armed pastoralists and farmers clashed in the vicinity of Shamanak (South Kordofan state, coordinates for Habila used at prec2). One person was killed, and six injured. Local authorities resolved the matter.

On or around July 21st, pastoralist militias were reported to have engaged in a spate of attacks against farmers at several locations in Kutum and Tawila localities (North Darfur state). The farmers were beaten and expelled from their farms. Two events coded (one in Tawila, the other in Kutum, both at prec2).

On or around July 21st, pastoralist militias were reported to have engaged in a spate of attacks against farmers at several locations in Kutum and Tawila localities (North Darfur state). The farmers were beaten and expelled from their farms. Two events coded (one in Tawila, the other in Kutum, both at prec2).
On July 21st, demonstrators (including students and private sector employees) gathered in Khartoum, to commemorate the June 3rd massacre in Khartoum. [size=no report]
On July 21st, demonstrators (including students) gathered in Omdurman, to commemorate the June 3rd massacre in Khartoum. [size=no report]
On July 21st, demonstrators gathered in Atbara (River Nile state), to commemorate the June 3rd massacre in Khartoum. [size=no report]
On July 21st, demonstrators gathered in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), to commemorate the June 3rd massacre in Khartoum. [size=no report]
On July 21st, demonstrators gathered in El Suki (Sennar state), to commemorate the June 3rd massacre in Khartoum. [size=no report]
On July 21st, demonstrators (including students) gathered in Sennar (Sennar state), to commemorate the June 3rd massacre in Khartoum. [size=no report]

On July 21st, academics protested outside of the Sudan University for Science and Technology (Khartoum), demanding the resignation of the director and for a free union to be established. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On or before July 23rd, SLM/A-Nur rebels claimed they had repulsed an attack by RSF paramilitaries in the area of Barabara (Central Darfur state), killing many (10 fatalities coded), and looting supplies.

On or before July 22nd, demonstrators gathered in Katayla (South Darfur state), to protest against the continued presence of Bashir regime figures in the local administration. Security forces (coded here as police) arrested six. [size=small]
On July 22nd, students at the University of Khartoum commemorated the June 3rd massacre, and called for a civilian govt and a fair investigation into the causes of the massacre. [size=no report]

On July 22nd, demonstrators gathered in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), to commemorate those missing as a result of the June 3rd massacre in Khartoum, and calling for a transparent report into the events to be released. [size=large]
On July 22nd, demonstrators gathered in Singa (Sennar state), and called for a transition to a civilian government, and condemning an immunity from prosecution on the part of the TMC. [size=large]

column9: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On July 23rd, students, teachers, and public and private sector employees, demonstrated in Khartoum, in solidarity with the families of those missing in the June 3rd massacre. Soldiers and RSF paramilitaries ""intercepted"" the demonstrators, though the source does not specify whether any violent dispersal occurred. [size=large]
On July 23rd, students demonstrated in Omdurman, in solidarity with the families of those missing in the June 3rd massacre. [size=no report]
On July 23rd, health workers gathered in Singa (Sennar state), to demand to know the fate of those missing in the June 3rd massacre. [size=no report]
On July 23rd, demonstrators gathered in Kassala (Kassala state), to demand to know the fate of those missing in the June 3rd massacre. [size=no report]

On July 23rd, health workers gathered at El Tura hospital in El Mahas (Northern state, coordinates for Delgo used at prec2), to demand to know the fate of those missing in the June 3rd massacre. [size=no report]

column7: PDF: Popular Defence Forces; NCP: National Congress Party
column9: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces; Government of Sudan (1989-2019)
column16: Radio Dabanga; Al Rakoba; Sudan Tribune
column17: On July 24th, the military announced it had thwarted a coup attempt, led by head of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Lt Gen Hashim Abdelmutalab. Over the coming days, a number of senior commanders, NCP politicians, and the head of the PDF paramilitary force, were arrested. SAF and RSF paramilitaries were deployed in the capital.

On July 24th, demonstrators gathered in Dilling (South Kordofan state), in protest at the killing of a soldier (by torture), who was detained in the custody of Military Intelligence earlier that week. [size=large]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change; Labour Group (Sudan)
column17: On July 24th, and following the banning of an FFC-organised symposium at the GNPOC oil firm in Khartoum by NISS, workers at the company and FFC representatives demonstrated against the ban. [size=no report]

On July 24th, government employees demonstrated in Khartoum at the Agricultural Ministry, calling for an elected Farmer's Union, and for a transition to a civilian government. Health workers also demonstrated in solidarity for those missing in the June 3rd massacre. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On July 24th, members of FFC district committees demonstrated in Khartoum North, in solidarity with the families of those missing in the June 3rd massacre, and calling for a civilian government. [size=no report]
On July 24th, medical staff gathered in Nyala (South Darfur state), in solidarity with the families of those missing in the June 3rd massacre, and calling for a civilian government. [size=no report]

column9: NCP: National Congress Party; Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services; Rioters (Sudan)
column17: On July 24th, police and security services (coded as NISS) dispersed student demonstrators in Omdurman, who fled to a nearby cemetery. A youth mob of NCP students then attacked the demonstrating students as police and NISS looked on. A number of demonstrators were then arrested. [size=no report]

On July 24th, the house of the editor of El Baath newspaper was attacked by a group of unknown armed men in Khartoum. The source does not specify whether there were any injuries. The offices of the paper were ransacked by an unknown group on July 29th.

On July 25th, the village of Koya in southern Jebel Marrah (no geographic information found; coordinates for Jebel Marrah, Central Darfur, used at prec2) was shelled by government forces (coded here as SAF), killing four students (including a child), and wounding over twenty. Livestock were killed in the blast, and properties destroyed.

On or around July 25th, students demonstrated in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), following the decision of the Faculty of Medical Sciences and Technology to continue exams and studies in a time of national crisis. [size=no report]

On July 25th, protesters gathered in Wakara (South Kordofan state), to protest the resumption of gold mining in the area, which has been linked to harmful effects on human health and the local environment. [size=no report]

On July 27th, demonstrators gathered in Khartoum and Omdurman, to reject the findings of the official investigation into the June 3rd massacre. Security forces intervened to disperse the demonstrators [size=large]

On July 27th, demonstrators gathered in Khartoum and Omdurman, to reject the findings of the official investigation into the June 3rd massacre. Security forces (coded here as police) used tear gas and rubber bullets against demonstrators, causing a number of injuries. [size=large]

On July 28th, sit-in protests were held at the University of Khartoum and University of Science and Technology, to reject the findings of the official investigation into the June 3rd massacre. [size=no report]
On July 28th, demonstrators gathered in Khartoum North and Omdurman, to reject the findings of the official investigation into the June 3rd massacre. [size=large]
On July 28th, demonstrators gathered in Khartoum North and Omdurman, to reject the findings of the official investigation into the June 3rd massacre. [size=large]

On July 28th, secondary school students engaged in a spontaneous demonstration in El Obeid (North Kordofan state), over detiorating economic conditions. [size=no report]

column7: Students (Sudan); FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column8: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column16: The Guardian; Radio Dabanga; Sudan Tribune
column17: On July 29th, secondary school students engaged in a second sponteneous demonstration at El Obeid (North Kordofan state) against deteriorating economic conditions. RSF paramilitaries opened fire upon the demonstrators, killing five (four students and an activist, coded as FFC), and wounding over 60 (eight seriously, one of whom subsequently died). Seven RSF soldiers have been arrested. [size=large]

column6: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-) General Intelligence Service
column17: On July 29th, the TMC announced that the notorious intelligence agency NISS was to be renamed the General Intelligence Service, and its powers to arrest and search revoked, in line with proposals to reoreient the agency to intelligence operations and away from regime policing.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On July 29th, two Sudanese employees of an international NGO and a local leader were abducted at Tarbi village near Golo (no geographic information found, coordinates for Golo, Central Darfur, used at prec2) by suspected SLM/A Al-Nur """"elements"""". They were released at an unspecified later time.

On July 29th, demonstrators (including IDPs from South Kordofan, and University students) gathered in Omdurman, to protest against the killing of protesters by RSF paramilitaries at El Obeid that same day. [size=very large]

On July 29th, demonstrators (including University students) gathered in Khartoum and Khartoum North, to protest against the killing of protesters by RSF paramilitaries at El Obeid that same day. [size=tens of thousands]

On July 31st, the SPLM-N under Abdelaziz al Hilu declared a ceasefire to last from August 1st to December 31st 2019.

On July 31st, students demonstrated in El Geneina (West Darfur state), following the sudden closure of schools across Sudan. An additional march condenming the El Obeid massacre took place. [size=large]
On July 31st, students demonstrated in Ed Daein (East Darfur state), following the sudden closure of schools across Sudan. [size=large]
On July 31st, students demonstrated in Nyala (South Darfur state), following the sudden closure of schools across Sudan, whilst lecturers demonstrated against the El Obeid massacre. [size=large]
On July 31st, students demonstrated in Zalingei (Central Darfur state), following the sudden closure of schools across Sudan. [size=large]
On July 31st, demonstrators (including students) gathered in Khartoum, condemning the TMC as well as the recent massacre at El Obeid. [size=large]
On July 31st, demonstrators (including students) gathered in Rabak (White Nile state), condemning the TMC as well as the recent massacre at El Obeid. [size=large]
On July 31st, demonstrators (including students) gathered in Geziret Aba (White Nile state), condemning the TMC as well as the recent massacre at El Obeid. [size=large]
On July 31st, demonstrators (including students) gathered in El Obeid (North Kordofan state), condemning the TMC as well as the recent massacre in the town. [size=large]
On July 31st, demonstrators (including students) gathered in Abu Jubailha (South Kordofan state), condemning the TMC as well as the recent massacre at El Obeid. [size=large]
On July 31st, demonstrators (including students) gathered in Bandah (West Kordofan state), condemning the TMC as well as the recent massacre at El Obeid. [size=large]
On July 31st, demonstrators (including students) gathered in Ghubeish (West Kordofan state), condemning the TMC as well as the recent massacre at El Obeid. [size=large]

On August 1st, demonstrators gathered in Khartoum and Khartoum North, as part of a day of nationwide protests against the massacre at El Obeid on July 29th, and for justice for the victims of other acts of violence by state security organs during the course of nationwide protests. Security was heavy in the area, though no incidents have so far been reported. [size=very large]

On August 1st, demonstrators gathered in Khartoum and Khartoum North, as part of a day of nationwide protests against the massacre at El Obeid on July 29th, and for justice for the victims of other acts of violence by state security organs during the course of nationwide protests. Security was heavy in the area, though no incidents have so far been reported. [size=very large]

On August 1st, demonstrators gathered in Umm Rawaba (North Kordofan state), as part of a day of nationwide protests against the massacre at El Obeid on July 29th, and for justice for the victims of other acts of violence by state security organs during the course of nationwide protests. [size=large]

On August 1st, demonstrators gathered in Ed Daein (East Darfur state), as part of a day of nationwide protests against the massacre at El Obeid on July 29th, and for justice for the victims of other acts of violence by state security organs during the course of nationwide protests. [size=large]

On August 1st, demonstrators gathered in El Geneina (West Darfur state), as part of a day of nationwide protests against the massacre at El Obeid on July 29th, and for justice for the victims of other acts of violence by state security organs during the course of nationwide protests. [size=large]

On August 1st, demonstrators gathered in El Fasher (North Darfur state), as part of a day of nationwide protests against the massacre at El Obeid on July 29th, and for justice for the victims of other acts of violence by state security organs during the course of nationwide protests. [size=large]

On August 1st, demonstrators gathered in Nyala (South Darfur state), as part of a day of nationwide protests against the massacre at El Obeid on July 29th, and for justice for the victims of other acts of violence by state security organs during the course of nationwide protests. [size=large]

On August 1st, demonstrators gathered in Zalingei (Central Darfur state), as part of a day of nationwide protests against the massacre at El Obeid on July 29th, and for justice for the victims of other acts of violence by state security organs during the course of nationwide protests. [size=large]

On August 1st, demonstrators gathered in Gideer (North Kordofan state, coordinates for Kadugli used at prec3), as part of a day of nationwide protests against the massacre at El Obeid on July 29th, and for justice for the victims of other acts of violence by state security organs during the course of nationwide protests. [size=no report]

On August 1st, demonstrators gathered in Kassala (Kassala state), as part of a day of nationwide protests against the massacre at El Obeid on July 29th, and for justice for the victims of other acts of violence by state security organs during the course of nationwide protests. [size=large]

On August 1st, demonstrators gathered in El Obeid (North Kordofan state), as part of a day of nationwide protests against the massacre in the city on July 29th, and for justice for the victims of other acts of violence by state security organs during the course of nationwide protests. [size=large]

column16: The Guardian; Radio Dabanga; Sudan Tribune
column17: On August 1st, demonstrators (including students) gathered in Omdurman as part of a day of nationwide protests against the massacre at El Obeid on July 29th, and for justice for the victims of other acts of violence by state security organs during the course of nationwide protests. Security forces (coded here as police) shot dead four protesters, and wounded an unspecified number. [size=large]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On August 1st, RSF paramilitaries beat and shaved the heads of young men in Kutum market (North Darfur state). One source suggests RSF soldiers were attempting to provoke youth to demonstrate, in order for the RSF to have a pretext to attack the protesters.

On 1 August 2019, protesters gathered in Gedaref (Gedaref state), calling for justice for those who have been killed or injured by state security organs in the course of the uprising. [size=no report]

On August 1st, demonstrators gathered in Barah (North Kordofan state), as part of a day of nationwide protests against the massacre at El Obeid on July 29th, and for justice for the victims of other acts of violence by state security organs during the course of nationwide protests. [size=large]
On August 3rd, security forces (coded here as police) fired at civilians celebrating the Constitutional Declaration in Omdurman. A stray bullet hit and killed a boy in his house.

On August 4th, protesters gathered in Dongola (Northern state), in protests at the deterioration of electricity services in the city. Regular forces (coded here as SAF) fired live rounds at protesters, killing one. [size=no report]

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column8: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On August 4th, the TMC and FFC signed the Constitutional Declaration, laying out an agenda for the transitional government, and paving the way for the establishment of its central legislative and executive institutions across various dates in late August. The agreement has been publicly rejected by the SRF, and the Sudanese Professionals Association has declined to participate in the power-sharing arrangements.
On August 5th, demonstrators gathered in Dongola (Northern state), in protest at the killing of a protesters the previous day in the same town. [size=no report]

From August 5th to 7th, striking doctors protested in El Geneina (West Darfur state), calling for the new director-general of the state Health Ministry to be replaced by a figure untarnished by association with the Bashir regime, and for an improvement in their working environment. [size=small]
On August 5th and 6th, demonstrators gathered at the electricity office in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), calling for an end to power outages in the city. [size=dozens]

column7: Beja Congress - Corrective; SLFA: Sudan Liberation Force Alliance
column17: On August 6th, three rebel groups - including the SPLM-N faction headed by Abdel Aziz, the Beja Congress - Corrective, and the SLFA - announced they were forming the United Sudanese National Congress alliance (aka 'Kush Alliance').
On August 6th, demonstrators gathered in Khartoum to express solidarity with the family of a boy killed by a stray bullet in Omdurman on Aug 3rd. [size=large]

From August 5th to 7th, striking doctors protested in El Geneina (West Darfur state), calling for the new director-general of the state Health Ministry to be replaced by a figure untarnished by association with the Bashir regime, and for an improvement in their working environment. [size=small]
On August 5th and 6th, demonstrators gathered at the electricity office in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), calling for an end to power outages in the city. [size=dozens]
On August 7th, demonstrators gathered in El Obeid (North Kordofan state), in solidarity with the victims of an attack on protesters in Omdurman which killed 4 on Aug 1st. [size=no report]

On or around August 7th, protesters from West Kordofan state gathered at the Ministry of Oil in Khartoum, demonstrating against the harmful effects of oil production in the area, and the lack of economic benefits to the public. [size=no report]

From August 5th to 7th, striking doctors protested in El Geneina (West Darfur state), calling for the new director-general of the state Health Ministry to be replaced by a figure untarnished by association with the Bashir regime, and for an improvement in their working environment. [size=small]

On or around August 7th, employees of the Savings and Social Development Bank in Khartoum, and demonstrated against the reassignment of colleagues involved in anti-govt protests, and the for the director to resign. [size=no report]

On or around August 7th, parents of university students gathered at the Ministry of Higher Education in Khartoum, to protest against admissions procedures for students who failed their secondary school exams. [size=no report]

On or around August 7th, residents of Kalakla (Khartoum state) demonstrated at the locality office against the failure of authorities to prevent rain water from accumulating on streets in the area. [size=no report]
On or around August 7th, pastoralists demonstrated in Kassala (Kassala state) against the encroachment on pasture lands by farmers. [size=no report]
On August 8th, armed pastoralists attacked and beat seven children at Dobo Umda (North Darfur state), and abducted two of those children.

On August 10th, approx. 20 armed pastoralists shot four farmers in the area of Dolma (North Darfur state, coordinates for Kabga used at prec2), killing three (update: the fourth farmer later died of his injuries on Aug 20th). The attack was in retaliation for the farmers moving animals belonging to the pastoralists to Shangil Tobaya police station, after they trespassed on their land.

On August 12th, protesters (including IDPs) marched in El Fasher (North Darfur state), in protest at the killing of three farmers and wounding of one by pastoralists at Dolma on August 10th. [size=large]

On August 14th, three armed pastoralists abducted and raped two female children (aged 14 and 11) as they worked on their farm near Abu Zerega (North Darfur state). The girls (one of whom is in a coma) were released the following day. A vigilante group arrested the attackers and handed them to the police.

column16: Darfur Network for Monitoring and Documentation; Radio Dabanga
column17: On August 14, 2019, armed men in military uniform (coded as SAF) attacked farmers in the area of Kaag Kulli (South Darfur state), beating them and robbing them of property.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On August 15th, men wearing RSF uniforms and riding camels (Note: the source describes the attackers as armed pastoralists in RSF attire) attacked a group of farmers near Katur (North Darfur state). After firing in the air, they then beat the farmers with whips.
On August 17th, protesters from East Darfur demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for jailed paramilitary leader Musa Hilal to be released. [size=no report]

On August 17th, IDPs from Zamzam camp demonstrated against the power-sharing agreement reached between the TMC and FFC, on the grounds that it does not sufficiently address the problems associated with war in Darfur. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Military Intelligence Service
column17: On August 17th, military intelligence officers detained three civilians (including one teacher) at Fanga (Central Darfur state), claiming that they had stolen a missing weapon. The three were tortured by officers whilst in detention.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column8: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On August 17th, the final documentation of the power-sharing agreement and Constitutional Declaration were signed at a ceremony in Khartoum, initiating the new transitional government. Executive and legislative organs are to be appointed and instituted over the coming weeks. UPDATE: On Aug 21st, the Sovereign Council was appointed, comprising five members of the military, five members of the FFC, and a civilian agreed upon by both. Lt. Gen Abdel Fattah al-Burhan has become president.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On August 17th, RSF paramilitaries attacked civilians at Fanga (Central Darfur), killing three and wounding two, according to SLM-Al Nur rebels.

On August 18th, two teenage boys were killed when unexploded ordnance detonated at a farm in Murnei locality (West Darfur state, coordinates used at prec2). Their 19 year-old sister lost her hand in the explosion.

On August 18th, armed pastoralists attacked Hajjaj village near Tunjur (North Darfur state, coordinates for Tunjur used at prec2), wounding one civilian. The attackers were involved in an attack on nearby Taradona village the same day, where they claimed to be searching for stolen animals.

On August 18th, armed pastoralists attacked Taradona village (North Darfur state), abducting eight civilians (who were retrieved by security services the following day). The attackers claimed to be looking for stolen animals.
On August 18th, four armed pastoralists abducted a farmer at Fanga (Central Darfur state). There is no further information.

column8: UNISFA: United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (2011-)
column17: On August 19th, armed youths attacked a UNIFSA patrol (who appear to have been attempting to also arrest a suspect) at Dari market in the Northern Sector of Abyei (coordinates for Diffra, Abyei area, used at prec2). One peacekeeper was injured and a Misseriya man killed during the clash.

On August 19th, residents of Port Sudan (Red Sea state) blocked the road to Saukin following an attack by SAF soldiers on a family at their home. The protesters agreed to disperse when Military Intelligence officials agreed to find the perpetrators. [size=large]
On or around August 19th, demonstrators gathered in Jabal Aulia (Khartoum state), in solidarity with those missing from the June 3rd massacre in Khartoum. [size=no report]

On August 19th, attackers (implied to be armed pastoralists from Aroul settlement) attacked two civilians at a farm at Kumbo Kesri (Central Darfur state, approximate coordinates 10km from Mukjar used at geoprec2). One teenage girl was killed, and her mother seriously injured.

On or before August 19th, SAF soldiers stormed a house in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), beating and threatening its inhabitants and wounding several (including a child), and then looted money and belongings from the dwelling.
On August 20th, demonstrators gathered in Kassala, in protest of the high bread price. [size=no report]

On August 20th, a large group of farmers from Zamzam IDP camp were fired upon by unknown gunmen, after they refused instructions by police and the chief of the area to return to the camp. Nobody was injured in the gunfire, which occurred in the vicinity of Abu Delek (North Darfur state).

On August 20th, armed pastoralists attacked displaced farmers at an unspecified location between Turmo and Tur IDP camp (Central Darfur state, coordinates for Tur used at prec2). One person was injured, and second was wounded but died at a hospital in Nietiti the following day.

column16: Al Rakoba; Sudan Tribune; Radio Dabanga
column17: From August 21st to August 24th, intercommunal clashes occurred between Beni Amir forces and a Nuba militia, comprised of armed IDPs, in Port Sudan in unclear circumstances. 37 people were killed (including an Imam, on Aug 24th), 126 injured (in addition to 3 injured SAF soldiers, coded as AssocActor1), and dozens of dwellings torched. The state governor has been removed and a state of emergency declared, with soldiers and RSF paramilitaries deployed to the city. Fatalities distributed across four events.

On August 21st, three armed men (suspected of being pastoralists) attacked three schoolgirls who were farming near Teiga IDP camp (South Darfur state, coordinates used at prec2). Two of the victims escaped, the other was repeatedly raped.
On August 22nd, supporters and relatives of detained paramilitary leader Musa Hilal demonstrated outside of the Sudanese Professional's Association in Khartoum, calling for his release. [size=small]

column16: Sudan Tribune; Al Rakoba; Radio Dabanga
column17: From August 21st to August 24th, intercommunal clashes occurred between Beni Amir forces and a Nuba militia, comprised of armed IDPs, in Port Sudan in unclear circumstances. 37 people were killed (including an Imam, on Aug 24th), 126 injured (in addition to 3 injured SAF soldiers, coded as AssocActor1), and dozens of dwellings torched. The state governor has been removed and a state of emergency declared, with soldiers and RSF paramilitaries deployed to the city. Fatalities distributed across four events.

On August 22nd, family members and friends of some of those killed in the course of the national uprising gathered at the army HQ in Khartoum to commemorate the death of their loved ones. [size=dozens]

column16: Al Rakoba; Sudan Tribune; Radio Dabanga
column17: From August 21st to August 24th, intercommunal clashes occurred between Beni Amir forces and a Nuba militia, comprised of armed IDPs, in Port Sudan in unclear circumstances. 37 people were killed (including an Imam, on Aug 24th), 126 injured (in addition to 3 injured SAF soldiers, coded as AssocActor1), and dozens of dwellings torched. The state governor has been removed and a state of emergency declared, with soldiers and RSF paramilitaries deployed to the city. Fatalities distributed across four events.

column16: Al Rakoba; Sudan Tribune; Radio Dabanga
column17: From August 21st to August 24th, intercommunal clashes occurred between Beni Amir forces and a Nuba militia, comprised of armed IDPs, in Port Sudan in unclear circumstances. 37 people were killed (including an Imam, on Aug 24th), 126 injured (in addition to 3 injured SAF soldiers, coded as AssocActor1), and dozens of dwellings torched. The state governor has been removed and a state of emergency declared, with soldiers and RSF paramilitaries deployed to the city. Fatalities distributed across four events.
On August 24th, demonstrators gathered in Khartoum, calling for federal intervention to address the violence in Port Sudan. [size=no report]
On August 24th, demonstrators gathered in Kassala, calling for federal intervention to address the violence in Port Sudan. [size=no report]
On August 25th, demonstrators gathered in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), demanding an end to the violent clashes which have rocked the city in past days. [size=no report]

On August 25th, ongoing clashes in Port Sudan between the Beni Amar and IDPs from the Nuba mountains continued. There are no reports of injuries or fatalities but several homes were reported to have been torched.
On August 27th, retired police officers demonstrated in Khartoum, following the stoppage of their pensions. [size=no report]

On August 27, clashes flared up once more in Port Sudan, involving the Beni Amar and IDPs from the Nuba mountains. One person was reported to have been killed in the violence, and a number of buildings torched.

On August 27th, the Sudanese Artists Association demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for Bashir-era staff of the judiciary to be removed; for justice for the victims of violence during the national uprising; and in support of nominated judicial candidates for cabinet positions. [size=small]
On August 27th, students of the Shambat campus of the University of Khartoum demonstrated against the indefinite suspension of classes announced by the University. [size=no report]

On August 27th, teachers demonstrated in El Gedaref (Gedaref state), following the appointment of Bashir-era officials in the state ministry of education. The protesters called on the governor to remove the Director-General who appointed them, and to repeal the appointments. [size=dozens]

On August 27th, students demonstrated at El Razi University in Khartoum, following the suspension of three students, and calling for Bashir-era University directors to be replaced. Students also demonstrated at Wadi El Nil University, calling for the director to be replaced. [size=no report]

On August 28th, demonstrators gathered outside the courthouse in Omdurman, calling for justice for Ahmed El Kheir (who was tortured to death in Kassala on Feb 2nd). Police fired tear gas and live rounds at the protesters, and several lawyers were prevented from accessing the trial of the victim's alleged killers. [size=large]
On August 28th, demonstrators gathered in Port Sudan, calling for peaceful coexistence in the city, and an end to racial and tribal discrimination. [size=no report]
On August 28th, demonstrators gathered in El Gedaref calling for peaceful coexistence in Port Sudan. [size=no report]

On August 28th, demonstrators gathered at Karari bus station (coded as Khartoum at prec2), calling for peaceful coexistence in Port Sudan, and an end to racial and tribal discrimination. [size=no report]
On August 28th, demonstrators barricaded roads and set fire to tires in Burri in eastern Khartoum, following water shortages and power outages. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On August 28th, FFC-organised protests took place in Saraf Omra (North Darfur state), calling for Bashir-era doctors (accused of selling medicine illegally) to be prevented from returning to the hospital. [size=no report]
On August 28th, demonstrators gathered in Kassala (Kassala state), calling for the provision of basic health services in the Khatamiya neighbourhood. [size=no report]

On August 30th, SAP demonstrators gathered in Wad Medani, El Gazira to protest against the transportation union linked to the Bashir regime. Soldiers were reported to have beaten protesters, injuring four. [size=no report]

On August 31st, Beni Amir protesters set off on a march to Port Sudan from Kassala, walking to Aroma (where vehicles collected them to transport them to Saukin). The demonstrators were calling for peaceful reconciliation following deadly clashes between the Beni Amir and Nuba refugees in the city over the past weeks. [size=hundreds]

On September 1st, Beni Amir protesters marching from Kassala (and who had driven from Aroma to Saukin, before continuing on foot) arrived in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), calling for peaceful reconciliation following deadly clashes between the Beni Amir and Nuba refugees in the city over the past weeks. [size=hundreds]

On September 1st, IDP supporters of the major Darfuri rebel groups comprising the SRF demonstrated in El Fasher, North Darfur against the exclusion of rebel groups from the transitional government, and prevented an FFC-organised event at the football stadium from taking place. Note that one source says FFC leaders were ""attacked"" by the demonstrators, though this is not elaborate upon (actor 1 coded as protesters pending further information). [size=no report]
On September 1st, supporters of RAC leader Musa Hilal called for his release at a demonstration at Misteriya, North Darfur. [size=no report]

On September 2nd, journalists and members of other labour groups demonstrated outside the offices of El Jareeda newspaper in Khartoum, demanding full pay, and against the decision of the administration of the paper to dismiss several journalists for demanding money owed to them. [size=no report]

On September 2nd, armed pastoralists shot and wounded several farmers (three seriously) at El Jadeed (South Darfur, coordinates for Manawashi used at prec2). The farmers had been attempting to clear the pastoralists of their land.

On September 3rd, supporters of deposed leader Omar el-Bashir demonstrated outside Kober Prison in Khartoum North, calling for him and other senior members of his regime to be released. Police used batons and tear gas to disperse the demonstrators. [size=no report]

On September 3rd, the two factions of the Sudan Revolutionary Front announced they were reunifying, and announced the appointment of SLM-TC head El Hadi Idriss Yahia as leader following the elapsing of Minni Minawi's term. Malik Agar is deputy, and Jibril Ibrahim secretary-general. On Sep 5th, President Salva Kiir announced that peace talks were to be held in Juba (involving most, though not all, Sudanese rebel groups), with government delegates scheduled to arrive on Sep 9th.
On September 3rd, demonstrators gathered at Central Omdurman Court, calling for justice for the killers of a teacher who died in Kassala in February. [size=hundreds]
On September 3rd, demonstrators marched in Khartoum and Khartoum North, to commemorate the victims of the June 3rd massacre. [size=large]
On September 3rd, demonstrators marched in Khartoum and Khartoum North, to commemorate the victims of the June 3rd massacre. [size=large]

On September 3rd, protesters began a sit-in demonstration (which lasted at least two days) at Kalogi, South Kordofan, calling for gold mining companies who have caused harm to human and animal health through the use of chemicals to be removed from the area, and for compensation to be paid to those affected by the negative environmental effects of the mining. [size=no report]

On September 4th, professors and staff protested at the University of El Fasher, calling on the director of the university to prevent the allocation of university land plots to members of the RSF paramilitary. [size=dozens]

On September 4th, supporters of RAC leader Musa Hilal called for his release at a demonstration at Damrat El Sheikh Abdelbagi (North Darfur state, coordinates for Kutum used at prec2). [size=no report]
On September 4th, demonstrators protested outside the Sudanese Professionals Association offices in Khartoum, calling for a transparent investigation into the June 3rd massacre. [size=no report]
On September 4th, demonstrators protest against the increase in bread prices, and the manipulation of the sizes of bread loaves, in Kosti (White Nile state). [size=no report]

On September 4th, protesters continued a sit-in demonstration at Kalogi, South Kordofan, calling for gold mining companies who have caused harm to human and animal health through the use of chemicals to be removed from the area, and for compensation to be paid to those affected by the negative environmental effects of the mining. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 5 September 2019, RSF paramilitaries attacked Golo (Rokoro locality, Central Darfur state), killing one civilian and wounding three others.

On September 6th, demonstrators gathered at the military garrison in Golo (Central Darfur) to protest against attacks in Jebel Marrah the previous day, and calling for the perpetrators to be brought to justice. [size=dozens]

On September 6th, demonstrators barricaded the locality offices in Talodi (South Kordofan state) after a large demonstration in the town. The demonstrations are against the use of toxic chemicals by mining companies throughout the area. [size=hundreds]
On September 8th, demonstrators marched in Talodi (South Kordofan state). The demonstrations are against the use of toxic chemicals by mining companies throughout the area. [size=no report]
On September 8th, protesters gathered in Rokoro (Central Darfur), to protest against the murder of a villager the previous day. [size=dozens]

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On September 8th, RSF leader Lt. Gen. 'Hemeti' brokered an agreement between the Beni Amir and Nuba ethnic groups in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), following fighting in the city. Hemeti threatened both parties with expulsion from the city and repatriation to their home area of Kassala and the Nuba mountains (respectively) if they did not sign the agreement.

On September 9th, protests continued in Talodi (South Kordofan state), which has lasted at least three non-consecutive days. The demonstrators are calling for mining companies operating in the area to be closed down, after companies dumped toxic chemicals near mining areas. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On September 9th, a civilian was abducted by RSF paramilitaries in the area of Hajar-Jawad (South Kordofan state, coordinates used), and taken to nearby Alkugul, where he was tortured for two days, on suspicion of being a member of the SPLM-N rebellion. He was then released.

On September 10th, demonstrators protested at El Awsat courthouse in Burri (Khartoum), demanding the relase of youth from the area who had been arrested following the dismantlement of the sit-in camp in Khartoum on June 3rd. [size=no report]

On September 10th, students demonstrated at the East District court of Khartoum in Burri, calling for students who have been suspended from the University of Medical Sciences and Technology to be reinstated. [size=no report]
On September 10th, demonstrators gathered in Khartoum demanding that ""perpetrators of genocide"" in Sudan face charges in court. [size=no report]

On September 11th, displaced farmers from Zamzam camp demonstrated in El Fasher (North Darfur state), calling for authorities to tackle violence and threats by armed pastoralists in areas they farm in. [size=dozens]

On September 12th, demonstrators marched in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), demanding an independent judiciary, and for the swift appointment of the Chief Justice and Attorney General under the new transitional government. [szie=hundreds]

On September 12th, demonstrators marched in Khartoum, demanding an independent judiciary, and for the swift appointment of the Chief Justice and Attorney General under the new transitional government. [szie=hundreds]

On September 12th, neighbourhood committees and workers demonstrated in industrial areas of Omdurman and Kober (Khartoum North), calling for an improvement in services, the reversal of degradation of the environment, and issues surrounding local taxation. [size=no report]

On September 12th, neighbourhood committees and workers demonstrated in industrial areas of Omdurman and Kober (Khartoum North), calling for an improvement in services, the reversal of degradation of the environment, and issues surrounding local taxation. [size=no report]

On September 12th, demonstrators marched in Gedaref (Gedaref state), demanding an independent judiciary, and for the swift appointment of the Chief Justice and Attorney General under the new transitional government. [size=hundreds]

On September 12th, demonstrators marched in Kassala (Kassala state), demanding an independent judiciary, and for the swift appointment of the Chief Justice and Attorney General under the new transitional government. [szie=hundreds]

On September 12th, demonstrators marched in Singa (Sennar state), demanding an independent judiciary, and for the swift appointment of the Chief Justice and Attorney General under the new transitional government. [size=hundreds]

On September 12th, demonstrators marched in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), demanding an independent judiciary, and for the swift appointment of the Chief Justice and Attorney General under the new transitional government. [size=hundreds]

On September 12th, demonstrators marched in Ed Duweim (Northern state), demanding an independent judiciary, and for the swift appointment of the Chief Justice and Attorney General under the new transitional government. [size=hundreds]
On Sept 14th, in Khartoum, pupils held a demonstration to protest the resumpion of the study after a long pause. [Size=dozens]
On 14 September 2019, SAF soldiers attacked pastoralists at Hadra village (South Kordofan state), killing one, and looting 17 cows.
On Sept 14th, teachers gathered in front of the Ministry of Education to protest the decision to cancel holidays from school on Saturadys. [Size= no report]

column9: Police Forces of Sudan (2019-) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On Sept 15th, in Mershing camp, displaced people staged a demonstration to protest the killing of a displaced student by RSF. The demonstrators moved towards the police station of Mershing, where they went to the office of the neighbouring National Intelligence and Security Service (NISS). When the demonstrators wanted to break into the office of the agency, shots were fired at the crowd, killing one demonstrator and injuring two. [Size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On Sept 15, two armed men from the Rapid Support Forces tried to take the cell phone of a student of the Zalingei University, who was also a displaced person staying in the IDP camp. When the student tried to resist them, RSF men shot and killed him.

On Sept 16th, the families of detainees, prisoners of war and members of the Revolutionary Awakening Council held a protest in El Geneina, to demand the release of the political detainees who were arrested two years ago in Darfur. [Size=no report]

On Sept 16th, residents of the localities of Talodi and Kadeer held a vigil in Khartoum against the gold exploration companies in the state, which are continuing operating, despite an order by the governor for an immediate stop to all gold mining activities in the state. [Size=no report]

column9: Police Forces of Sudan (2019-) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On Sept 16th, in Mershing camp, displaced people staged a demonstration against the killing of two displaced people during the demonstrations on the previous day. The crowd marched to the police office and the neighbouring National Intelligence and Security Service (NISS). As they tried to break in, two demonstrators were shot to death. The demonstrators set the offices on fire upon that. No further details. [Size=no report]

On Sept 17th, the Sudanese Professionals Association staged a demonstration in front of the courts compound in El Geneina to protest the trials of eight coordinators of SPA in the Ministry of Finance because of their involvement demonstration and the strike. [Size= no report]

On Sept 17th, a protest was held in Nyala condemning the killing of three IDPs and wounding several others by the police forces during the demmonstrations held in Mershing on Sept 15th and 16th.[Size=no report].
On Sept 17th, a march was held in Simit East to demand the closure of a mining company in the area. [Size= no repot]
On Sept 17th, workers and engineers protested demanding the removal of the former regime's officials. [Size=no report]
On Sept 17th, minibus drivers staged a protest in El Obeid, against the decision of the governor to prohibit them from transporting passengers in the state. [Size=260]

On Sept 17th, in West Kordorfan (exact location not clear, coded as El Fula at precision2), people protested calling for the departure of the company Zain Sudan, which has been working in the area for one year an a half. [Size=no report]

On Sept 17th, in El Rahad, protesters demonstrated against marginalization. Protesters claimed that, when operating in support of some areas affected by the flood, the government did not include their area. [Size=no report]

On Sept 17th, in the village of Idan (Gereida) armed pastoralist trespassed with their camels through farmers' territory. When farmers decided to claim damages to the police, the herders opened fire on them, killing 3 people (including a child) and wounding 7. 6 people went missing in the attack.

On Sept 18th, in Talodi, a mass demonstration was held to demand the dismissal of the acting state governor because of his incapability and his identification with the remnants and leaders of the former regime. [Size=no report]

On Sept 18th, in Kadeer, 22 km from Abbasiya (coded as Al Abbasiya at precision2), a mass demonstration was held to demand the dismissal of the acting state governor because of his incapability and his identification with the remnants and leaders of the former regime. [Size=no report]
On Sept 18th, residents of Gedaref staged a protest demanding the removal of the state governor. [Size=no report]

On Sept 18th, in Kalogi, a mass demonstration was held to demand the dismissal of the acting state governor because of his incapability and his identification with the remnants and leaders of the former regime. [Size=no report]

On or after 18 September 2019, demonstrators gathered in Al Abbasiya (South Kordofan state. Event presumed to in Al Abbasiya town, and coded as such at geoprec1) to protest against the killing of a farmer in Garda village by suspected PDF paramilitaries. [size=no report]

On September 18th, three men in PDF uniforms (and coded as such) killed a Nuba farmer near Garada (South Kordofan state; coordinates for nearby Tab az Zaraf used at prec2) after he told them to move their animals from his farm.
On Sept 18th, a peaceful protest was held in Abu Na'ama against the use of genetically modified cotton. [Size=no report]

column7: Teachers (Sudan); Labour Group (Sudan); Government of Sudan (2019-)
column17: On Sept 18th, in Port Sudan, teachers and other government employees staged two demonstrations demanding the removal of a government official affiliated with the former regime. [Size= no report]

On September 18th, three men in PDF uniforms (and coded as such) opened fire on local residents and a police officer who went there after a Nuba farmer near Garada (South Kordofan state; coordinates for nearby Tab az Zaraf used at prec2) was killed.
On Sept 18th, a protest was held in Port Sudan to demand the removal of the former regime symbols from educational institutoins . [Size=no report]
On Sept 18th, in Tebeldina,a man was shot dead by unknown gunmen wearing military uniforms (allegedly herdsmen) at his farm. His son was wounded.

On Sept 18th and 19th, in Gereida, 8 people in total (including a woman, a child and an army lieutenant) were killed by unknown perpetrators armed with Kalashnikov and other machine guns. Fatalities are spread over two events (2).

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 18 September 2019, protesters gathered in Golo (Central Darfur state), condemning the RSF attack on the village on 5 Sep, and calling for the arrest of the perpetrators. RSF paramilitaries arrested five of the demonstrators. [size=at least 5]

On Sept 18th, the Sudanese Professionals Association staged a demonstrations in front of the courts compound in El Geneina to protest the trials of eight coordinators of SPA in the Ministry of Finance because of their involvement demonstration and the strike. [Size=no report]
On Sept 18th, in Nyala, a demonstration was staged to demand the immediate dismissal of the current acting governor. [Size=no report]

On Sept 18th, a demonstration was held in Gereida, to protest over the pastoralists' attack which took place the day before in Idan. Protesters also demanded authorities to reinforce security. [Size=no report]
On Sept 19th, in Kassala, protesters marched against marginalization and exclusion, and chanted slogans calling for the autonomy of the states of eastern Sudan. [Size=no report]
